HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Air Products Adds Charge for Swap Losses

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: ALLENTOWN, Pa., May 16

 BODY:
Air Products and Chemicals Inc. said yesterday it would take a charge of $9 million in the third quarter because of losses on derivatives trading.
The charge is in addition to a $60 million after-tax charge for the second quarter that the company reported last week. 
 The company entered into five interest-rate swaps with the Bankers Trust New York Corporation between October and December last year. The swaps, a form of the complex and highly publicized financial contracts known as derivatives, were bets that United States and European interest rates would remain stable. Companies use swaps with the aim of paying a floating interest rate when they think rates will fall and paying a fixed rate when they think rates will rise.
Air Products terminated three contracts after last week's announcement of the losses, resulting in an extra loss of $7 million, the company said. One of the other contracts was essentially closed out by buying some additional derivatives, Kevin Ramundo, a company spokesman, said.
The fifth contract, which is tied to Dutch interest rates, remains on Air Products' books, though the company said it had bought an interest-rate option to protect it against big moves in rates. If Dutch rates rise one percentage point, Air Products will lose a further $2 million. A similar drop in rates would bring the company a gain of $7 million.
"The ultimate charge in the third quarter, we can't say for sure," Mr. Ramundo said.
The company's loss on its swaps reduced net income to $13 million, or 12 cents a share, in its second quarter. Without the charge, earnings would have been 65 cents a share.
Air Products' loss is the latest in a series of setbacks companies have suffered in derivatives trades. Procter & Gamble said last month that it lost $102 million after taxes on a leveraged swap with Bankers Trust. Gibson Greetings Inc. said it lost $19.7 million and the Mead Corporation announced a $7.4 million loss on swaps last month. An ARCO pension fund lost $22 million on derivatives, the company said this weekend.
 
 
Cost of Debt Service
 Air Products, which employs 14,000 people, has used swaps to guard against swings in interest rates that could raise the cost of servicing its $1.3 billion in debt.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
TIFFANY & CO. (TIF,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Tiffany & Company reported yesterday that first-quarter net income rose 80.9 percent, to $1.88 million, or 12 cents a share. Shares of Tiffany jumped $2.75 yesterday, to $31.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading volume was more than 156,000 shares, greatly surpassing the three-month average daily volume of 32,000 shares.
Sales in the United States increased 18 percent, to $57.2 million from $48.5 million for the quarter, which ended on April 30. Tiffany, the New York jewelry retailer, said comparable United States sales, or sales at stores open at least a year, were up 16 percent, reflecting growth in Tiffany's flagship New York store and all American branch stores. 
 "We are pleased to be experiencing such strong results in our U.S. stores, which clearly indicates the success of Tiffany's strategic initiatives, along with a generally favorable economic climate," said William R. Chaney, the company's chairman.
International retail sales increased 29 percent, to $55.2 million, from $42.9million a year ago. The company said the increase primarily resulted from Tiffany's strategic realignment of its Japanese business in July 1993.
International same-store sales fell, which Tiffany attributed to soft economies in Japan and Europe. Worldwide sales, including catalogue operations, rose 20 percent, to $131.2 million from $109.5 million.

HEADLINE: Killings by Ex-Police Officer Leave Town Wondering Why

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ROME, N.Y., May 16

 BODY:
Joseph Merola did not get along especially well with his neighbors in this blue-collar city dotted with small wood frame homes, arguing with them over the late-night howling of his bassett hound, Murray, and the long black garden hose he would inexplicably leave running in his driveway for days at a time.
But for all his frictions, no one in this sleepy community 35 miles east of Syracuse expected what happened on Saturday night. Stepping out his back door at 9:23, Mr. Merola, a 34-year-old former police officer, unwrapped a licensed semiautomatic weapon from a gray sweatshirt and opened fire, killing two youths -- ages 14 and 15 -- and wounding a 17-year-old youth and a 43-year-old woman. He then brought the gun to his head and killed himself. 
 Mr. Merola's one-minute reign of terror at the corner of North Charles and Elwood Streets has shaken this community of 45,000, leaving city officials, former police colleagues and neighbors wondering what caused him to snap and whether his actions could have been prevented. It has also left school officials trying to counsel the hundreds of children who attended Strough Junior High School with the two popular youths who died: Mike McSweeney, who was in the eighth grade, and Dellon DiPasqua, who was in the ninth.
At a news conference this morning at City Hall, Mayor Joseph A. Griffo and Police Chief Merino J. Ciccone detailed Mr. Merola's troubled, six-year tenure as a police officer, which was marred by two suspensions and his dismissal for insubordination in May 1993. In a 1991 lawsuit that was settled out of court, he was accused of slapping and kicking a teen-ager whom he had arrested for skateboarding on the city mall. But two department-ordered psychological examinations found Mr. Merola to be no threat to the community.
City officials said that after Mr. Merola arrested the 14-year-old skateboarder in April 1991, Dr. Joseph T. Himmelsbach, a psychologist who examined him at the city's request, wrote, "There was no evidence of a major emotional disturbance or a significant mental disorder, nor were there indications that he is a hostile, angry person about to explode."
Mayor Griffo said that a second examination by another doctor a year later concluded that Mr. Merola was somewhat anxious and depressed, but most likely to recover in a few weeks.
Instead, Mr. Merola's life seemed to spiral steadily downward. He was dismissed from the department last May after he was found guilty of administrative charges that he had abandoned his post without authorization, faked an illness and reported to work out of uniform. City officials declined to give further details. Mr. Merola was believed to have been unemployed ever since.
 
Marksman and Gun Collector
 Then, about six months ago, Mr. Merola's father, Joseph, a beer distributor, died of cancer. The two were said to have been close and had lived together since moving to North Charles Street in the mid-1980's, not long before Mr. Merola's mother, Angeline, died after a lengthy battle with multiple sclerosis. Mr. Merola, who was not believed to have ever married, had lived alone in the house since his father's death.
Chief Ciccone said today that the department had been aware that Mr. Merola was an avid marksman and gun collector -- 14 handguns, all of them believed to have been licensed, were recovered from his home -- but had received no indication from his neighbors that he had threatened to use the guns against them.
Mr. Merola began to unravel Saturday evening, when he summoned the police to his home about 9 P.M. after discovering his garden hose had been slashed about six inches from the nozzle. In front of the officers, witnesses said, Mr. Merola exchanged angry words with several members of the Garofalo family, who live across the street and whom he had initially accused of cutting the hose. He then blamed several teen-agers who had joined the dispute, the witnesses said.
Finding no evidence that linked anyone to the cutting of the hose, the officers left at 9:15 P.M., Chief Ciccone said. The chief said the officers described Mr. Merola as "satisfied" with their efforts and "not upset."
But eight minutes later, the chief said, Mr. Merola re-emerged from his home and shouted something to the effect of, "You cut my hose and now you're going to pay." He then fired off at least 20 rounds of bullets.
 
Shot Trying to Run Away
 Matt Thompson and John Conner -- two teen-age witnesses who watched the shootings from under a parked car -- said Mr. Merola shot and wounded Mike McSweeney, who was standing only a few feet away. When Mike, a football and lacrosse player, got up and tried to run away, Mr. Merola shot him fatally in the head, Matt and John said.
Dellon DiPasqua, a track and field standout, tried to run away before he was fatally wounded in the head, the witnesses said. A third youth, James Nasci, 17, a swimmer who had shaved his head to a sleek, blond fuzz earlier in the day, was wounded next, in the elbow. He was listed in fair condition today at University Hospital in Syracuse.
Mr. Merola then sprayed the Garofalo home with bullets and struck Elvira Garofalo, 43 -- who, the police said, was sitting on her porch -- in the wrist. Mrs. Garofalo was treated at a local hospital and then released, the police said.
Finally, the witnesses said Mr. Merola turned toward his driveway, put the gun to his temple, fired once and fell to the ground.
Chief Ciccone said that the police believed one of the victims, whom he declined to name, might have been involved in the cutting of the hose, but that the others were believed to have been "in the wrong place at the wrong time." The precise words and actions that led up to the shooting, he added, will most likely never be known.
"What his rationale was, I don't know," Chief Ciccone said. "We were very lucky, if you could say there was any luck here, that we do not have more casualties."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Close Higher Awaiting Action by Fed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities finished higher yesterday as traders and investors awaited the outcome of today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee.
The Fed is expected to raise its short-term interest rate target for the fourth time this year soon. But market analysts are split over whether the increase in the target for the Federal funds rate, which is now 3.75 percent, will be a quarter of a percentage point or a half of a percentage point. And some argue that the Fed may wait a little longer and not act today. 
 In late trading the 30-year bond rose 17/32 , to 8527/32 for a yield of 7.44 percent, down from 7.49 percent on Friday. The yield is the lowest since May 5, when it was 7.33 percent.
Last week's subdued inflation reports have given rise to feelings by some investors that the three-month-plus bond retreat may have run its course.
 
Inflation Reports Cited
 The Labor Department reported on Friday that inflation was subdued through April, with consumer prices climbing just 2.4 percent over the last year. For all of 1993, consumer prices rose 2.7 percent. On Thursday, the department said producer prices in the 12 months ended April fell four-tenths of a percent -- the first drop in two years, based on the 12-month change.
Mark Grant, managing director and head of fixed-income investing for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said he expected nothing immediate to come from the Fed's meeting today. He said the Fed governors might wait "until they have a better picture of the economy."
When the adjustment does come, he thinks it will be 25 basis points and not anything as large as the 50 that has been speculated. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
"We have been reacting to inflation and to a stronger economy than some thought," Mr. Grant said. "A lot of those fears have turned out not to be so well founded."
As a result a 25-basis-point increase in rates may not get much of a market reaction, he says, where as weeks ago it would have caused the market to hemorrhage.
 
'Beginning to Calm Down'
 "The market is beginning to calm down, and is taking a more realistic view of where the economy is going," Mr. Grant said. "It's finding its base after a three-month decline, in what many think has been the worst bond market in the last 10 years."
Elsewhere in the Treasury market, traders and dealers said the three- and six-month bill auction was strong, and was helped by reinvestment demand from the issues maturing. The average discount rate for three-month bills was 4.22 percent, down from 4.32 percent last week, while the average for the six-month bill was 4.69 percent, down from 4.81 percent.
According to traders, retail interest at the auction was good, because many investors were parking their money in the short end of the market.
In early trading, bonds were little changed after the Fed said industrial production rose three-tenths of a percent in April, and the percentage of factory capacity in use was unchanged at 83.6 percent. Both reports were in line with market expectations. The production increase was the 11th consecutive monthly gain. Analysts said the only surprise to some was the lack of a rebound in utilities, which fell six-tenths of a percent in April after a 2.3 percent drop in March and 1.9 percent drop in February.
The solid performance in manufacturing despite the drag from lagging motor vehicle sales should reinforce perceptions of a healthy pace of growth, other analysts said.
An 85 percent capacity utilization rate has been considered a point that would translate into production bottlenecks and higher prices on manufactured goods. But the fact that more American production is done abroad makes this high capacity level less of a concern, some analysts contend.
 
Commodity Rise Shrugged Off
 Analysts at MMS International said bonds were not under pressure as much as they usually would by a sharp rise in the Commodity Research Bureau index. The index rose more than three points to 230.49. But the jump was largely a result of a surge in coffee and grain prices.
"Coffee has been pressured by supply constraints, rising another 3 percent today and nearly 50 percent in the past couple of weeks," said James Hale, an MMS International analyst.

HEADLINE: A Benign Bundesbank?;
Germany's Rate Arbiter, and Europe's Too, Lowers Interest as the Economy Recovers

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, May 16

 BODY:
Has the Bundesbank, the monetary lion that has had all Europe cowering before German tight-money policies, rolled over and started purring like a pussycat?
After the German central bank lowered both its key interest rates by half a percentage point last week, some financial analysts here are beginning to think just that. 
 A new era, they say, might be dawning under the Bundesbank's politically shrewd president, Hans Tietmeyer, a former close aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl who took charge of the central bank on Oct. 1.
If the Federal Reserve decides on Tuesday to raise American short-term rates for the fourth time this year, many Bundesbank-watchers will see the increase as confirmation of a suspected two-part agreement with the Fed to help halt the decline of the dollar on international currency markets.
Whether Mr. Tietmeyer and the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, made such a deal is, of course, not known. But the notion that the Bundesbank would stubbornly defend the mark despite the consequences of a tight-money policy on the dollar, on other European currencies and on European unity has now faded.
Some German officials caution, though, against assuming that the new Bundesbank has done an about-face. A few close colleagues of Mr. Tietmeyer on the 16-member Central Bank Council, the equivalent of the Federal Open Market Committee in the United States, which approved last week's interest-rate cuts, say that the Bundesbank is able to be more cooperative internationally because Germany's financial situation has changed.
The bank under Mr. Tietmeyer is "less dogmatic and more pragmatic," one official said. At the same time, the nation's emerging economic recovery means that staggering budget deficits, which had constrained Bundesbank policy in the early 90's, are now less of a problem. Some critics also note that this is an election year for Chancellor Kohl and his party, the Christian Democratic Union.
The Bundesbank confirmed its reputation as an uncooperative central bank late in 1992 and in 1993, when it stuck to high interest-rate policies although a run on other European currencies was threatening the stability, even the existence, of the European Monetary System. As a consequence, the monetary system all but fell apart.
But Mr. Tietmeyer, a silver-haired north German with a florid speaking style, appears to be setting a new tone. He has escaped the constant complaining about the Bundesbank's being too restrictive that dogged his predecessor, Helmut Schlesinger, a stolid monetarist without much flair for sugar-coating the painful anti-inflation steps that he led the bank to take during his 26-month leadership.
In part, this is because Mr. Schlesinger had already begun reducing German interest rates, in small and gradual steps, after the monetary storms that broke when the bank jacked up rates to record levels in the summer of 1992.
Setting the discount rate at 8.75 percent and the Lombard rate at 9.75 percent then, the bank hoped to keep the financial pressures of German unification from sending inflation up so sharply that it would seem out of control.
By the time Mr. Tietmeyer took over last fall, those rates -- which define the range within which German commercial short-term interest rates fluctuate -- had come down by two and a half percentage points.
The critical step that made people sit up and ask about a new Bundesbank was the 50-basis-point reduction the Bundesbank made last week, bringing the key rates down to 4.5 percent and 6 percent, respectively.
Technically, the bank could say that it had lowered interest rates for the almost the same reasons it raised them two years before -- keeping inflation low and the mark strong, the mandates of its charter since it was founded in 1957.
 
Recovery and Politics
 It reduced rates last week, the bank said, because German inflation was headed down and because it wanted to encourage long-term investment and capital formation. It also appeared to have more leeway to reduce rates because the mark was especially strong, having steadily gained against the dollar for weeks.
Still, the big rate cuts seemed to mark a watershed, one that may have as much to do with German domestic politics as international economics.
"Tietmeyer is a political animal and the Bundesbank is a political institution," said a Frankfurt banker who knows both well. "After nearly two years of recession, he now has a majority of the Central Bank Council members in favor of expansionary economic policy."
Politically, Mr. Tietmeyer's patrons in Chancellor Kohl's Government welcomed the rate reductions as a decisive contribution toward accelerating Germany's fragile economic recovery in time to help them win the elections on Oct. 16.
But if the German domestic considerations had not changed, it is likely that Mr. Tietmeyer would look less cooperative and the Bundesbank, less changed.
His job in persuading the Central Bank Council to cut rates may have been made easier by help from members appointed by state governments that are controlled by the opposition Social Democratic Party. All five of them are believed to have voted for the relaxation of monetary policy because stimulating the economy would be good for their states as well as for the country.
"Tietmeyer is more of an internationalist than his predecessor," agreed Allan Saunderson, editor of The Old Continent, a Frankfurt financial bulletin published by the daily Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung's information services division. "But this decision," he said, "was entirely based on domestic considerations."
Other analysts share that view. "The latest move represents a bold judgment by the Central Bank Council that their strategy of cutting short-term rates will slow the growth of the money stock and bring down inflation," said Kermit L. Schoenholtz of Salomon Brothers International in London, alluding to the bank's definition of the M-3 money-supply measure -- currency in circulation plus short-term deposits at financial institutions.
Since that definition excludes time deposits of more than four years, by this analysis high short-term German interest rates discouraged domestic investors from putting their money into long-term instruments like bonds. If it is correct, this may have contributed to the turbulence in international bond markets that began when the Fed began raising American short-term rates early in February.
This view, too, would represent a shift by the Bundesbank, because under Mr. Schlesinger it seemed to view surges in the money supply as a reason to keep short-term rates high -- to discourage consumer borrowing that fed inflation.
"If they had followed the current logic two years ago, they wouldn't have raised rates in the summer of 1992," one critic said. "But," he added, "this is an election year."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Economic Analysis

HEADLINE: Mario Einaudi, An Educator And Writer, 90

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Mario Einaudi, who spent most of his life explaining Europe to Americans and America to Europeans, died on Sunday in the house in which he was born in Piedmont, Italy. He was 90. For most of the last 30 years he had divided his time between Italy and Ithaca, N.Y.
He died after a brief illness, his family said. 
 At his death he was emeritus Goldwin Smith Professor of Government at Cornell University. At the university, he founded the Center for International Studies, which was later renamed the Mario Einaudi Center for International Studies.
Professor Einaudi was the oldest son of Luigi Einaudi, an economist who was the first President of the Italian Republic, from 1948 to 1955. Mario Einaudi created the Fondazione Einaudi in Turin, in memory of his father. His father's library formed the basis of what has grown into an important collection of texts on economic history. The foundation also provides graduate research fellowships for students from around the world.
Educated at the University of Turin, Professor Einaudi first came to this country as a Rockefeller Foundation Fellow to study at Harvard University in 1927. He returned in 1933 as a political refugee from the Fascist Mussolini regime in Italy.
He taught political science at Harvard University and Fordham University before joining the Cornell faculty in 1945. While there he twice served as chairman of the Department of Government and in 1965 founded the Center for International Studies.
One of his widely known books, still in print, is "The Roosevelt Revolution" (1959), an appraisal of the legacy of the New Deal for American society. He was co-author of two other books that remain in print, "Communism in Western Europe" (1951) and "Christian Democracy in Italy and France" (1969).
Professor Einaudi's wife of 57 years, Manon Michels Einaudi, died in 1990. He is survived by three sons, Luigi of Bethesda, Md., Roberto of Rome, and Marc of Stanford, Calif.; two brothers, Roberto of Milan and Giuglio of Turin, and nine grandchildren.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gains in Soybeans and Corn Push Silver and Metals Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Corn and soybean prices rose yesterday, helping to touch off a rally in silver and other precious metals, as the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities climbed to its highest point since late March.
Surging prices for coffee also contributed to the rise in the index, a widely watched gauge of inflation, which ended at 230.49, up 3.11 points. 
 Corn and soybeans rose on concerns that dry weather could damage crops almost as badly as flooding hurt them last year. Corn for July delivery gained 6.25 cents a bushel, to $2.6725 on the Chicago Board of Trade. July soybeans rose 13 cents a bushel, to $6.7850, and July wheat rose 6 cents, to $3.2625.
Rainfall over much of the Midwest has been below normal in the last few weeks.
"Weather is much more important after last year's reduced crop," said Bill Biederman, research director at Allendale Inc. in Crystal Lake, Ill.
Flooding last year left stockpiles low. The Agriculture Department estimates corn stocks at 827 million bushels, down from 2.11 billion a year earlier.
The gains in corn and soybeans, and the resulting rise in the Commodity Research Bureau index, led silver and other metals higher, traders said.
Silver for July delivery rose 16.2 cents an ounce, to $5.597 on the Commodity Exchange, while June gold gained $2.20, to $383.70 an ounce. July platinum rose $2.60 an ounce, to $405.50 on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Silver is often used as a hedge against inflation. Some traders believe in a connection between silver and soybean prices. A rally in one market often causes a rally in the other.
"When they forecast dry weather," the grains started to rise, said Leonard Kaplan, vice president with Imperial Bank in Los Angeles. "Silver took off on the basis of the C.R.B. rallying."
Higher industrial commodity prices "would push inflation higher," Mr. Kaplan said. Even so, silver could fall if the Federal Reserve raises interest rates today.
On other commodity markets, coffee prices soared, rising for the 13th straight day as concern grew about reduced supplies from Brazil and Colombia. July coffee gained 12.35 cents, to $1.2805 a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, the highest price since June 1989.
"The worst things that can happen are all happening at once," said John Connolly, managing director with Alpine Capital Management. Falling exports, rising demand, poor crops next year and falling stockpiles all contributed to the 45 percent rise in coffee prices during the last three weeks.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Little Change As Fed Meeting Is Awaited

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed against most leading currencies yesterday as traders waited to see whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates at its policy-making meeting today.
Many analysts and traders expect the Fed to raise interest rates to stave off the inflation that often accompanies an economic expansion. Higher American rates usually make dollar-denominated deposits more attractive, bolstering demand for the currency. 
 "The currency market was paralyzed today," said Victor Polce, head of foreign exchange marketing at Commerzbank A.G. "Everyone is waiting to see what the Fed does."
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6735 German marks, up a fraction from 1.6701 on Friday. It was little changed at 104.80 Japanese yen, down from 104.95 yen.
The Fed has raised interest rates three times this year so far, pushing the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans to 3.75 percent, from 3 percent, in increments of a quarter of a percentage point.
Another quarter-point increase is not expected to lift the dollar because many traders have been anticipating a larger increase, Mr. Polce said. Indeed, he said, a quarter-point increase would hurt the dollar more than it would help because expectations are so high.
Bond prices rose yesterday, pushing the yield down to 7.44 percent from 7.49 percent on Friday.
"The market is looking for reassurances that the Fed isn't abandoning bondholders," said David De Rosa, director of foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation. "The dollar is in for some trouble unless the Fed looks like it's vigilant on inflation."
In the first four months of this year, the dollar tumbled as much as 6 percent against the mark and 10 percent against the yen as investors abandoned bonds and other United States assets. The slide could resume if the Fed does not steady the bond market, Mr. De Rosa said.
Many traders expected the Fed to raise interest rates to support the dollar after it joined 18 other central banks in heavy dollar-buying on May 4.
In other currencies, the Greek drachma fell yesterday as speculators bet that it would be devalued soon. The Greek central bank pushed one-month interest rates to 25 percent yesterday from 22 percent to try to defend the drachma. The market rate fell to 248.15 drachmas to the dollar yesterday from 246.16 drachmas on Friday.
Also, the British pound was quoted at $1.5028, up from $1.4991 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Joint Effort in Sports Cars

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 16

 BODY:
The Vector Aeromotive Corporation, whose principal shareholder owns the Italian sports car maker Automobili Lamborghini S.p.A., said today that the companies would explore joint projects, including the development of a new engine.
The shareholder, Robert Braner, is president and chief executive of both companies and holds a large stake in Megatech Ltd., an Indonesian company that acquired Lamborghini from the Chrysler Corporation last year. 
 The companies are reviewing design plans on an all-new engine for Vector's Avtech SC Super Coupe, which is due to be introduced later this year.
"The synergy that can be created between the two exotic sports car manufacturers will serve to broaden Vector's market appeal and strengthen Vector's economic viability," Vector said.
Vector said it plans to move operations from Wilmington, Calif. to Jacksonville, Fla., where Lamborghini USA is based, to cut costs and retail prices.
The move may cause minor delays in achieving production goals of 50 of its 1995 model Avtech SC cars, Vector said. The company still plans to make a total of 250 to 300 of the Avtech SC's.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Big League Money Can't Buy Happiness

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
Ask any baseball fan if he (or she) would play third base for a major league team for a $500,000 salary plus $2,500 a game or second base for a $1.5 million salary plus $10,000 a game beyond the 90th game, and that fan couldn't answer yes quickly and emphatically enough.
Most fans, in fact, would tell you they would play for nothing. Of course, none of them have the ability to play major league baseball, but that doesn't stop them from wondering how anyone who does could be unhappy playing any position for $500,000 or $1.5 million or any salary major leaguers earn these days. 
 Tony Fernandez is unhappy playing third base for the Cincinnati Reds. Bip Roberts is unhappy playing second base for the San Diego Padres. The aforementioned salaries and bonuses are theirs.
Fernandez, a career shortstop, wants to play short. Roberts, who has displayed a career of versatility, wants to play the outfield. Barry Larkin is the Reds' shortstop, the best in the National League, and Fernandez knew that when he signed with them as a free agent during spring training. The Padres' strongest area is their outfield, and Roberts knew that when he signed with them as a free agent in January.
These are changing times in baseball. The owners want to change the economic system from a get-what-you-can market to a market fixed by a salary cap. The players don't want a salary cap and note that even National Football League team officials are complaining about their new salary-cap system. Rather, they were complaining until the commissioner threatened to fine them for their critical comments.
In advance of their effort to secure a salary cap, the baseball owners implemented an interim system under which they set out to eliminate the middle class of salaries. Not players; they still want the players. But they want them at their idea of a correct salary -- $350,000 for Jack Morris, for example, instead of last year's $5,425,000.
Or $500,000 for Fernandez instead of $2.3 million and $1.5 million for Roberts instead of $3.9 million.
Unlike their collusive assault on free agents in the mid-80's, the owners' strategy to get players at drastically reduced salaries is legal and sensible. If they create a two-tier salary system of stars and spear carriers and in the process make the spear carriers unhappy, all the better to lure the players into a salary-cap system, they reason.
For the most part, though, players do not grumble about the lower salaries they are forced to accept. Maybe if Fernandez and Roberts were making more money, they would not be so unhappy at their present positions. But this most likely is not primarily about money.
In their free-agent forays, the 31-year-old Fernandez and 30-year-old Roberts discovered they didn't have much of a market.
John Davimos, Fernandez's agent and manager of the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, Michael Moorer, asked Toronto for three years at what the club said -- but Davimos denies -- was $12 million. The Blue Jays, for whom Fernandez had a big post-season last year, had no interest in such a lengthy or lucrative deal. Three weeks into spring training and two agents later, Fernandez reluctantly accepted the Reds' offer to play third.
Recently, however, Fernandez, who always has been unusual, has behaved erratically, tossing his clubhouse chair into a laundry bin, knocking over a clothes hamper and putting items from his locker in equipment bags and storming out of the clubhouse.
"Jim Bowden and Davey Johnson have been very above board and very patient with Tony," said Tom Reich, the agent who secured the job for Fernandez, referring to Cincinnati's general manager and field manager, respectively. "It's understandable that he's terribly frustrated. He lost his spot and a couple million dollars to boot. Hopefully, it will work out. He's better off where he is than sitting at home."
The deal with the Reds apparently includes an understanding that the club will trade Fernandez to a team seeking a shortstop if the opportunity arises. But no such prospect is in sight. Pat Gillick, the general manager of the Blue Jays, a team that could use a shortstop, said yesterday that he has no plans to trade for Fernandez.
Roberts, hitting only .217, rejoined San Diego in Chicago last night after receiving permission to leave the Padres for a few days, the club said, "to help him cope with stress and pressures that have been bothering him."
Roberts's problems were said to stem more from migraine headaches than playing second base, but he wasn't always a happy player the previous two years in Cincinnati because of the position or positions he was playing. Although he is one of the most versatile players in the majors, Roberts doesn't like changing positions and he doesn't like second base.
But the Padres have Tony Gwynn, Derek Bell and Phil Plantier in their outfield, leaving no room for Roberts.
So Roberts and Fernandez are stuck with their unwanted jobs and their lower but nonetheless livable salaries. In these changing times, they should be happy they have any jobs at all.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Padres' Bip Roberts wants to play the outfield and not second base. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
America The Best

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The United States is the best country in the world. In America, you are free to become anything you want. The only person who can stop you is you. You can say what you want, pray as you want, or don't want. The police will never bother you unless you break the law. So don't break it. In America, if you want to work you can make a living. Only America gives you all these things. God blesses the golden land.
I knew that was all true when I was a small boy. My parents told me so straight out, at home. They compared it with Europe and America won, in every way except maybe the fruit was a little fresher there. 
 In school, teachers gave us lessons and books that fully backed up what my parents said about America. Mostly they were Irish women presiding over quiet classrooms of little Jews and Italians.
Sometimes the teachers talked about God and how important it was to honor Him and your parents. At Christmastime, teachers put up wreaths. My parents said why not -- after all, it was their country too, wasn't it?
Now in Tavares, Fla., the school board has passed a regulation that children be taught that American culture and values are inherently superior to other "foreign or historic cultures."
My parents and teachers would have thought the board stupid. My father detested right-wing noseybodies, plus Communists and Socialists. They all reminded him of the Russia he left. He would have said that if you need a law to teach a child right from wrong you should go back to school yourself.
But he is also saying in my head, right now, that on second thought if those regulators don't know that America is made up of "foreign or historic cultures" maybe they are too ignorant to profit by school.
Mrs. Margaret McCarthy and other teachers for whom we stood up and shut up would have said Tavares should hire teachers and elect board members who understood America before they got near a schoolhouse. Neither parents nor teachers ever used the words "values" or "culture"; the word "America" summed it up nicely for them.
Please note, readers, that my parents and teachers never said America was the perfect country, just the best. Not everybody agreed in those days.
Some thought Nazi Germany was better. They paraded in New York City -- not often after the first time, believe me.
Other Americans thought the Soviet Union was better. Some were young people who believed Stalin was the only bulwark against Hitler. Others were older in tooth and even softer in mind -- such as professors who babbled about the wonders of the Soviet system until it fell to dust. To this day they are not inclined to go into the matter of the gulag.
My parents and teachers did not talk much about tarnish marks on the golden land -- crime, poverty and race.
About crime, I promise not to glaze any more eyes with stories about how we spent summer nights sleeping in the park. (But we did). Now, though, when it comes to crime, we are not the best but among the worst. And there we will stay, as long as we are sentimental about either gun nuts or recidivists.
About poor, that was Our Crowd. What was there to say except someday things will be better, meantime join a union? My father believed that any white man who could not make a living in America was lazy or a fool, or both. That thought lurks in me still.
From my childhood, I remember not a single real discussion about minorities. Our neighborhoods were working-class, mildly liberal, and color-segregated. We did not know any "minorities." As a matter of fact, we thought Jews and Catholics were the minorities.
If I were black maybe I would become smart enough not to fret about ugly people who slighted me for my color. I doubt it. But I know that I would burn day and night at injustices that stood between me and believing everything in the opening paragraph of this column.
What I wind up thinking is this: Because of America's range for economic hope, and its Constitution, this is the best country in the world for all Americans, any shade.
That's not good enough. In school and out, the American prayer should now be that one day the country will soar farther, and make the first paragraph true, every word for every person. It will happen.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
