HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Prices Drop Steeply With North Sea Oil Plentiful

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Crude oil futures prices took their steepest dive in seven weeks yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as a flood of North Sea crude met a slowdown in buying by United States refiners.
Light sweet crude oil for June delivery fell 47 cents, to $17.59 a barrel. It was crude's steepest one-day slide since March 28, when near-term deliveries fell $1.05. 
 Crude prices were due for a correction after rising from less than $14 a barrel in late March to Friday's high of $18.54 "with hardly taking a breath," said James Fiedler, a vice president of ED&F Man International Futures Inc. in New York.
He said the availability of North Sea crude had increased, but United States refiners have become reluctant to buy at such high prices.
Some Russian crude has also arrived in the Gulf of Mexico, an unusual event, said Ric Navy, vice president of Paribas Futures Inc.
He said refiners had trimmed operations because the rapid rise in crude prices had reduced their profit margins. Consequently, "people are worried we're going to start building crude stocks," he said.
But a weekly industry report released after trading ended contradicted expectations for a rise of one million to three million barrels. The American Petroleum Institute said United States crude oil stocks fell by three million barrels last week.
Although refinery activity declined slightly, the group said gasoline stocks rose by 870,000 barrels, contrary to expectations for a decline of up to three million. Supplies of petroleum distillates, which include heating oil and diesel fuel, rose by 2.7 million barrels, as expected.
In other energy trading yesterday, June unleaded gasoline fell 0.70 cent, to 50.47 cents a gallon, while June heating oil tumbled 0.77 cent, to 47.04 cents a gallon.
On other commodity markets, platinum led precious metals after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to calm inflation fears. July platinum fell $6.10, to $399.40 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, June gold fell $1.70, to $382 an ounce. May silver sank 5.5 cents, to $5.508 an ounce.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
HOME DEPOT INC. (HD,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Home Depot Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter net income surged nearly 31 percent, exceeding Wall Street's expectations, as expansion into the Midwest and Canada fueled a strong sales increase.
Based in Atlanta, Home Depot, the nation's largest home-improvement retailer, said net income in the quarter ended May 1 rose to $139.7 million, or 31 cents a share. Wall Street was expecting the company to earn 29 cents a share, based on the mean estimate of 24 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. Results reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in July and a 4-for-3 split in April. 
 Revenue increased almost 32 percent from the corresponding period a year ago, to $2.87 billion.
Home Depot's chief financial officer, Ronald Brill, said that while the quarter exceeded expectations, he cautioned against raising annual estimates, for which the consensus is about $1.32 a share. He cited a dilution of a penny or two from an acquisition propelling the company into Canada and concerns about rising interest rates.
Sales rose 7 percent at stores open at least a year, even though last year's numbers received a boost from a construction boom in South Florida after Hurricane Andrew. Excluding the 10 South Florida stores, same-store sales rose 10 percent from the corresponding period a year ago. In 1993, Home Depot posted an average 7 percent gain in same-store sales.

HEADLINE: Housing Shows Vigor Even as Starts Slip 2.5%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
Housing starts dropped 2.5 percent in April, led by declines in the South and West, the Commerce Department said today.
April's annual rate of 1.455 million starts followed a 12.3 percent jump in March, to 1.492 million, as builders in the Northeast and Midwest recovered from the harsh winter. 
 The results exceeded the expectations of economists in a survey. They had predicted that rising mortgage rates would send housing starts down 3.4 percent in April.
 
 
'Still Pretty Strong'
 "The housing market is still pretty strong," Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, said.
While rising mortgage rates are likely to slow things down later this year, "it's going to be a pretty good market at least for most of the summer," she said.
The average rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage climbed to 8.77 percent last week, the highest in two years, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
"Housing is not as frenzied as it was, but you're still going to have more starts this year than last year," Robert McGee, chief economist at Tokai Bank, said.
Housing "is still going to be a contributor to the economy unless mortgage rates get a lot higher," Mr. McGee added.
Another analyst, Robert Dederick, chief economist at Northern Trust in Chicago, emphasized that the housing expansion was running out of steam.
"The end of the housing surge is now upon us," he said. "Housing has probably done its job for this expansion."
Economists, home builders and mortgage bankers expect rates to continue to rise, putting a damper on housing construction and home sales for the rest of the year.
Higher lumber prices were also driving up housing costs, Tommy Thompson, the president of the National Association of Home Builders, said. "This situation will not improve until harvests resume in the national forests of the Pacific Northwest," he added.
Mr. Thompson also said rising rates were probably responsible for the larger declines in the South and West, which were less affected by winter storms.
Starts fell 6.8 percent in the West, to an annual rate of 342,000, and declined 4.9 percent in the South, to a 608,000 pace.
In the Northeast, though, starts rose 3.6 percent, to a 143,000 rate, and in the Midwest, they advanced 4 percent, to 362,000.
Permits for new construction rose 4.4 percent in April to an annual rate of 1.371 million after rising 4.9 percent in March.
Single-family home starts fell 4.4 percent in April to a 1.205 million rate, while new construction of apartments and condominiums rose 7.8 percent, to a 250,000 pace.

HEADLINE: Eating Well: The Debate Over Milk and an Artificial Hormone;
More Milk, More Confusion: What Should the Label Say?

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
PUBLIC apprehension about milk from cows treated with the artificial bovine growth hormone is not going away, despite the efforts of the hormone's manufacturer to allay the fear.
The conflict over the hormone, which the Federal Food and Drug Administration approved for use last November and which is meant to increase milk production, is reflected in torturous confusion over labeling of milk products. 
 Before it was approved for use, there had been warnings that using the drug -- known as recombinant bovine somatotropin (rbST) and recombinant bovine growth hormone (rbGH) -- would result in a drop in sales of milk products because of public concern about the hormone's safety.
But there is no way to tell yet whether national sales have been affected. Lisa Watkins, a spokeswoman for the Monsanto Company of St. Louis, which is manufacturing the drug under the trade name of Posilac, said there was no change in milk sales in February, when the drug went on the market. But dozens of companies are advertising that their milk comes from cows that have not been injected with the hormone.
Use of the drug, which is genetically engineered, was approved over the objections of those who believe it has not been sufficiently tested on humans.
The critics include the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, and scientists like Dr. Michael Hansen, a scientist at the Consumers Union, and Dr. Samuel Epstein, a professor of occupational and environmental medicine at the University of Illinois at Chicago. They also include public interest groups, like Mothers and Others for a Livable Planet, an environmental and consumer group; Women's Health Network, an organization devoted to women's health issues, and the Pure Food Campaign, a project of the Foundation on Economic Trends, a group headed by Jeremy Rifkin, a critic of biotechnology.
In its decision to permit the use of the hormone, the F.D.A. acknowledged certain risks it described as "manageable." In the warning statement included with the drug, Monsanto says there are possible detrimental health effects on cows treated with the drug. They include reduced pregnancy rates and a greater risk of disorders involving reproductive and digestive organs. There is also an increased risk for mastitis, an inflammation of the udder.
At the center of the confusion is a statement issued in the Federal Register by the F.D.A. on Feb. 10, about voluntary labeling of dairy products from cows treated with the hormone.
Calling the suggested wording "interim guidance," meaning it has no force of law, the agency said that because all milk contains the natural hormone bST, it would be false and misleading to label any milk product as bST-free. But the term "rbST" could be used because rbST is the artificial hormone used in treated cows. Even labeling a milk product as rbST-free could be misleading, the agency said, because it implies that the "milk from untreated cows is safer or of higher quality than milk from treated cows."
To avoid such an implication, the F.D.A. suggested that a statement be added to the label to put the claim in proper context: "No significant difference has been shown between milk derived from rbST-treated and non-rbST-treated cows."
The agency has not recommended or required similar caveats for products whose labels say things like "no MSG," "no artificial color," "preservative free" or "organic."
The agency's statement has caused confusion among those who have pledged not to use the hormone in their herds and would like to put some kind of statement on their products to that effect. It has also confused state authorities who are uncertain how to regulate the labeling.
Monsanto has added to the confusion by warning companies through letters that labeling is false and misleading unless it complies with the F.D.A.'s suggested wording. Ms. Watkins said letters had been sent to at least six companies that have used advertisements, letters or labeling to indicate that their milk products contain no rbST. Monsanto neglected to mention that the F.D.A.'s statement on labeling does not have the force of law -- so that whether someone follows the suggested wording is of no consequence unless the statements are false and misleading.
Many of the parties believe that if there are regulations governing labeling, they should be in the hands of the F.D.A., not states, individual producers or retail markets. And some believe that products containing the artificial hormone should be labeled. An F.D.A. official acknowledged that instead of clearing the air, the interim guidelines have muddied the waters, and the agency is trying to figure out what to do next. Dr. David A. Kessler, the Commissioner of the F.D.A., said that the agency wanted "to make it clear that voluntary labeling is permitted, and it would be best to put it in context."
The F.D.A. has received thousands of comments about the labeling issue, but they have not been compiled yet.
Even within individual state governments, there is disagreement about how to proceed. The Attorney General of New York, G. Oliver Koppell, advocates full disclosure because, he said, "I do not believe that a sufficient time period has elapsed to make conclusary statements that rbST is harmless." But Richard T. McGuire, the state's Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, does not want products labeled because, he said, there is no difference between treated and untreated milk.
Ms. Watkins said Monsanto believes that voluntary labeling is all right. In March, the company sent a letter to Dr. Kessler, asking him to "take immediate steps to stop this false and misleading food labeling and to inform the public and the marketplace that F.D.A. intends to enforce its interim guidance." The company enclosed examples of advertisements, food labels and promotions that they believe to be misleading.
One example is a newspaper advertisement for the Elfco Food Co-op of East Lansing, Mich. "Concerned about the use of synthetic bovine growth hormone?" the advertisements asked. "Elfco offers milk, yogurt, cheeses and butter from farmers committed to dairy production without the use of rbGH."
Elfco's statement did not include the suggested caveat.
Monsanto has sued two companies that have made similar claims, saying they have made false and misleading statements.
In addition, several trade associations -- the International Dairy Foods Association, the Grocery Manufacturers of America and the National Food Processors Association -- have sued the state of Vermont over a law that starting in June will require all products made from the milk of cows injected with the artificial hormone to say so on the label. The Nutrasweet Company, which is owned by Monsanto, is a member of the first two trade associations.
"Everyone is terrified," said the owner of a wholesale dairy in the Northeast that was threatened with a lawsuit by Monsanto because of an advertisement the company had run in a newspaper. "It is quite ominous."
The owner asked not to be identified because, he said, he did not want any more trouble with Monsanto.
There are dozens of other companies that continue to label their products, including Farmland Dairies of Wallington, N.J. The company, which sells milk in the New York metropolitan area, has labeled its milk as follows: "Farmland Dairies Farmers have pledged in writing that they will not use rbST (recombinant bovine somatotropin) on their cows. When administered to dairy cows, rbST increases their milk production. Although the F.D.A. has approved the use of rbST and found no significant difference between milk derived from rbST-treated cows and those not treated, we want to know how you feel about this issue." The president of the company, Marc Goldman, said the company had received 800 letters and more than 1,000 telephone calls, all but two of which supported the decision not to use rbST.
And earlier this month, Land O' Lakes, a huge dairy cooperative in Minnesota, began selling a Superior Brand milk that is free of the hormone, in addition to its regular line of milk, which contains it.
Mothers and Others for a Livable Planet has compiled lists of other companies that are notifying customers about their artificial-hormone policy. The lists include supermarket chains and distributors that, according to Mothers and Others, have documents stating that they will carry some dairy products from cows that have not been treated with the synthetic bovine growth hormone. Products from brand-name companies on the list are all untreated. Regional lists are available from Mothers and Others for a Livable Planet, 40 West 20th Street, New York, 10011.

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Sarah Lyall 

 BODY:

Cat in the Hat Is Back
It was more than a year ago and Audrey Geisel, the widow of Theodore Geisel, commonly known as Dr. Seuss, was going through the painful, painstaking task of sorting through old papers at home in La Jolla, Calif. Buried at the bottom of a drawer was an old typescript of a unpublished story in Dr. Seuss's distinctive style. She began to read. "It's hard to believe such a thing could be true/And I hope such a thing never happens to you," it said. "But it happened, they say, to poor Mayzie McGrew."
Narrated by the Cat in the Hat, the star of his own previous book, the new story, "Daisie-Head Mayzie," tells of a girl who unexpectedly finds a daisy sprouting from the top of her head. Ridiculed by her friends and pursued by bees, Mayzie (who is not related to the identically named bird in the 1940 "Horton Hatches the Egg") hires a press agent and capitalizes on her new-found acclaim, only to learn valuable lessons at the end. Mrs. Geisel said in an interview yesterday that her husband, who was 87 when he died, had mentioned the idea to her just once, many years earlier. 
 "To find something like that after I no longer had him was just wonderful for me," Mrs. Geisel said.
Mrs. Geisel took the book to Random House, her husband's publisher, which recently announced that it planned to publish "Daisy-Head Mayzie" in the winter. The story, 20 years old, was written as a screenplay for an animated feature but will be released as a regular Seuss-style narrative, with drawings based on black-and-white pencil sketches that Dr. Seuss included in the manuscript. The story is also to be made into an animated television special, to be shown on the TNT cable network.
Mrs. Geisel said that she particularly liked the character of the daisy, who doesn't say anything but who is depicted as quite emotional, expressing fear, disdain, arrogance, amusement and concern. "It feels everything that Mayzie feels, which is very hard to do when you just have a stem," she said.
As for Mrs. Geisel, who is 72 and was married to Dr. Seuss for 23 years, she said that unearthing "Daisy-Head Mayzie" was like "having him back in the only understandable way that one could."
"Very few people have that marvelous opportunity of revisitation," she said. "Had I a daisy on my own head, it would have been quivering with joy."
 
A Void at the Top
 The death over the weekend of Erwin A. Glikes, 56, the former publisher of the Free Press, stunned people in publishing, who had come to consider him one of the industry's biggest brand-name editors for a certain kind of book. He had just been settling into his new job at Penguin U.S.A.
Having made several best sellers out of serious nonfiction books, many of them politically conservative, Mr. Glikes had amassed a formidable list of loyal authors. Although many are contractually obligated to remain with the Free Press (which is now owned by Simon & Schuster), at least two authors with books scheduled for the fall -- George F. Will and Sen. John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri -- had editor's clauses allowing them to remain with Mr. Glikes.
As a result, the future of the two books has been thrown into confusion. John Ekizian, a spokesman for the Free Press, said that people there were still too shocked to focus on the issue. Peter Mayer, the chairman of Penguin U.S.A., said essentially the same thing. "I'm shaken still and we just haven't had time yet to raise business questions," he said in an interview.
In Washington, Steve Hilton, a spokesman for Senator Danforth, said that the Senator had not made up his mind where to publish his book, "Resurrection: The Confirmation of Clarence Thomas," a sympathetic look at Justice Thomas's confirmation battle by his chief sponsor in the Senate. And Mr. Will, whose book is to be a collection of essays entitled "The Leveling Wind," did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
 
The Choice of Norton
 For the fifth time in its 71-year history, W. W. Norton, an independent publisher that is owned entirely by its employees, has appointed a new president. He is W. Drake McFeely, the vice president, editor and associate director of the company's college department, and he is to take over the job from Donald S. Lamm.
Mr. Lamm, 62, who is to remain as publisher, said in a statement that the appointment of Mr. McFeely, who is 39, would help the company move into a new era. "Drake McFeely's appointment affirms Norton's resolute commitment to independent publishing, uncompromisingly free of control or interference from outside interests," said Mr. Lamm, who has helped the company rebuff takeover offers in recent years. "With Drake at the helm, a new generation of leaders is now in place."
Mr. McFeely, who joined the company in 1976 as a college representative, has been an editor since 1982, focusing on books about economics and physics.
 
An Auden Poem
 From "Shadowlands," the novelization of the film (which was based on a play based on a docudrama inspired by a real story), to "Like Water for Chocolate," the American translation of a Mexican novel that had been made into a successful film, books are being served very well by movies these days. This may well extend to poetry, too, says Vintage Books, an upscale trade paperback arm of Random House Inc., which reports unexpected consumer interest in W. H. Auden since the release of the movie "Four Weddings and a Funeral." Auden's anguished poem "Funeral Blues" is read to great effect in the movie's funeral scene.
As a result, Vintage plans to publish a $6 soft-cover volume that includes "Funeral Blues" and nine other Auden poems. The publisher will print 40,000 copies, to be distributed in special displays near bookstores' checkout counters.
Forty thousand is an enormous number; most poets, even the most distinguished, are lucky to sell several thousand. The 36-page book, "Tell Me the Truth About Love," is to be advertised in stores by a photograph of Andie MacDowell and Hugh Grant, the winsome stars of "Four Weddings and a Funeral." An audio version will also be available, to be read by John Hannah, the actor who recites the poem in the movie.

HEADLINE: Forty Years and Still Struggling

 BODY:
Yesterday's celebration of the 40th anniversary of Brown v. Board of Education, the landmark school desegregation decision, was an occasion both for national pride and national shame. In 1954 the Supreme Court knocked over the bankrupt notion of separate but equal. Chief Justice Earl Warren, guiding the Court to unanimity with both moral fervor and political sense, liberated the nation from centuries of apartheid.
Forty years later, it seems the national consciousness has changed but the reality lags far behind. An unacceptable number of minority students still attend all-minority or nearly all-minority schools. Where statutorily sanctioned segregation once kept the races apart at school, now the trends of suburbanization, white flight, industrial decay and political ennui have combined to keep minority students in poorer districts, in schools with lower expectations for their students' achievement, in communities that are nurseries for failure. 
 The Supreme Court said in 1896 that separate seating on public transportation did not deny equality to anyone. It fatuously argued that if enforced segregation stamped one race as inferior, that was "solely because the colored race chooses to put that construction upon it."
America could not begin to move forward before rejecting that bogus sociology. The Chief Justice held simply that separate facilities were "inherently unequal" in education, and later in transportation and other aspects of life.
That, however, only began a new chapter of the struggle that met widespread resistance in the South and more subtle non-compliance in the North. The goal of genuinely integrated schooling suffered a tragic setback in 1974 when the Supreme Court, in a case from Michigan, allowed the city line across which many whites had fled to set the boundaries of Detroit's efforts to desegregate its schools.
Still, the school decision slowly awakened America's conscience and energized Congress to topple segregation in other areas, most conspicuously in public accommodations, where anticipated resistance quickly melted away. While legal employment barriers also were hurdled, many minorities still see only a widening income gap in a shrinking economy.
Another conspicuously successful product of Brown, the 1965 Voting Rights Act, brought thousands of minorities to elective office. Indeed, President Clinton told the pupils of Martin Luther King Jr. Middle School in Beltsville, Md., yesterday that his own election was due in large part to the support of empowered minorities.
The anniversary's blend of satisfaction and frustration would not have surprised Thurgood Marshall, strategist of the movement that won the Brown case. He and his colleagues in the NAACP Legal Defense Fund were under no illusions of immediate success.
The struggle continues. Lawsuits all around the country are now challenging the inherent inequities in the funding of school districts with local property taxes -- creating huge disparities in the resources available to children in city and suburban districts -- and in the district lines themselves, which allow residential segregation to be reflected in the schools.
In the decade between this year and the 50th anniversary of this revolutionary decision, Americans owe it to their children to find ways to live up to its promise. If they do not, the price will be high.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: The Fed's Prudent Course

 BODY:
The decision by the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates surprised no one. The hike of one-half of one percentage point was twice as high as many economists believe is warranted. Yet in an uncertain economic environment, the Fed's decision is a defensible move to ward off future bouts of inflation and bring order to volatile currency and financial markets.
Some will criticize the Fed's move as an unnecessary blow to economic growth. Others will say it should have raised rates even higher. The squabbling reflects disagreement about the best way for the Fed to set monetary policy in order to achieve steady growth without igniting inflation. The Fed's effort since February to nudge interest rates higher one step at at time is within prudent guidelines. 
 The economy is moving along at a 3 or 4 percent annual clip. Growth puts upward pressure on interest rates as businesses borrow money to expand capacity. If the Fed were to keep interest rates low, it would have to pump more and more money into the economy to satisfy the demand for loans -- a misguided policy that would stimulate an economy that is already growing and thereby trigger higher inflation. But how high should the Fed set short-term rates? The arguments for steep hikes include steady growth, falling unemployment and factories operating near capacity. By the end of the year, unemployment is expected to drop well below 6 percent, a range that could ignite wage and price inflation. To keep that from happening, the Fed has to start now to rein in the money supply.
On the other hand, unemployment remains above 6 percent, retail sales are lagging and there is no current evidence that inflation is rising. The Fed has thus been forced to choose. Should it keep rates low, thereby risking rapid growth, rising inflation and a day of reckoning when it might be forced into a clampdown that could send the economy into a tailspin? Or should it lift rates, risking a slowdown in economic activity?
The Fed chose the latter course -- and the reaction in financial markets was favorable. Banks raised their prime rates, the basis for many consumer loans. But long-term rates in financial markets tumbled. Apparently traders decided that the Fed's decision proved inflation would not creep higher. They thus bid down long-term rates, which incorporate their expectation about future inflation. The Fed's three previous rate hikes did not turn the economy sour. Nor, judging from yesterday's market reaction, will the fourth.

HEADLINE: A City in the Enterprise Zone;
Trenton Wrestles With a New Old Way of Beating Urban Ills

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Amid the abandoned factories and urban blight of central Trenton, the Apex Lumber Yard stands out as a island of hustle and bustle.
"My parking lot is bursting at the seams," said Mark Goitein, the owner of Apex Lumber. "Sometimes it gets so busy we have to go out and start directing traffic." 
 What's the attraction? As a company in Trenton's state enterprise zone, one of 10 inner-city business tax havens that New Jersey established in the last decade, Apex Lumber is allowed to sell its goods with only a 3 percent sales tax. That's half the usual rate. In six years, the sales appeal of lower taxes has helped the lumber and hardware store double its revenues to $10 million a year, and double its work force as well, to 48 employees.
 
Inventive About Incentives
 Long dubbed the laboratories of democracy, the states have rarely pursued that function so thoroughly as in the mushrooming of enterprise zones around the country.
While Washington was paralyzed by ideological warfare between conservatives and liberals, 37 states and the District of Columbia, like so many mad scientists trying to breathe life into a corpse, offered widely varying concoctions of tax breaks and other incentives to encourage business to locate or expand in poor areas.
New Jersey's program, at an annual cost of about $15 million in reduced state sales tax receipts, is considered one of the best state efforts. New York is expanding its mix of tax credits, low interest loans and reduced utility rates to as many as 34 cities. Connecticut has extended its basket of tax abatements to 11 cities.
So far, experts say, the urban enterprise zones have become neither the boon their promoters dreamed nor the boondoggle their critics feared.
Trenton is a case in point. Thanks to its enterprise zone, the rundown city is the unlikely home of one of the largest Steinway piano dealers in the country. But the city may also be the only state capital in America that cannot support a movie theater or a top-quality hotel.
 
No Magic Bullet
 "Enterprise zones do not possess magical qualities which can overcome all physical, social and economic barriers to revitalization," Margaret G. Wilder of Cornell University and Barry M. Rubin of Indiana University concluded in a study of state programs to be published this year. Still, "despite their limitations, enterprise zones appear to have some capacity to stimulate new employment and investment in certain areas," they wrote.
Experience varies widely. If run energetically and tied to other programs -- as in Trenton, Syracuse and several other places -- the incentive programs have helped struggling cities save some businesses that might have failed and retain some jobs that probably would have migrated elsewhere.
By doing so, several declining cities have bolstered their tax base at a comparatively low cost. Enterprise zones, generally not as dependent on political connections as many other economic development projects, have also been relatively scandal free.
Despite serious setbacks in Camden, a severely troubled city, a study found that Trenton and other New Jersey cities with enterprise zones added a total of almost 10,000 new jobs in the latter half of the 1980's. Estimates of the cost to the state varied from about $5,600 a job to $13,000. Similarly troubled cities that did not establish zones lost twice as many jobs altogether.
 
'You Have to Be Realistic'
 But as an antipoverty program, enterprise zones have minimal results. They have not overcome the fundamental ailments of the urban slums or done much more than slow the flow of jobs and people out of the inner cities. And the state efforts have not enabled more than a relative handful of America's urban poor to find decent work.
"You have to be realistic," said Alan Mallach, director of Trenton's Department of Housing and Development. "Even the most effective urban economic development strategy imaginable would not do much to help those without jobs who are most in need of them. They are held back by poor education, substance abuse, and a tangle of other personal and social ills."
An archetypal Northeastern city, Trenton has watched its industrial base vanish during the last few decades. "The steel I-beam was invented here," said Thomas McGough, Trenton's enthusiastic and voluble enterprise zone coordinator. "We supplied the wire rope for the Brooklyn Bridge. But ask a Trentonian today and, by gosh, they don't even know it. It's tragic!"
Today Trenton, a city of 88,000, relies largely on jobs in government services and health care. It reached its employment peak of the last decade in 1989, when more than 25,000 people worked within its city limits.
Even then, according to Census figures, one in 10 of its residents was unemployed and nearly one in 5 lived in poverty. That compared with a statewide jobless rate of 5 percent and a poverty level of 7.6 percent. Despite having an enterprise zone since 1985 that covered most private workplaces in the city, joblessness was actually worse than a decade earlier and the state's overall economic improvement had barely dented Trenton's poverty rate.
 
The Downturn
 And 1989 was as good as it got. In the 1990's, the region's severe economic downturn and a cutback in state government employment have cost Trenton more than 4,000 jobs, pushed unemployment over 13 percent, and left even more people in poverty.
Despite their limitations, the appeal of enterprise zones remains strong. Today, more than 15 years after Representative Jack Kemp first proposed enterprise zones as a Republican answer to inner-city poverty, a Democratic White House is trying to turn the basic concept into an elaborate, Government-supported reality.
Under legislation approved last summer, the Clinton Administration is scheduled by the end of the year to designate six sizable "empowerment zones" within impoverished areas of major American cities. Applications are due next month; each winner will receive $100 million in grants and other Federal benefits. In contrast with most state programs, the Federal plan looks well beyond business. Local development agencies are supposed to offer a comprehensive package of community-based education, housing and anticrime services.
"The Federal program is modeled after the broader approach we pioneered here," said Liz J. Abzug, an official who ran New York State's economic development zone program and is now lobbying to win Federal designation for New York City.
 
The Candidates
 A part of New York City beginning as a broad swath of Harlem and extending into the South Bronx around Yankee Stadium, is all but certain to be one of those six. A zone called Philadelphia-Camden, encompassing rundown sections of those two cities, has an excellent shot at the designation reserved, at the impetus of Senator Bill Bradley, for an empowerment zone crossing state lines. But Newark, whose politicians and community leaders are working overtime to win it designation as an empowerment zone, is likely to be shut out because political considerations impel the Government to favor regional diversity.
In a kind of consolation prize, Washington also plans to grant $3 million for each "enterprise community" in another 65 smaller urban neighborhoods around the country.
Meanwhile, state enterprise zones are multiplying across New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Connecticut, which began its enterprise zone program in the early 1980's, recently expanded its 11-city program to Stamford and widened the zone in New London. Among other benefits, the state provides property and corporate tax abatements to manufacturers, tax deferrals to other businesses, and tax savings to owners who improve rental housing.
New York, which began its program in 1987, is about to name as many as 15 new economic opportunity zones to join the 19 that now exist. The state offers tax credits, reduced utility rates and low interest loans to businesses that locate or expand within the zones. It also requires local administrators to work with social service organizations to provide job training, child care and transportation assistance.
New Jersey recently decided to make another 10 cities eligible for its program. Its most visible gains have come in Elizabeth -- where Ikea, a home furnishings store, heavily advertises the 3 percent tax savings -- and in Jersey City, which has lured lots of back-office jobs from Wall Street because of its convenient location and lower costs.
 
For Some, a Waste
 For all their popularity with local politicians, some critics say the zones remain largely a waste of resources that distract from more direct efforts to help the poor.
"State and local officials feel the need to do something about inner-city decline, and tax abatement is one of the few tools they have at hand," said Henry Coleman, director of the Center for Government Service at Rutgers University. "But if the only thing you have is a hammer, everything looks like a nail." Instead, Mr. Coleman favors more specific antipoverty programs and help for inner-city schools.
To advocates, though, enterprise zones are more promising than anything else within reach.
"Most academics scoff at this stuff, but what other politically viable choices do we have?" asked Prof. Marilyn Marks Rubin of John Jay College in Manhattan. She is working on New York City's application for a Federal empowerment zone.
"Are they going to work?" Professor Rubin said. "I don't know. Is is worth a try? Absolutely."
Trenton provides fodder for both points of view. Its zone covers 30 percent of this city, and more than 50 businesses qualify for its special tax benefits. The 3 percent sales tax break is particularly attractive for small retailers.
"About 80 percent of our clientele comes from out of town," said Al Kotsch, owner of Chopin Piano and Organ, one of the three largest Steinway piano dealers in the country. Chopin sells 800 pianos a year, from a few thousand dollars to $100,000 each. "They come to the city because of the sales tax savings. For me, the enterprise zone is the difference between staying and leaving."
The zone helps in other ways. For the first time in years, Trenton has lured an industrial concern, Pennington Metals, to a new $2.3 million factory being built with Federal, state and city money. Because it is in the zone, all purchases of supplies and equipment are exempt from sales tax.
Outside the zone, Trenton has a thriving Italian restaurant district in Chambersburg, east of downtown. Mercer County built a new baseball stadium for the Trenton Thunder, an AA minor league team in the Detroit Tigers farm system that just moved from Canada. After years of neglect, the city started more than 500 units of new low-income housing under Mayor Douglas H. Palmer, who was re-elected last week to a second four-year term.
 
Decades of Decline
 But it is still all but impossible to overcome decades of decline. Trenton has no big supermarket. This state capital has no decent hotel or movie theater and only got a bookstore last year. The downtown business district shuts down by 6 P.M. A plan to redevelop the mostly-empty 40-acre Roebling Complex, which provided the suspension cables for the Brooklyn, George Washington and Golden Gate Bridges, has been stalled for eight years.
"Sometimes you have to wonder about all the sweat and effort it takes just to get a Laundromat built," said Mr. Mallach, Trenton's housing and development director. "And then you see how easy it is to put up an entire suburban shopping center."
"We're fighting 30 years of neglect of the cities," he said. "The private sector, left to its own devices, has basically written off urban America."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Trims Early Losses After Rate Increase by Fed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady against most leading currencies yesterday, paring early losses after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the fourth time this year to head off the inflation that often accompanies economic growth.
Many traders bought dollars after the Fed pushed up short-term rates by half a percentage point, raising its discount rate to 3.5 percent and lifting the Federal funds rate to 4.25 percent. Higher interest rates usually make dollar-denominated assets more attractive to investors. 
 "This may not be the beginning of a huge rally, but it should stop the rot in the dollar," said Keith Cheveralls, director of foreign-exchange at First National Bank of Boston. "It was a good move by the Fed. The markets liked it."
 
 
Earlier Concern
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6725 German marks, little changed from 1.6735 marks on Monday. It had fallen as low as 1.6619 marks before the Fed acted, amid concern that the central bank's rate increases would not meet expectations.
The dollar also ended at 104.68 Japanese yen, down a fraction from 104.80 yen.
The dollar failed to rise further after the rate increases because so many traders had already expected the Fed, at its policy meeting yesterday, to push up rates to quell investor concern about inflation and to shore up the American currency.
The dollar has fallen sharply against the mark and the yen so far this year.
Strong rallies in the stock and bond markets also helped the dollar yesterday after the Fed's move.
Stocks and bonds surged in part because the Fed suggested that it was finished raising interest rates for now. Yesterday's rate increases, and the three others before it, "substantially remove the degree of monetary accommodation which prevailed throughout 1993," the Fed said in a statement.
 
 
Confidence Cited
 David Durst, a trader at Bear, Stearns & Company, said: "The fact that they indicated they're done raising rates for a while gave people the confidence to buy U.S. assets again. That really helped the dollar, too."
Currency traders have been waiting for the Fed to raise rates since May 4, when the Clinton Administration called on the Fed and 18 other central banks to buy dollars to stem its slide.
Still, some traders remained skeptical of the prospects for the dollar because of its failure to rally after this year's previous rate increases. Unless the Fed's actions succeeded in restoring confidence in American stocks and bonds, the dollar would suffer anew, they said.
"All the Fed did today was stabilize the dollar," said Earl Johnson, foreign-exchange adviser at the Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. "Bonds and stocks have to keep rising after today to keep the dollar moving higher."

HEADLINE: CHINA SEES RISK TO ITS STABILITY IN U.S. DEMANDS

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 18

 BODY:
China's leaders have told the United States that they are willing to make further gestures on human rights to build more constructive relations. But they have asked for understanding on what they see as the need to clamp down on dissent and preserve "social stability."
The importance of President Clinton's decision whether to extend China's preferred trading status, a decision that is expected next week, has prompted an extensive high-level dialogue, including the dispatch of a secret envoy from the White House. 
 According to a senior State Department official, the envoy, Michael H. Armacost, a former Ambassador to Japan and Under Secretary of State, was recruited for the mission by Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
The official said Mr. Armacost, in his talks with Chinese leaders, had reviewed "in painstaking detail" the seven areas in which Washington insists that Beijing improve its record on rights. He made progress in several areas, the official said, and Washington expects other gestures soon.
In addition to Mr. Armacost, other American experts on China have had conversations with Chinese leaders. These experts and diplomats here say the Chinese expressed deep concern about social unrest rising from widespread unemployment, inflation and rampant corruption.
Because of these real and perceived threats to stability, China has clamped down on dissent, even as it has taken some steps to meet Washington's demands.
Thus China is pursuing these two goals at once:
*A stronger relationship with the United States, to protect $30 billion in export trade that is an engine of China's growth, and is desperately needed to satisfy the demands of a fast-growing population.
*The preservation of stability at all costs, even if that means confronting Washington over a rights policy that some Chinese say is aimed at undermining Communist rule.
Diplomats say these contradictory goals account for the mixed signals China has been sending.
Prime Minister Li Peng, in remarks this week, urged the White House not to listen to dissidents and rights advocates who say Beijing's mixed record over the past year warrants canceling or restricting China's trade privileges.
"Foreign statesmen will surely make mistakes in their decisions if they base their understanding of China merely on the words or views of a tiny number of Chinese, and ignore the interests and wishes of all other Chinese people," Mr. Li said to Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Jimmy Carter's national security adviser. Mr. Li's comments were reported by the New China News Agency.
Mr. Li voiced what has become a fundamental appeal from the Chinese leaders, as well as a warning: stable growth in China will contribute to world peace in the next century, and an unstable China could be a disaster for Asian security, the international economy and the environment.
"In the early period of establishing a socialist/market economic structure, it is of strategic importance to maintain social stability," Mr. Li told party officials this week.
 
'Excruciating Dilemma'
 Similar messages delivered to emissaries from Washington underscore the hard choices Beijing faces.
"China's leaders face an excruciating dilemma," said David M. Lampton, an American specialist on China who has just completed a week of discussions with party officials. "They cannot send a signal of accommodation to the United States without seemingly encouraging dissidents at home, and they cannot stifle dissent at home without further complicating relations with Washington."
Mr. Lampton is the president of the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations, a nonprofit foundation in New York that finances research and exchange programs with China.
On the one hand, China has released on medical parole the "black hands" behind the Tiananmen Square uprising in 1989, Wang Juntao and Chen Ziming, both of whom were serving 13-year sentences. The United States Ambassador, J. Stapleton Roy, has characterized their release as a "significant" gesture of progress on human rights.
 
Prisoners and More Prisoners
 But on the other hand, security forces continue to make arrests anywhere dissent breaks out.
There are still at least 3,000 political prisoners in China, and more are discovered by rights organizations every day. Indeed, Human Rights Watch, based in New York, released a list of 500 political prisoners today who it says are still being held from the 1989 uprising.
At the same time, economic reforms begun 15 years ago by Deng Xiaoping, the paramount leader, are entering a new and decisive stage, pushing hundreds, perhaps thousands of state-owned factories into bankruptcy and forcing others to close. Millions of workers are being sent home, and there is no welfare safety net to rescue them.
"For the first time, the reforms are creating losers as well as winners," said Michel Oksenberg, a China expert traveling with Mr. Brzezinski. "The reform process is creating enemies as it never did before, and at the same time they are having to bring down the growth rate and deal with the problems of inflation," said Mr. Oksenberg, president of the East-West Center in Hawaii. "These are the reasons for their nervousness."
 
A Few Areas of Progress
 As the grievances of millions of workers merge with those of political reformers into a wave of protest and strikes, party leaders have gone into a defensive crouch. Still, they continue to make some concessions.
This week, China agreed to begin "technical" discussions with the United States on ending the jamming of Voice of America broadcasts; President Clinton had asked for progress on that issue.
The Foreign Ministry has also responded to an inquiry from Washington about Wei Jingsheng, China's best-known dissident, who was re-arrested in March. The ministry said Mr. Wei was under investigation but was not facing "treason" charges, as one news report said this week.
Still, whether China's leaders can control all the forces turned loose by 15 years of economic reform remains an open question.
"The authority of the regime continues to erode," Mr. Oksenberg said in an interview. "As that authority erodes, there are more opportunities for testing the limits of the regime's control."
Chinese officials insist they are making steady progress on human rights, but they have told United States diplomats that this progress should not be confused with a willingness to turn lose dissident forces, especially when those forces are a threat to Communist Party rule.
The Politburo's fear of being overturned cannot be underestimated. With Mr. Deng's health in serious decline -- he will turn 90 this year -- the next generation of leaders is aggressively guarding its rights of accession.
Since March, when China gave Secretary Christopher a bruising reception, senior leaders have reiterated that they are willing to confront any Administration whose rights policy seems aimed at undermining Beijing politically.
These officials see the State Department's embrace of Mr. Wei, who says the Communist leadership is irredeemably tainted by its past repression, as the beginning of a destabilization campaign.
Mr. Lampton, of the U.S.-China committee, said a meeting in Beijing on Feb. 27 between Mr. Wei and the State Department's top rights official, John Shattuck, "increased the level of suspicion and the Chinese elite's resolve to take a tough public line during Secretary Christopher's visit."

HEADLINE: SOUTHEAST ASIANS HIGHLY DEPENDENT ON WELFARE IN U.S.

BYLINE: By ASHLEY DUNN 

 BODY:
Nearly 20 years after the end of the war in Southeast Asia brought thousands of Cambodians, Laotians and Vietnamese refugees to this country, many still languish in poverty, giving Southeast Asians the highest rate of welfare dependency of any racial or ethnic group.
More than 30 percent of all Southeast Asian households in the nation now depend on welfare for survival, according to a report on the economic diversity of Asian-Americans released Wednesday in Washington. Among some groups, like Cambodians and Laotians in California, the percentage of those on welfare reaches 77 percent. Nationwide, only 8 percent of households received public assistance in 1991. 
 Still, Southeast Asians account for a small fraction of the welfare budget. Of the one million here, about 300,000 receive public aid, making up about 2 percent of the total welfare population.
In addition to highlighting the poverty of Southeast Asians here, the report seeks to add depth to the nation's often two-dimensional picture of Asian-Americans, who are the fastest-growing segment of the population. Their numbers have risen from 1.4 million in 1960 to more than 7 million in 1990, or 3 percent of nation's total.
The report, based on variety of sources like the Census Bureau, the Immigration and Naturalization Service and state governments, was prepared by the Asian Pacific American Public Policy Institute, based in Los Angeles, and the Asian American Studies Center at the University of California in Los Angeles.
The success of Asian-American entrepreneurs and professionals has fostered an image of a "model minority" -- ostensibly more affluent, stable and highly educated.
Indeed, the report showed, the stereotype is true in many respects. Asian-Americans have the lowest divorce rate of any racial group (3 percent), the lowest rate of teen-age pregnancy (6 percent), the highest median family income ($35,900) and the lowest rate of unemployment (3.5 percent). The number of Asian-owned businesses skyrocketed by nearly 1,000 percent from 1972 to 1987.
But, the authors argued, those figures mask the group's economic problems. For example, many of the Asian-owned businesses suffer high turnover and low profits, and the per capita income of Asian-Americans, $10,500 in 1990, is lower than that of non-Hispanic whites, $12,000.
Paul M. Ong, a professor of architecture and urban planning at U.C.L.A. and co-author of the study, said the stereotype of the "model minority" and public ignorance of the diversity of Asian-Americans had prevented the group from being adequately considered in national policy debates on issues like poverty, economic development and health care.
 
'Complex Population'
 "It's been a problem in that people say, 'Asian-Americans, they don't have any problems,' " Dr. Ong said. "What we're trying to do is educate people so they know there is more to it than just median income. This is a very complex population."
The public policy institute that cosponsored the study is affiliated with Leadership Education for Asian Pacifics, a nonprofit organization created to expand the leadership roles of Asian-Americans.
Asian-America has become a world of striking contrasts, the report said. For every Asian-American family with an annual income of $75,000 or more, there was roughly another making less than $10,000 a year. While more than a third of all Asian-Americans have at least a college degree, another 23 percent of those older than 25 had less than a high school diploma. For every Asian-American scientist or engineer, there was another making minimum wage.
The bustling atmosphere of neighborhoods like Chinatown in Manhattan belie the harsh reality that many businesses in these areas pay low wages and provide no health care benefits. The unemployment rate in Chinatown was 6 percent in 1990, but a quarter of all families were nevertheless living below the poverty level.
Asian-American professionals have become significant members of fields like medicine and engineering. Yet they have also been frustrated by a "glass ceiling," an inability to advance into management positions because of discrimination or language and cultural barriers, the report said.
 
Few in Management
 A study of three major public hospitals in Los Angeles revealed that while Asian-Americans made up 34 percent of all doctors and nurses, they filled only 12 percent of management positions.
The institute says the "model minority" image also obscures the economic diversity within Asian-America. For example, 47 percent of Asian Indians hold professional or managerial jobs, while 22 percent of Korean-Americans do. (This compares with 24 percent for whites.)
The report found the severest economic difficulties among Southeast Asians, a finding that will not surprise social workers or advocacy groups.
Dr. Ong said the Southeast Asians' prolonged and pervasive reliance on government assistance provides a grim lesson in the failure of current welfare programs that stress cash over long-term job training.
"The country has not dealt very well with those on the margins," he said. "It's a tragedy and it affects us all."
The flow of refugees from Southeast Asia began in 1975 after the end of the Vietnam War. The influx was originally seen as temporary, but the flow continues today as new political upheavals and natural disasters draw more refugees to this country.
 
Trauma of War
 The first large group of refugees that came between 1975 and 1978 was almost entirely Vietnamese. Many had advanced educations and job skills and assimilated with relative ease.
But many of the refugees in later migrations came from rural areas with few skills to survive in the United States. In general, the study says, this group, which included Cambodians, ethnic Chinese from Vietnam and Laotians, spent longer periods detained in refugee camps in Thailand and elsewhere, further burdening their adjustment to America.
Their transition has been made all the more difficult by their war experiences, by the traumatic journey to America and by welfare programs that do not account for their special needs, the study said.
Today, three-quarters of all Southeast Asian adults on welfare in California have less than a high school education and limited proficiency in English. Forty percent of the nation's Southeast Asians live in California, and the welfare rate is substantially higher there than in other states, partly because of California's less restrictive treatment of two-parent households.
The lack of skills, low pay and lack of health benefits in the jobs available to them have kept the Southeast Asians trapped on welfare, the study says. Possibly more than a quarter of Southeast Asians will remain on public assistance after more than a decade in this country, Dr. Ong said.
He also noted that many welfare programs have been designed for people with different needs. For example, nearly 90 percent of Southeast Asian families on welfare have both parents present, making them ineligible for some programs that are meant to help the more traditional welfare population of single-parent families and families headed by teen-agers.
Changing welfare programs to place greater emphasis on job training would help Southeast Asians free themselves from public assistance, Dr. Ong said.
"This population is now so enmeshed within the public assistance system that their well-being is and will be determined by this system and future reform," the report says.

HEADLINE: A Thief Dines Out, Hoping Later to Eat In

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

 BODY:
Every now and then, Gangaram Mahes slips on his best donated clothes and lives the high life. He strolls to a nice restaurant, sips a fine aperitif, savors a $50 meal and finishes with hot black coffee. The waiters call him sir, but Mr. Mahes could not dig a dollar from his pocket for a bus ride to heaven.
He is a thief who never runs, a criminal who picks his teeth as the police close in. To be arrested, to go home to a cell at Rikers Island, is his plan when he unfolds his napkin. 
 Homeless off and on for several years, he steals dinner from the restaurants because he wants the courts to return him to a place in New York where he is guaranteed three meals a day and a clean bed. In a prison system filled with repeat offenders, the 36-year-old Mr. Mahes is a serial diner.
He has committed the same crime at least 31 times, according to his prison record, always pleads guilty and never urges his lawyer to bargain for a reduced sentence. In his eyes, he is just tunneling inside again, with a knife and fork.
"It's tough on the outside," said Mr. Mahes, who is serving 90 days for stealing a swordfish steak from a midtown Manhattan restaurant.
Prosecutors say it is not their job to consider whether locking some criminals up actually gives them what they want: refuge from poverty or hunger. But Legal Aid lawyers, while they have no statistics, said they had seen a small but growing number of people who commit petty crimes with the intent of going to prison. Mr. Mahes is unusual because of his method, and his persistence.
It is life in a cage, sometimes violent, often demeaning, but to Mr. Mahes it is better than drifting from shelter to shelter or living in cardboard boxes. There is order to prison, and you always dine on time, he said.
"I like to live decent," he said. "I like to be clean."
Christina Swarns, a young Legal Aid lawyer defending a man who does not want her help, faces Mr. Mahes through the wire screen of the holding pen at criminal court and does not know whether to laugh or cry.
"It's funny at first, 'The Serial Eater,' " she said. "But it's a very sad thing. How bad is it, his life, that he would prefer prison?"
On one hand is a man who goes to jail at will without hurting anyone, who steals only expensive New York restaurant food. Instead of throwing a rock through a window, he orders a T-bone.
On the other hand is a man who seems to have abandoned hope of ever having anything better, who prefers society's idea of punishment to his place in the society, said Ms. Swarns. In the past two years, he has seldom been free more than a few days before enjoying an illegal entree.
 
Not Too Cheap
 He has patronized the American Festival Cafe and the Taj Mahal in Manhattan, and Tony Roma's in two boroughs. He chooses restaurants that are not too cheap, not too expensive. If a restaurant is too pretentious, it might not seat him. If it is too cheap, he might not be arrested for stealing its food.
"If they really wanted to punish him," said Ms. Swarns, "they would stand outside Rikers and say, 'You go away.' "
Instead, Mr. Mahes does 90 days for stealing fish.
It costs taxpayers $162 a day to feed, clothe and house Mr. Mahes at Rikers Island. His 90-day sentence will cost them $14,580, to punish him for refusing to pay the $51.31 check. In five years he has cost them more than $250,000.
Louis Fasulo, a supervising lawyer at Legal Aid, said the real shame was that Mr. Mahes was returned to jail over and over before anyone questioned if it was the right thing.
"No one took the time," he said.
His lawyers have asked for alternative sentencing, including counseling, but prosecutors denied it. If Mr. Mahes wants to live in prison, the City of New York will let him.
Barbara Thompson, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan District Attorney, said Mr. Mahes was returned to prison because he was a thief, with a long record of stealing.
"He does belong in jail," she said. "It's the same as if it were a string of shopliftings."
Ms. Thompson said Mr. Mahes was not snatching bread crusts to keep from starving.
"One of his meals cost $100," she said.
 
Nothing Left to Lose
 All around Mr. Mahes in the holding cages at criminal court are inmates who just want to go home. He is already there, said Ms. Swarns.
She said her client had no expectations, so there were no disappointments: he did not envy people who were free, because they were free to suffer.
Once an inmate accepts where he is, what he is, jail has its good times, Mr. Mahes said.
"Last night," he said, "we had beef stew."
Even in the open room he sits with his arms close to his body and his knees together: people who do time, who share space, sit that way. He tells his life story in a detached monotone, as if he were just some vague acquaintance he used to know.
Raised in poverty and fear as a child in Guyana, he left for the United States in 1976, when he was 18. His myth of New York shimmered in the distance.
"I thought it was going to be milk and honey," he said.
What he found was a country in a recession, with lines for gas, lines for work.
Looking for refuge again, he joined the Army. The Army took care of its own; clothed them, fed them. He would have stayed, but five years and one drug addiction later -- to hashish -- he was on the street.
He wandered to Florida and Virginia to pick collards and peaches in migrant camps where conditions were barely human. One camp fed its workers just once a day.
He went home to Guyana, and returned to the South Bronx with a wife, who left him. For years he drifted, homeless, drinking himself happy.
"I would drink to forget how the day passed," he said.
By the late 1980's, the one constant in his life was jail. He had done time for a string of misdemeanors. Jail took care of its own; clothed them, fed them.
Getting inside was easy. All he had to do was pretend to be part of the mainstream, the middle class. Then, when the waiter brought the check, he told the truth.
In that golden space of time between being shown to his table and the second the check arrives, he is as good as anybody.
He has the same rights, the same respect, the same choices between fried cheese sticks and French onion soup. He can ask for a table near the window, or send back a steak if the center is not pink enough.
He likes a glass of Johnnie Walker and the chicken and rib platter at Tony Roma's.
"No dessert," he said. "But they did offer."
He was fond of the buffet at an Indian restaurant in midtown, but it closed.
"The curried lamb," he said. He almost smiles.
 
He Knew What He Wanted
 On April 10, he visited the American Festival Cafe at Rockefeller Center. He ordered swordfish, lightly grilled, delicately seasoned.
"He had very good taste," said Paul Sharpe, the cafe's manager.
Mr. Sharpe said Mr. Mahes did nothing to attract attention at first. "He didn't order 50 lobsters to go," he said.
Instead, he acted like a man who knew what he wanted and expected to get it.
"I think he was drinking Chivas Regal," Mr. Sharpe said.
That was a Sunday. He had been released from prison on Thursday.
Court has become purely a formality for him. But in that, he is nothing special.
Arraignments in criminal court in New York are not personal things. An army of blank-faced men and women wait in the pews or in the holding pens for their cases to be called. Most plead guilty and wait for a blank-faced judge to rule on a negotiated sentence.
Over and over, he glided through without complication, accepting 10, 40, even 180 days. Most times they did not even bother to spell his name right. He is also known as Gram Mays, Gangaral Mahez, Gangaram Males and Reggie Mays.
He expected this time to be no different, that he would be assigned another charity lawyer who would glance at his file and cut a deal with thinly disguised indifference.
In walked Ms. Swarns, for the defense.
Fresh from law school at the University of Pennsylvania, a 25-year-old in her first job, she bothered to ask why he did it.
Christina Swarns would argue paint off a wall.
Members of her family on Staten Island have learned to agree with her. That, or leave the room and shut the door. Her voice carries.
"I love to argue," she said.
It was clear to her and to Mr. Fasulo that punishing Mr. Mahes by putting him in jail was like throwing Br'er Rabbit in the briar patch.
Mr. Mahes could commit more serious crimes and go to prison for years, but that is not who he is, said his lawyers. He does not want to hurt people or rob a bodega or hold up a taxi driver. He just wants to eat well and sleep in peace.
Mr. Fasulo fears that jail is becoming a warehouse for the poor. The courts dump them into Rikers because it is the easy thing to do, he said.
In winter, "they take batteries out of cars and stand there waiting, so they can be out of the cold," he said.
Before his arraignment in April, the prosecutor wanted Mr. Mahes to serve a year. Mr. Fasulo and Ms. Swarns argued for placement in a halfway house, where he would have food and counseling.
"We felt that, given his record, it was appropriate to ask for a year," said Ms. Thompson, the District Attorney's spokeswoman.
His lawyers knew that would just continue the cycle.
The judge offered 90 days in jail. Mr. Fasulo and Ms. Swarns did not want to take it, but behind them Mr. Mahes chanted, "Take the 90 days."
She said it was maddening to defend him. Every time she gives him her card and tells him to call, so she can help when he gets out, he throws it away. She cannot compete with prison. The food at Rikers is tasty, said Mr. Mahes. For supper, he had pork chops.
He said he was thinking of quitting this life someday. But when the bus came to take him back to Rikers, he was content. It was almost lunchtime.
"Fried chicken," he said.
He does not have a family to miss him. He does not have an old neighborhood where people know his name.
The bars at Rikers Island are there to hold him in, and to hold onto.

HEADLINE: House Leaders Are Criticizing Welfare Plan

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
President Clinton's plan to change the nation's welfare system hit another snag this week, when leaders of the House sharply criticized the Administration strategy for financing it.
In a closed meeting with top Administration officials on Tuesday, several House leaders also expressed regrets that events were forcing the White House to propose a bill this year, said several people who were at the discussions. 
 The Congressional leaders said they recognized that Mr. Clinton had publicly committed himself to going forward with a bill this year, but they stopped short of asking him to change his mind. They said they were worried that the contentious welfare debate could detract from the effort to pass a health care plan.
Nonetheless, Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director, said the Administration planned to propose a bill in early June. He outlined possible cuts in other program as well as tax changes the Administration was considering to try to raise about $9.5 billion over five years. The people affected by the potential changes include veterans, farmers and affluent investors, all of whom are represented by powerful Washington lobbies that oppose the money being spent on welfare recipients.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said at the meeting that some of the ideas were not politically feasible He also warned that "we need every dollar for health care" and other pending legislation, people at the meeting said.
"The cupboard is bare," Mr. Rostenkowski said publicly after the meeting. "There are few ways of funding that are palatable."
While most of the meeting was devoted to the financing questions, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley reminded the Administration officials that he had warned them last year not to propose a welfare bill this session. He said it was unfortunate that Mr. Clinton had committed himself to doing that in the State of the Union Message.
Representative Dick Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, expressed a concern that the welfare debate would consume the time and political leadership needed for health care legislation, people in the meeting said.
The meeting underscores the tangle of financial and political problems President Clinton has encountered after making a prominent campaign pledge to overhaul the welfare system by expanding training opportunities for welfare recipients, while requiring those still unemployed after two years to join a work program.
But Mr. Clinton is now facing a struggle to raise the necessary money and to demonstrate his sincerity to rivals inside and outside the Democratic Party. Citing Mr. Clinton's pledge to "end welfare as we know it," House Republicans have accused Mr. Clinton of dragging his feet, and they are trying to take charge of the issue by forcing a vote on their own proposal.
House leaders warned Mr. Clinton last year that debate on welfare could slow his health care bill, since both proposals must travel through the same Congressional committees.
But when it was disclosed that Mr. Clinton was thinking of slowing down the welfare plan, the President was publicly rebuked by an ally, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. The New York Democrat is chairman of the Finance Committee, which oversees both health care and welfare legislation.
 
Political Embarrassments
 Questioning the President's sincerity, Mr. Moynihan accused him of using welfare only to score campaign points, employing the issue as "boob bait for the bubbas." Mr. Moynihan said he might hold the health care plan hostage unless the White House sent up a welfare bill.
Several weeks later, in his State of the Union Message, Mr. Clinton said he would send a welfare bill to Congress this spring.
The search for welfare financing has produced a series of political embarrassments for the Administration, as one option after another was disclosed only to meet a wave of political opposition. Top officials have been forced publicly to disown options like taxing food stamps and taxing gambling receipts.
At Tuesday's meeting, Mr. Panetta outlined a number of items that remain on the list, including cuts in programs for veterans and farmers, cuts in the Superfund environmental cleanup program, and changes that would restrict disability payments for drug addicts and alcoholics.
Several people at the meeting said Mr. Panetta had all but ruled out the cuts in veterans' programs, which would have raised about $2 billion over five years. The House leaders warned Mr. Panetta and Lloyd Bentsen, the Treasury Secretary, that they would encounter fierce opposition to a plan that took money away from veterans and spent it on welfare recipients.
Mr. Rostenkowski sharply criticized another option that Mr. Panetta outlined, which would limit the amount of tax-deferred interest that could accumulate in annuities. The life insurance industry has been vigorously fighting the proposal, blanketing Washington with Mailgrams opposing the move.
Mr. Panetta said the Administration might attempt to obtain some money by lowering the interest rate paid to people who redeem savings bonds before they mature. But Mr. Bentsen told the legislators that he did not like that idea, and that it, too, seemed destined for a drawing-board death.
The House Republican proposal would require recipients to join a work program after two years but probably offer fewer exemptions and require longer fewer hours than the plan the White House is expected to propose. The Republicans would pay for their bill by cutting about $20 billion over five years in aid to legal immigrants. The Administration is proposing a much smaller set of cuts for those immigrants, raising only about $2 billion over the same time.
The Hispanic caucus and outside advocacy groups have vowed to oppose a welfare bill financed with deep cuts in programs for immigrants.
A Congressional aide who attended the meeting said the list of financing options was discouraging to both sides. "They didn't put this forward with trumpets of great pride, and it wasn't received with great enthusiasm," the person said.
Asked about the meeting, Barry Toiv, a spokesman for Mr. Panetta, declined to discuss the specific financing options. "Financing a package like this is never easy, but we're confident that we'll get it done," he said.

HEADLINE: Etienne Hirsch, 93, Backer of a Europe United Like the U.S.

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS 

 BODY:
Etienne Hirsch, a French administrator who was a leading advocate of a United States of Europe, died on Tuesday in Paris. He was 93 and lived in nearby Sevres.
The cause was a heart problem, his family said without releasing further details. 
 After World War II Mr. Hirsch directed a program to modernize the French economy. He served later as an administrator of the European Coal and Steel Community, created in 1951 to pool the production of six Western European countries, and the European Community, founded in 1957 to forge a common market. He was an assistant to Robert Schuman and to Jean Monnet, who were among the guiding forces of postwar European cooperation.
In 1959 Mr. Hirsch became the chairman of the European Atomic Energy Community but was removed after only 18 months in office by President de Gaulle, who felt Mr. Hirsch was putting the interests of Europe before those of France.
 
Attacked Nationalism
 On leaving office in 1961, Mr, Hirsch attacked the nationalistic spirit that he felt had scuttled his dreams of fusion. He argued that the executive branch of the European Community should be allowed to operate in "complete independence," without accepting instructions from any government. He said he had tried to uphold that ideal, but "I must tell you in all frankness that I had difficulties in doing so."
The steel, trade and nuclear institutions eventually merged into one entity, the European Union, which now has 12 member countries. In 1993 it eliminated its internal trade barriers, and its members seek to forge common positions on foreign policy.
Mr. Hirsch was a chemical engineer. Immediately after the fall of France to Hitler's Germany in 1940, he and his wife and four children fled to London, where he became an officer in the Free French forces. General de Gaulle put Mr. Hirsch in charge of supplying arms to the French Resistance forces on the Continent.
He is survived by his wife, Genevieve, two daughters, Francoise Roth and Helene Eisenmann, all of Sevres; and a son, Antoine, of Paris.
