HEADLINE: For Whitman, Applause in the Early Acts

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 18

 BODY:
Take it or leave it, Christine Todd Whitman has been saying since she took office four months ago, pressing her unwavering drive for lower taxes and smaller, more efficient government.
And while legislators wilt and worry, while state workers fume about attacks on their pensions and pay and while Wall Street frets about some of the Governor's budget plans, the people of New Jersey seem to be loving every minute of it, and of her. 
 The hard-headed Governor widely known by the little-girl name of Christie is riding a crest of popularity in the state that was quantified in a recent poll and can be measured, more subjectively but just as significantly, in the diffidence that the opposition Democrats in the legislature display toward her.
The statewide poll, released Sunday by The Asbury Park Press, found that 78 percent of the respondents said Mrs. Whitman was doing a good or excellent job, and she scored nearly as high on questions about her financial responsibility, personal integrity and compassion. The poll of 628 people had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
Mrs. Whitman won the election against Gov. Jim Florio by less than 1 percent of the vote.
 
Democrats Are Reticent
 Popularity like hers has not been reported in New Jersey polls since 1986, when Thomas H. Kean, then the Governor, was winning similar approval ratings at the start of his second term. New Jersey and Mr. Kean were riding the giddy crest of an economic boom at that time, while Mrs. Whitman presides over a far more somber mood, grumpy about taxes and suspicious of government.
But that is a mood that exactly fits her message and may help explain her popularity, said Steven Salmore, a professor of politics at Rutgers University and a Republican campaign consultant.
"She's pretty effective in getting out a pretty good message," Mr. Salmore said. "She talks about cutting taxes, she talks about cutting government, she talks about belt-tightening, and people react positively."
Mrs. Whitman's popularity, and the fact that polling has not turned up strong negative views about her, has stifled dissent among the Republican legislative majority and left the Democrats shaking their heads in rueful admiration.
"The Governor has very successfully assumed the role of governor in many important ways, and I give her credit for that," said Senator Bernard F. Kenny of Hoboken, a Democratic member of the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee. "It's not easy being governor and she has addressed the issues she's interested in very effectively. But in politics each day is a new chapter, and you never know what's around the corner, what minefield or what breaks you're going to get."
 
Remaking Government
 Democrats and Republicans agree that Mrs. Whitman is clearly bent on storing up as much public acclaim as she can during these early months of budget writing, against the day when the political weather changes. Since her inauguration on Jan. 18, the Governor has been on an ambitious round of speeches, in Washington, up and down New Jersey, and in New York, selling her state and her policies.
On Tuesday, Mrs. Whitman delivered two keynote addresses before noon, and two other smaller-scale speeches by mid-afternoon. A third keynote, before an international management conference, was delivered today.
In each speech, as in the radio and television call-in shows that have become her hallmark, Mrs. Whitman touches again and again on the themes of her young administration: law and order, lower taxes, efficient government, an investment and a regulatory climate friendly to business.
Nothing less than a revolution will do, the Governor told a management meeting with the heads of several transnational corporations in Princeton today.
"In order to reshape government's connection with business, we must begin to remake government itself," she declared.
 
Growing Budget Protests
 As it happened, Mrs. Whitman shared the dais today with Colin Powell, the retired head of the Joint Chiefs of Staff whose position as a national and international figure only underscored Mrs. Whitman's rising national profile.
The Governor's name is already in play among Republicans as a potential vice presidential candidate. Richard Nixon, in an interview that was not published until after his recent death, said as much: "Christie Whitman would be a real sleeper on the ticket," he said of the woman who, as a little girl in the 1950's, the daughter of the New Jersey Republican state chairman, sold lemonade to raise pennies for the Eisenhower-Nixon ticket.
Governor Whitman's critics complain that her popularity is unearned, because she has not yet faced real tests in governing.
Her first budget, containing a second installment on the 30 percent income tax cut she has promised to deliver for three years, has not yet been enacted by the Republican-controlled legislature, and the narrow streets around the State House have echoed in recent days with the shouts of state workers, public college students, teachers and social services recipients demonstrating against the governor's hard-handed budget reductions to pay for her tax cuts.
Several other nettlesome problems also lie before her, including finding the money to pay for a huge deficit in a state-financed auto insurance pool and for an expected court order requiring a sharp increase in state aid to poor school districts.
Looming above all other challenges, however, is the growing protest against her budget plans from teachers and state employees. To close a $2 billion deficit and save enough money to cut income taxes by 10 percent next year, the Governor wants to end a 2-percent subsidy to these workers' pensions as well as end a practice of pre-paying some pension expenses.
 
Sparring With Teachers
 On Monday, the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. plans to put thousands of workers on West State Street in front of the State House to howl down this plan. "Florio revalued the pension in '92 and stole $1.6 billion from us, and we're not going to let her tinker with our pensions any longer," said Bob Yackel, a firefighter who heads the public employees council of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. "We're going to put 5,000 people in the streets while the Senate is in session and we're going to let them know they won't get another bit of that apple."
Mrs. Whitman has also picked a fight with the state teachers union, the New Jersey Education Association, whose muscle and money destroyed Democratic control of the State House following Governor Florio's tax increases and set the stage for Mrs. Whitman's victory over Mr. Florio last November.
The Governor all but applauded a widespread rejection of school budgets last month, saying voters must force local governments to control costs.
Governor Whitman has attacked lifelong teacher job security, a bedrock issue for the union, by calling for periodic teacher recertification. She has begun planning for a trial parental-choice voucher program for Jersey City that would send tax dollars to private schools, and she has suggested a two-tier pay scale, separating the best teachers from the rest, perhaps as a way of underlining her belief that some schools suffer from "burned-out" teachers.
On Friday, the leadership council of the education association will decide whether to approve a plan, advanced by the union's executives, to raise a $10 million war chest over the next two years by assessing each member $50 per year. The fund would be used to fight "anti-public education disinformation," the union said.
The Governor has two words for recipients of tax dollars who complain about her policies: "special interests."
"If I eliminate the Governor's Study Commission on the Transmission of Blood by Transylvanian Vampires," she joked at a February speech, "someone will accuse me of cutting funds for health care."
Mrs. Whitman's success in painting public workers as tax spenders has hardened the unions against her, but it has also brought the public closer to her view, as reflected in polling attitudes towards union demands, making the unions' task all the harder, and perhaps stifling dissent even among Republicans for her program.
"Everyone is taking note of how passive the Legislature is in all this," Senator Kenny remarked. "If there is one criticism of the style of the administration that explains why people back off, it's that they characterize anyone who disagrees with them as having a negative motivation."

HEADLINE: An Uncertain Future For 3 Deep-Water Ports

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.

 BODY:
The bananas unloaded off ships from South America keep 62 longshoremen busy for two days every week at the port here. The manager for Turbana Corporation, the banana importer, says the port is one of the most efficient in the nation.
But the workers unloading the bananas face an uncertain future. New Haven Terminal Inc., the private company that owns and operates the port, is seeking investors or a buyer because of financial problems, and the amount of cargo coming into Bridgeport is less than half of what it was five years ago. 
 The picture is even bleaker at the port of New London, which has been closed since last year when the state-owned pier collapsed.
 
100 Workers Laid Off
 Connecticut's three deep-water ports -- Bridgeport, New Haven and New London -- which had thrived handling raw materials for the state's once-vibrant manufacturing economy, have been on the decline for decades. New Haven still serves as a major port for petroleum products. Volume there declined during the early 1990's, but picked up with the resurgence in the economy.
But shipments of other cargo at all three ports have been falling, and in the last four years, the ports of New Haven and Bridgeport have laid off 100 workers. Most Connecticut businesses that ship by sea use the container port in Elizabeth, N.J. The state's small ports cannot handle large volumes of container traffic.
The state concedes that it has paid little attention to its ports. Maintenance and infrastructure improvements in Bridgeport and New Haven have been in the hands of private businesses. Before the pier collapsed in New London in April 1993, the state had spent only $3.2 million for maintenance, design work and emergency repairs in seven years.
However, that may be changing.
The state has begun studies to assess the liabilities, assets and potential of its ports, with an eye toward improvements and more aggressive marketing.
"We have to look at what it is that we have to sell," said Richard Strauss, Connecticut's deputy transportation commissioner. After the reports are completed, the state plans another study to assess what role the state should play in investing in the ports' infrastructure, he said.
 
Ports Were Ignored
 It wasn't until the recession hit that Connecticut even began to talk about the value of its ports, business leaders and officials say.
"Everyone figured all you needed was highways," said Sally Bolster, vice president in the Bridgeport office of the Connecticut Development Authority, a quasi-public agency. "In my experience, there was no long range planning in this state."
Business groups, and some government officials, say improving the ports could help the state's economy.
"The state is losing out on economic opportunities because our port development capacity is not sufficient to handle opportunities out there," said Paul Timpanelli, president of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council, a group with 1,100 members. "I don't think the state saw the ports as an economic opportunity. Finally, now, they are paying some attention to it."
 
Not Like the Port Authority
 Connecticut stands in sharp contrast to its neighbors to the west, where the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey generated $90 million in revenue from its ports last year. Its operations handled nearly 28 million tons of bulk cargo plus container traffic last year, and they employ 3,500 longshoremen.
By comparison, Connecticut's revenue from the port of New London was $90,000 in the last fiscal year. The ports of Bridgeport and New Haven, which are privately run and employ 144 longshoremen, handled less than nine million tons last year, and most of that was petroleum products coming into the tank farms of New Haven.
Bridgeport, which handled steel shipments until the late 1980's, now handles only fruit. Before it shut down, New London handled mostly wood pulp.
Some Connecticut businesses say they are losing time and money because they have to use ports outside the state. Yet most Connecticut business groups say they don't expect to see any of the state's ports becoming big container ports like the one in Elizabeth.
 
Niche Ports
 Instead, Connecticut's ports would compete as niche ports for cargo like steel, fruit, wood pulp and paper products, which are not shipped in the large steel containers that come through Elizabeth, Connecticut officials say. But there is still talk about attracting limited container cargo.
"To develop a port here in Connecticut would take a major investment and a lot of infrastructure," said Steve Cerchia, traffic manager for the Devtec Corporation in Windsor, Conn., which exports about 70 percent of the aircraft ground-support equipment it makes. Devtec is well served by Port Elizabeth, Boston and Wilmington, Del., he said. It ships its manufactured goods in containers and in specialized ships.
"If you put in a viable port in Connecticut and can support it and not have it be a tax boondoogle for the state, I'd certainly support it," said Mr. Cerchia. "As a businessman, I don't think it's worth the investment."
But others like Richard Bodine, vice president of sales and marketing of the Bodine Corporation in Bridgeport, says Port Elizabeth is so busy he sometimes has to wait weeks for the Customs office there to clear his shipments of parts used to build assembly machines. Having a port capable of handling containers in Bridgeport would be a "tremendous advantage," Mr. Bodine said. He estimated that his shipping costs would be cut by 20 percent if he could ship through Bridgeport.
 
No Agency of Its Own
 Unlike New York, New Jersey and other states in the region, Connecticut has had no port authority to market its ports or issue bonds for improvements. Compared with other states around the country, it is also unusual that two of the state's general-cargo ports are privately owned.
Last year, the General Assembly created a Connecticut Coastline Port Authority, but it has no financing. John Byrne, deputy city administrator of Bridgeport, one of 13 commissioners, describes it as advisory.
A bill to give the group more power and take away the state's authority over the three ports didn't make it out of the legislature's Transportation Committee this year. "It was wishful thinking, but not realistic," said Matthew Nemerson, president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce and a port commissioner. "We have no revenue base," he said.
So far, only one port study has been completed. The Bridgeport report, released in January, estimates that a $53 million investment would be needed to capture a bigger share of refrigerated cargoes like fresh fruit and attract containerized cargoes and new markets like automobiles. By the year 2000, such an investment would generate 623 jobs at the port, the study said.
In New London, the state has demolished a storage shed and gone ahead with design work to for reconstruction. Mr. Strauss said he hopes to have a portion of the pier operating by the end of next year.
But some port commissioners and shipping executives have questioned why the state is spending money in New London before the port study is even finished. The two general cargo operators are concerned that a company chosen to run a new facility in New London would have a competitive advantage.
"It's going to be a first class, well constructed dock and to simply allow someone to operate from there and have a monopoly is a concern," said Orest Dubno, marketing director of Gateway Terminal, a cargo operator in New Haven, which employs 100.
 
Worried About New London
 During a tour of the gritty, largely unpaved port in New Haven, the state's biggest with 135 acres, Marty Tristine, vice president of New Haven Terminal, said, "A lot of money has been put into this business. It's not in terrific shape now, but it'll be in worse shape if the state continues what they're planning" in New London.
Mr. Tristine and Joseph Crowley, the company's president, whose grandfather founded the business, said New Haven Terminal would not be able to compete with a state-subsidized port. Mr. Strauss responded that New Haven Terminal could apply to the state for low-interest loans for improvements.
"We have a responsibility to repair that publicly owned facility," said Mr. Strauss. "Essentially, this is taking care of deferred maintenance."

LENGTH: 1119 words

HEADLINE: G.A.O. Seeks Sweeping Rules for Derivatives

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
A two-year Congressional study of the explosive growth in financial derivatives that was released yesterday calls for sweeping new regulation of the companies that create these often complex financial products and the companies that use them.
The General Accounting Office said the banks, brokerage firms and insurance companies that deal in derivatives should be subject to uniform rules on how to manage the risk of their trading positions, how much capital to keep to cushion against losses, and how to disclose data about their derivatives activity. 
 Currently, banks are subject to strict supervision, but other derivatives dealers are more lightly regulated, if at all. While the recommendations effectively seek to force all market participants to follow what are generally regarded as the best industry practices, derivatives dealers were quick to call the recommendations unwarranted.
Derivatives are contracts with values that are based on, or derived from, underlying financial markets. The owner of a stock option, for example, can make profits or lose money as a stock price rises or falls, without owning any shares of the stock. Some derivatives, like options, are used by investors to speculate or to hedge positions in stocks, bonds and commodities. Others, like swaps, are used by corporations to reduce their risks from the fluctuations of interest rates and currencies.
The G.A.O., which is the investigative arm of Congress, said more regulation was needed because the use of derivatives might increase the risk of a financial crisis. On the other hand, the report said, derivatives could also reduce the risk of such a crisis.
Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who is the chairman of the House subcommittee that requested the report, endorsed its recommendations. "It is a tour de force, blistering, scalding indictment of the deficiencies in the current regulatory safeguards," he said. "They identified a regulatory black hole when it comes to derivatives."
Mr. Markey said he endorsed all the recommendations and he expected to introduce a bill to enact them this year in his subcommittee on telecommunications and finance, which oversees brokerage firms. The House banking committee is working on a separate bill to strengthen regulation of derivatives activities by banks. Congressional aides say that none of the bills are likely to pass this year.
The Clinton Administration has not decided whether derivatives activities of brokerage firms and insurance companies should be subject to increased regulation, but it opposes new legislation regarding banks.
"I don't know of any new authority that bank regulators feel they need," Frank Newman, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, said. Over all, he played down any danger of derivatives to the nation's financial system. "It's a risk that needs to be looked at," he said. "But I don't think anyone, including the G.A.O., is portraying this as some imminent, likely danger."
Banks and brokerage firms were uniform in denouncing the report.
"Derivatives are an essential component of modern financial activity and a critically important risk management tool for corporations, financial institutions, and governments around the world," said six banking and brokerage trade associations in a rare joint statement. "If implemented, the G.A.O. recommendations would increase the cost and reduce the availability of these essential transactions," the associations said.
The G.A.O. did not propose restricting any derivative products or limiting their use. Instead, the 200-page report raised concerns that derivatives activity is concentrated at a handful of banks, brokerage firms and insurance companies and that derivatives may increase the linkages between various markets.
As a result, the report said, some regulators and market participants felt that if one major dealer failed or withdrew from the market, it could cause problems for other dealers and in other markets.
Other regulators, the study noted, argue that derivatives actually reduce the risk of such cascading problems. "No empirical evidence was available for determining the actual effects of these characteristics because no crisis caused by derivatives has occurred," the report said.
Still, the report concluded that the potential for such a crisis was sufficient to require greater Government involvement.
 
Dealers Assail Recommendations
 Derivatives dealers were especially critical of the report, saying its data did not back up the assertions. "They don't have material in the report that justifies their recommendations," said Mark Brickell, an executive of J. P. Morgan and vice chairman of the International Swaps and Derivatives Association.
The report does present data to show that all but one of the largest United States banks have greater credit risk from loans than from derivatives. And though the report warns that derivatives' principal risks to the system result from the relatively small number of dealers, the G.A.O.'s own survey shows that just 11 percent of the credit exposure of American derivatives dealers are with other domestic dealers.
Most banks would face more losses if another financial firm failed from foreign currency trading or from loans than from derivatives trades, Mr. Brickell said. "Why does a dealer in derivatives deserve those burdens when a dealer in foreign exchange is not faced with them?" he asked.
James L. Bothwell, the director of financial institution and markets issues for the G.A.O., argued that the study found many weaknesses in risk management and that those problems justified the report's concerns.
"We have no empirical basis to say the risk is likely, but the risk certainly is there; it could happen," he said.
 
Seeks Routine Disclosure
 The G.A.O.'s principal recommendation is that derivatives dealers at brokerage firms and insurance companies be subject to the same sort of strict regular examinations and rules for disclosure, internal controls and capital as Federally insured banks.
Other recommendations included updating accounting standards to reflect derivative exposure better; fostering uniform international regulations, and forcing corporations that use "complex derivatives" to have adequate controls and disclosures.
More broadly, the G.A.O. said Congress should consider more sweeping reform of financial regulation because it has not kept pace with the blurring of lines between industries.
"Banking, securities, futures and insurance are no longer separate and distinct industries that can be well regulated by the existing patchwork quilt of Federal and state agencies," the report said.

HEADLINE: Kellogg Seeks to Reset Latvia's Breakfast Table

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIGA, Latvia

 BODY:
For as long as anyone can remember, the favorite breakfast here and in much of the former Soviet Union has been a hearty plate of sausage, cold cuts, potatoes, eggs and a few slices of thick, chewy bread slathered with wonderfully high-cholesterol butter.
But now one of the great missionary enterprises in American business, the Kellogg Company of Battle Creek, Mich., is trying to change the way hundreds of millions of Russians, Latvians and other former Soviet citizens start their day. 
 Attracted by the prospect of reaping fortunes in one of the few remaining cereal frontiers in the world, the company has opened a plant in the birch and pine woods on the outskirts of this Baltic capital to make Kellogg's Corn Flakes. And Kellogg is pressing ahead with one of the more ambitious education programs in the annals of eating.
 
A New Way to Eat Breakfast
 "We have to teach people a whole new way to eat breakfast," said Philip D. Stewart, a specialist in Soviet affairs who left Ohio State University to command Kellogg's forces in the former Soviet Union.
Kellogg is making its biggest push here in Riga, a medieval city of towers and spires with a population of nearly a million people. But Kellogg is also testing the waters in neighboring Estonia and Lithuania and has established beachheads in a few Russian stores in St. Petersburg and Moscow.
To win converts, Kellogg is relying mainly on slick television advertisements showing a family joyfully digging into their Corn Flakes, and on demonstrations in grocery stores that the company refers to as "taste testings."
The emphasis is on American-style health and nutrition, but there's the unmistakable suggestion that breakfast can be fun, too. As a column of creamy white milk cascades into a bowl of Corn Flakes in the television ad, the camera moves in for a tight shot and the message "eight vitamins" flashes across the screen.
One recent afternoon in Kekava, an old town just south of Riga, a young Latvian sales representative for Kellogg stacked a table in the immaculate Dalderi grocery store with red and white boxes of Corn Flakes and little white paper bowls. Behind the display were chest-high deli cases displaying giant blocks of cheese, a dozen varieties of sausage and glistening slabs of fatty bacon.
The Kellogg display drew a cluster of women and children and a few men. The sales representative held a bowl of Corn Flakes and urged someone to have a try.
"It's delicious," she said, "It has lots of calories, lots of vitamins."
Ausma Meijere, a woman in her 60's in a heavy black coat, reached for the bowl and took in a couple of crunchy mouthfuls.
 
A Different Taste
 "It's quite substantial," Mrs. Meijere said with mild surprise. "Normally I have boiled macaroni with milk and sugar. But I'm planning to buy some of these. The crispiness is different from what we're used to."
On another afternoon in the Baltic Sea resort of Jurmala, Ilze Sulmane, a journalism lecturer at the University of Latvia, said her children adored cornflakes. But at the equivalent of a little more than a dollar and a half for a box in a country where most Latvians earn less than $100 a month, she said, "we can't afford them."
"Sometimes," Mrs. Sulmane said, "we buy them for a gift."
Juris Paider, the editor of Dienas Biznes, a financial newspaper in Latvia, can afford cornflakes. But like many Latvian men, as Kellogg discovered in focus groups and other research, Mr. Paider scoffed at the new breakfast food.
"This is not food for a man," he said. "My wife likes it because it is very fast, easy to serve. The kids eat it not only in the morning but between meals. They take little bits in their hands. But it's not for me. I've been eating a different kind of food all my life. I'm too conservative to change."
The grumpy reaction of some men notwithstanding, Richard Lovell, the head of corporate communications for Kellogg in Battle Creek, said that initial sales in the former Soviet Union, as well as in the new markets of Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic, had been encouraging. Mr. Lovell would not say how much cereal the company was selling in the region or give other details of Kellogg's sales or marketing strategy.
 
No Quick Return Seen
 Kellogg invested $22 million in its Corn Flakes plant in Riga without expectation of a quick return. "We don't expect to realize profits for years in an operation like this," Mr. Lovell said. "It's going to be part of long-term growth."
It took 40 years to develop the Latin American market, Mr. Lovell said, and the company views Latvia, its 18th international outpost, in the same spirit.
Already the world's most successful cereal company, with 51 percent of the market, Kellogg is opening another plant in Bombay, India, this summer and has started work on one in China that is expected to begin turning out breakfast cereal in mid-1995.
Since becoming independent in 1991, Latvia has created a climate for foreign investors that seems tranquil compared with the chaos in much of the former Soviet Union. It has established its own currencies and has managed to rein in inflation.
But Kellogg tumbled into Latvia through a series of improbable developments that began eight years ago. The first overture came not from Battle Creek but from Moscow. On a visit to the United States, Georgi A. Arbatov, an adviser on American affairs to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former Soviet President, fell in love with Kellogg cereals and wanted to see them on breakfast tables at home.
So when Mr. Stewart, as a consultant to the Kellogg Foundation while at Ohio State, went to him in 1986 to ask for help in arranging some seminars on the military, Mr. Arbatov saw a chance for some horse trading.
It was an easy sell, Mr. Stewart said, because Arnold G. Langbo, then president of Kellogg's international division and now chairman and chief executive officer, already had his eye on the Soviet Union, as well as China and India.
But discussions sputtered along for two years before Mr. Arbatov suggested a joint venture with a collective farm outside Riga. Before the deal could be closed, the Soviet Union collapsed, Latvia became independent and Kellogg decided to go it alone.
Mr. Stewart retired from Ohio State University and took charge of building Kellogg's plant in Latvia. Every step of the way meant reinventing the wheel. Kellogg wanted to build its plant with Latvian workers but, Mr. Stewart said, "No local builder understood the kind of standards we were talking about."
So Kellogg brought in architects, engineers and supervisors from England and Germany. The company also hauled in hardware and plumbing supplies as well as the machinery to make cornflakes. Kellogg has been able to buy some supplies locally, but the most important ingredient -- corn -- is still imported, reportedly from Canada and Argentina.
Once the plant officially opened in November, Kellogg had to reach retail outlets in a country where there was no effective distribution system.
Instead of recruiting a work force by word of mouth or through old relationships, Kellogg advertised in the Riga newspapers and interviewed hundreds of applicants. Every employee hired had a high school education and many had college degrees, Mr. Stewart said. But factory workers had to learn how to make Corn Flakes, a technique that is a closely guarded company secret. Office employees also had to learn Western management and accounting methods, and the sales force had to learn what it means to sell.
"We started with a work force of people who had never seen a cornflake," Mr. Stewart said. "And the skills of salesmanship and merchandising, none of that had existed here for more than 50 years."
But gradually, Kellogg has been making a dent. These days, Mr. Stewart said, "You'd have a hard time finding a store in Latvia that doesn't have Kellogg's Corn Flakes."

HEADLINE: Why the Fed Acted

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
On the face of it, the Federal Reserve raised interest rates on Tuesday mainly to take some steam out of a growing economy so that it would not become inflationary.
But that explanation, offered by the Fed itself, hardly tells the whole story. Quite apart from inflation, which is still quite modest, the Fed was forced to deal with a concoction of events -- most of them only loosely connected to the real economy -- that had pushed up interest rates. More than in the past, rates and reality became disconnected. 
 Even Paul A. Volcker, the former Fed chairman famous as an inflation fighter in the 1980's, acknowledged as much. "The apparent sensitivity of the markets to inflationary fears seems overdrawn," he said in a recent speech that he cited again during an interview. "I am not in the school of those concerned that any significant economic growth will bring stronger price pressure."
The problem is that the higher interest rates that have resulted from the concoction of events -- financial speculation was one, trade policy and the weak dollar was another, a selloff of Treasury securities by the nation's banks was a third -- could be damaging. By restricting borrowing, the higher rates have the potential of taking more steam out of the economy than the Fed may have wished, greatly diluting an economic expansion that was so promising and powerful during the winter, but has now lost some of its bloom.
"Interest rates at today's levels certainly hasten the day when the economic recovery begins to peter out," Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist, said. "There have to be people on the margin already closed out from buying houses and cars."
Interest rates had risen by more than 1.5 percentage points since October on most loans of two years duration or more. Recognizing this upward trend, the Fed in February raised a key rate that it controls to catch up, and to signal its intention to fight inflation by slowing the economy, if necessary.
But the Fed's February action, along with similar quarter-point increases in March and April, only seemed to excite the markets and to push up interest rates even more, beyond the Fed's goals. The bigger half-point increase on Tuesday finally brought calm -- for the moment.
"The marketplace is satisfied; we have gotten the dark cloud of uncertainty from over our heads," said Albert Wojnilower, senior economic adviser to the CS First Boston Investment Corporation, a Wall Street firm. "For a few months, we can let the economy roll on, but then the Fed will probably have to raise rates again."
 
The Inflation Haters
 Mr. Wojnilower is a member of a powerful constituency -- embodied in the nation's bond markets -- that wants to keep inflation down. It argues that the best way to do this is to push rates high enough, at least for a while, to slow the economy.
The bond market, in effect, represents the nation's lenders. They are wealthy individuals, banks, mutual funds, pension funds, brokerage houses, insurance companies and money managers. They have out on loan more than $8 trillion to business and to government. That is $2 trillion more than the value of all shares on the nation's stock exchanges.
The lenders make these loans by investing in Treasury securities, municipal bonds and corporate bonds. And they are worried that the expanding economy will generate inflation, reducing the value of their bonds. To make the point, they often overstate the inflation danger -- and the Fed finds itself responding to the pressure.
"I am an economist, and as an economist I don't understand why interest rates went up so much," said Nicholas Sargen, who is also chief investment officer for a Prudential Insurance Company fund that lends $4 billion, most of it on behalf of mutual funds and pension funds.
As an economist, Mr. Sargen ticks off reasons why the pressure among lenders for higher interest rates to prevent inflation lacks justification in the real economy, with its stagnant wages and numerous companies that can't make price increases stick. "I personally agree that the markets may have overstated the risk of an upsurge in inflation," he said.
 
Cuts Back on Treasuries
 But as a lender, he has added his voice to the hue and cry about inflation. More to the point, he has sharply reduced his purchase of Treasury bonds. That strategy remains in place, despite the Fed's Tuesday rate increase and despite Mr. Sargen's private skepticism about inflation. Besides, he has an alternative.
More easily than in the past, he can shift money quickly into foreign bonds, and he has. His fund holds European bonds, and it recently purchased long-term Australian government bonds, which offer an annual yield of nearly 9 percent, well above similar American Treasuries.
Mr. Sargen's reluctance to purchase American bonds, multiplied many times over, helped to make interest rates rise. Because of the Sargens in the marketplace, bondholders wanting to sell have not found enough eager buyers. If a bondholder is offering for sale a $100 bond, for example, he has had to lower the price to entice a buyer. Perhaps he receives only $80. If the bond pays $6 a year or 6 percent interest, then that $6 annual payment represents a 7.5 percent yield for the bond's new owner, who has invested only $80.
 
Speculation Emerges
 This reluctance to buy coincided with a rush to sell, not so much because of fears about inflation, but because of speculation. During a long period of weak economic growth and unchanging interest rates -- a period that ended late last year -- bond buyers invested not only their money, but also money they borrowed.
They would borrow at, say, 3 percent for six months and invest in 10-year bonds that paid 6 percent interest. That leverage worked as long as interest rates stayed steady. But when they began to rise, and fluctuate, the game became dangerous. There was a rush to sell, and the difficulty in finding buyers forced down prices and pushed up yields.
"You say to yourself, 'Bonds are a good value, and I should buy,' but then you say to yourself, 'Maybe I can wait until tomorrow, because they are still going down in value,' " said Robert Johnson, a managing director for funds sponsored by the financier George Soros. "And then you say, 'I would like to buy bonds,' but then you say, 'That's crazy, because there are all these people who still have to sell first.' Only now is that selling finally coming to an end."
The selloff by speculators coincided with another selloff, by banks, for a different reason. During four years of weak economic growth, the banks, lacking borrowers, invested their depositors' money instead in Treasuries, which paid interest rates higher than the depositors received. The Fed had encouraged this safe and profitable tactic to strengthen banks, which had been hurt by loan defaults.
 
Banks Sell Treasuries
 But with the economy expanding again, businesses and consumers borrowed more, and to raise money to service this loan demand, the banks have been selling Treasury securities, driving down their value and driving up their yields.
Finally, a weak dollar has put upward pressure on interest rates. Rather than risk currency losses, foreigners, particularly the Japanese, sold Treasury bonds and converted the dollars into their own currencies. American trade policy inadvertently aided this process. When trade talks with Japan broke down in February, foreign exchange traders concluded that the Administration would respond by favoring a weaker dollar against the yen -- a tactic that might hurt Japanese exports.
The Administration denied such a tactic, but the dollar fell anyway. And the United States, with 16 other countries, finally intervened, buying dollars to stabilize the currency's value. But to really stabilize the dollar, bondholders reasoned, the Fed had to endorse the currency intervention by raising rates to make Treasuries, purchased in dollars, more attractive. And the Fed did so on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Fails to Respond To the Fed's Rate Increases

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against many leading currencies yesterday after the Federal Reserve's increase in interest rates failed to restore the market's confidence in the American currency.
Many traders had expected the dollar to gain after the Fed pushed up both its discount rate and the Federal funds rate on overnight loans among banks by half a percentage point on Tuesday. Higher rates usually bolster the dollar by making dollar-denominated assets more attractive. 
 But the dollar fell instead, as traders concluded that the Fed was unlikely to raise rates again soon and that Tuesday's increase was not large enough to justify buying dollars.
The Fed suggested that further rate increases were not needed to head off the inflation that often arises with strong economic growth. But at 3.5 percent, the Fed's discount rate on its overnight loans to member banks is still a full percentage point lower than the rate in Germany.
"The dollar looks like it's heading lower," said Bill Arnold, chief currency dealer at the Chemical Bank. "Market participants have concluded that there won't be any more rate increases" in the United States in the near future.
 
Yen and Mark Up
 In late New York trading, the dollar was down 1.5 pfennigs, at 1.6575 German marks, from 1.6725 marks on Tuesday. The dollar fell to 103.55 Japanese yen from 104.68 yen.
Traders lost confidence in the dollar earlier this year when previous rate increases by the Fed failed to drive it higher. A flight of capital from slumping stock and bond markets also weighed on the dollar.
Some traders suspect that the Fed raised short-term rates as part of its effort to shore up the dollar. The Fed and other central banks bought dollars on May 4 to stem its slide. A week later, the Bundesbank lowered German interest rates in what looked like a coordinated effort to drive the dollar higher.
"This is a dangerous scenario for the dollar," said Hunt Taylor, managing director at the Reynwood Trading Corporation, a Short Hills, N.J., currency trading firm that manages $100 million. "The strongest weapon a government has to defend its currency is interest-rate policy. If that doesn't work, nothing will."
The dollar remains weak against major currencies in part because European assets are more attractive right now, traders said. With interest rates falling on the Continent, European stocks and bonds promise to rally more than American assets.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Most Treasury Rates Lower in Active Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Interest rates on most Treasury securities moved lower again yesterday in what dealers said was active but orderly trading.
But weakness in the dollar and a rise in some commodity prices preyed on long-term bond yields, which were rose fractionally following Tuesday's big drop. 
 The dollar's renewed weakness was a source of concern because it came only a day after the Federal Reserve Board's aggressive increase in two key short-term interest rates. Since interest rate rises are not usually associated with a declining currency, some bond traders voiced concern that the Fed might have to raise rates again to support the dollar if the currency continues to falter.
"The dollar has been the big discussion topic," said William Michaelcheck, president of Mariner Partners, a private New York firm that concentrates most of its activity in trading short-term Treasury securities.
"We have a risk that if the Clinton Administration and the Fed appear to send out a message they have gone as far as they are going to go" in raising interest rates, "then currency traders will hit the dollar."
 
Raising of Interest Rates
 In its statement announcing the half-point increases in the overnight Federal funds rate and the discount rate Tuesday, the Fed left the clear impression that for the time being it has finished raising interest rates.
In a statement that rattled currency traders, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen underscored that notion yesterday. Mr. Bentsen said he "would hope" the Fed's latest rate increase will provide a "respite" from additional increases.
Mr. Bentsen's comments "were a mistake," Mr. Michaelcheck said, because they will likely be viewed by currency traders as an opportunity to test the Administration's commitment to supporting the dollar.
"The market certainly has the impression that there is a tacit understanding between the Fed and the Treasury that this was it for a while," he said. "The foreign exchange market is kind of nervous about that."
Yet, even as the prospect that the Fed may for the time being be finished with raising interest rates sent small ripples through the bond market, the same possibility was providing comfort to traders of short-to- intermediate-term securities.
Indeed, after Tuesday's chaotic session, traders and analysts said they were satisfied with the market's overall performance yesterday.
"Tuesday's rally was explosive," said Steven Saslow, an executive managing director at HSBC Securities. "Today was more gradual, with a continued flow of retail investors coming into the market. There is increasing comfort that the Fed will sit for a longer period of time."
The big drop in yields on Tuesday also provided corporations and tax-exempt municipal bond issuers the opportunity to price new issues yesterday.
More than $1 billion in new corporate bonds were priced yesterday, while states and cities offered just over $750 million worth of new securities.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the benchmark 6 1/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2023 were offered late yesterday at a price of 87 22/32 , down 1/8 of a point from late Tuesday, to yield 7.27 percent. During overnight trading, before the dollar began to weaken, bond prices had been as much as half a point higher.
Among intermediate- and short-term Treasury issues, the 6 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at a price of 99 5/8, up 1/4 point, to yield 6.58 percent. And prices of the 5 1/2 percent two-year notes rose by 6/32 , to 99 1/2, to yield 5.77 percent.
Confidence that the Fed has finished tightening monetary policy for the foreseeable future was visible in the Treasury bill market, where rates eased by as much as 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. was the biggest issuer in the corporate debt market yesterday, as it offered $500 million worth of 10-year notes.
The notes were priced at 100, or par, to yield 7.50 percent, 46 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.25 percent ten-year notes at the time of pricing.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for the issue, which is non-callable for life. The securities are rated AA-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The State of Maryland had the largest offering in the tax-exempt municipal bond market, selling $120 million in general obligation bonds at competitive bid.
The bonds, which are rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's, were priced to yield as much as 5.65 percent on bonds maturing in 2009.

HEADLINE: Dow Climbs by 12.28 in a Late Recovery

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
It was a baffling day in the markets yesterday, as traders pondered the steep interest-rate increase they had long lobbied for and got. The stock market drifted in the morning, but recovered strongly in the afternoon, especially as measured by the broad-based Standard & Poor's 500.
For much of the day, however, stock traders scratched their heads over the course of the dollar, which failed to rally after the Federal Reserve Board's increase in interest rates. 
 "All day the stock market was confused because of the dollar," said David F. DeRosa, a director of foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation. "The dollar began to stop selling off around noon and then the bond market recovered, so the stock market decided to recover, too."
As near as he could piece it together, Mr. DeRosa said, European traders had been enthusiastically buying dollars as of 3 A.M., Eastern time, but as buying waned, other potential buyers were expecting dollar purchases by the Federal Reserve Board and European central banks. When the expected intervention did not happen, the dollar, which had been unsteady, began to fall.
"This was a major disappointment for the dollar bulls," said Mr. DeR osa, who described himself as bearish on the dollar. "It spilled over into other markets."
The American currency declined against the yen and the Deutsche mark yesterday, despite recent European cuts in interest rates, notably in Germany. The dollar fell to 103.55 yen, from 104.68 yen at the previous close, and to 1.657 marks from 1.6725 marks.
Meanwhile, the bond market seemed to be coming out of its tailspin, in large part to the Fed's action Tuesday. Bond prices were little changed yesterday, and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond edged up slightly to 7.27 percent.
 
A Steadying of Bond Prices
 The steadying of bond prices helped the stock market. In heavy trading, stock prices rose on all the leading indexes, although much more strongly on the Nasdaq composite index, which failed to rise Tuesday after the Fed action. High-technology stocks, battered for weeks, recovered moderately.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.28 points, to 3,732.89 and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 4.32 points, to 453.69. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 10.38 points, to 721.90.
The fact that the markets recovered was the only important conclusion from the day, said Easton Ragsdale, chief quantitative analyst for Kidder, Peabody. "As long as you have decent volume and the market is up, that's a good thing. The market may be getting back to important questions like, Are corporate earnings going up? And the answer to that is yes."
Yesterday, the number of shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 337.7 million shares, 12 percent above this year's average of 302 million shares.
Indeed, the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the trading value of shares bought and sold, as of yesterday, totaled $1 trillion so far this year, three weeks ahead of last year's record. The $1 trillion mark was reached on June 10 last year.
By Tuesday, more than 28 billion had been traded on the Big Board, compared with 25.1 billion in the period a year ago. A record $2.25 trillion worth of stock was traded last year, or about 67.2 billion shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 2.60 points, to 250.73. Advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks by 1,629 to 679. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.92 points, to 434.90.
Of the 30 component stocks in the Dow industrials, 16 rose, led by Philip Morris, whose price was up 1 1/2 points, to 53, on no discernible news.
Of the 500 component stocks in the S.& P. 500, 332 rose, led by AT&T, whose price rose 1 3/8, to 55 1/4, also on no discernible news.
Both AT&T and Philip Morris are widely held by both institutional and small investors and are sometimes traded for reasons specific to their portfolios.
The most active stock, at 10 million shares, was Cisco Systems, whose stock has declined three of the last four sessions. But yesterday, it rose 1 3/4, to 23 7/8.
The second-most-active stock, at 5 million shares, was Telefonos de Mexico, which closed up 1 1/8, to 58 3/8.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Soybean Rally Helps to Push Price Index to 3 1/2-Year High

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodity prices rose to a three-and-a-half-year high yesterday as soybean prices surged, even though the Federal Reserve had raised interest rates the day before in an effort to slow growth in prices.
The bureau's index rose as high as 231.45, its highest since October 1990, before settling at 230.98, up 1.45 points. Of the index's 21 components, which include everything from copper to coffee, 14 were higher. 
 The rise in the bureau's index is evidence of a turnaround for goods that have been depressed by a weak global economy and ample supply, Bill O'Neill, senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch & Company, said.
"There are a number of commodities that have been in long down cycles," including copper, coffee and sugar, Mr. O'Neill said. "What we're seeing is a recovery in some of those markets."
The prospect of inflation also concerns investors, he said, even as the Fed raises rates to contain it: "It shows that even with the Fed doing this, there is still a certain background fear of inflation."
 
Weather Forecast Moves Grains
 Soybeans rose to a four-month high on forecasts that dry weather in the Midwest will last for at least the next few days. Soybeans for July delivery gained 21.50 cents, to $7.0075 a bushel, extending a 5.5 percent rally this week on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Among other grain contracts, July corn rose 2.25 cents, to $2.6925 a bushel, but July wheat fell 2.00 cents, to $3.24 a bushel.
Little rain is expected during the weekend and temperatures should be above normal, according to the Weather Services Corporation of Bedford, Mass. Traders said this season's lack of rainfall was particularly disturbing. Stockpiles are low after flooding last year reduced the harvest.
"Any little turbulence makes you nervous," Victor Lespinasse, vice president with Dean Witter in Chicago, said. "If you fall this time, you're going to get hurt because there's no cushion."
 
Oil Prices Rise
 Elsewhere, crude oil joined the commodity market rally, following the American Petroleum Institute's institute's weekly report that showed a decline in crude oil stocks.
June crude rose 40 cents, to $17.99 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, while unleaded gasoline rose 0.85 cent, to 51.32 cents a gallon, and heating oil gained 0.66 cent, to 47.70 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Japan Likely to Retain Curb on Software Raiding

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 18

 BODY:
In an apparent victory for the United States, the Japanese Government is expected to abandon a plan to revise its copyright law in a way that would have made it easier for one company to reverse-engineer another company's computer software.
An advisory committee to Japan's Agency for Cultural Affairs has finished its deliberations without reaching a conclusion on whether and how the law should be changed, according to committee members, industry officials and Japanese press reports. 
 "Right now the committee couldn't reach an agreement to prepare a draft of an amendment to revise the copyright law," said Shigeru Miki, a Tokyo lawyer and a member of the advisory panel.
Without a recommendation from the committee to change the law, the cultural agency is expected to drop the matter, at least for now.
Washington, as well as American computer and software companies like Apple, I.B.M. and Microsoft, vigorously protested the contemplated change in copyright law, saying it would have made it easier for Japanese companies to learn how American programs work and to develop competing products. Software is an industry in which American companies are the acknowledged world leaders and in which the Japanese are considered weak.
 
Some U.S. Companies Dissent
 But a smaller group of American companies led by Sun Microsystems argued in favor of revision, saying it would spur innovation and competition and make it easier for different programs and different machines to work together.
The advisory panel's report, which is expected to be made final on May 30, reportedly lays out several positions on the matter without backing any of them. "There are so many opinions," Mr. Miki said. "The chairman couldn't get a single agenda."
But if a lack of consensus is the official reason for shelving the proposal, the real reason might be that Japan does not want to stick another thorn in the side of the United States at a time when it is trying to ease touchy trade relations.
Overall trade negotiations broke down in February, and Japan's politically weak coalition Government is having trouble delivering on promises to deregulate the economy, increase spending and open markets. Washington has begun to ease pressure on Japan for immediate results.
At issue in this case is a process called "decompilation," a way of dissecting computer programs to learn how they work.
When software is written in a programming language, like Fortran, it undergoes a process of compilation that turns the program into the ones and zeroes understood by the computer. Such a collection of ones and zeroes, which are on the disk or tape a customer buys, are extremely difficult to decipher. Decompilation turns this binary code back into a programming language that trained people can more readily understand.
 
Japanese Litigation Seen
 In the absence of a change in the law, experts said, it is somewhat unclear whether decompilation is permissible in Japan under some circumstances. The matter is likely to be tested in Japanese courts, just as it has been in American courts.
Washington thinks that Japanese law prohibits the practice. But Mr. Miki, the lawyer on the advisory panel, said the practice might be permissible under some circumstances, just as making copies of a copyrighted work is allowed in some situations.
The European Union in 1991 allowed decompilation when it is necessary to make one program operate with another. In the United States, two court decisions have let video-game software companies use the practice to evade lockout devices preventing them from making games for Sega and Nintendo machines.
Proponents say decompilation speeds innovation because one program can build on another. Learning how a program functions is legitimate, they say, because copyrights do not protect ideas, only how ideas are expressed. They also say the practice allows smaller companies to make programs that work with, or compete against software from giants like I.B.M. and Microsoft that have become industry standards.
Opponents say there are other, legal ways to find out how a program works. The process of decompilation itself involves making a copy of the software being analyzed, which is illegal, they say.

HEADLINE: Daimler Says Sales Rose

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 18

 BODY:
Daimler-Benz, Germany's largest industrial company, said today that sales rebounded in the first quarter.
Edzard Reuter, the company's chairman, said at the annual shareholders meeting in Berlin that sales in the quarter were up 19 percent from the corresponding period in 1993, when Germany was in deep recession and export sales were slumping. 
 An upturn in the United States market led the surge in Daimler's biggest division, the luxury car maker Mercedes-Benz. The report said Mercedes's United States sales rose 45 percent in the first quarter, compared with a 28 percent increase in all of Western Europe and 17 percent in Germany. Mr. Reuter said the company over all showed a 30 percent increase in sales in the United States for the quarter.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
All the Signs Are Pointing to Another Major-League Strike

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

 BODY:
How naive it all seems now.
March 1990, wee hours of the morning, a hotel ballroom filled with stale cigarette smoke, half-empty coffee cups and fatigued players, management officials, labor negotiators and reporters. And, everyone thought, a breath of fresh air. 
 Baseball's power brokers were signing a peace treaty, but in a far different fashion from the hostile ends of previous stoppages. In 1981, negotiators would not even be photographed together after a bitter 50-day strike ended. In 1985, player-negotiators broke open champagne, but refused to offer sips to their counterparts on management's team at the end of a two-day strike.
March 1990 was different. A lockout that wiped 32 days from the spring-training schedule had ended. And the combatants turned the pact signing into a public soul-searching and love fest, applauding each other and tantalizing their weary fans with thoughts of tending to their responsibilities to the sport with much less hostility and mistrust.
"This is a very resilient industry, but it's really important for this industry that we lift it out of the anger, end these whacks we take at each other every three or four years," Bud Selig said that day.
Selig, the owner of the Brewers and an active participant in labor negotiations, is now the acting commissioner and responsible for keeping the games going.
A little over four years later, those promises and hopes seem all but forgotten. As life preservers tossed to what was then and still is a troubled game, they proved to be all but useless.
For baseball's owners and players are back at the bargaining table. And it's beginning to look as if nothing short of a miracle will enable the game to avoid another work stoppage.
It has been almost five months since the collective bargaining agreement has expired. It has been almost five months since the collective bargaining agreement has expired. It has been twice that long since the owners opted to open the agreement in order to allow an extra year to try to hammer some revolutionary ideas into the players' heads, mainly a salary cap.
Not surprisingly, the extra year -- a call for the invention of a better wheel to make baseball owners' financial world go round -- has resulted in little, if nothing.
Oh, the two sides met yesterday at a midtown hotel, the first negotiating session since March. "It was a useful, constructive conversation," said Richard Ravitch, the president of the management's Player Relations Committee and the man who will have his first experience leading the owners into a labor fracas. "But there are no headlines."
The two sides will meet again on Monday in Los Angeles to discuss non-economic issues. The owners have given the players a slew of financial reports to look over, a precedent-breaker and required reading for a group trying to determine if they share a moral obligation to buck up foundering franchises. But even if the players find more money in the coffers than they were initially led to expect, it probably will not matter.
"The owners are no longer pleading poverty," Lauren Rich, the assistant general counsel for the Major League Baseball Players Association, said after yesterday's session. "They want a cap no matter what."
That is not likely to endear the owners to the players. Just as the lack of a proposal has not. The owners have not detailed their salary cap idea, which illustrates how preliminary the talks remain even though both sides must realize a countdown on a labor stoppage may have already begun. The players' union representatives are scheduled to meet in Pittsburgh on July 11, the day before the All-Star Game, and may vote on setting a strike date.
"It is clear that the owners are in no great rush to speed up negotiations," Rich said. "It's been 18 months since they re-opened and we still have gotten a proposal."
Management negotiators, with fresh memories of a detailed proposal that was rejected in 1991, sought to work out a proposal with the players this time, Ravitch said.
But the players do not want a salary cap. So, quite naturally, they see no reason to help construct one.
So Ravitch says he plans to present the owners' cap proposal in mid-June, without the players' input. He can only hope it lasts more than the short-lived pay-for-performance issue did in 1990.
So baseball's antagonists stand where they usually do -- poles apart. Until a crisis forces them to settle on a more traditional deal. Nothing thus far suggests that the crisis will not enter, stage right, on cue, as always. That is why the players' executive board will meet in Chicago on June 9, and all of their representatives will meet in Pittsburgh on July 11 to discuss the one step that they may already have concluded is the only way to stop the owners from forcing the salary cap upon them.
The owners? Even though they did not lock the players out earlier this year, they did flex their muscles by requiring that any deal with the players be approved by two-thirds of the 28 owners as opposed to a simple majority. Many immediately saw that rules change as assuring that a militant few can shut down the game and keep it shut.
Ravitch, the self-described optimist, does not buy into such inevitabilities, not as long as there are good-faith negotiations. But, he added: "Strikes and lockouts occur when one side underestimates the determination of the other side. Where the union may think that the owners won't insist on change, I think that the union is going to be wrong. So I hope that this gets done without miscalculation on anybody's part."
So much for the island of peace the two sides supposedly stumbled upon that March day in 1990. One can only hope that day turns out to be more than a failed cease-fire in baseball's otherwise unrelenting version of the 100 Years War.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 599 words

HEADLINE: On the Brink With North Korea

 BODY:
Tiring of cat-and-mouse bargaining with North Korea over its nuclear program, the two Senate leaders, George Mitchell and Robert Dole, want to rush to impose economic sanctions. Their impatience is especially ill timed: international inspectors arrived yesterday at the site of the North's nuclear reactor, which has been shut down for refueling. A move to sanctions is almost sure to get them sent home.
Washington's top priority is to prevent North Korea from diverting spent nuclear fuel to bombs while refueling. The inspectors' presence over the coming months is the best guarantee that that will not happen. Only if North Korea impedes the inspectors from witnessing the refueling would immediate sanctions be warranted. 
 The Senators are understandably disturbed that the North is resisting inspectors' efforts to determine whether it diverted nuclear material to bombs in the past, and if so, to restore that material to international safekeeping.
But first things first. As long as the North allows the inspectors to monitor the refueling and prevent any new diversion, bomb-making will be held in check. Washington can meanwhile negotiate with Pyongyang about untangling its past nuclear history when high-level talks resume.
The North seems to be amenable to inspection of the refueling. That, in turn, could open the way to a deal allowing investigation of the past. Refueling a reactor takes time -- at least two months, to unload thousands of fuel rods. The rods and spent fuel have to be handled with care; they are brittle, hot, toxic and radioactive. They must be removed and placed in water-filled storage tanks.
The fuel rods themselves are made of low-enriched uranium, which cannot be used for bomb-making without further enrichment, a process the North is not believed to be equipped to do. But the spent fuel also contains plutonium, which, when separated, can be fabricated into bombs.
The International Atomic Energy Agency has cameras in place to record the refueling, which inhibits diversion of the spent fuel. But the inspectors' presence would give the world added confidence that no diversion can take place. If North Korea does not intend to make nuclear arms, it has an interest in assuring the world of that.
The inspectors also want to draw samples from the reactor core. Those samples, when assayed, could help determine whether any diversion had taken place in 1989, before inspections began. As long as the inspectors can catalogue and store samples of the core for subsequent assaying, they may be able to retrace the North's nuclear history. But Pyongyang may want a deal with Washington before allowing that to happen.
The Clinton Administration has rightly said it would negotiate with North Korea as long as it was assured the North was not diverting nuclear fuel and separating and reprocessing the plutonium in it. But North Korea's cooperation with inspectors has been grudging and fitful. In March it kept inspectors from taking swabs and radioactivity readings to ascertain whether any reprocessing had occurred over the past year. Now, however, if the North allows the inspectors to complete the work they began in March and to monitor the refueling, as it has pledged, the way would be open to resumption of high-level talks.
At those talks, Pyongyang could trade a verifiable end to its nuclear program in return for U.S. diplomatic recognition, security assurances and political and economic ties. That will take patient diplomacy, not rash sanctions. But why be in a hurry to go over the brink with North Korea?

HEADLINE: A Rank That Rankles: New York Slips to No. 3;
Now Texas Is 2d Most Populous State

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
New York, first in the American League, second in apple production, has slipped to third in population, behind not only California but now Texas.
Texans have already laid claim to unofficial bragging rights as the nation's second most populous state. And yesterday, the Census Bureau disclosed population projections indicating that Texas had indeed overtaken New York sometime in January. 
 "I don't know what difference it makes, frankly," said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, not entirely a good sport. "I think we're regularly undercounted, so I don't believe the Census Bureau." Of course, the other biggies -- California, Texas, Florida -- have some problems with undercounting as well.
Other New Yorkers conceded it was inevitable that the Empire State, which ranked first in population from 1810 to 1970, was being bumped to third -- a status it last held in 1800, when it was poised to leapfrog over Massachusetts and Pennsylvania.
"Once you're not No. 1, it doesn't matter where you are," said Jerry Della Femina, the New York advertising executive and reputedly the fastest quote in the East. "Nobody ever shouted they were No. 2 except for Avis."
 
Texas's Edge
 The Census Bureau had figured that Texas would not overtake New York for another six weeks or so, but, responding to a request, it produced a revised projection yesterday to reflect the latest trends.
Between Jan. 1 and Feb. 1, Paul R. Campbell of the Census Bureau estimated, New York's population edged up by a mere 1,000 to 18,151,000. By contrast, Mr. Campbell said, Texas swelled by 26,000 in January to 18,163,000 by Feb. 1.
A relative loss in population hurts a state's standing in Congress, but Texas's expected gain of two more Congressional seats at New York's expense will not occur until the reapportionment after the next decennial census in 2000. Federal aid is typically disbursed according to a state's population, rather than its rank.
The most immediate impact of the shift may be on states of mind in the two states, where superlatives are taken for granted. Egos in both may be too large either to be deflated by a statistical demotion to New York, which remains home to the nation's biggest city, or to be enhanced by the Government's validation of what Texans already consider gospel in Texas, which, with less than half the land area of Alaska, remains the biggest of the 48 contiguous states.
A New Yorker was churlish enough to point out that Texas also ranks first among the states in the number of homes without complete plumbing (85,000) and in cattle population (nearly 14 million). That prompted Mr. Della Femina to suggest that perhaps census takers had counted hooves and divided by four.
Until the last decade or two, Texans considered growth synonymous with progress.
"It's still the dominant view, but it is no longer the only view," said T. R. Fehrenbach, second to none as a Texas historian. "There is a strong feeling today that untrammeled growth brings problems."
Still, the Lone Star State has plenty of space for new Texans as the nation's population continues to shift to the South and the West, which, since 1980, have been home to a majority of Americans. Its population density averages 67 Texans a square mile; New York crowds 384 people in the like space. (And New Jersey has the nation's greatest population density, at 1,050 souls a square mile.)
"I have no doubt that Texans will burst with pride that they've passed New York, although New York is no longer the bete noire it was," Mr. Fehrenback said. "But to assume a mantle of superiority from this, I think, is quite dubious. No way either of us is going to surpass California."
New Yorkers, who still smart from Chicago's claim to having the world's tallest building and from California's primacy in population, struggled, with varying success, not to sound like sore losers.
"There's almost no connection between numbers and spirit," said Bobby Zarem, the publicist, who helped conceive the "I Love New York" promotional campaign and who recently began another, more defensive slogan: "New York -- It ain't over."
 
No Less Congestion
 Mr. Cuomo expressed no envy of Texas's gains. "They have a whole lot of people pouring over the border," he said, "so I don't take this to be a sign of economic growth or of added confidence by couples having larger families. What I think is significant," he added, changing the subject, "is how New York is situated to compete in the global economy in the years ahead.
"I wouldn't trade places with Texas -- or California, for that matter," Mr. Cuomo declared.
The shift in ranking does not mean less congestion in New York because the state is shrinking only relatively. Because of a continuing surge of immigrants from abroad, New York had defied earlier projections that it would slip to third by 1990.
Texas is growing faster, though, while New York has been hemmorhaging population to other states, including Texas. There the annual population increase is as much as 400,000, or more than all of Staten Island.
"Demography isn't such an exact art that we can figure it to the day," said Dr. Steven H. Murdock, chief demographer at the Texas State Data Center of Texas A & M University.
Texas grew by 2.1 percent or more than 300,000 from 1992 to 1993, Dr. Murdock said, absorbing more newcomers than any other state. He said the growth reflected a net gain in immigration from other states, a net gain from overseas and a natural increase, or surplus, of births over deaths.
In the years between decennial counts, the Census Bureau resorts to what Mr. Campbell described as a "computerized cohort component projection model" to estimate population. Life expectancy trends are applied by age, sex and race to the most recent population figures for each state. Births come from health records. Migration patterns are extrapolated from the 1990 census and from Internal Revenue Service returns. After projecting the nation's population, demographers refine the figures state by state and recalibrate them periodically.
In 1993, the Census Bureau said, 7 of every 100 Americans lived in New York. That share is projected to shrink to fewer than 6 in 100 by 2020, by which date Florida is expected to pass New York as third in population, in the bureau's 30-year projection. New York is projected to add 3.4 million people from abroad during that period but lose nearly 500,000 to other states.
Texans are expected to constitute nearly 8 in 100 Americans by 2020 as a result of an influx of 2.2 million immigrants from overseas, 333,000 transplanted Americans, and of about 6 million more births than deaths -- owing, in part, to higher fertility rates among the state's growing Hispanic population.
David C. Huckabee, an analyst with the Congressional Research Service, said if population projections pan out, New York's Congressional delegation will shrink to 29 from 31 after the 2000 Census. The Texas delegation will grow to 32, adding two seats, and California's representation will expand to 55 from 52 -- unless, he said, the membership of the House of Representatives is increased, which last happened in 1911.
"New York is not unique," said David R. Lamphere, an associate demographer with the New York State Department of Economic Development. "Even though we've been gaining in population slowly, we still have considerable out-migration. It's the entire Northeast. New York just gets more attention because we're the biggest," Mr. Lamphere said -- in the region, he meant.

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
A Youngster Looks Ahead Amid Troubled Time in Florida

BYLINE: By CHARLIE NOBLES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, May 18

 BODY:
Venus Williams, a promising junior tennis player, will celebrate her 14th birthday on June 17, an occasion that will allow her to become a professional. But the more important date for her father, Richard Williams, is July 6, when Venus will receive her final report card from school.
A straight-A report card, Williams said today, would be rewarded with an opportunity for Venus to play in her first professional tournament, the Virginia Slims championships in Manhattan Beach, Calif., in August. 
 "There is a great possibility that she will go into Manhattan Beach as a professional tennis player," Williams said today.
 
Moved to Florida
 Richard Williams recently moved his family from Compton, Calif., to Florida, lured by the prospect of improving his family's quality of life and securing the best possible chance of preparing his two talented daughters, Venus and Serena, 13, for pro tennis careers.
The move comes at a time when women's tennis is struggling with a shortage of stars, and Florida offers a junior tennis industry in which talented prospects are schooled by professional coaches at a number of academies.
Williams said he would not comment on the recent problems affecting another Florida product, Jennifer Capriati, who dropped off the women's pro tour last August.
But Bobby Curtis, the director of youth tennis for the Florida Tennis Association, returned to work today and voiced concern about the Capriati case. Curtis said he was not surprised that Capriati, now 18, seems to be rebelling. She was detained briefly in December in Tampa for shoplifting. On Monday, in a dingy Coral Gables motel, came another red flag: she was arrested on a charge of possession of marijuana.
 
'Potential Problems'
 "You had a situation where the family was mostly living off the daughter's earnings, when the daughter was a juvenile still," Curtis said. "I think when the teen-ager in the family is the big bread-winner, that sets up all kinds of potential problems."
Curtis recalls Capriati as "a bouncy kid winning all the time and moving rapidly through the ranks."
"All the way up, she was in a division only one year instead of two like everybody else," he said. "Her father kept pushing for her to move up. I guess he was right. She was that good."
At what price, people are wondering now.
The Capriati case follows another incident that hit the Florida tennis scene, the violent death of one of Curtis's former players, Steve Vasquez. Curtis said he was stunned by the Mother's Day killing here of the 23-year-old Vasquez by Vasquez's unemployed and divorced father, Rene.
While Curtis was teaching tennis to Vasquez, Curtis said he could see that the father was stern in dealing with his son, who rose to a No. 5 state ranking in the boys' 18's in 1990.
"He could be pretty tough on Steve, but I never expected anything like this," said Curtis, who lived next door to the Vasquez home. After returning from a junior tournament in Tallahassee, Curtis learned that the father had killed not only his son, but also had killed his own girlfriend and then himself with a gun Curtis said was kept at the house.
"The gun was handy, that's the big thing," said Curtis.
