HEADLINE: Stocks Up Sharply, With Dow Rising 26.09

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Continuing the rally that began when the Federal Reserve raised interest rates Tuesday, the stock market rose sharply yesterday, as bond prices continued their rise.
Blue chips like International Paper and General Motors, widely held companies like AT&T and Coca-Cola, technology stocks like Intel and Microsoft, which were battered for weeks, all benefited from the surge. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 26.09 points, to 3,758.98, and the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 3 basis points, to 7.23 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
The market has recovered enough that the Dow has edged into the plus column, up 0.13 percent for the year, from the 3,754.09 close at the end of last year.
 
A Lag in Key Indexes
 The broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 2.79 points, to 456.48, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 5.41 points, to 727.31. But these indexes still lag for the year, down 2.14 percent for the S.& P. 500 and down 6.37 percent for the Nasdaq.
Dennis Jarrett, a market analyst, said that this week's market activity reflected the general market jubilance over the Fed's increase Tuesday of key interest rates, a pre-emptive move against inflation that was seen as bullish for stocks. But it won't last, he said.
"The market acted nicely" yesterday, Mr, Jarrett said. But he said that some of the activity might be due to the exercising of stock options that expire today in a so-called double witching hour, when options on stock indexes and individual stocks simultaneously expire. Such expiration days often lead to "use-it-or-lose-it" pressure, prompting increases in trading volume.
Nonetheless, what Mr. Jarrett expects for the near-term is "probably a lot more sideways action for the bond market, which translates into similar action in equities."
If stock traders were taking their cue from currency markets, they probably should not, according to David F. DeRosa, a director of foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation.
The dollar was at 104.33 yen, up 0.78 yen, although new trade data showed the Japanese trade surplus with the United States growing. But, at the same time, Administration officials expressed optimism that trade talks with Japan were getting back on track.
But many currency traders are bearish about the value of the dollar. "No one I know -- and I mean no one -- thinks that the Clinton Administration does not have a weak-dollar policy," Mr. DeRosa said.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.43 points, to 252.16, on normal volume of 307.4 million shares. Advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks by 1,318 to 886. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.14 points, to 437.04.
Of the 30 component stocks in the Dow, 18 rose, led by International Paper, which rose 1 7/8, to 68 3/8, on no discernible news.
Of the 500 stocks in the S.& P. 500, 286 stocks rose, led by AT&T, which rose 1 1/2, to 56 3/4. AT&T won a multi-billion dollar contract from Bell Atlantic to offer advanced entertainment and other services to eight million homes. The other major winner, General Instrument, also saw its shares rise by 4 1/4, to 59 1/8.
But the most active stock yesterday, at 9.5 million shares, was the loser in the Bell Atlantic project, DSC Communications of Plano, Tex. DSC Communications shares fell 811/16 , to 491/16 , when analysts raised questions about the company's ability to win similar contracts from other phone companies. The equipment to be provided by AT&T is a linch pin for video-on-demand and other critical services for the so-called information superhighway. Other regional Bells may follow Bell Atlantic's lead.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
AT&T won its third big contract to build a video and data network for a regional telephone company, making it a principal architect of the national information infrastructure. [Page D1.]

HEADLINE: Commencements;
New President of Columbia Asks Graduates to Lead

 BODY:
In his first commencement address at Columbia's helm yesterday, President George E. Rupp told graduates that he hoped they would strive to become leaders.
"You will challenge us and lead us not only in your various disciplines and professions, but also in our common life as we engage the tasks that generations preceding you have left undone," said Dr. Rupp, who was named president last fall. 
 But borrowing a metaphor from the storminess of the day, Dr. Rupp also spoke of difficulties clouding the futures of this year's graduates.
"For some of you the place where you will work is not yet certain," he said. "We are confident that you will find what you are seeking, but you more than most of us are acutely aware that, even before the cheering stops on occasions like this one, celebration is tinged with anxiety.
"The arena of further work and study that you are entering," he continued, "is not the land of limitless opportunity that college and university graduates once at least thought they were entering."
In the full commencement ceremony marking the end of Columbia's 240th year, 8,215 graduate and undergraduate degrees were conferred.
 
A Call to Sacrifice
 The tone of sacrifice was taken also by the United States Surgeon General, Dr. Joycelyn Elders, during an address at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. She challenged the 136 graduating medical students to follow the example of the legal profession in providing services to the poor.
Dr. Elders said medical attention was a basic right, no less than legal aid, in a comment that drew applause from the 48 men and 88 women who had taken the Hippocratic Oath hours before.
"The only group of citizens in America that has a constitutional right to health care is our prisoners," she said. "We've got to make sure that we change that."
The medical school commencement was held in a soaking rain under tents in the chapel garden of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Washington Heights. It followed the large ceremony for all of Columbia's schools on the steps of the library on the Morningside Heights campus.
Seven honorary degrees were conferred in ceremonies at Columbia, including those given to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the United States Supreme Court and Betty Friedan, the feminist author.

Rutgers Honors Whitman
 NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 19 (AP) -- Rutgers conferred nearly 10,000 degrees at its 228th commencement today, including an honorary degree for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.
The university awarded 7,064 bachelor's degrees and 2,928 graduate degrees at ceremonies in the Louis Brown Athletic Center on the school's Livingston College campus.
While the university held the campuswide ceremony at the athletic center, actual diplomas were handed out at separate convocations held by each college.
Speakers at those ceremonies included Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, who told the 2,058 graduates of Rutgers College that they were making a transformation to life after college at the same time the United States made a transformation to deal with a new world.
Other speakers included the ABC News correspondent Morton Dean, who spoke to the 843 graduates of Livingston College, and the jazz pianist Billy Taylor, who addressed the 65 graduating seniors and 59 master's degree candidates of the Mason Gross School of the Arts.
The Rutgers president, Francis Lawrence, also presented an honorary doctor of science degree to Robert M. Solow, winner of the Nobel Prize in economics in 1987. Honorary doctor of humane letters degrees were conferred upon Charlayne Hunter-Gault, national correspondent for the MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour; Mort Pye, editor of The Star-Ledger of Newark, and Alvin J. Rockoff, chairman of Rutgers' Board of Governors.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Fall

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for state unemployment benefits tumbled for the first time in two weeks, the Labor Department said today. New jobless claims dipped by 14,000, to 367,000, in the week that ended May 14 from a revised 381,000 in the previous week. But the four-week moving average rose to 359,000 in the week of May 14, from a revised 358,750 a week earlier.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chrysler to Raise Dividend and Finance Pensions

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 19

 BODY:
Flush with record earnings and anticipating further growth in the North American auto market, the Chrysler Corporation announced today that it would raise its quarterly dividend by a nickel a share, to 25 cents, and that it would fully finance its pensions by the end of the year.
If Chrysler makes good on its vow to set aside the money required to meet its obligations for current and future retirees, it will be the first time in its history that the No. 3 auto maker has fully financed its pension plan. 
 Today's announcement on the dividend gives Chrysler shareholders their second dividend increase in six months. In December, Chrysler raised the dividend to its current level from 15 cents, where it had been since Chrysler halved it during the grim days of 1991.
In a statement during the company's annual shareholders meeting today in Toledo, Ohio, Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, said the company had not planned to act so quickly on the dividend or pensions. "But because of our strong cash flow and what looks like a continued strong auto market and general economy, we believe these actions are warranted," he said.
 Moody's Investor's Service, which monitors the long-term health of companies, responded to Chrysler's pension announcement by raising its rating of the company's senior debt and preferred stock. Moody's cited Chrysler's "conservative financial policy" and improving product mix as reasons for improving the rating. Moody's raised its rating on $17.5 billion of Chrysler senior debt two notches, to A3 from Baa2.
Investors were also pleased with the announcements, bidding up Chrysler stock on the New York Stock Exchange to a close of $47.125, up 62.5 cents a share, in active trading.
During its lean years, Chrysler fell behind on payments to its pension fund, until by the end of 1991 it owed $4.4 billion, the widest gap in the company's history. By the end of last year, it owed $2.2 billion.
To finance pensions fully this year, Chrysler plans to contribute $1.8 billion, on top of $700 million set aside in the first quarter. Previously, the company planned to contribute $600 million more in 1994, and to finance pensions fully by the end of 1995.
Chrysler's strong sales this year, which generated record earnings of $938 million on record revenues of $13.2 billion in the first quarter, appear to have given the company the confidence to make the additional investment. Mr. Eaton said Chrysler had $5.9 billion in cash after the first three months of the year, up from $4.5 billion at the end of 1993. He has set a goal of $7.5 billion in cash to protect Chrysler during the next downturn in the auto market, which many analysts predict will come after 1996.
"Chrysler has never been in such a strong financial position as it is today," Mr. Eaton said.
In its lean years, Chrysler fell behind in setting aside money for its pension plans. While the Ford Motor Company's pensions are fully financed, the General Motors Corporation estimated that it owed $22.3 billion at the end of 1993. Since then, G.M. has set aside $1.9 billion, and it is awaiting Federal approval to contribute $10 billion in cash and stock by October 1995.
The dividend announced today will be payable on July 15, to shareholders of record as of June 15, Chrysler said. Last month, Ford bolstered its quarterly dividend 12.5 percent, to 45 cents a share. G.M. pays 20 cents a common share, down from 40 cents in the third quarter of 1992.

HEADLINE: Bank Takes Giuliani Incentives To Keep Workers in New York

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that Republic National Bank of New York, the banking subsidiary of the nation's 20th-largest bank holding company, had accepted $6.4 million in incentives to remain in New York City and was canceling plans to move 900 workers to New Jersey.
Under the agreement, the Giuliani administration will help the bank by issuing bonds to finance construction of a $55 million, 232,000-square-foot addition to its midtown Manhattan headquarters at Fifth Avenue at West 40th Street and to finance a $23 million renovation of its data center at 1 West 39th Street. 
 City officials said they would also waive the sales tax on $6.4 million in machinery and equipment that the company will buy in connection with its expansion.
At a news conference at City Hall, Walter H. Weiner, Republic's chairman and chief executive, said that the package meant the bank would keep 900 data center workers in New York City and that the expansion would enable the bank to hire another 200 workers.
The agreement represented the first incentive package negotiated with a major corporation in the five months since Mr. Giuliani took office. During the mayoral campaign, Mr. Giuliani often criticized Mayor David N. Dinkins for losing too many battles to keep companies in the city.
The package offered fewer incentives than some of the deals reached in recent years, including the $32 million in incentives accepted in October by Kidder, Peabody & Company, the Wall Street firm, to move its headquarters from Lower Manhattan to Rockefeller Center. Under another deal two years ago, Morgan Stanley & Company, which had threatened to move to New Jersey or Connecticut, accepted an incentive package worth $39.6 million to remain in New York.
Mr. Weiner declined to comment on where in New Jersey the company had considered relocating. But he said the company had finally decided to remain in New York City because of "the efficiency of keeping our operation in one place."
The decision to remain in New York City was based in part "on the continuing improvement in atmosphere," he said, particularly since Mr. Giuliani's election.
"It's an atmosphere that makes businesses more comfortable," he said. "We feel more comfortable here."
The bonds, issued by the city Industrial Development Agency, will allow Republic to pay lower interest payments over the 15-year period of the agreement because it will exempt the company from paying taxes on interest to the city and the state.
"We provide the vehicle to get lower interest rates, but it doesn't cost the city any money do it outside of the administrative costs," said John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development. "And we actually ask people like Republic to help subsidize that. So in the end it really doesn't cost the city anything. But they get a very significant savings in the cost of interest."

HEADLINE: Coca-Cola Reaches Into Impoverished Albania

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TIRANA, Albania, May 19

 BODY:
Dirt-poor Albania has hardly an economy to speak of, but as of today it has Coke.
The average wage is less than $30 a month. Its main export is its unemployed, with an estimated 300,000 Albanians working abroad, mostly in Greece and Italy, and sending money home. 
 But today, in a lush field outside the capital, President Sali Berisha joined Coca-Cola executives from the United States and Italy to cut a red and white ribbon that opened a $10 million Coca-Cola bottling plant, the first major foreign investment in the country and another step in Coca-Cola's march into formerly Communist, now liberated, Eastern Europe.
"It might not be what they need the most," said Hans Christian Jacobsen, a food industry expert with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, who attended the opening today, "but it has symbolic value to create awareness that Albania is still here."
 
Coca-Cola's Shrinking Globe
 Albania becomes the 197th country where Coca-Cola is made, leaving only a handful of blank spots on the Coca-Cola globe, most notably Libya, Iraq, Cuba and North Korea, where the soft drink remains banned.
But for some of Albania's struggling 3.3 million people, the reinforced-concrete factory gleaming under sunny skies resembled a Martian spacecraft landed amid the country's pervasive poverty and shimmered like light at the end of the tunnel.
"This is a country where only three years ago foreign investment was forbidden by law, and foreign investors were considered agents of treason," Dr. Berisha, a cardiologist, said before the ribbon ceremony.
"It's a real symbol of the deep changes that have taken place in Albania in the last two years."
Dr. Berisha later pressed a button, and bottling machines shook and hissed while young Albanians clad in red T-shirts emblazoned with the Coca-Cola logo scurried about loading bottles or shouted orders at each other.
The factory is a joint venture involving the development bank, Coca-Cola, an Albanian company called Invest P.F. that is affiliated with the Ministry for Foodstuffs and Italy's Busi Group, the largest franchised bottler of Coca-Cola in Italy. The factory will have the capacity to turn out 24,000 bottles of Coke an hour and will provide jobs directly for about 100 Albanians and indirectly for another 400 to 500, like truck drivers or distributors.
"It's a completely different experience, in every sense," said Lalo Idlir, a 33-year old mechanical engineer who joined Coca-Cola three months ago. "The organization, the discipline, the manner of working, the technology -- it's a totally new experience."
Mr. Idlir guessed that Albanians, who traditionally drink beer or wine with their meals and consume enormous quantities of clear white raki, a potent grape brandy, would snap up Coke.
Fatbardh Ganai, a 40-year-old engineer who worked for 12 years at the Government's Institute for Food Research before joining the factory, said the jobs there were prized. "We get about twice what you'd make outside," he said, casting nervous glances at the rattling line of six-ounce refillable bottles.
At current wage levels outside the Coca-Cola plant, an Albanian would have to work about an hour and a half to buy a bottle, which costs 25 lek, or about 25 cents.
Mr. Ganai tasted cheap imitations of Coca-Cola brought in from Greece about three years ago, "but there's no comparison with the real thing," he said.
 
A Media Event
 Coca-Cola celebrated the plant opening with a media event, chartering an Alitalia jetliner to haul 38 reporters and eight television crews into Tirana's scruffy airport.
Coca-Cola officials stressed their commitment to rebuilding Albania, which United Nations officials have classified a "least developed nation," the only one in Europe.
E. Neville Isdell, senior vice president of the Coca-Cola Export Corporation, said Coke was "doing more than opening a bottle plant."
"This is the crucial first step in building a strong, thriving, world-class business system," he said.
The Stalinist totalitarian regime that ruled Albania since 1944 fell apart several years ago with the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe. Albania was in chaos until the elections of March 1992, which the Democratic Party of Dr. Berisha won in a landslide.
His Government has been committed to shock therapy, and today Dr. Berisha boasted of its achievements to reporters. Inflation, he said, fell to 30 percent last year from 400 percent two years ago, and is projected to drop below 20 percent this year.
Albanians bought 50,000 new cars last year, he said, and installed 30,000 satellite dishes, a revolution in a country whose old Communist leadership allowed Albanians virtually no access to outside information.
In downtown Tirana, traffic is bustling and boutiques and snack bars are sprouting. Everywhere, big gray satellite dishes have been affixed to crumbling apartment blocks.
Foreign officials like Mr. Jacobsen agreed that projects like the Coca-Cola plant served a useful function, galvanizing local efforts to transform the economy.
According to the Government, foreign investors have committed $290 million to Albania, more than 50 percent of it from Italy, and the figure is expected to double this year. But little of the investment money has flowed in yet.
Muhtar A. Kent, the 41-year-old president of Coca-Cola East Central Europe, said the company expected a positive cash flow in Albania "very soon," perhaps within 18 months. The capital, he said, would be plowed back into more trucks, equipment and retailing capability.
Mr. Isdell said Coca-Cola's success in Eastern Europe was based on pent-up desire for the symbols of the West.
"We're all about refreshing people around the world," he said. "That's what we do."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Sali Berisha of Albania, center, toasting the opening of Coca-Cola's plant in Tirana with E. Neville Isdell, right, a senior vice president for Coca-Cola, and Franko Busi, president of the Busi Group in Italy. (Reuters)
 
Map/Diagram: "Coca-Cola's Eastern Bloc"
 Since the fall of the Berlin wall, the Coca-Cola Company has opened or renovated 27 production plants in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. (pg. D3)

HEADLINE: Clarkstown Court Loss May Bring Trash War

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CLARKSTOWN, N.Y., May 19

 BODY:
Charles Holbrook says garbage has been the hallmark of his tenure as supervisor of this Rockland County town.
In nine years, he has presided over the state's forced closure of Clarktown's dump, an anxious moment when it seemed no one would take the town's garbage, the establishment of a lucrative recycling program and the curious turn of events when garbage haulers and the town began competing for trash. 
 Now, national attention has been drawn to the trash of Clarkstown, a town located at the western end of the Tappan Zee Bridge.
On Monday, the United States Supreme Court struck down Clarkstown's "flow control" law, which required that all garbage collected here be taken to the town's transfer station, rather than landfills elsewhere that might charge lower rates. The law, like others throughout the country, was intended to insure an adequate volume of garbage to make the transfer station economically viable.
 
From Trash, a Fight
 "From that residue," Mr. Holbrook said, pointing to a heap on the transfer station's floor, "we went to a nationwide fight on garbage. Who would have ever thought we'd fight about this."
Mr. Holbrook's struggles mirror battles throughout the region, and the Supreme Court ruling has left many towns wondering how much the new free-market garbage economy might cost them. So far, no one is willing to speculate on how the decision will affect the average homeowner.
But in states like Connecticut, which has floated $1 billion in bonds since the late 1980's to create five waste-to-energy plants, six landfills, 18 transfer stations and three recycling centers, the cost of competing for garbage might be considerable.
"Connecticut is probably affected more than any state in the union," said William R. Darcy, president of the state's Resources Recovery Authority, who estimated that 86 percent of Connecticut's garbage now goes to its waste-to-energy plants. "Residential pickup is usually done by the towns anyway, so that should stay the same. But the commercial and industrial sector now has the opportunity to go to out of state landfills."
 
A Bidding War for Trash?
 About half of Connecticut's three million tons of garbage a year is commercial waste which could, under the Supreme Court ruling, be trucked out of state by haulers who can beat the local price. The Hartford waste-to-energy plant now charges $51 a ton, but the one near Danbury charges $78 a ton.
In New Jersey, officials say the ruling will have no impact, saying that their "flow control" laws are so different from Clarkstown's as to be unaffected. That position is viewed skeptically by both Mr. Holbrook and Mr. Darcy. However, New Jersey has informed the state's garbage haulers that, until the courts say differently, the New Jersey law is valid and will be enforced.
Nationwide, 27 states have "flow control" laws allowing municipalities to require that all garbage be taken to a government-owned center for processing. Clarkstown's law was challenged by the C. & A. Carbone carting company of Nyack.
Under pressure from the state to close its town dump, Clarkstown, in 1990, contracted with a private company, Clarkstown Recycling, to build a transfer station. At the station, all of Clarkstown's non-recyclable trash was sorted and baled and reloaded onto trucks and shipped to a landfill or incinerator at a cost of $81 a ton. The town has a contract that guarantees Clarkstown Recycling 120,000 tons a year of garbage. If less than that is delivered, the town is required to make up the difference.
 
Court Leaves an Opening
 C. & A. Carbone sued the town, saying that it could dump commercial garbage at a lower rate out of state.
The Supreme Court struck down the Clarkstown law by a 6-3 vote, citing its interference in interstate commerce, but it left open the door for Congress to enact a Federal law allowing flow control.
Mr. Holbrook thinks the decision will have little impact here.
Unlike communities that have huge debts to repay on expensive projects like incinerators, Clarkstown's transfer station, a relatively simple corrugated steel structure, will be paid off by the end of 1995, when the town's contract with Clarkstown Recycling will elapse.
 
Concern and Consternation
 But elsewhere, there is consternation.
"The Federal Government encouraged this," Mr. Darcy, of Connecticut, said. "All of these facilities were built in the belief that these laws were legal." He said Congress must now act "so that their increasingly strict mandates, on recycling and solid waste, are implemented."
Some environmentalists are also concerned about the impact of the ruling.
"It's going to make the financing of projects, particularly recycling projects, more costly," said Allen Hershkowitz, a scientist with the National Resources Defense Council.
But for all the jitters among government officials, garbage haulers have hailed the Supreme Court decision as a victory for consumers.
"The moment you have a monopoly, you lose efficiency," said Kenneth H. Resnik, the lawyer for C. & A. Carbone. "Now that you have no monopoly, prices will go down. Flow-control laws led to a kind of toll-booth operation that only drove prices up."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The United States Supreme Court ruling on Monday striking down a "flow control" law enacted by Clarkstown, N.Y., has left many towns in the region wondering how much the new free-market garbage economy might cost them. Trash was processed early this week at the Clarkstown transfer station. (Lenore Davis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Trade Gap With Japan Widens as Talks Start

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
As new data today showed America's trade deficit with Japan soaring, American and Japanese officials held talks to see whether they could revive their moribund negotiations for gaining more access to closed Japanese markets.
The talks extended late into the evening and were not expected to conclude until Friday morning. Late today, however, an official involved in the talks said that the Japanese side had come with "detailed, serious proposals" that the American side felt were worth exploring. 
 But officials cautioned that it was still too soon to say whether the Japanese overture would provide enough of an incentive for the Clinton Administration to resume full-scale trade negotiations with Japan. The American side does not want to restart the talks only to have them fail again, or to provide political help to a weak Japanese Government without producing any breakthrough.
 
25% Jump in Deficit
 As the negotiators sat down at the table, the Commerce Department reported a 25 percent jump in the American trade deficit with Japan in March. The deficit ballooned to $5.8 billion in March from $4.63 billion in February, making it the third-biggest monthly trade deficit with Japan on record. There was also good news in the figures: The nation's trade deficit with all nations shrank as American exports grew.
Deputy Trade Minister Sozaburo Okamatsu and Deputy Foreign Minister Sadayuki Hayashi of Japan spent the day closeted with the White House trade experts W. Bowman Cutter and Charlene Barshefsky, trying to hammer out language that would entice both sides to resume the negotiations that were broken off Feb. 11.
Before the negotiations started, a senior American trade official said that the "magic words" the White House wanted to hear from the Japanese side were that Japan would accept an overall goal of "increased access and sales" for foreign companies to five relatively closed sectors. Those are autos, auto parts, telecommunications, medical equipment and insurance.
Since the negotiations began last July, the Japanese have resisted committing to that specific goal, or to the numerical indicators that the American side has demanded as proof that Japan really is meeting that goal. The Japanese came to Washington with new language meant to address American concerns on both of these points, American officials said.
 
Differences in Economies
 One big reason for the rising deficit with Japan is that the American economy has been very strong -- pulling in imports from all over the world -- while the Japanese economy is just climbing out of recession and the leadership there has been reluctant to cut taxes and engage in measures that could stimulate consumer demand.
Hidden in these overall trade numbers, though, was some good news. While it is true that American imports from Japan grew 10.5 percent in March, American exports to Japan grew by 7.5 percent. That is well above the world average for American export growth, which is about 5 percent this year. In other words, Japan is buying more from the United States, but the problem is that the surging American economy is buying even more from Japan.
The American trade deficit for goods and services with all nations shrank to $7.5 billion in March from $9.2 billion in February. American exports registered increases in virtually every category of manufactured products, capital goods, aircraft, consumer goods, agricultural products and services.
 
Japan Asked for Meeting
 It was the Japanese who asked for today's meeting with Clinton officials to see if there was some basis for restarting the negotiations aimed at opening Japanese markets. The United States broke off the negotiations when Japan refused to accept that the goal of the talks should be increased access and sales by foreigners to designated markets, with numerical indicators that would prove whether Japan was really living up to that commitment.
American officials were wary about re-engaging with the Japanese. They believe that the fragile new Government in Tokyo, led by Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata, is eager to show some progress in dealing with the Americans to demonstrate to the Japanese electorate and Parliament that it is taken seriously abroad and can manage the relationship with the United States. In addition, Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko of Japan are scheduled to visit Washington on June 10 and the Japanese are anxious not to have trade tensions sour their stay in the United States.
But the questions American officials have been asking themselves are: Do the Japanese want a deal or do they want a conversation? Do they want progress or do they want a photo opportunity that will make it appear that tensions are being resolved without any substantive movement?

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Bonds Rise, Tracking Dollar's Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Yields of Treasury securities declined modestly yesterday, despite rising commodity prices that threatened to reignite inflation worries among some investors only days after the Fed moved to calm those fears.
In a seesaw session, the bond market managed to erase morning losses after the release of new trade data, rebounding in sync with the dollar amid reports that the Fed was buying intermediate Treasury securities for the accounts of foreign central banks. 
 Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading strategist at CS First Boston, said: "In general, you couldn't point to anything specific behind the market's move, but when the dollar recouped so did the market. Rumors of the Fed being in the market buying securities for customer accounts gave bond prices an added boost."
 
 
'A Level Field'
 It is not unusual for the Fed to make purchases in the market for customer accounts. Foreign central banks often have the Fed do such buying for them after they have intervened in the currency market and ended up with a lot of dollars, as happened after recent moves by the United States and its allies to support the sagging dollar.
Analysts note that the market has been trading well since Tuesday's half-point increase in short-term interest rates. The reason, they say, is that the move removed all uncertainty about the Fed's intentions. "Everyone is now playing on a level field," Mr. Alexy said. "The cash that has accumulated over several months is now being put to work."
The market largely overlooked the nearly two-point rise in the Commodity Research Bureau index of commodities, because soaring coffee and soybean prices have been the primary driving force. But analysts say the strong rise in the index could be a red warning flag for bonds, since the index is regarded as a harbinger of future price pressures.
 
Lower Trade Deficit
 Yields initially rose after a Government report showed that imports and exports jumped in March, a confirmation that the economy was still doing well. The Commerce Department said the trade deficit in goods and services fell to $7.5 billion, compared with a revised gap of $9.2 billion in February, orignally reported as $9.7 billion. Economists had expected an $8.4 billion gap in March.
 Exports rose to $58.33 billion from $53.24 billion, and imports rose to $65.79 billion from $62.39 billion.
Both exports and imports sharply outpaced market estimates. It was the surge in exports that narrowed the trade gap more than expected. The data also showed that while the overall gap had narrowed, the nation's trade deficit with Japan widened sharply, by 25 percent.
By the close of the New York cash market, the 30-year bond was up 16/32 , to 886/32 , for a yield of 7.23 percent, down from 7.27 percent on Wednesday. Outstanding two-year notes, which were thought to be among the maturities being bought by the Fed, saw yields drop 6 basis points, to 5.71 percent, while a 10-year maturity dropped 7 basis points, to 6.94 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 In when-issued trading ahead of next week's auctions, the new two-year issue was yielding 5.77 percent, an improvement from the 5.84 percent on Wednesday. The five-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.53 percent, down from 6.61 percent.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that unemployment claims fell 14,000 last week to 367,000. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News had predicted that claims would drop by 24,000.
Also released was the Philadelphia Fed index, which rose to 14.8 in May from 11.6 in April, in line with many expectations. The report of regional business activity showed the prices-paid index retreating slightly to 27.4, after surging to 33.1 in the previous month, and the prices received index rising to 12.1 from 6.4. Employment fell to 2.0 from 11.1. Analysts said the prices paid and employment subindexes were slightly positive for bonds. "However, most of the data just canceled each other," Mr. Alexy said.

HEADLINE: 2 Exchanges Set Uncovered Short Sales Records

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Continued volatility in financial markets encouraged those betting that stock prices will fall, as short-selling activity climbed again in the month ended May 6, the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange reported yesterday.
The Big Board reported that the number of shares borrowed and sold short, but not yet covered by repurchasing the shares, rose 6 percent, to a record 1.48 billion shares, surpassing the previous record 1.39 billion shares set the previous month.
Meanwhile, the Amex reported that short interest rose 1 percent, to a record 113.76 million shares, from 112.55 million in the period ended in mid-April. 
 The increases came as the stock market remained vulnerable to rising interest rates. The figures cover trades settled May 13, which means those transacted a week earlier.
 
A Steady March Higher
 Short interest has been rising for well over a year, but proved a largely unprofitable strategy as long as leading market indexes were marching to record highs. While there are several reasons someone might sell a stock short, the most common is the expectation that the stock's price will fall.
Over the last few months, those expectations have begun to be realized, in large part as a result of sharply rising interest rates.
"Through the end of April, the shorts were up an average of 7.1 percent," said Harry Strunk, a Palm Beach, Fla. investment consultant who tracks the performance of short- sellers. "That is the best four-month period they have had since 1990."
Shorting a stock is the flip side of buying a security in the hope it will go up; a short-seller borrows shares, sells them and later buys them back to return to the original owner. If the share price has dropped in the meantime, the short-seller makes a profit.
Traditionally, a high short-interest level indicates that many investors are bearish on the markets. But some analysts say that big short-interest positions are a positive sign, because the short-sellers will eventually have to buy shares.
 
Motorola Short Sales Jump
 High-technology companies have been a favorite of short-sellers. Last month, Motorola Inc. showed the biggest increase in short positions. Short interest in Motorola shares nearly doubled from the previous month, to 12.28 million shares.
For the second straight month, the largest short-interest position was in RJR Nabisco. The company is trying to put a new financing plan in place. Short interest in the stock rose to 40.69 million shares, from 36.63 million the previous month.

Short Sales Tables Explained
 These tables show issues with a short interest position in the current month of at least 500,000 shares or a change up or down from the previous month of at least 99,994 shares.
 Cover ratio represents the number of days, at average volume level, that it would take to purchase the number of shares sold short.
 A -- American Stock Exchange.
 N -- New York Stock Exchange.
 N.L. -- Not listed.
 + -- Stock split.
 * (American Stock Exchange only.) May have been affected by arbitrage transactions resulting from any one or more of the following: proposed or pending acquisitions; convertible securities of the same company; rights offerings; stock splits or distributions; tenders; other special situations.
 Short interest may also be affected by options positions.
 # Indicates a change of 75 percent or more from the previous month.

PUB-DATE: May 20, 1994,

SECTION: Section D; Page 13; Column 1; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 457 words

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Tops $18 a Barrel; Coffee Reaches 5-Year High

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices rose above $18 a barrel yesterday amid perceptions that falling stockpiles in the Midwest would mean a shortage of crude available for delivery against the New York Mercantile Exchange's June contract.
Coffee rose to a five-year high as rain caused floods on the Indonesian island of Java, and cotton rose as much as is permitted in a day amid speculation that China or Pakistan would buy more United States cotton. 
 The increases helped to push the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities up 1.45, to 232.43, the highest level since October 1990. The index is a closely watched gauge of inflation.
Today is the last trading day for West Texas intermediate crude oil to be delivered in June. Stockpiles in the Midwest, which includes Cushing, Okla., where crude is delivered, fell last week and are 10.8 percent below a year ago.
Midwest stockpiles "are down significantly from a year earlier," said Elaine Levin, a trader with Smith Barney Shearson. "With the contract expiring tomorrow," she said, traders are eager to secure supplies.
Crude oil for June delivery rose 46 cents a barrel, to $18.45 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, while unleaded gasoline rose 0.76 cent a gallon, to 52.08 cents, and heating oil rose 0.16 cent, to 47.86 cents. Natural gas gained 1.4 cents, to $1.957 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Strong demand from refiners who need to make gasoline for the summer driving season is lowering the stockpiles, Ms. Levin said.
"These runs have just been chugging along," she said. Refineries were running above 95 percent of capacity last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Coffee soared to a five-year high, as concerns grew about falling supplies from Indonesia, Brazil and Colombia, the three largest producers.
Coffee for July delivery gained 7.60 cents a pound, to $1.3255, extending a rally this month on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York that has sent coffee prices up 49 percent.
Brazil's crop is expected to fall 18 percent from last year, according to United States Department of Agriculture estimates, and Colombia's crop will also be reduced by worm infestation. Heavy rains on the island of Java, Indonesia's largest coffee-producing region, are hampering the harvest there and could damage coffee trees.
Cotton prices rose their daily limit, settling just below a three-year high, on speculation that China would buy more American cotton. July cotton rose 2 cents, to 82.65 cents a pound.
Traders speculated that a report on export sales from the Agriculture Department would show either China or Pakistan buying more American cotton. The report, which was issued after trading ended, did not any show sales to China or Pakistan.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
License for Torture

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Finally and with startling clarity, the Chinese Communist dictatorship is sending its core message to the United States: Nationwide repression by arrest of dissenters will not only continue but widen.
By June 3, President Clinton will decide whether to live up to his executive order to remove China's low-tariff privileges unless it makes significant progress toward giving the Chinese and Tibetan people some relief from such instruments of government as political arrests, forced labor and torture boards. 
 No longer is there any possible doubt that the Communists have failed to do that -- and will not unless economic pressure is applied. The Communist regime is working with some American officials and businessmen to dredge up a few fringe human rights crumbs that Mr. Clinton can call "progress" if he decides to betray his word and the cause of human rights.
But Beijing is increasingly terrified of human rights. It is increasingly unsure of its hold on the Chinese people. It is increasingly fearful of them. Now it tells diplomats and American business executives that the right to dissent without being arrested would bring instability.
To dictatorships, "instability" is a synonym for weakening their police-terror control in any way.
So even as it makes a public-relations release of a prisoner or two, Beijing carries out more political arrests. And at least 500 political prisoners, previously unknown to the West, have been added to the list of thousands of others, by Human Rights Watch/Asia. In China, of course, arrest means electric shock, iron rods, floggings and deprivation of food, visits and shower water.
In its renewed insistence on smashing dissidence and dissidents, Beijing demolishes the arguments of the U.S. China-trade lobby and its servants in Congress, the Treasury, the National Economic Council and the Commerce Department. These fellows campaign openly against the President's own human rights policy. He does not shut them up.
For years now the China lobby has been peddling the line that economic growth in China would bring political liberty. That propaganda is a perversion of history, an insult to all who died under Hitler and Japan's dictatorship during their economic surge.
The lobby preaches also that removing low-tariff privileges will somehow hurt the U.S. more than China. But as the deadline approaches, Beijing itself drops that economic bluster and admits its fear of losing those privileges. Thanks to the low tariffs and to slave-wage labor costs, China has built a $30 billion annual trade advantage over Uncle Sucker.
Billions of that export profit come from products made in the factories and prisons of the Chinese Army -- rifles and assault weapons by the boatload, plus furniture, toys, tools, machinery. Other forced-labor prisons export pumps, carpets, clothes, machinery -- dozens of products undercutting American labor.
China lobby propaganda about Great China slamming its market shut on America is ludicrous. That market sells us four times as much as it buys and would keep exporting even with higher tariffs.
The lobby's little secret is that the Chinese Communists have shown themselves susceptible to economic pressure -- so important to them is their huge rake-in from the U.S. and American investment.
Revocation of low tariffs stands much greater chance of freeing prisoners chained to torture boards than have the fruitless years of American appeasement.
Some members of Congress have surrendered to the lobby, become defectors from the human rights cause they once backed. But a strong group of human rights supporters remains -- people like Representatives David E. Bonior of Michigan, Richard Gephardt of Missouri, Tom Lantos of California, Frank Wolf of New Jersey and, of course, San Francisco's gift to America and the people in the prison cells, Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat and supporter of Mr. Clinton.
"I still believe in Hope," she says.
If Mr. Clinton does walk out on his executive order or weasels it down to a mockery, he will be giving the Chinese Communists the special license they now ask for:
A license for more repression, more arrests, more torture cells, all handsomely subsidized by the United States of America.

HEADLINE: Clinton Spells Out Reasons He Might Use Force in Haiti

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
President Clinton today offered the clearest explanation yet of why his Administration is considering the use of military force in Haiti while resisting it elsewhere in the world.
"It's in our backyard," the President said at a White House news conference as he ticked off the first in a list of six reasons why he is weighing military action to oust Haiti's leaders if economic sanctions do not force them to step down. 
 He said Haiti's proximity to the United States and the danger that more of its citizens could seek refuge in southern Florida meant that his Administration had an obligation to promote an end to the military dictatorship there.
Mr. Clinton's comments, in response to a question at a joint appearance with India's Prime Minister, also represented a response to Republican critics who say it would be wrong to risk American lives to restore the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
With a tighter United Nations embargo on Haiti to take effect at midnight on Saturday, aides to Mr. Clinton emphasized that no American military action there was imminent. After facing criticism on past occasions in which the Administration has appeared to back away from tough talk on Bosnia, the aides said no decision on whether to use military force in Haiti would be made until the sanctions have been given time to work.
But with opinion polls showing mounting public dissatisfaction with his conduct of foreign policy, the aides say that Mr. Clinton has grown concerned that he has failed to cast the challenges he faces in proper context and that, in particular, he has not adequately explained why his Administration is suddenly devoting so much attention to Haiti after 32 months of military tyranny there.
A senior White House official, who said Mr. Clinton had planned his answer, described it as part of an effort to build public support for military action in Haiti that would allow him to act even if other countries remained opposed to such a mission.
Among the six reasons Mr. Clinton mentioned today as adding up to a "significant" American interest in restoring democracy to Haiti were its proximity and the fact that Haiti had been used as a staging area for drug shipments bound for the United States. In addition, he said Haiti was now the only country in the Western Hemisphere where military leaders have seized power from an elected leader, making it and Cuba the hemisphere's only remaining non-democracies.
 
'Massive Outflow' Feared
 He also mentioned the several thousand Americans who live in Haiti and the one million Haitian-Americans who live in the United States as reasons Americans should be intent on restoring democracy there.
But Mr. Clinton saved his strongest warning for what he described as "the continuous possibility" that Haitians left poor and desperate under military rule would join in a "massive outflow" and seek refuge in the United States.
Mr. Clinton spoke after a meeting with Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao of India on a day in which he devoted unusual attention to security issues. He had back-to-back meetings with his top foreign policy advisers and with American military commanders from around the globe.
His meeting with Mr. Rao was the first between an American President and an Indian Prime Minister in seven years, a lag emblematic of the uneasiness between the two countries after successive Administrations have spoken disapprovingly of India's human rights record and its development of nuclear weapons.
 
Protest March Over Kashmir
 Outside the White House today, hundreds marched in opposition to India's policies in Kashmir and other northern regions, and Mr. Clinton acknowledged that the United States and India still had differences over human rights and the spread of nuclear weapons.
But the President praised India for having overcome internal strife and remaining the world's second largest democracy, and he said of the disagreements that "in the context of our common interests and our common values, we believe they can be managed in a constructive way."
The yearlong American standoff with North Korea over nuclear weapons still has the potential to become the Administration's biggest foreign policy crisis. But Mr. Clinton and his aides have made clear in recent weeks that they are looking with more impatience at the intransigence of Haiti's military leaders, who seized power in September 1991 from Father Aristide, the democratically elected President, and have refused since last fall to honor an agreement in which they pledged to step down.
The strict United Nations sanctions that are to be imposed on Saturday represent a new effort by the United States and other powers to force Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras and his fellow commanders from power. But the President has been forthright in saying he would consider using military force to oust them if the sanctions fail, and Administration officials say the misery the embargo may inflict means that the White House could reach that point of decision as soon as this time next month.
 
'Time for Them to Go'
 Mr. Clinton said recently of the military commanders that "it's time for them to go," and aides have described him in recent weeks as increasingly determined to see democracy restored.
The President's new special adviser on Haiti, William Gray, held a well-publicized meeting here today with Father Aristide in a sign of the White House's commitment to stepping up its efforts on his behalf.
Asked today why he appeared to be putting Haiti in a different category from Bosnia and Rwanda, where he has ruled out putting United States forces in ground combat roles, Mr. Clinton said he was not prepared "to discuss hypothetical uses of force." But he went on to make clear that he believed that the American interests in Haiti set that country apart from more distant trouble spots.
His remarks seemed intended in part as an answer to critics like Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, who this week said an American invasion of Haiti "would be the wrong act at the wrong time for the wrong reason." Senator Dole and other Republicans have called on Mr. Clinton to seek a compromise with Haiti's military leaders that would restore democracy without providing for Father Aristide's return, but that is a step the White House has been unwilling to take.

HEADLINE: Severance Begins to Take Its Toll;
As New York City Workers Depart, Agencies Juggle Needs

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
With thousands of city workers leaving their jobs today, signs have been posted on the doors of the Parking Violations Bureau's Manhattan center warning motorists fighting parking tickets that next week the office will cut its hours, opening later and shutting earlier.
The City Health Department is bracing to lose 3 of its 10 pharmacists who man the Poison Control bureau 24 hours a day, dispensing such information as what to do if a child has just swallowed bleach. At the Parks Department, one of three specialists who restore and maintain the city's 700 monuments will be departing.
 
4,800 to Leave Today
 And at the small Conflicts of Interest Board, which is charged with monitoring the ethics of more than 200,000 government employees, the only attorney charged with enforcement will be leaving. 
 Across the city's vast municipal landscape, it was easy to find the signs of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's effort to pare the city work force. Today, 4,800 workers are scheduled to clean out their desks, the first to leave under Mr. Giuliani's offer of a severance package to cajole 6,800 off the payroll.
As the deadline approached, managers have spent the last few weeks trying to juggle workers, rearrange priorities and assess needs in an effort to do more with less. But how successful they will be remains in question.
Many commissioners say much will depend on how well and how quickly the administration is able to redeploy people from less critical jobs into crucial ones and how adaptable employees are to new work in different fields.
"There's going to be a transition period," said Abraham M. Lackman, the city budget director. "Will redeployment work? That's the great unknown."
The severance program marks the first phase of Mr. Giuliani's larger plan to pare 15,000 employees, or 7 percent of the municipal work force, from the payroll by July 1995, through severance and attrition. So far Mr. Giuliani has declined to spell out how the cuts will affect government services.
"The reason that we can't predict for you where the effects on services will take place is that I am asking the people who manage New York City to manage it more effectively," he said when he announced his budget on May 10. "I am asking people for something revolutionary, to work a little harder."
Outside the government, others were skeptical about how the redeployment process would work. "It's either Russian roulette or musical chairs, and where everyone ends up, nobody knows," said Gene Russianoff of the New York Public Interest Research Group. "This is a city government that has a tough time doing its job when everyone stays in the same place."
The employees who are departing range from clerical workers to senior employees with highly specialized skills, from computer specialists to social workers with years of experience. Their ranks include essential workers and scores of employees whom managers say they will not be sorry to see leave. About another 2,000 workers will be leaving on June 3, bringing the work-force reduction to near 6,800.
 
Waiting for Replacements
 For the last week, senior city officials have held back-to-back two-hour meetings with the commissioners of 26 senior agencies, trying to avert problems as crucial employees walk out the door. Donna Lynne, the director of the Mayor's Office of Operations, said that about 100 employees, set to leave today or on June 3, were asked to stay on until no later than July 15 so that replacements can be found.
One of them is the only employee in the Community Development Agency who knows how the antipoverty agency's 20-year-old computer system functions. Diane McGrath-McKechnie, the agency's commissioner, said she had been greatly relieved when the employee agreed to stay. "It can only work if the employee agrees to it, and this employee does agree to it, thank heavens,"she said.
In creating its severance offer, the administration prohibited uniformed officers like police, firefighters and sanitation workers from applying and also excluded engineers and scientists judged as essential employees. It created goals for individual agencies, but beyond that the program was uncontrolled, leaving uncertain which workers would opt to leave, lured by cash packages ranging from $3,500 to $25,000 or a year's pay. The packages also provide health benefits for nine months and leave the workers eligible for unemployment compensation.
 
Some Agencies Hit Hard
 The result has been that some agencies have been hit harder than had been desired. The Health Department, for example, had so many unfilled vacancies in its roster that it needed to lose only 55 employees to meet a staff reduction goal set by the Mayor. But 296 people applied for the buyout. The Commissioner, Margaret A. Hamburg, said some of the employees leaving have such specialized skills that the department will have to look outside the city government to hire replacements. Redeployment of existing employees will not fill the gap, she said.
"It's sort of ironic," Ms. Hamburg said. "We're paying people to leave only to rehire to fill those jobs."
Other agencies like the Transportation Department fell far short of their severance goals. Elliot G. Sander, the Transportation Commissioner, said only 335 people in his department had decided to quit, well below the target of 935. In addition, he said, many of those who took the severance packages do not work in the areas that the Mayor's budget had slated for consolidation or reductions.
Because of such discrepancies, administration officials have designated such agencies as the Transportation Department, the Human Resources Administration and the Homeless Services Department as "donors," agencies that will be called on to offer surplus workers to other agencies. The administration is aiming to carry out the redeployment over the next six weeks to two months.
 
Complicated Procedures
 But the redeployment procedures the Giuliani administration negotiated with the municipal unions are complicated. The administration agreed to begin by asking for volunteers to switch agencies. Then it must move workers, starting with those with the least seniority.
Besides adhering to the redeployment agreement negotiated with the unions, the administration must also adhere to existing Civil Service rules. If Civil Service lists of potential candidates already exist for certain jobs, hiring must be done from the lists. "It will certainly be," Ms. Lynne paused, "the word we're using in the administration now is challenging."
Ms. Lynne said that commissioners will not be able to screen and reject employees sent to them through redeployment. She admitted that some of the commissioners were not pleased to learn that.
In the meantime, city agencies will be struggling to make do. At the Conflicts of Interest Board, Mark L. Davies, the executive director, pointed out that the severance program, coming on top of past cuts and vacancies, had reduced his staff by a third. "Is there a commitment to ethics in city government or isn't there?" he asked. "The message we're getting right now is it just doesn't make that much difference."
At the Consumer Affairs Department, where 14 of 41 people are leaving the licensing division, Marc A. Wurzel, the department spokesman, said the agency would seek quick redeployment. "Thankfully all of our licenses don't come up at one time or we'd have lines wrapped around Wall Street," he said. He said that the Department is expected to take over some of the staff and functions of the Taxi and Limousine Commission in several months, which could bring in more employees to handle licensing. The department licenses 82 types of businesses and activities.
The Health Department averted an immediate staffing crisis in the Poison Control Bureau by persuading the three departing pharmacists to stay on past today until a backup system is in place. Ms. Hamburg said she would be using redeployed workers, overtime and resident fellows from the Bellevue Hospital Center to keep the bureau running 24-hours.
At the Human Resources Administration, about 75 of the 470 caseworkers in the Division of AIDS Services have taken severance. A senior official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the division, which helps AIDS patients wend their way through the city's social services bureaucracy, would "begin more of a triage approach to case management and deal with emergencies as they come up."
Henry J. Stern, the Parks Commissioner, said he was losing 17 percent of his recreation workers who supervise activities at city playgrounds and recreation centers. Harking back to one of his predecessors, Robert Moses, Mr. Stern said, "In the two generations since Moses built them, hundreds of the city's playgrounds have lost what is practically all the staffing." He said he would be seeking more help from volunteers.
Mr. Stern was delighted, however that he had kept all three of the city's monument restorers from accepting severance. "All three were going and we persuaded two to stay," he said. "Two out of three ain't bad."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 21, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's severance offers for city workers misstated the amounts given to workers who left their jobs. The offers ranged from $3,500 or two weeks pay for newly hired workers to $15,000 for employees with 30 or more years of service; they did not range up to $25,000 or a year's pay.

HEADLINE: Citing Progress, U.S. Plans New Talks With North Korea

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
Deciding that North Korea has met key United States demands on inspection of its nuclear program, the Clinton Administration decided today to resume high-level talks with the North Koreans, American officials said.
The decision was made at a White House meeting of top Administration officials this afternoon against a backdrop of rising concerns about nuclear efforts, officials said. 
 The United States previously held two rounds of high-level talks with the North Koreans. But it refused to hold a third round, at which a package of political and economic incentives was to be discussed, until the North Koreans agreed to Washington's initial inspection demands.
Explaining today's decision, an Administration official said that the International Atomic Energy Agency told Washington that North Korea has not diverted any of the fuel it recently removed from its reactor for nuclear weapons purposes.
North Korea, Administration officials said, also allowed agency monitors to complete a long-sought inspection of its plutonium reprocessing plant at Yongbyon and to replace the film and batteries in cameras in the nuclear reactor there.
Administration officials acknowledged that there were still important differences between North Korea and the atomic energy agency. They said Washington was prepared to break off the talks if North Korea took steps that made it impossible for the atomic energy agency to conduct measurements of how much plutonium North Korea might have diverted in the past or otherwise impeded the agency's inspections.
The agency's assurance that the recently removed fuel was not being diverted was publicly disclosed today in a series of unusually explicit statements by top Administration officials. The statements appeared designed to counter the impression that North Korea was refusing to accept any constraints on its nuclear program.
Administration officials said that North Korea has not been informed of the new stance and that no date for the high-level talks has been set. The American delegation will be led by Robert Gallucci, an Assistant Secretary of State and the Clinton Administration's point man on North Korea.
Before that assurance was given, the Administration had been confronted by a quandry. On the one hand, Washington is eager to explore every diplomatic opportunity before trying to muster support for economic sanctions. On the other hand, the Administration does not want to be portrayed as weak, particularly in light of criticism that it has vacillated on foreign policy.
The problem was compounded last week when North Korea announced it was beginning to withdraw fuel rods from its nuclear reactor at Yongbyon. That development worried Washington because the fuel, if reprocessed at North Korea's plutonium separation plant, could provided enough material for four or five nuclear bombs.
The pressure also intensified when Hans Blix, the director general of the atomic energy agency, sent a message describing the removal of the fuel as a serious violation of its agreement with North Korea.
But today, Administration officials took pains to describe the developments in less alarming terms.
One Administration official, who asked not be named, said that North Korea has removed about 5 percent of the 8,000 rods in its reactor and that they have been placed in special ponds that the atomic energy agency is allowed to monitor.
Defense Secretary William J. Perry, who has underscored the danger of allowing North Korea to proceed with its nuclear program, also played down the military significance of the move, describing the removal of the rods as a technical violation.
"The I.A.E.A., in fact, has told us that it is confident that there has been no diversion of the fuel that has just been discharged," Mr. Perry told reporters today.
 
No Irrevocable Steps
 Administration officials also said the North Koreans have not taken irrevocable steps that would prevent the atomic energy agency from conducting measurements of some of the rods.
The agency wants to analyze the spent fuel from the reactors to determine how long they have been in the reactor. That, in turn, would enable the agency to determine if North Korea has previously unloaded enough fuel from the reactor for one or two nuclear bombs, as the Central Intelligence Agency believes, or has simply withdrawn a small number of damaged fuel rods, as North Korea maintains.
To conduct the measurements, the agency wants to examine 300 of the rods from specific parts of the reactor. The agency has asked North Korea to either set aside the rods for inspections or leave them in the reactor so that the measurements might be carried out in the future.
So far, however, the North Koreans have rebuffed the agency's demands. But they have also not brought the dispute with the agency to a crisis by removing the rods that the agency wants to measure.
An Administration official said that if the North Koreans continue to remove the fuel at their current pace and according to their current procedures, it could take weeks before they remove the rods in question.
At the same time, Mr. Gallucci, the Administration's point man on the dispute, said the North Koreans have allowed international monitors to complete the inspections of the reprocessing plant that they had sought to carry out in March.
Administration officials described the North Korean moves as part of a perplexing pattern that has left Administration experts divided over whether Pyongyang is simply trying to drive a hard bargain in its negotiations with the Washington or is determined to build a nuclear arsenal.
"They are skirting right to the edge of the red line, but without crossing it," an Administration official said.
While Administration officials sought to portray their decision to proceed with the talks as a sober exploration of a diplomatic opening, it was likely to stir debate about whether Washington was being prudent or timid about North Korea.
Throughout its diplomatic dealings with Washington, North Korea has continued to work intensively on building a new larger reactor and on expanding its plutonium reprocessing capability.
There are other unanswered questions as well, including exactly what position the Administration will take in the talks.
Washington has offered to expand diplomatic and economic ties with Pyongyang if it agrees to abandon its nuclear weapons program. But the Administration has not made clear exactly what incentives it plans to propose.
