HEADLINE: NEW YORK SHIFTING FOCUS OF WELFARE TO JOB PLACEMENT

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 20

 BODY:
Having rejected many of the punitive measures embraced by other states, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo says New York State is trying to reduce welfare dependency by changing welfare offices into places that push applicants to find work instead of simply processing checks.
Governor Cuomo's "Jobs First" strategy, announced in an election year when his opponents are already making welfare a major issue, would direct welfare applicants into job training and job searches even before they are approved for welfare benefits. 
 Both state and local social services officials say Mr. Cuomo's approach would require a major change in the state's welfare bureaucracy, which historically has been preoccupied with determining eligibility.
For example, in Albany County, home of one early example of this new approach, some applicants who are able-bodied and childless must show evidence that they have applied for at least six jobs a week during the 45-day waiting period when eligibility for welfare benefits is determined. If they do not take proof of their contacts with employers to their caseworkers, they can be rejected for benefits.
The Cuomo administration is pressing other counties to impose similar requirements or to adopt other job-training and job-search programs that are being tested with some success in other parts of the state.
But state officials concede that there are many obstacles, especially in New York City, which has two-thirds of the state's welfare recipients, higher unemployment than in the rest of the state, and union rules that make it difficult to give welfare workers new responsibilities.
Mr. Cuomo is also seeking permission from the Federal Government to offer welfare applicants one-time grants, if such payments would help them stay employed. For instance, applicants could be given enough money to fix a car, or to hire a child-care worker, if such measures would eliminate obstacles to working.
Mr. Cuomo is offering his new approach at a time when measures have been gaining approval in other states to curtail benefits to discourage certain behavior or to pressure recipients to leave the rolls.
The Governor says New York will not place a two-year limit on welfare benefits, as Florida does. It will not deny increased benefits to mothers who have additional children, which is New Jersey's new policy. It will not eliminate its welfare program for able-bodied adults without children, as Michigan recently did. And unlike Oklahoma, which reduces welfare benefits for families whose children skip school, New York is proposing both to cut benefits in cases of chronic truancy and to increase them for good attendance.
Mr. Cuomo has scoffed at such sanctions, calling them counterproductive.
Just as Mr. Cuomo offers life without parole as an alternative to the death penalty, his approach to welfare gives him alternatives in both political and policy discussions.
The notion of transforming welfare offices into job-placement offices may seem like "a fanatical implementation of common sense," to use the words of Jane G. Lynch, a social services official from Monroe County. But welfare experts, like Mark R. Greenberg, senior staff attorney at the Center for Law and Social Policy in Washington, contend that the new direction in Albany is no less radical than that in Tallahassee or Trenton.
 
Seeking Fundamental Change
 "I think that the goal of this kind of approach is not simply to put forward a catchy slogan but rather to fundamentally change the day-to-day operations of the welfare system," Mr. Greenberg said.
One of every 11 New Yorkers -- a total of 1.6 million people -- is now on welfare. Seventy-six percent, or 1.2 million people, are supported by Aid to Families with Dependent Children, a program largely for mothers and children that is financed by the Federal, state and local governments. The remainder, 388,000 people, are recipients of Home Relief, a state and local program primarily for childless, and often able-bodied, adults.
Fully 60 percent of the state's adult welfare recipients are considered employable. Yet recipients of Aid to Families with Dependent Children stay on the rolls for an average of 2.5 years, significantly longer than the national average. Many return more than once, although the state does not have reliable statistics about recidivism.
The state's welfare rolls grew by 32 percent from 1989 to 1993, and its spending on welfare increased by 48 percent to $4.07 billion, or 13 percent of the state's general fund budget. An additional $5.3 billion was spent on Medicaid, much of it to pay for health care for welfare recipients.
 
Opposing Punitive Measures
 Mr. Cuomo's strategy, which is being put in place in selected counties, acknowledges that New York's welfare system must be revamped to place a new priority on jobs. But the plan also reflects the Governor's arguments that many measures embraced by other governors, and by President Clinton, may be both counterproductive and inhumane.
In a speech on welfare earlier this month, Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, ridiculed the practice of denying increased benefits to women who have additional children. "If you make another baby, I'll take the money away from you and then you and the baby are going to starve," he said. "That's terrific. What a dumb thing that is."
Republican lawmakers and gubernatorial candidates laud Mr. Cuomo's new emphasis on jobs. They also support his calls for expanding the state's experimental program of fingerprinting welfare recipients to combat fraud and for tougher enforcement of child-support orders.
But many Republican leaders support more Draconian measures, and they question why Mr. Cuomo waited 12 years to propose his Jobs First plan.
"I'm always amused that Mario Cuomo comes up with proposals after problems reach alarming proportions," said Herbert London, a Republican candidate for governor.
Cuomo administration officials said that a major jobs program would have had little success at a time when there were few jobs to be had, particularly for low-skilled workers. After losing more than 500,000 jobs from 1989 to 1993, employment in New York has started to creep upward only since January.
Since 1988, when Congress passed a welfare package that funneled new money for job training to the states, New York has nearly doubled the number of welfare recipients in programs that require schooling, job training or work.
But fewer than one of every six employable welfare recipients participate in such programs, at least in part because of inadequate financing. And the number of welfare recipients who joined the work force increased to only 44,709 in 1993 from 32,245 in 1988.
Mr. Dowling, who was appointed Commissioner of Social Services last year, acknowledges that even now the state's job growth is too lethargic to move large numbers of people from welfare to work. But he is urging business leaders to make more jobs available to welfare recipients and has called for larger tax credits for those who do.
 
A Message About Work
 His goal, looking toward a day when the economy blossoms, is for every welfare office to send a message about work. "From the moment someone walks in, instead of the worker saying, 'I'm here to see if you're eligible,' they should say, 'I'm here to make sure you don't become eligible,' " he said.
As part of its effort, the state is expanding a demonstration project, highly regarded by the Clinton Administration and academic experts on welfare, that encourages welfare mothers to find jobs by allowing them to keep part of their benefits while they work. The project, known as the Child Assistance Program, is being expanded this year from seven counties to 14, including Brooklyn, its first location in New York City.
A recent state-financed study found that the program, which is voluntary, significantly increased the average participant's income while modestly decreasing the state's costs. It was inconclusive about whether the program will ultimately reduce long-term welfare dependency.
Mr. Dowling said it would be difficult, but not impossible, to put the whole Jobs First plan to work in New York City.
Besides the sheer magnitude of the welfare caseload there, the city has a higher unemployment rate. Its welfare eligibility offices are currently distinct from those that administer its job training and employment programs.
Union rules regulate the tasks performed by caseworkers, making it difficult to require bureaucrats to take on new responsibilities. And Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has proposed cutting 4,658 of the city's 23,696 social services workers, meaning the city will have fewer workers at a time it wants its welfare system to do more.
Marva L. Hammons, the Commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, said the Giuliani administration fully supports the state's initiative and is planning to experiment with it this year. But she also said she did not underestimate the challenge.
"Over the last 10 to 15 years, we've been asking welfare agencies to get the checks out and to have good participation rates in a variety of programs," she said. "We've gotten very good at doing that. But when we change the goal to job placement, that is a very big change in philosophy and direction. It may not seem like a big change, but really and truly it is."
At Albany County's main welfare office, there are few physical manifestations of that change. Like many public assistance offices, it consists of a dingy waiting room cluttered with plastic chairs and a warren of paper-strewn desks.
But by adopting the Jobs First philosophy, the county managed to trim its Home Relief caseload to 2,137 in late April from 2,775 in early February, a decrease of 23 percent.
Ross A. Prinzo Jr., social services commissioner for Albany County, said much of the caseload reduction came from forcing Home Relief applicants to look for work during the 45-day period that is used to determine eligibility for benefits.
Once applicants are determined to be employable, meaning that they are not disabled, addicted to drugs or alcohol or lacking vocational skills, they are required to apply in person for at least six jobs a week. A job search handbook advises applicants to "dress neatly" and "smile!"
Increasingly, those who cannot find work on their own are placed into programs that require them to earn their benefits as custodians, groundskeepers and file clerks in government offices -- with an eye toward building their experience in the working world.
Using a two-year-old state program called Working Toward Independence, the county has placed 120 Home Relief recipients in part-time jobs, usually averaging 18 hours a week, for state agencies like the Office of General Services and the Department of Social Services.
Some welfare recipients, after learning of the new requirements, simply drop from the rolls, Albany County officials said.
"The younger ones say: 'I never had to do this before. All I had to do was show up,' " said Concetta M. Dominski, a senior social welfare examiner in Albany. "I say: 'Surprise. The taxpayer is tired of footing the bill.' And then I say, 'Come on, you don't want to do this the rest of your life.' "

HEADLINE: Collecting Child Support. A special report.;
Private Firms Help Single Parents Get What's Due

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
Casey Hoffman knows plenty about the difficulties of enforcing child-support orders.
He used to run Texas's child-support office, and in 1990, the year he left that job, his program was rated the most improved in the nation; indeed, Mr. Hoffman was named the outstanding child-support manager of the year. 
 But these days Mr. Hoffman plays a different role as a private entrepreneur in child support, a kind of bounty hunter who tracks down absent parents, makes them pay, and keeps a third of the money he collects.
The very existence of a private company like Mr. Hoffman's Child Support Enforcement, and about 100 others that have sprung up nationwide in the last five years, is, to advocates for single parents, a stark indication of the inadequacy of the state child-support system.
The Association for Children for Enforcement of Support, an advocacy group based in Toledo, Ohio, sees the private companies as leeches whose fees siphon off money badly needed to support children in single-parent families.
"If they take 33 percent of the money that's supposed to feed the children, what are they taking? Breakfast, lunch or dinner?" asked Geraldine Jensen, the founder of the association, which lobbies for stronger child-support laws and teaches parents their legal rights. "It's a symptom of how badly broken the system is that women are turning to private profiteers. It's true, the system doesn't work unless you really push it. But we need to fix the system, not let private companies profit at the expense of kids."
Many women for whom Mr. Hoffman has recovered money disagree, arguing that a third of the money is a reasonable fee for the personal attention and fast results his company provides.
"I got child-support money for maybe a year after we separated in 1981, and then it stopped," said Nancy Sissons, 47, of Glen Cove, L.I. "I filed with Nassau County, but that went on for nine years and I got nothing. Finally they gave up. The woman in the Nassau office told me I might as well forget it. But a girlfriend in Texas told me about Casey Hoffman's company. I was little bit leery of it, to tell the truth, but I didn't have anything to lose."
 
Laws Are No Help For State Collections
 What happened next seemed little short of miraculous to Ms. Sissons, who for years had worked two jobs to support her two daughters.
"Within three days they called to say they had located him," she said. "He ended up paying $37,000, and after their fee, I got $25,000. That seems reasonable to me. After we got his address, my older daughter wrote to him. And this year, for the first time in 12 years, she got a birthday card from him."
Despite child-support laws that have steadily been made tougher, the percentage of cases in which the state collects child support remains small -- and largely unchanging.
According to the Department of Health Human Services's Office of Child Support Enforcement, overburdened state agencies nationwide collected money in only 18.7 percent of their child-support cases in the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30, 1992, compared with 19.3 percent the previous year.
Private child-support enforcement is still a new field and one that is completely unregulated. State officials and consumer advocates alike warn that the potential for consumer fraud is high. Some companies have taken in application fees from hundreds, even thousands, of clients and then quickly folded.
There are also complaints that some companies have been overly zealous, hounding the relatives of those who have not paid their child support. Mary Wilson, an Arlington, Tex., woman whose son owed support, said she was harassed with constant calls at work by a private child-support company in Houston, threatening to put her son in jail. The company subsequently went bankrupt.
But for many mothers, and a few fathers, who are frustrated by the government's failure to collect their child support, the calculation is simple: 66 percent of something is more than 100 percent of nothing.
Such was the case of Connie Velasco, a 24-year-old Austin woman whose former husband had ignored child-support orders for their son, Jaime, now 6, and moved to Oklahoma, frustrating efforts by the Texas Attorney General's Office to collect. So Ms. Velasco signed up with Mr. Hoffman's company: "Within a few months, I was getting my money," she said. "It does bother me, how much they take as their fee, but it was the only way I was going to get anything."
Most of Mr. Hoffman's clients have spent years trying to get the state to collect the money they are owed. In many cases, the absent parent is out of state, complicating enforcement for state workers already burdened with overwhelming caseloads. And most of the state agencies' attention goes to the welfare cases that make up the bulk of the 15 million cases in the system -- cases in which the state keeps much of the money it recovers to recoup its welfare payments to the mother.
"We don't have any magic that the state doesn't have," said Mr. Hoffman, who practiced family law and headed the Massachusetts bar association before he moved to Texas. "But they have huge backlogs and more cases than they can handle. We don't handle welfare cases, our investigators have reasonable caseloads, and we have the financial incentive."
Ron Dusek, press secretary to the Texas Attorney General, warns that the field is unregulated and ripe for fraud, but he acknowledges that the state can use private companies' help in collecting child support. "We're a free service with hundreds of thousands of cases, and there is plenty of work to be done, so there is certainly an opportunity for private collections," Mr. Dusek said. "And it's true, they can work a case a lot quicker."
 
State System Shows Improvement
 Critics of the state child-support offices acknowledge that the system is improving, thanks to tougher laws that provide for wage garnishment, computerization, better interstate collection procedures and more.
Still, the states' collection efforts are stymied by the millions of babies whose paternity is not officially established, making it impossible to collect money from their fathers. Although states seek paternity orders, they succeed for only about a third of the 1.5 million babies born each year to unmarried women.
Even where paternity is not an issue, millions of mothers never get a court order requiring child support. And even among those who have court orders requiring support, only about half get the full amount they are entitled to.
Experts say unpaid child support is a prime reason that more than one in five American children live in poverty. According to an Urban Institute study, children in single-parent families would get $34 billion if all child-support obligations were met.
The Clinton Administration may include in its proposal to overhaul the welfare system a Federal registry of all child-support orders and a provision making it possible to track noncustodial parents as they move from job to job by requiring all new employees to complete a form about whether they owe child support. But Mr. Hoffman and others say it will be decades before government has a smoothly functioning system.
"With all the attention the problem has gotten, and all the new laws, the percentage of paying cases nationwide grew 1.6 percent in 14 years," Mr. Hoffman said. "I would love to be put out of business if the state could collect money for all the children who should be getting it. But we're light years away from that."
Other entrepreneurs have reached a similar conclusion. Just last month, Find Dad, a private child-support company with the most elaborate marketing program -- complete with a catchy phone number, 800 PAY-MOMS -- was acquired last month by Casino & Credit Services Inc., a publicly traded company in Conshohocken, Pa., that provides credit information to casinos.
And Charles Drake, who in 1988 in San Antonio, Tex., started what was apparently the first private child-support business, Children's Support Services (Its slogan: "We can't make him care, but we can make him pay."), has served as a consultant to dozens of others joining the field. But as many as half the new child-support companies that were started in the last five years have failed.
With advice from Mr. Drake, Mitchell Levin invested $100,000 two years ago to expand his Long Island collection agency to include child-support enforcement, but he dropped out of the field after a few months. "It's a very hard game to play," Mr. Levin said. "We did a lot of advertising, and we got 10,000 phone calls from people who wanted help, but most were on welfare, and it only turned into 35 cases. There's certainly a big problem with child support in this country, but it's not one a private company can solve."
 
An Alternative To Lawyers
 Still, private companies can fill a need for some parents who have a court order, are not on welfare and are owed a large amount in back support payments. While affluent parents have used lawyers to collect child support, lawyers typically charge high retainers and hourly fees, payable whether or not any money is recovered.
Mr. Hoffman's company sometimes gets support payments just by tracking down and contacting the absent parent, usually a father. More often, though, the company must have his wages garnisheed, go to court to collect the money or persuade local law-enforcement officials to arrest him.
In one creative case, where the former husband was unemployed and broke, Mr. Hoffman's company arranged for the wife to receive a mobile home that the man's mother's will had bequeathed to him, to his former wife and to a charity, which agreed to donate its share to the woman.
The big draw of the private child-support companies is that they work on contingency. Though many charge a nonrefundable application fee -- Mr. Hoffman's is one of the few that does not, though his 33 percent cut is higher than most -- the private companies get their cut only if they collect. Some companies take a percentage of the back support payments only; others keep a portion of every payment.
In the Hancock Center shopping mall here, Mr. Hoffman's company gets thousands of calls every month from parents, mostly mothers, who are not receiving the money they are owed.
For all the demographers who chart the breakdown of the American family, all the statisticians who track the rise in childhood poverty, it may be Vanessa Diaz, sitting in her basement mall office, who knows the problem best.
Ms. Diaz is one of Child Support Enforcement's client-service representatives, taking calls on the 800 line and sifting out the people on welfare, the ones with no court order, the ones who are not owed at least $5,000 in back support.
She hears it all: the mother of four facing eviction because she cannot pay the rent, the mother with a seriously ill child and no medical insurance, the mother whose ex-husband just bought a new boat but will not pay a cent in child support.
 
A Sympathetic Voice On the Phone
 To callers who meet the company's guidelines, Ms. Diaz sometimes offers her own story -- part reassurance, part marketing tool -- of spending six years trying to collect child support through the Texas Attorney General's Office. Then she found Mr. Hoffman, and got her money in eight weeks.
Soon after, Mr. Hoffman offered her a job. "I thought it was important that women who call us talk to women who can identify with what they are going through," he said. "I knew she'd be great when she told us how mad she got about being put on hold every time she called the Attorney General's Office. One time it went on so long, she got in her car, drove to the office, and said, 'See those blinking lights on the phone? That's me.' "
For investigators, Mr. Hoffman has turned primarily to alumni of the state child-support collection office, many of them former repo men, who see child support as a sort of repossession in the public interest.
"There's not a lot of personal satisfaction in repo-ing a mobile home, knowing the family has nowhere to go," said Al James, an investigator who started as a repo man and went to the Fort Worth child-support office before joining Child Support Enforcement. "Here, I know I'm doing something that benefits children."
Finding the absent parent is usually the easy part, investigators say, given the availability of credit bureaus, law-enforcement authorities and, sometimes, disgruntled former girlfriends.
"Finding them isn't the problem," said Shepherd Green, another investigator who has in the past worked as a repo man, an undercover policeman, an investigator for a bank and a loan officer. "The problem is what you find. They could be homeless. They could be dead."
Mr. Hoffman says his the company finds about 85 percent of the parents it looks for, and about 60 percent of those ultimately pay something.
Besides the "gotcha" moments of tracking down someone who has eluded discovery for years, what investigators seem to relish most are the cases in which a father who has long been incommunicado renews contact with his children after paying what he owes.
"Sometimes after a father starts paying, he'll send a letter for us to forward to the kids," said Mr. James, who handles 200 to 300 cases at a time, compared with the 2,800 he was responsible for when he worked for the state. "Once they pay, they can stop being ashamed, and start having a relationship with their kids again."

HEADLINE: Thousands of Rwanda Dead Wash Down to Lake Victoria

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 20

 BODY:
As many as 10,000 bodies from Rwanda's massacres have washed down the Kagera River into Lake Victoria in Uganda in the last few weeks, creating an acute health hazard, a senior Ugandan official says.
Cloaking the countryside with the stench of death, the bodies -- as many as 100 an hour -- are being washed ashore in the Rakai district of southern Uganda or onto islands in Lake Victoria and have been seen as far north as Entebbe. 
 A clean-up operation by the Ugandan Government and international relief agencies has been hampered by the remoteness of the area, heavy rains and the difficulty of fighting off the wild animals and dogs feeding on the bodies. Worried about epidemics of cholera and other diseases, the Health Ministry of Uganda is telling villagers to boil drinking water and to cook all fish thoroughly.
"It's basically an appalling sight," said Keith Sherper, the director of the United States Agency for International Development in Kampala, who is assisting the Ugandan Government in the clean-up.
The Kagera River flows through southern Rwanda, mostly through Government- and militia-controlled territory, and bodies have been carried by the current for weeks. Relief officials say the killers must have dumped the bodies into the river by the truckload. Many are mutilated.
"I've never seen hatred like this in my life," said Manuel Pinto, a member of the Ugandan Parliament from the Rakai district and the head of the clean-up operation who gave the estimate of up to 10,000 bodies. "There are so many of them. Children are skewered on sticks. I saw a woman cut open from the tail bone. They have removed breasts and male genital organs."
The massacres in Rwanda began on April 6 when its President, Juvenal Habyarimana, was killed in a suspicious plane explosion. Most of the killings have been done by the majority Hutu military and militia and have been directed against the minority Tutsi tribe in what human rights officials say is an "ethnic cleansing" of the Tutsis. Battle deaths in fighting between the military and the Tutsi rebels have been relatively few in comparison.
Reliable estimates of the death toll are hard to find, but some range up to and beyond 200,000.
The Kagera River empties into Lake Victoria in the Rakai district near the fishing village of Kasensero, once an important trading center but now decimated by AIDS and with about 1,000 inhabitants. It was in Kasensero that the first cases of AIDS were reported in the 1980's.
The clean-up operation in Uganda began on April 25 but was at first limited to a local effort. Western donors have now pledged more than $150,000. World Vision International and the Lutheran World Federation are the two main relief agencies, but in a broad show of support, Ugandan volunteers are providing time, money, trucks, fuel and excavators for mass graves. The Ugandan Government is trucking in drinking water.
 
Working Round the Clock
 Workers are trying to remove bodies before they reach the lake, and crews work round the clock, Mr. Pinto said. They use motorized canoes and must somehow trap the bodies, pull them to shore, wrap them and load them onto trucks.
Many bodies have already washed ashore and are rotting. This attracts wild animals and dogs and fills the area with a gagging stench. On one island, as many as 700 bodies had washed ashore, Mr. Pinto said.
At first villagers dug shallow graves, but heavy rains have washed away the sandy earth and exposed the bodies. Mr. Pinto said the clean-up force has assigned people to shoot scavenging dogs. The rains have also made dirt roads impassable, and the bodies have to be ferried with the canoes.
There is the danger of pollution as well. Lake Victoria, the second largest body of fresh water in the world, borders Uganda, Tanzania and Kenya and is also the source of the Nile. The fishing of Nile perch is the backbone of local economies. Health experts believe that the perch, who like to eat live prey, will not feed on the bodies, but the experts have advised the local inhabitants to cook the fish thoroughly.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed on Fears Of a 5th Rate Increase

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday as the market focused on the dollar's sharp decline against the German mark, which raised questions about whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates for a fifth time this year.
Adding another shiver of anxiety to the markets yesterday was a surge in commodities prices, which could point to possible inflation. The Commodities Research Bureau's futures price index, which has been rising this week, hit a new high for 1994 yesterday. 
 "All of this could pressure the Fed," said Todd Clark, senior director of equity trading at Mabon Securities Inc. "But the markets are actually holding together fairly well at the moment, so we'll just have to see how next week works out."
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.37 points yesterday to close at 3,766.35, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 1.56 points, to 454.92.
 
Clearer Statement Needed
 Earlier this week, the Fed pushed up short-term interest rates by half a percentage point in an effort to insure that inflation remained under control and to support a sagging dollar.
But some traders contend that the Clinton Administration needs to make a clearer statement that it wants a strong dollar rather than simply trying to avoid a weak dollar. "Right now, we're just as confused as anyone else," said Kevin J. Laurie, manager of foreign-exchange trading at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
Indeed, German interest rates remain higher than American rates, despite the Fed's recent action, and thus mark-denominated securities are still more lucrative than dollar-denominated securities.
The weakened dollar helped push down bond prices, and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, jumped to 7.30 percent, from 7.23 percent on Thursday.
With the exception of blue-chip stocks, the overall stock market declined as well.
Yesterday was the "double witching hour," when two kinds of options on indexes and individual stocks expired, but that did not seem to push up trading volume, which totaled 293.5 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Traders said that much of the options-related trading probably occurred on Wednesday and Thursday during the rising sessions that followed the Fed's raising of interest rates.
 
Philip Morris Up
 Of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 12 stocks rose, led by Philip Morris and Sears, Roebuck, which accounted for all of the Dow's rise. Philip Morris rose 2 1/2, to 53 3/4, after an analyst for Merrill Lynch said in a report this week that Philip Morris stock could be worth $64 if the company split into separate food and cigarette units. Sears rose 1 1/8, to 50 7/8, on no discernible news.
Of the 500 stocks in the S.& P. 500, 287 stocks fell, led by Royal Dutch Petroleum, which fell 3 5/8, to 107 3/4, despite a jump in crude oil prices yesterday. Analysts said there was concern in the market about the supply of crude oil available for delivery.
The most active issue yesterday, at 5.3 million shares, was the American depository receipts for Telefonos de Mexico, the Mexican phone company, which because it is widely held often acts as a proxy for the entire Mexican stock market. The A.D.R.'s, which each represent 20 ordinary shares, rose 7/8, to 60 1/4, after it was announced that Telmex was part of a consortium that would link the United States and Chile with advanced fiber optic cable.
Among other market indicators, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 0.61 point, to 726.70, and the American Stock Exchange market value index fell 1.16 point, to 438.20. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.58 point, to 251.58. Declining stocks edged out advancing stocks by 1,146 to 1,027.
In Tokyo, stocks ended higher yesterday on a late flurry of index-linked buying. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 120.83 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,342.17.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
June Oil Ends Day at $18.92; Surge Lifts Precious Metals

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The surging June oil contract touched $19 a barrel yesterday before it expired just short of that level as strong demand for crude oil drove the market upward.
Domestic refiners were operating at a feverish pace, partly to insure plentiful supplies of gasoline for the coming driving season, analysts said. 
 June crude rose 47 cents, to $18.92 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the highest price since mid-June of last year.
"June crude is going out in a blaze of glory," said Hans Kashyap of Analytics Research Corporation in Bethesda, Md.
The July oil contract gained a modest 31 cents, to $18.21 a barrel. June gasoline rose 0.52 cent, to 52.60 cents a gallon, and June heating oil added 0.46 cent, to 48.32 cents a gallon.
 
June Gold Contract Climbs
 The rallies in oil and soybean prices helped touch off a rise in inflation-sensitive gold and other precious metals. The moves combined to push up the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities for the fourth straight day. It hit 233.73, its highest since October 1990, before receding to 233.69, up 1.26.
Continued weakness in the dollar also made gold attractive to some investors, and the June contract climbed $4.50, to $386.30 an ounce, at the Commodity Exchange in New York. July silver rose 11.5 cents, to $5.66 an ounce, and July platinum ended $5.40 higher, at $405.90 an ounce.
Soybeans continued a recent price surge that has pushed the market up more than 5 percent in the last week. A strong ridge of high pressure lingering over the Midwest has caused fears of a dry growing season that would reduce the crop.
"Monday's open depends on the moisture amounts over the weekend and Monday's forecast, how much and where it falls," said Nick DeBrown of E.D. and F. Man International.
"If there is no rain this weekend we'll be sharply higher Monday, but if it rains we'll be sharply lower -- it's that simple," another trader said.
The wheat crop, which is nearing maturity, was affected by frost worries, since maturing wheat stands need warm, dry weather to enhance final development.
July soybeans rose 8.25 cents, to $7.02 1/2 a bushel; July corn edged up 0.75 cents, to $2.68 3/4; July wheat added 3.75 cents, to $3.26 3/4, and July oats rose 1 cent, to $1.23 1/4 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops vs. the Mark On Interest-Rate Outlooks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against the German mark yesterday amid signs that American interest rates may have peaked and that short-term German rates are unlikely to fall anytime soon.
German interest rates remain as much as a percentage point higher than American rates even though the Federal Reserve pushed up short-term rates this week by half a percentage point. 
 "People are convinced that German interest rates aren't going down again and that U.S. rates aren't going up," said Lisa Finstrom, currency analyst at Smith Barney Shearson.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6470 German marks, down from 1.6577 marks on Thursday. But it was little changed at 104.25 Japanese yen, down from 104.33 yen, amid growing optimism about American-Japanese trade talks in Washington.
The dollar is down 5.4 percent against the mark and 7.1 percent against the yen this year, hurt by a capital flight from American stocks and bonds, a widening trade deficit and lingering concern about the Clinton Administration's trade policies.
Even so, the dollar may be close to a bottom, some traders said. Marc Cohen, managing director at C-Wave Capital Management, a currency trading firm in Fort Lee, N.J., predicted that economic growth would eventually push up interest rates, thus buoying the dollar. "The recent slump is overdone," he said. Higher American interest rates usually make dollar-denominated investments more attractive.
Many traders sold dollars yesterday after unidentified officials of the German central bank were quoted in in a leading German newspaper as saying they expected a surge in the German money supply growth, the Bundesbank's gauge of future inflation.
With the money supply rising so fast, fewer traders expect the Bundesbank to cut interest rates anytime soon.
Similarly, many traders gave up hope for higher American rates on Tuesday when the Federal Reserve raised the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans to 4.25 percent from 3.75 percent and suggested that the increase was the last one for some time to come. The Fed raised its discount rate on loans made directly to banks to 3.5 percent from 3 percent.
The dollar fell further yesterday after the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, was quoted by the German weekly Der Spiegel as saying that the dollar's decline against the mark this year was more a result of the mark's stability than the dollar's weakness.
"Mr. Tietmeyer's comments really hurt the dollar," said Lynn Tierney, a trader at Shawmut Bank of Boston. "He sounds like he wants a strong Deutsche mark."

HEADLINE: Man Charged in Slaying of 2 Prominent Maryland Lawyers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
An unemployed handyman with a record of committing burglaries was charged by the authorities in Maryland today with two counts of first-degree murder in the shooting deaths of two prominent Washington lawyers.
Scotland E. Williams of Arnold, Md., was arrested by the police on Thursday night at his home after he had used a bank card that had belonged to one of the victims, Jose Enrique Trias, 49, the chief counsel for the Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Chevy Chase, Md. 
 In all, Mr. Williams had used the cards three times since the slayings and had been photographed each time by the bank cameras, the police said.
The bodies of Mr. Trias and his wife, Julie Noel Gilbert, 48, a lawyer with the Washington firm of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, were found on Monday at their weekend home across the Severn River from Annapolis.
In Maryland, first-degree murder is punishable by death under certain circumstances, including when more than one homicide has occurred. "It's not automatic," said Jerry Anderson a county prosecutor, adding that the decision must be made by the Anne Arundel County state's attorney, 30 days before trial.
Earlier this week in Baltimore, John Frederick Thanos became the first person to be executed in Maryland in 33 years, for the slaying of three teen-agers in 1990.
The Anne Arundel County police said Mr. Williams, 31, who was released from jail last month after his second arrest for burglary, was apprehended at home.
The police said they had the photographs from the cameras above the automatic teller machines at each of the Citibank branches Mr. Williams used. In at least one of the photographs, he wore glasses and a bandana. They also said that when Mr. Williams used the card the third time, at a shopping center south of Baltimore, a witness noticed him and provided a description that resembled the photos of Mr. Williams.
The police said that in their questioning of Mr. Williams he identified himself as the man in the photographs and admitted that he had used the bank card. They also said that at the time of his arrest Mr. Williams was wearing a watch that had belonged to Ms. Gilbert.
Sgt. Rick Tabor of the Anne Arundel County Police said the authorities were investigating the possibility that at least two other people had been involved in the slaying, but that it was too soon to know if Mr. Williams or the others had known the couple. He said he doubted it.
"His forte was being a cat burglar, breaking in when people were home," Sergeant Tabor said of Mr. Williams. "But before this, violence had never been attached to any of his burglaries before."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The police have charged Scotland E. Williams of Arnold, Md., in the slaying of two prominent lawyers, Jose Enrique Trias and his wife, Julie Noel Gilbert, over the weekend. The police said the suspect had admitted he was the man photographed using Mr. Trias's bank card. (The Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges Young to Reject Pessimism

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 20

 BODY:
President Clinton today urged a troubled new generation of American adults to overcome pessimism and embrace an obligation to community that he portrayed as crucial to the nation's future.
In his message, an address at the University of California at Los Angeles, Mr. Clinton served striking notice of his intent to use the Presidency to preach not just about what government should do, but also what Americans must do. 
 The President's call for young Americans to hew to their responsibilities sounded a more traditional theme than his more familiar monologues on governmental activism. But his aides made clear that it reflected a determined effort to call attention to the moral burdens that citizens still carry.
Today's speech was the first that Mr. Clinton has addressed so explicitly to Generation X, the vaguely defined group of Americans born after 1964 who, public opinion polls suggest, regard the future with unusually scant hope.
 
'A Generation of Seekers'
 "What I have seen today is not a generation of slackers but a generation of seekers, and I am much encouraged," the President said, expressing faith that the young people in the audience and their contemporaries could triumph even in a whirlwind world.
But his speech in mortarboard and gown at Pauley Pavilion on the U.C.L.A. campus was a pointed and Kennedyesque call on the graduating class to "act in the spirit of America" by doing more to contribute to their society and its institutions.
Speaking at an academic convocation marking the university's 75th anniversary, Mr. Clinton issued a stark warning against the example set by members of what F. Scott Fitzgerald called the "Lost Generation." Fitzgerald wrote that that generation had come of age in 1919 to find "all gods dead, all wars fought, all faith in man shaken."
The President said, "Many say that this generation of college graduates is filled with pessimism, with a sense of generational despair that our glory days are behind us." . He said his own generation had been bombarded by unflattering images of today's young adults, and acknowledged that this year's college graduates faced "uncertain times."
But he urged the 9,000 people who filled the gymnasium to turn for answers not just to government but also to "the far, far greater power of the American people to transform themselves, their families and their communities to seize the future and make it yours."
 
An Echo of Kennedy
 As he has in the last week in speeches at Gallaudet University and before the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund Inc., Mr. Clinton portrayed that ideal as an essential complement to his own attempts to use government as an instrument of change.
But his exhortation to young Americans to do more for their country carried a deliberate echo as he reminded listeners that Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, who died Thursday night, had -- as had her first husband -- wanted Americans to see the world as "possibilities, not problems; to build up, not tear down; to unite, not to divide."
The President's emphasis on value-based themes is described by aides as an effort to address what he regards as aspects of American life that are too often neglected. But it has also served to inject new variety into addresses that in recent months had become repetitious soliloquies on health care and crime, and for that reason may serve to distract attention from more sensitive subjects, including efforts by Mr. Clinton and his lawyers to devise a strategy to fend off a lawsuit accusing him of sexual harassment.
As the President noted today, many of those graduating from U.C.L.A. and other universities this year were born in 1973, a year he described as "a watershed year in American life," when he said the steady increase in family incomes that began after World War II came to an abrupt halt.
Some public opinion polls seeking to measure sentiment among members of the generation have found that three in four of those surveyed believe they will never be as prosperous as their parents. But Mr. Clinton insisted today that there was no reason for cynicism, that an American breakdown could be reversed, and that the future remained "something you have to make."
Before his address, he was presented with an honorary medal by the university's chancellor, Charles E. Young, and the citation praised him for having "engaged the spirit of America in a renewed sense of national community."
This was Mr. Clinton's 12th trip to California since he took office, a frequency that is a measure of his concern about his political prospects in a state whose economy is still sagging.
 
Stop at Closed Base
 Even on the way to the convocation, the President made sure that Air Force One landed first in San Bernardino, 70 miles to the east, so that he could visit the former Norton Air Force Base, one of several California military installations that have been closed since the collapse of the former Soviet Union.
Mr. Clinton sought to portray the experience as more of a success than a setback, and noted the local authorities were in the process of transforming the sprawling base into a new international airport.
But he ran into stern words from Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat who is running for re-election this year. She called attention once again to the burdens that cuts in military spending have inflicted on the state by urging the small crowd gathered near a runway to "importune the President to give us some breathing ground" by postponing the next round of base closings from 1995 to 1997.
Mr. Clinton also planned to use his trip to California to raise at least $2.5 million for Democratic candidates for Congress, including Senator Feinstein.

HEADLINE: U.N. to Help U.S. With Haitian Refugees

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The United Nations will work with the Clinton Administration to help insure that refugees from Haiti who fear political retaliation are not forcibly returned, the White House said today.
The new arrangement was agreed on in a one-hour meeting Thursday evening between William Gray, President Clinton's new special adviser on Haiti, and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata, a White House statement said. 
 Mr. Gray, a former Democratic congressman from Pennsylvania, met with ousted Haitian President Jean-Bertrand Aristide for the first time just before the White House meeting. A stepped-up United Nations embargo against Haiti, to include all but humanitarian aid, is set to take effect on Saturday if Haitian military leaders have not stepped down. There was no indication they would do so.
Under the cooperative agreement, the United Nations refugee agency will counsel Haitians and make training available to the United States officials involved in determining who are legitimate political refugees. United Nations refugee officials will also monitor the overall process and help place political refugees in other countries, the White House said.
Mr. Clinton named Mr. Gray and spelled out the new policy on May 8 as criticism mounted that his Administration was sending back to Haiti not only people seeking relief from economic trouble but legitimate political refugees.

HEADLINE: Japan Spares No Expense in Effort to Control Yen

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 20

 BODY:
Japanese officials have contended for months that they cannot accept the Clinton Administration's demands for guaranteed increases in imports because the measures would amount to interference with the free play of the markets. Yet, in another realm, the Japanese Government has engaged in one of the heaviest waves of market intervention in memory in an attempt to manage the value of the yen and keep Japan's exports flowing.
Data on Japan's foreign exchange reserves show that since the beginning of last year, the Bank of Japan has used more than $35 billion in an effort to brake a sharp rise in the value of the yen against the dollar, one of the most sustained and costly campaigns to control currency values ever attempted. 
 Some economists say the intervention amounts to a policy of controlling Japan's trade flows, since the yen's rise -- to 104.32 today in Tokyo trading -- is expected to reduce the huge trade surplus by making Japanese goods more expensive overseas and by encouraging imports.
 
Some New Figures
 Their concern was underscored by the release on Thursday of bilateral trade figures, which showed that the American merchandise trade deficit with Japan soared from $4.63 billion in February to $5.8 billion in March, the third-largest monthly deficit on record.
The critics have also said that the intervention flies in the face of a responsible interplay of supply and demand, a principle to which Japan's Government says it adheres.
"This has been a waste of money," said Kazuaki Harada, the chief economist at the Sanwa Research Institute. "The reason for the yen's rise is the trade surplus. And judging from the continuing large size of the surplus, I think we can expect an even stronger yen."
C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, agrees: "This is the most dramatic example of managed trade in the relationship between the U.S. and Japan over the last year or so. It's very clear that the yen would have strengthened well beyond 100 in the absence of this intervention."
The issue touches on one of the most sensitive aspects of the United States' troubled relationship with Japan -- not just Japan's gaping surplus, but what methods are appropriate for tackling it.
The United States has said Japan must cut its trade surplus or relations cannot improve. The reform-minded Japanese Governments in office since last summer have said they share this goal. But they have asked for more time to devise a plan.
Nevertheless, the Bank of Japan, which operates under the influence of the Finance Ministry, has consistently sold yen to buy dollars, trying to counter heavy purchases of the yen by investors, corporations and speculators, both here and abroad. Those purchases have driven the yen's value to 104.25 yen to the dollar in New York today from 145 yen in 1990.
Japanese Government officials have said the bank's intervention has been aimed at calming jittery markets or smoothing out the many excessively volatile swings in trading. They have also said the yen's appreciation does not reflect underlying economic factors like the anemic economic growth rate or low Japanese interest rates.
Privately, some senior officials characterize the heavy intervention as a holding action. The logic is that if the yen's rise can be halted long enough for the Government to enact a credible program to reduce the surplus, the market will take over and push the yen lower. The problem has been that the previous and current coalition governments have been so weak that they have been unable to push through such a plan.
In some instances, the Bank of Japan has had help from abroad. The Federal Reserve in the United States and other central banks acted in concert with the Bank of Japan earlier this month, spending billions of dollars when the yen suddenly lurched and ignited fears of disruptions in stock and bond markets.
But a number of economists argue that the sustained nature of the Japanese intervention and the huge amounts involved make clear that the effort is an attempt to interfere with market forces and, ultimately, manage trade in Japan's favor.
 
A 'Both Ways' Approach?
 "They are spending money like water," said Richard Koo, a senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute. "If you are saying you are in favor of free trade, that means that you should let the yen go. If you intervene as they have, you are saying you don't want the price-adjustment mechanism to work. You can't have it both ways."
One of the best measures of the intervention by a central bank in the currency markets is its reserves of foreign currencies and gold. Economists and Bank of Japan officials say that increases generally reflect occasions when the bank has been selling yen and buying foreign currencies, usually dollars.
Since February 1993, the value of Japan's reserves has risen from $69.15 billion to $104.6 billion last month, a record high, according to the Bank of Japan. The reserves are likely to increase another $5 billion or more this month, economists say, because of further intervention.
In the last decade, the major industrial nations acted jointly on several occasions to manage exchange rates to achieve their common policy objectives. During a meeting at the Plaza Hotel in New York in September 1985, the governments agreed to reduce the value of the dollar and increase the value of the yen, in part to lower Japan's widening trade surplus. The surplus did decline temporarily, but now it has risen to more than $130 billion annually.
When the Clinton Administration took office, it vowed to attack the Japanese surpluses aggressively. After various Treasury officials hinted that they would not object to an appreciation of the yen, traders got the message. The dollar fell from 125 yen at the beginning of last year to lows of almost 100 yen last August and again earlier this month.
 
A Hard-Hit Sector
 The yen's rise has hurt Japanese exporters badly, making it unprofitable for many of them to sell goods overseas. Economists here estimate that exporters break even at a level of about 115 yen to the dollar and begin to lose money below that.
In addition, the slump in exports has slowed the economy, which is already in the midst of its longest recession since World War II.
Many economists thus contend that Japan should take stronger measures to reduce its trade surplus to avoid the punishment of a rising yen. This could be done with a large increase in public works spending, tax reductions, interest rate reductions or some combination of these steps.
Toshihiro Kiribuchi, a former Finance Ministry official and now an executive at the Omron Corporation, an electronics manufacturer, said he sympathized with the Bank of Japan's heavy intervention. He argued, though, that the ultimate solution was not pouring more money into the currency market but aggressive economic policies to reduce the surplus.
"To stop this, the Japanese Government has to come forward with a very effective package of economic stimulus measures, lower interest rates and come up with more deregulation," Mr. Kiribuchi said. "Without these steps, the whole burden is placed on the shoulders of the Bank of Japan. But it cannot stop the dollar's decline alone."

TALKS ARE CONTINUING
 WASHINGTON, May 20 (Reuters) -- An American official said that the United States and Japan held "good and cordial" trade consultations today and would meet again on Saturday.
"We have had a good and cordial conversation and we will be meeting again," Bowman Cutter, a deputy economic adviser to President Clinton, told reporters.
The two sides met for three hours today, continuing exploratory talks that opened Thursday.
Formal trade negotiations to cut Japan's trade surplus collapsed in February, and the two sides are seeking ways to resume such discussions.

HEADLINE: Migrant Oasis;
Central American Day Laborers Are Drawn to a Suburb

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., May 18

 BODY:
Journeying across nations in search of work, Lazaro Chinchilla arrived here about a month ago to share a run-down bungalow with seven other men in a rugged settlement of migrants like himself.
"Hunger brought us here," Mr. Chinchilla, an immigrant from Guatemala, said the other day as he wandered along one of the dusty roads that lace the settlement, called El Petencito by its residents. "But it feels like we have come to the edge of the earth." 
 In fact, the small community of some 20 bungalows housing slightly more than 100 is only a few steps from the buzz and neon glow of Route 59, a typically suburban strip of dairy marts, fast-food joints and car dealerships in this Rockland County village.
But tucked behind a wooded area alongside a waterfall, El Petencito -- named after part of Guatemala's frontier -- is an outpost of Central American workers who have come here in search of jobs laying bricks, planting trees, mowing lawns, tending gardens, cleaning homes, whatever they can get.
Only a generation or so ago this same cluster of bungalows was known simply as Hyenga Lake, a popular summer retreat for New York City residents seeking a respite from the urban grind. Its transformation into a migrant camp underscores how the quest for work has driven some of the metropolitan New York region's newest immigrants to improbable places.
The Guatemalans and Salvadorans who have settled in El Petencito are little different from the Mexican day laborers who gather at dawn on a street corner in Mamaroneck in Westchester County or the Hondurans who wait each morning for jobs along Main Street in Mount Kisco farther up county. The Center for Immigrants Rights in Manhattan estimates that there are about 3,000 such day laborers in the region, most of them from Central American countries.
But the striking thing about El Petencito -- where the yards and paths are a jumble of clothes lines, wooden crates, gardening tools and broken cars -- is that, only 25 miles north of the George Washington Bridge, it resembles a tightly knit and secluded Central American village. At dusk, men gather alongside bungalows trading stories and news about their homeland as the rattle of pans and dishes echo from within the houses.
Many of its settlers -- including some who admit they are in the country illegally -- say they are simply passing through with the aim of amassing enough savings to take back a nest egg for their families at home.
Meanwhile, El Petencito represents an inexpensive way station where the rents -- which residents say run $600 to $700 a month for each bungalow -- are split among the men who cram themselves into its bungalows.
"I sleep on the floor or wherever," said Mr. Chinchilla, who is 45 years old.
This is not the first time that Mr. Chinchilla has come to Spring Valley for work. He spent a year here in 1987 washing dishes at a local restaurant for $300 a week before returning to his wife and four children with $1,500 in savings.
This time he makes as much as $50 a day in landscaping and construction work. "I don't know when I will go back," he said. "But this area is good because there are many jobs."
Not everyone is pleased about El Petencito, most of which is within the boundaries of Clarkstown. As the newcomers have proliferated in the last few years, some longtime residents have complained of litter, overcrowding and other problems that they contend have put a strain on local services.
"I've been down there a couple of times, and I'm appalled by the conditions," said Spring Valley's Mayor, Allan Thompson. "I'm sure most of them are law-abiding people who want an opportunity. But it is not the kind of environment I like to see close to my village."
The entrance to El Petencito is marked by rows of metal mailboxes often stuffed with letters arriving from abroad. The people of the settlement gather there each morning, on the edges of Route 59, to secure a day's work from anyone who will hire them.
Their way of life has its risks. Juan Hernandez, 39, said the owner of a landscaping company had hired him to plant trees and flowers one day four months ago. At the end of the day, however, the man drove Mr. Hernandez back to the settlement and refused to pay.
"He told me he'd pay me the next day, but never did," Mr. Hernandez recalled. "Almost all of us have been through something like that. It's part of the life here."
These days, though, he works full time at a factory where he prints designs on shirts. Earning about $200 a week, Mr. Hernandez regularly wires money to his wife and three children in Guatemala.
"It saddens me not to be with them." he said. "But it's a sacrifice that I have to make to support my family."
Jobs are not the only thing that bring the newcomers to suburban hamlets. Many say that such areas offers them a level of security and tranquillity that they feel is lacking in larger cities like New York and Los Angeles.
"My intention was to stay in New York City when I came," said Juan Jose Ramirez, as he washed his car at the edge of a lake near his bungalow.
"But in the city," the 22-year-old Guatemalan immigrant continued, "we would live in despair, locked up inside apartments. This is much calmer; it reminds me of our country."
Likewise, Alejandro Medina, 22, said he left Bridgeport, Conn., where he was living with a friend, after his family urged him to join them in El Petencito. "They told me that there was work and that I would be living with my own people," he recalled.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Migrant laborers from Central America have established a settlement in Spring Valley, N.Y., seeking jobs and the security of a suburban community. A few waited near the settlement along Route 59 yesterday for offers of work. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)(pg. 23)

HEADLINE: Interest Rates Move Up On Weakness in Dollar

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Interest rates rose yesterday, as the dollar's weakness and rising commodity prices continued to put pressure on the prices of Treasury issues.
The Treasury's 30-year bond fell 26/32 yesterday, to 8711/32 , while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.30 percent, from 7.23 percent on Thursday. 
 The dollar helped to pull down bond prices as it fell sharply against the German mark amid signs that the Bundesbank of Germany had little intention of lowering interest rates soon. Despite the Federal Reserve's move this week to push up short-term interest rates by half a percentage point, German rates remain up to a percentage point higher.
A weaker dollar diminishes the value of dollar-denominated assets like Treasury securities, making them less attractive to foreign investors.
 
 
Jump in Precious Metals
 Traders were also troubled by strong upward movement in precious metal prices, causing the Commodity Research Bureau index, a closely watched gauge of future inflation, to gain more than a point.
Adding to the bond market's worries were big auctions of Treasury bills and notes next week, said James Hale, a fixed-income analyst for MMS International, a Wall Street research and analysis firm.
"Dealers do not want to be stuck with a lot of paper in a bear market," Mr. Hale said. "One of the reasons the market is particularly nervous is its memory of the May 11 auction of 10-year notes, one of the worst auctions in a long time. Similarly, the five-year note auction last month was also poor. And that has to be on the back of their minds."
For that reason, Mr. Hale said, some dealers are looking to push up yields ahead the auctions to make the Treasury securities more attractive to investors and thus easier to sell.
Aside from the regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, the Treasury will be selling $17 billion of new two-year notes on Tuesday and $11 billion of five-year notes on Wednesday, along with $16.5 billion of new one-year bills on Thursday.
 The auctions are expected to be an important gauge of whether the market's sentiment has turned around.
In when-issued trading, the two-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 5.81 percent, up 4 basis points, or four-hundredths of a percentage point, from Thursday. The five-year notes were being offered at 6.59 percent, up 6 basis points.
The outstanding one-year bill rose 2 basis points, to 4.84 percent.
Analysts say the bond market will also focus next week on the Government's report on April durable goods orders. While the consensus of forecasts for the survey calls for a 1 percent rise, Mr. Hale thinks it will be more like two-tenths of a percent. "The number has potential for being bullish and positive for the market," he said.
Traders showed little appetite throughout the day to challenge the market's direction one way or the other. They were nervous about the dollar and sold into anything that looked like an uptick.
The Fed's decision to raise short-term rates earlier this week for the fourth time this year, this time by half a percentage point, went a long way toward calming the financial markets.
 
 
Thoughts of Another Rise
 But some economists believe there may eventually be yet another rate increase. Fourteen of 30 analysts in a Reuters survey said yesterday that the Fed could raise short-term interest rates again as early as July, while 13 said the Fed would not move until later this year.
On Tuesday, the Fed raised the discount rate -- the rate it charges banks for overnight loans -- to 3.5 percent from 3 percent. It also allowed the target for the Federal funds rate -- the rate charged for overnight loans between banks -- to rise to 4.25 percent from 3.75 percent.
One economist predicted a rate increase in June, and two said the central bank had completed its monetary tightening for 1994.
"After pushing interest rates up 125 basis points in about three and a half months, the central bank will take a moment to see what it has done," said David Blitzer, vice president and chief economist at Standard & Poor's. "Moreover, in the past, the discount rate has often been used to signal the end of a series of tightening or easing moves."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. Outlines Its Asian Strategy to Shareholders

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SHREVEPORT, La., May 20

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation displayed its strategy today for taking advantage of rapidly expanding Asian markets by building far more cars and trucks there, especially in China. Company executives said that they would begin production in India and Indonesia by the end of the year, and that they were in final negotiations to make mini-vans and subcompact cars in China.
These plans, set forth at the company's annual meeting, held here today, mark G.M.'s latest effort to expand its vastly profitable foreign operations even as its North American automotive units pursue the far more modest goal of showing a net profit this year after repeated losses. 
 General Motors is already leading the Big Three in China. It owns 30 percent of a $100 million joint venture that plans, despite obstacles and delays, to begin making small pickup trucks, similar to the Chevrolet S-10, and sport utility vehicles, like the Chevrolet Blazer, early next year.
 
 
Ford Is Far Behind
 The Ford Motor Company produces nothing in China, although it is exploring several joint ventures for components production and auto assembly. It is close to at least one agreement, to produce plastic components in Shanghai.
Because of its 1987 purchase of American Motors, the Chrysler Corporation participates in a 10-year-old joint venture that produces about 15,000 Jeep Cherokee sport utility vehicles a year in Beijing. The factory also produces about 35,000 other sport utilities derived from a Russian chassis, and Chrysler is considering trying to assemble small cars as well.
Together with Mercedes-Benz, Chrysler is also a finalist for the South China Mini-Van Project, a joint venture the Chinese Government is trying to set up to produce about 60,000 mini-vans and 100,000 engines a year.
Auto makers see the world's developing nations, especially in Asia, as their best prospects for the sort of sales growth no longer possible in mature markets. "Eighty-two percent of the world's people live in the new and expanding markets outside the traditional markets of North America, Europe, Japan and Australia," Louis R. Hughes, president of G.M. Europe and head of international operations, told G.M. shareholders at the annual meeting. "Asian markets are experiencing near-explosive growth and are a prime focus for G.M.'s expansion drive."
 
 
More Exports From Europe
 Mr. Hughes noted that exports from G.M. Europe to South America, Eastern Europe, Russia and the Pacific Rim were five times as high as their level of three years ago.
Preparations to start making trucks by G.M.'s current joint venture in China, formed in 1992 with the Jinbei Automotive Company in the northeastern industrial belt, came to a virtual halt last year as the Government moved to cool China's rapid economic growth. G.M. has invested $30 million of the $100 million total cost. Michael Meyerand, a G.M. spokesman, said that training and the renovation of an antiquated assembly line were now progressing well enough to allow production to begin in early 1995.
G.M.'s automotive components group is already involved in eight business ventures there, he said. China requires cars to have at least 50 percent local content, although Mr. Hughes is aiming for at least 60 percent.
The partnerships would make a new version of the Chevrolet Lumina mini-van as well as Opel Corsa subcompacts like those already produced in Europe and Brazil.
In other Asian joint ventures, G.M. plans to start building 18,000 cars and trucks annually in Indonesia this year, and 20,000 Astra subcompacts a year in a partnership with Hindustan Motors of India in the third quarter.
At a news conference after the shareholders meeting, G.M.'s chief executive, John F. Smith Jr., left open the question of whether President Clinton's threatened denial of preferred trading status to China over its human rights record could block the company's plans.
"We're hoping that doesn't happen," Mr. Smith said of the possibility of trade sanctions. "That's caused quite an issue." Mr. Clinton's decision on whether to renew what is called most-favored-nation status for China is due by June 3.
General Motors held its annual meeting in Shreveport to show off its pickup trucks and a local assembly plant that makes them. The site of the meeting, far from Detroit and other large cities, limited attendance to 364 people, the lowest level in 45 years.

Shareholders were told that the No. 1 auto maker was planning to expand its operations in Asia, particularly in China. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Hiring Welfare Recipients and Making Them Management

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Isabel Cruz's life used to revolve around the 7th and 27th day of each month. Those were the days the welfare checks came.
Then her caseworker handed her a flier from a South Bronx company whose business is attending to the elderly and ill in their own homes. After 11 years on public assistance, Miss Cruz, 34, got a job. After four years with the company, she is running for its board. 
 Miss Cruz works for Cooperative Home Care, a home-aide service begun nine years ago with 20 workers. Today, there are 300, almost all former welfare recipients.
At a time when the nation is focused on the effectiveness of the welfare system, Cooperative Home Care is one of several organizations, both profit and nonprofit, that revolve around finding jobs for people on public assistance.
But while most such organizations place clients in a variety of fields, Cooperative Home Care focuses on one field, and not only trains its employees but also makes them partners in the business.
 
Program Being Copied
 The goal is to improve conditions and promote careers in an industry in which poor people are likely to land jobs. The philosophy: better salaries and training in what has historically been a low-paying, almost transient field will increase motivation and, hence, the level of care.
Jack Litzenberg, a program officer with the Charles Stewart Mott Foundation, which has helped finance Cooperative Home Care, says his organization is now working with other "sectoral development" projects, one in Philadelphia to develop child-care careers and another in Appalachia in food processing.
An operation modeled after Cooperative Home Care opened last year in Philadelphia, one is starting this year in Boston and two more are slated for unannounced Midwestern cities later this year. The Ford Foundation has pledged $400,000 and the Mott Foundation $1 million to help Cooperative Home Care set up the new companies and train personnel. According to the plan, the new cooperatives should become self-financing within two years as they attract clients and a stream of revenue.
"It's a wonderful recipe for success," said Margaret MacAdam, who studies home health care at the Baycrest Center for Geriatrics in Toronto. "They're the model."
The Visiting Nurse Service of New York, which taps 24 home-care agencies for aides, consistently rates the cooperative in the top four or five, said Brenda Lowther-Mandel, in charge of contracting with home-care agencies.
Each day, Miss Cruz goes to the apartment of Lillian Goldson, 96 and blind after two strokes. She makes strawberry shakes, describes the weather, dispenses medicine.
Miss Cruz welcomed the revolution in her life, though she allowed that it wasn't easy. "I was nervous and excited at the same time," she said. Like more than 80 percent of her co-workers, Miss Cruz is a company co-owner: she is buying her $1,000 share in $3.65 weekly installments.
The cooperative recruits half its employees -- most of them black or Hispanic, and all but two women -- through word of mouth and half through New York City's Department of Social Services. On the basis of references and interviews, one of five job applicants is selected.
The workers must pass a four-week training program, with courses ranging from bathing a patient to handling emergencies. In addition, there are regular brush-up sessions.
Rick Surpin, 44, the cooperative president and a longtime community organizer, started the cooperative in response to poor people's statements that they want jobs more than anything else. His strategy, developed in the early 1980's when he worked for the Community Service Society, was to pinpoint a growing economic sector and to improve job satisfaction and the workers' sense of well-being.
 
Less Profit, More Pay
 There are 70,000 home-care aides in New York City. The industry, experts says, traditionally pays slightly more than the $4.25 minimum wage to a part-time work force with no benefits.
Cooperative Home Care pays its workers $7 to $8 an hour and offers medical, dental and vacation benefits. But cooperative workers are still far from financially comfortable, with most earning just a bit over $200 a week.
The company has been set up as a for-profit enterprise to enable employee ownership and dividend payments. Cooperative employees split profits of $150,000 a year on $4.5 million in revenues. The dividends amount to a return of 20 percent to 50 percent. Workers must sell their shares for the $1,000 value when they leave the cooperative.
Aside from profit sharing, the company is bucking industry practices by guaranteeing at least 30 hours of work a week.
"They have created a workplace environment that is startlingly different from most of the home-care agencies in New York City," said Donald Gould, vice president of the United Hospital Fund, a New York hospital philanthropy and policy center that has given Cooperative Home Care $150,000. "Better care comes from better jobs."
Continuing training is vital, in part because learning sessions allow staff members to gather as a group, a break from what are often monotonous and lonely jobs. Four times a year, aides gather to learn new techniques and discuss problems.
It is this active involvement Mr. Surpin most values. He says it represents a shift in mind-set for the aides, who often had long felt it was best for them to avoid attention.
"These women thought if somebody saw them, they'd criticize them," he said. "Now, they become some of the most important people in the world to middle-class people worried about their parents and grandparents. That changes their lives in a fairly substantial way."
Phyllis Brown is an example. She takes care of Annie Peterson, who has diabetes, is nearly deaf and needs an ulcer treated twice a day, in the Jackson Avenue area of the South Bronx. "We are a bunch of serious people, intelligent, good workers," Ms. Brown said.
Mrs. Peterson said of her aide, "Ain't no problem with her."
"Am I a good cook?" Ms. Brown asked.
"A-plus," Mrs. Peterson shot back.
"See, I think that's what she loves me for."

At the prospect of holding a job for the first time in her life she said, "I was nervous and excited at the same time." Miss Cruz attended Lillian Goldson, 96, at her apartment. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)
