HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Istanbul

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL; ALAN COWELL is the head of the Rome bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
In a world that is changing rapidly, Istanbul retains a flavor of the exotic that seems increasingly rare, even in Turkey itself. Although the city's outer limits have been transformed by high-rises and freeways, the central core of old Istanbul remains intact: the six minarets of the Sultan Ahmet mosque, the clamorous tangle of the Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace and the spangled confines of the Bosporous itself with its shoreline villas and grand Ottoman palaces.
That is not to say, though, that the newer areas are without attraction. For Istanbul's smart set -- far more at home with Armani suits than with any vestigial memory of the fez -- the city's residential spread onto the eastern shoreline of the Bosporous provides the setting for some of the trendiest new discos and restaurants. 
 And, with the expanding Istanbul International Festival offering theater, classical music and jazz from May through July, the city is also striving to carve a place on a cultural circuit offering a range of drama, opera and ballet.
Yet, for some long-time visitors, the charm of the city is still its simpler offerings -- the ferry ride on the Bosporous to the fish restaurants of its northernmost settlements, or just browsing through the wares of rug dealers, enjoying the bargaining without a commitment to buy.
To all this, though, there is a serious word of warning. Kurdish separatists have exploded two bombs in the Grand Bazaar this year and have threatened a war on tourism similar to that waged in Egypt by Muslim fundamentalists. There is, so far, no State Department warning urging Americans to stay away from Istanbul, but it would be imprudent to travel there if the attacks continued.
Less seriously, the Turkish lira is tumbling against the dollar and many of the more expensive restaurants and hotels quote prices in dollars or adjust their lira price every week to account for this. The tumbling lira helps Americans in places that quote their prices in Turkish lira, like many restaurants, but not big hotels that are priced in dollars.
 
 
Events
 The dominant event in this year's Istanbul calendar is the Istanbul Festival, which started in April with a movie section, moved on to theater, classical music from June 15 to July 21 and ends with jazz from July 10 to 25.
Much of the programming, particularly for the later part of the festival, is still provisional. For precise listings closer to performance time, The Guide, a bimonthly Istanbul publication (telephone 264 25 27) costing around $2, promises details.
The classical section (258 32 12) offers an array of works by Brahms, Wagner and Beethoven, played by several orchestras including the Dresden Philharmonic, the BBC Symphony Orchestra and the Kirov Opera and Chorus, all at St. Irene's Church on the grounds of the Topkapi Palace. Ticket prices range from $10 to $25. Soloists giving recitals at St. Irene's include the flutist James Galway and the cellist Julian Lloyd Weber. The Ballet National de Marseille and the Spanish Ballet of Clara Romana are both set to perform in Istanbul's Open Air Theater between June 24 and 29.
The jazz program at the Open Air Theater, Harbiye, Istanbul, between July 10 and 25 promises performances by a wide range of jazz and rock artists including the Bobby McFerrin trio, Gary Moore, Jack Bruce, Ginger Baker and Neil Young.
 
 
Sightseeing
 Many of Istanbul's traditional sights are in the Sultan Ahmet district, where the mosque itself, the former basilica of Hagia Sophia, now a museum (open 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M., entrance fee around $1, closed Monday), the Topkapi Palace (9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M., entrance fee $1.50, closed Tuesday) and the Grand Bazaar (9 A.M. to 7 P.M., no entrance fee, closed Sunday) are all within easy walking distance of one another.
With crowded sidewalks and too much traffic, Istanbul is not really a walker's city, so it comes as something of a relief that city authorities have broadened the sidewalks around the Sultan Ahmet district. And, innovatively, Istiklal Caddesi, the main shopping street running from Taksim Square down toward the Bosporous, has been turned into a pedestrian area with a turn-of-the-century tramline running down its middle. Sadly, the old Galata Bridge across the Golden Horn, with its accumulation of water-level eateries and vendors beneath it, has been replaced by a newer, more sterile version that, while more suited to the weight of Istanbul's modern traffic flows, offers none of its predecessor's bustle.
No visit to Istanbul is complete without an hour's Bosporous Ferry ride from Eminonu, the principle boat-landing on the Golden Horn near the main Sirkeci railroad station, to Rumeli Kavagi on the western bank at the northern tip of the Bosporous and Anadolu Kavagi on the eastern bank. The ferry from the Eminonu jetty at 10:35 A.M. and 1:35 P.M. and a return ticket costs just over $1. The slightly rundown vessels zigzag up the Bosporous, stopping at just about every landing on the way and giving spectacular views of the two soaring bridges connecting Europe and Asia and of the 15th-century Rumeli Hisari fortress.
Once at Rumeli Kavagi or Anadolu Kavagi there is ample time for a meal at one of many fish restaurants where a lunch of freshly caught Black Sea fish with Turkish meze (hors d'ouevres) costs between $10 and $15.
 
 
Where to Stay
 Istanbul's hotel operators seem to have concentrated in recent years on creating spectacular new places with magnificent views of the Bosporous and high prices so that there is a wide choice of top-flight accommodation. In a lower price and amenity range several hotels offer accommodations with more unusual or historic connotations, albeit at a price. The ornate Pera Palas (Tepebasi, 251 45 60, fax 251 40 89) is the same 19th-century establishment once used by travelers on the old Orient Express as they completed the European leg of their journeys farther east. Close to the American Consulate, the hotel's six suites and some of its 139 rooms have views over the Golden Horn and the minarets beyond. A double costs $180 plus tax.
Less expensive and equally quaint is the 20-room Yesil Ev (5 Kabasakal Caddesi, Sultanahmet, 517 67 85, fax 517 67 80), a restored Ottoman villa equipped throughout with period furniture from the 19th century. It lies close to the Sultan Ahmet mosque and the Topkapi palace. A double costs $125 plus tax.
Budget: Budget hotels abound in the Sultan Ahmet district, as they always have. They are generally smaller and can be rough-and-ready. Residents recommend the following:Historia (23 Amiral Tafdil Sokak, Sultanahmet, 517 74 72, fax 516 81 69), has 27 rooms costing $80 for a double plus tax, and Cordial House (8 Bayram Firin Sokak, Sultanahmet, 518 05 76, fax 516 41 08), with 10 rooms; a double is $45 plus tax.
 Luxury: In this category, the Ciragan Palace Kempinski (Ciragan, Besiktas, telephone 258 33 77, fax 259 66 86) is right on the Bosporous shoreline. Some of its suites are in a restored Ottoman palace that also houses a casino. It has 294 rooms and 29 suites. A double is $240 plus 15 percent tax for a Bosporous-view room and $210 plus tax for a view inland over a park.
The Conrad (Yildiz Bulvari, Besiktas, 227 30 00, fax 259 66 67) commands a Bosporous view from higher above the water and looks over the Yildiz Imperial gardens. Among its 627 rooms and 36 suites, a double costs $220 plus tax for a Bosporous view, and $205 plus tax for a garden view.
 
Where to Eat
 Istanbul's restaurants have boomed in recent years with the economic turnaround of the 1980's and the sudden appearance of a new middle class looking for the same sophistication they would find in Europe. At the same time, it is still possible to eat for a few dollars on a plate of doner kebab and other Turkish specialties at eateries near the main sites in Sultan Ahmet.
For the smart set, the in place is 29 (Yirmidokuz in Turkish) at Ulus Parki, Etiler (265 61 81). It has a stunning Bosporous view and the chef is French. Dinner with wine will cost a minimum of $40 a person, but, for free, visitors can watch Istanbul's see-and-be-seen crowd. Starters include seafood crepes at $6, artichokes in olive oil at $5 and smoked salmon at $8. A la carte specialties include poached sea bass (around $10), lamb fillet ($8) and a variety of kebabs and kofte meatballs at $5 to $8.
Korfez, on the Asian side of the Bosporous at 78 Korfez Caddesi, Kanlica (216-413 4314, closed Monday), is another seaside place in a similar price range. The specialty is seabass oven-roasted in layers of rock-salt above and below it. Then, when it is brought to the table, the waiters crack open the salty shell and serve the fish inside.
In a lower price range, Sureyya at 26 Istinye Caddesi, Istinye (277 58 56, closed Sunday), is one of Istanbul's old favorites, offering Russian, Turkish and European cuisine. Caviar blinis and chicken Kiev are specialties. Prices for dinner with wine start at around $25 a person.
Slightly cheaper is the Asitane in the Kariye Hotel, 18 Kariye Cami Sokak, Edirnekapi (534 84 14), next to the Church of Chora. The cuisine is known as Nouvelle Ottoman and Turkish classical music is played while you eat. Asitane offers three fixed-price menus ranging from $12 to $18 without wine and all composed of traditional Turkish cuisine. The most extensive, at $18, features an array of dishes made with olive oil, such as stuffed vegetables, followed by hot appetizers, the Sultan's Favorite veal stew on a bed of aubergine puree, salads and a choice of desserts.
For budget travelers, any number of eateries at Sultan Ahmet offer cheap doner, rice, lentil soup, beans, lamb dishes and dessert. One of the oldest is Sultanahmet Koftecisi (12A Divanyolu Caddesi, 513 14 38) known for its meatballs. The average price of a meal is around $5.
 
Shopping
 Shopping centers on the Grand Bazaar, where bargaining is routine except in those stores that display and insist on fixed prices. A canny bargainer never pays more than half the starting price, and it may be necessary to feign departure from the shop on several occasions to force prices down. Those who consider this a little undignified can, however, turn to the fixed-price stores at most up-market hotels, where prices are higher but there's more a guarantee of quality on such items as rugs, leatherware and jewelry.
Turkey has made much in recent years of its advances in the textiles business and the good quality items -- jeans and shirts -- abound, particularly in central areas such as Sisli. January and July are sale months, denoted in Turkish by the word indirim.
For those who'd like an older view of Turkish fabrics, Ottoman fabrics are on display at the Topkapi Palace from May 18 to the end of June.

HEADLINE: Seduction or Virtue?

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

DATELINE: Washington

 BODY:
In a town where all socializing is ultimately political, cynics might be forgiven for wondering about dinner at the Huffingtons'.
In less than two years, Representative Michael Huffington, Republican of California, and his wife, Arianna Stassinopoulos Huffington, a biographer and television talk-show host, have been the hosts of 20 dinners with what they call "critical mass." 
 Their idea is to have a diverse group of guests, all connected to a given topic, come together to discuss it and lend their spirit of altruism to problem solving. Their goal, the Huffingtons say, is nothing less than changing the face and focus of American politics: they believe that citizen-to-citizen help could make big government obsolete.
Certainly no one has seen socially conscious dinner parties of the Huffington ilk in the capital before. Instead of the usual talk of politics and economics, the Huffingtons serve up conversations on health care, volunteerism and spirituality along with sumptuous meals amid crystal, candlelight and waiters.
And in a town that is socially bifurcated by race and income, a Huffington guest list includes not only the usual lawmakers, lawyers and business leaders, but also people like Veronica Parke, who heads a soup kitchen here called Martha's Table, and Shahrazad Ali, the author of the provocative book "The Blackman's Guide to Understanding the Blackwoman."
A conservative lion like Irving Kristol is just as likely to be at a Huffington party as is a liberal like the Hollywood producer Norman Lear. At a dinner in April on volunteerism, Hannah Hawkins, who operates a shelter for young children in the Anacostia section of Washington, was as closely listened to as Allan Luks, executive director of Big Brothers/Big Sisters of New York and author of "The Healing Power of Doing Good."
"I'd never been to anything quite like that," said Alan Keyes, a black Republican who was among the guests at a Huffington dinner on race relations. A former State Department official in the Reagan Administration, Mr. Keyes accused the Republican Party of racial bias and lack of support when he ran for the Senate from Maryland in 1992. "The range of people was unusual," he said of the dinner.
Some pundits think the Huffingtons may have tapped into a new politics of virtue, a result of Mrs. Huffington's longstanding interest in melding spirituality and politics. Mrs. Huffington's television show on the conservative National Empowerment Network here is called "Critical Mass." And her new book, "The Fourth Instinct: The Call of the Soul" (Simon & Schuster), centers on her theory that altruism is the fourth instinct, after survival, sex and power.
But others take a more pragmatic view.
They point out that Mr. Huffington, 46, who became wealthy in Texas oil, is running for the Senate seat of Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, and has said he may spend as much as $15 million on the contest. Two years ago, Mr. Huffington, then a political neophyte, set a national record for a House race when he spent $5.2 million to unseat a nine-term Republican incumbent, Robert Lagomarsino, from the Santa Barbara district. Mr. Huffington doesn't discount the possibility of a run for the White House.
The Huffingtons build their dinner parties around a belief in a spiritual reformation of American life, a kind of New Age noblesse-oblige reliance on the compassion of the rich toward the less fortunate. Although that credo hasn't worked, neither sees it as a political liability.
"People can make anything look foolish," Mrs. Huffington, 43, said. "There is no point in being in politics and censoring what you believe."
Mr. Huffington, a political moderate whose Senate ambitions have the support of the Republican Party, said that he and his wife of eight years share a spiritual outlook on life and politics.
"It goes back to when we met," he said. "The first question out of my mouth when I met her in San Francisco was, 'What's the most important thing in your life?' She said, 'God.' We both believe in giving back, in a higher power, in looking at the best. I really believe that she is my soul mate."
They live in a mansion in the Wesley Heights section of Washington with their daughters, Isabella, 3, and Christiana, 5.
The first year he was in Congress, Mr. Huffington donated his salary -- $133,000 before taxes -- to the Partnership for the Children of Santa Barbara County, a bipartisan volunteer organization founded by Mrs. Huffington that helps needy children. Mr. Huffington does volunteer work and requires that members of his staff do so, too. Mrs. Huffington makes a point of working in a soup kitchen or lending a hand at a hospital while campaigning for her husband.
Jane Ikard, a longtime Washington social observer and consultant with the Joint Center for Political Studies, a research organization, said of Mrs. Huffington: "She's a brilliant girl, very personable and charming. She's a person who does instead of sitting around criticizing."
Mrs. Huffington, a ginger-haired native of Greece, was president of the Cambridge Union, a prestigious debating society at Cambridge University. Throughout each dinner, she guides the conversation, tape records it and takes notes.
"The format was like a talk show," said Frances Murphy, publisher of The Washington Afro-American newspapers in Washington and Baltimore, and a guest at the race relations dinner. "She put the subject out and gave introductory remarks and people discussed it from various angles. It was structured, but it was very, very pleasant."
The guests aren't necessarily friends or acquaintances of the Huffingtons. The dinner on race relations, for example, was put together by Mrs. Huffington and Armstrong Williams, a black conservative who is a syndicated radio talk-show host and a columnist.
Marsh Ward and Julia Lightfoot, founders of Clean and Sober Streets, a local program for homeless addicts and alcoholics, were mildly amused at being invited to the dinner in April on volunteerism. But they were soon engaged in lively conversations with James Pinkerton, a young conservative from the Bush Administration who tried to create a new approach to government and to solving social problems.
Mark A. Bloomfield, an economic consultant, who himself puts together dinners on economic topics, sees such efforts as attempts to change the "whole policy-making process in Washington."
"The way people learn and engage in debate is changing," Mr. Bloomfield said. "The Mr.-Smith-comes-to-Washington method of witness, hearing and legislation I'm not sure works anymore. Rather, it's through informal off-the-record discussions and debate."
The Huffingtons maintain that their dinners, initiated by Mrs. Huffington, are not politics as usual or even a bid to build a broad coalition of supporters for Mr. Huffington.
"Certainly, everything a spouse does that's positive helps the other spouse," Mrs. Huffington said. "But whether Michael was running for the Senate or not, I would do my show, I would have the dinners, I would do my books. These are ongoing, long-term concerns of mine and independent of Michael's career and much beyond Michael's career."
Noting that her husband has proposed legislation that would provide tax credits for people who volunteer their time, Mrs. Huffington said that the couple's quest was "how to seduce people into doing good."
Of the ultimate political goal of being in the White House, she once told a Los Angeles Times reporter: "There are many people who have been in the White House and have achieved nothing dramatic. What we are talking about is a crusade, which is so much bigger than being in the White House."

Michael A. Holt and Alice W. Maggin

 BODY:

HEADLINE: Bottom-Fishing for a Manhattan Co-op

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
EVERY New Yorker has seen advertisements for co-op apartments that seem too cheap to believe. What are those apartments really like?
To find out, this reporter tried to see every apartment listed in the May 1 classified section of The New York Times that met the following guidelines: full two-bedroom apartments under $200,000, one-bedrooms under $100,000, studios under $65,000; between the Battery and 96th Street -- Manhattan's prime co-op area -- with carrying charges for two-bedrooms under $1,400 a month, one-bedrooms under $1,100, studios under $800. 
 Apartments on or below the second floor of doorman buildings were excluded as were walk-ups of more than two flights because the market for such apartments is a more specialized one.
The more than 50 apartments viewed seemed to be clustered in certain areas: around 70th Street on West End Avenue, in the Upper East Side east of Third Avenue and on the fringes of midtown, Chelsea and Murray Hill, although there were exceptions. Surprisingly, there were few apartments in the heart of Greenwich Village or in the East Village, SoHo or TriBeCa and, not surprisingly, there were none in the blocks directly off Fifth Avenue or on Central Park West.
The owners of these apartments often expressed disbelief that their apartments -- priced so low -- had not sold. But as interest rates have risen, owners and agents say, New Yorkers and would-be New Yorkers have come out in force to look at apartments all over town.
While the wealthy may delegate one real estate broker to do their looking for them, less wealthy buyers often comb the want ads themselves, visiting open houses held by owners and brokers alike and working with as many as a dozen agents.
Many of these shoppers are out for bargains. They may feel they can still find a steal, or they may be just looking. They may make an offer far below the asking price.
Many owners seemed eager to bargain further; one woman said she had told potential purchasers to "just put something on the table -- anything."
In the real estate business, bargain hunters are known as "bottom fishers" and right now there is quite a range of apartments to fish for.
The seventh-floor apartment Zelda Eden is selling is next to her current apartment at 255 West End Avenue, between 70th and 71st Streets. It is a classic prewar Upper West Side apartment: high ceilings, original moldings, a maid's half-bath off the tiled kitchen. It has a view of West End Avenue from each of its two bedrooms and a slice of the Hudson River from the living room.
Yet it hasn't sold, despite its $179,000 price.
"I've learned the hard way," Ms. Eden said. "I now put the maintenance in the ad. I now put the square footage in the ad." The maintenance is $1,025, and the apartment has 1,000 square feet.
"When I didn't list the maintenance," she said, "they'd hang up the minute they heard it. They'd hang up the minute they heard the square footage. Since it's been on the market I've heard everything: it's too small, it's too big, it's too dark and it's too light.
"One person who was single told me it was too small. When I was single I lived in a place where I could touch the sides of the living room. What do people expect for $179,000 -- 1,500 square feet and an $800 maintenance?"
ACROSS town, Bill Brandt is trying to sell his one-bedroom at 320 East 42d Street in the Tudor City complex for $99,000. The 21st-floor unit is beautifully restored and has what Mr. Brandt calls a "Euro kitchen" -- a one-piece stainless steel unit with sink, stove and refrigerator, built into about as much space as a large hall closet. There are views of midtown and plenty of sunlight.
Mr. Brandt had lived in Florida for the last few years and rented the apartment out for "about $1,400."
"It's a great location, right near the U.N.," he said, "and if I don't sell it, I'll keep renting it out. The maintenance is $720, so with the tax breaks, I'm making money, but I'd like to get it off my back."
Alfred Tomaselli, who is selling a studio at 237 East 54th Street, near the Citicorp Center and down the block from Vong, the hot French-Thai restaurant, has been running his own advertisements since August 1993.
"Once they hear the square footage they say it's just too small," he said, sitting in a pleasant but tiny studio, with a view of backyard greenery. He is asking $49,500.
"I tell them it's 325 square feet," he said. "Actually, it's smaller than that, but I want them to at least see it before turning it down."
Mr. Tomaselli, who is leaving New York City, said he initially had another obstacle besides the size: Banks would not lend money to buy studio apartments.
"I took it upon myself to locate financial institutions," he said, "so when somebody is interested I can give them some names of lenders who guarantee they will not preclude the loan based on the square footage. But it's an uphill struggle I seem to be fighting. I just can't make this apartment bigger."
Mr. Tomaselli's lament is a familiar one and, after viewing the 50 apartments offered at prices below the average -- the Halstead Property Company's statistics, for example, show the average studio in Manhattan sells for $106,570 -- it seemed that many had what might be called a fatal flaw: They were smaller than average, had higher-than-average maintenance or had badly blocked views.
Agents and owners countered with a logical argument: If they didn't have those problems they wouldn't be so cheap.
None of the apartments viewed had a location generally acknowledged to be unsafe and none were totally dark. About a dozen had obstructed views. Three overlooked a ramp to the Queens Midtown Tunnel, although, oddly enough, they were quiet, at least when the insulated windows were closed.
Then there were apartments that had drawbacks like hefty maintenance, small size or marginal location but that also had one unusual selling point: a huge common garden or roof rights. Many of these involved trading off a bargain apartment in a spectacular prewar building in a great location for a view of the courtyard of the same building or the water tower of the neighboring one.
Sometimes it appeared that the only drawback was that the building was built after World War II.
At 310 East 70th Street, between Second and First Avenues, Apartment 7E is a 1,300-square-foot two-bedroom with two full baths. Unlike many postwar apartments, it has a striking L-shaped living/dining room whose 20-foot-long wall has five double-hung aluminum windows in a row.
The windows have rare narrow moldings and muntins and are unpainted; their matte aluminum is effective, and the layout provides a loft-like ambiance. The bathrooms have been left in their original late 50's state.
This sunny apartment whose views are of nondescript buildings across the street was advertised for $196,000 but the broker explained that that price was a mistake.
The relocation company that owns it actually is asking $191,500. The maintenance is $1,055 (maintenances on the Upper East Side are generally higher than on the Upper West Side, and for the size of this apartment, this maintenance is considered average to low, say brokers not involved in the sale).
A similar apartment was found on a comparable block on the Upper West Side, at 200 West 79th Street. There, a large fifth-floor postwar apartment also had what was advertised as "sep dining," which in these cases referred to the dining L off the living room, outside the galley kitchens. Brokers label these apartments four and a half rooms, or may refer to them as "convertible three bedrooms," explaining that the dining L can be blocked off and a bedroom created, since there is another entrance to the kitchen.
THE 200 West 79th Street apartment faced south, overlooking brownstones on 78th Street. The living room was 22 by 12 feet, the dining alcove 12 by 8 feet, the kitchen 11 by 7 1/2 feet and the bedrooms 16 by 11 feet and 14 by 10 feet. There are three walk-in closets, six smaller closets, a foyer and two bathrooms. The asking price was $199,000.
Also offered for $199,000 was a prewar apartment at 130 East 94th Street. The ad read: "Nineties/Carnegie Hill. PW $199K CHARM: F/S bldg. Two BR fea: Beau arch detail new kit, N/S exposure. 75% fin. Call now!"
Apartment 3E was indeed charming. It was not created with two bedrooms, however, but with a formal dining room and one bedroom. At some point, the 19- by 12-foot dining room was cut into a 12- by 12-foot dining room -- still spacious by city standards -- and a 7- by 10-foot second bedroom or study (with a 2-foot hallway carved out).
The split was made tastefully, and the 8- by 8-foot foyer made this relatively small two-bedroom apartment seem larger. The views were nothing to rave about: from the living room, the backs of buildings seen through the white fire escape; from the bedroom, a tiny needle of street trees seen through gaps in other buildings.
This apartment started at $235,000 in February 1992 and was reduced this March. The original glass-fronted cabinets in the kitchen have been stripped, and the blue and white shirred curtains behind the glass match the blue border of the original white wall tiles, which rise about 5 feet off the tiled floor.
Of the 50-odd apartments, there were only a few that had either a woodburning fireplace or outdoor space.
Tara Greany's tiny studio at 334 East 83d Street had at least a gray marble mantle and a fireplace that once worked. Ms. Greany was having an open house and an observer arriving a few minutes early found her bringing in a crate full of red geraniums for the window box outside the $55,000 studio's one big window directly above street level. With a $290 maintenance, "it's cheaper than renting," she said, readying her pitch.
Anthony Calnek's $99,000 one-bedroom apartment at 360 West 21st Street comes with a bonus: In the rear of the building is a lawn big enough for boccie or croquet and surrounded by a stone walk. There is also a stone patio and a barbecue grill, shared by all 52 residents. The maintenance is $670.
Outdoor space also came with a newly remodeled two-bedroom at the very end of West 70th Street; the roof space above the apartment at 345 West 70th was included in the deal, for $185,000, with a $685 maintenance. The view is the apartment's weakness as well as its strength. The current view is a sweeping one of the Hudson River, and of Donald Trump's Riverside South project. Depending on what is built there, the view may be substantially altered.
ONLY one apartment had both fireplace and outdoor space. It was listed for $99,000. Labeled "HOT PROPERTY," the apartment at 170 East 88th Street was in a red brick building that might have been part of a row of turn-of-the century brick tenements joined and "modernized" sometime in the last two decades. But the fourth-floor unit was as promised: There was a woodburning fireplace in the 18- by 20-foot living room and, off that room, a 3- by 8-foot railed balcony.
The view from the balcony was reminiscent of SoHo: the rear of some fairly nondescript brick warehouses. One was ivy covered and the other belonged to William Doyle, the auction house. The current tenant said she often watched the workers arranging antiques. Looking down, however, one had a panoramic view of backyard city gardens.
The cheapest apartment of all -- per square foot -- was probably May Wuthrich's one-bedroom for $55,000 at 230 West End Avenue, at 70th Street, although it has a rather steep maintenance of $830.
The prewar building has a uniformed elevator operator who escorts visitors into an old-fashioned wood-paneled cab with scissor gates. The building sits at the last corner of prewar West End Avenue; the next block south is a one-story grocery and across the street is the vast Lincoln Towers complex.
Not surprisingly, Ms. Wuthrich's apartment, 10F, is small, between 500 and 600 square feet. Yet there are east and north exposures, giving it morning sun, and three distinct rooms: a 4-by-8 kitchen with a window, a 10- by 14-foot bedroom and a 13- by 14-foot living room, the walls of which are covered with oil paintings by Ms. Wuthrich's grandfather, Frederich Wuthrich.
"The paintings don't go with the apartment," she said, adding that she was leaving only because she was getting married in August and her fiance, Marc Jaffe, owns a big two-bedroom apartment six blocks away.
Outside on the street, a slightly frazzled middle-aged man leapt out of a sedan with New Jersey plates. "Did you see that apartment, the one for $55,000?" he asked the apartment's most recent visitor. "What's it like? I couldn't leave the car; my wife and son just went up. Is it a nice place for a college kid? It seems awfully cheap."
He was told it might be just the place for a college kid.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

ON-THE-WALL BOOKS
Books that will never be on the shelves of your local bookstore nor available at the library, make up the exhibition called "Out of Bounds: Books as Art/Art as Books" at the Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven through June 25. They may, however, be hung on the wall or displayed in some other fashion. Juried by Richard Minsky, founder of the Center for Book Arts in Manhattan, the 75 pieces were selected from 345 entries.
Some are contemporary versions of tablets and scrolls, harking back to the earliest forms of non-verbal communication. One piece is a spin-off of the medieval monk's "girdle" book, or leather waistband from which a book, presumably a prayer book, was suspended. But most of the works were created by artists and craftspeople who were clearly unbound by any such traditions. 
 Text is subordinate to form, but text does exist in some of the works, written by the artist or someone else. One 3-foot-high tome opens electrically, another is made up of old book spines spines sewn together in the shape of a corset, and a third is a delicate contraption of five glass "pages" on which words are etched.
The most accurate description of the expanding pleated book binding would be a concertina, and a spiral-bound book of steel plates contains text and laminated photos relating to the steel industry. In the perishable category is a book made of two pieces of well-done white toast sandwiching paper pages of lithographs and text.
The workshop gallery is open Monday through Friday from 9 to 5 and Saturday from 9 to noon at 80 Audubon Street. Admission is free, but the "books" cost anywhere from $15 to $5,000, with most priced under $1,000. For more information, 562-4927.
 
ART AND ABSTRACTION
 The ideographic art of Robert Bryden may be seen on Saturdays and Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M. through August at the Field Museum, a gallery which he opened in his home at 140 Water Street in Guilford two years ago.
Mr. Bryden uses the American Heritage Dictionary definition of the word ideograph, meaning a picture, symbol, or diagram, suggesting an idea or object without specifically naming it. His paintings are actually abstracts, cleanly drawn and geometrically composed in combinations of pleasing colors. Each one is named for the idea that it represents. "Circus: A Variation on a Theme by G. Seurat," "Sun and Seed," or "Green Phoenix" are some examples.
The paintings are not for sale and the nonprofit museum, he says, is not a self-serving project but a place dedicated to promoting and teaching abstract art, which he is attempting to rescue from its current unfashionable status, restoring it to a level that it enjoyed in the 1960's when he was a student of Josef Albers at Yale's School of Art and Architecture.
He and his wife Barbara have established a trust by which they hope to attract 20 students a year to spend four hours at the museum absorbing Mr. Bryden's philosophy of abstraction as the intelligent expression of an idea. It is the oppposite, he says, of abstract-expressionism, which is the emotional expression of an idea.
The students will be paid $100 for making the trip, with a parent if necessary, and applying themselves to the lesson sufficiently to write an essay on the experience. Mr. Bryden expects to compile the commentaries in a book.
The museum welcomes the works of other exhibiting abstract artists, and holds informal talks about art and abstraction on Saturdays at 3 P.M. For more information call 453-5750.
 
AND IF ELECTED. . .
 "Connecticut Votes -- From 1894 to 1994" is the subject of an exhibition at the Unionville Museum through November. Covering the national elections from Cleveland to Clinton, and the state campaigns from Morris to Weicker, the display contains a broad selection of memorabilia.
Some of it was loaned by Connecticut candidates who won and others who lost, but the impressive core collection, owned by Frank Corbeil, president of the museum, has been shown at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington and the Museum of Political History at the University of Hartford.
The Whig ticket on an 1856 ballot, ribbons for Warren G. Harding and Calvin Coolidge worn by Aetna employes in the 1920's, buttons bearing names of candidates whom nobody has heard of since, and a slew of postcards, photographs, hats and souvenirs call up memories of Ella T. Grasso, the state's only woman governor; Ralph Nader of Torrington, who ran for President, Abraham A. Ribicoff, John N. Dempsey, Thomas J. Meskill, John Davis Lodge, and some names that reach back into the state's earlier history, like Trumbull and Baldwin.
The museum is housed in the restored Andrew Carnegie Public Library, built in 1917 at 87 School Street, dedicated to collecting and preserving local history. It is open free of charge on Wednesday, Saturday and Sunday from 2 to 4 P.M. For more information, 673-2231.
 
RAPTORS ON PARADE
 Hawks, eagles, a vulture, and an Andean condor will be among the avian performers onstage live at the Norwalk Maritime Center beginning Saturday and continuing through Labor Day.
The center's four-story tower will provide a perch from which the raptors will swoop down at their accustomed breakneck speed onto the outdoor stage below, displaying their skill in targeting prey. In addition, there will be other hunting birds, including owls, a red-legged seriema, and Pogo, a chatty cockatoo.
The program originates from Steve Martin's Natural Encounters, Inc. in Minnesota, where Mr. Martin has been training birds and taking his show on the road for 17 years.
The well-traveled birds have appeared in several countries around the world, throughout the United States, and on the "Tonight Show" and "Late Night with David Letterman."
Weather permitting, there will be three shows daily except Tuesday, at 10:30 A.M., noon and 4 P.M. Audiences will view the performances from a new 800-seat grandstand, and admission will be $1.25 in addition to the general Maritime Center admission of $7.50 for adults, $6.50 for children and adults over 62.
General admission tickets entitle the bearers to explore the Baja California exhibit, a 7,000 square foot re-creation of the natural beauty that is the basis for the 1,000-mile peninsula's art, religion and economy.
Another sight to see is the Tango -- a specially designed boat in which Dwight Collins of Darien pedaled his way from Newfoundland to Plymouth, England in 40 days in 1992, breaking the record for human-powered, trans-Atlantic navigation.
The center has many children's programs scheduled throughout the summer as well as other long-term exhibits, including artifacts from the Titanic and a 20-foot model of the wreckage. The display relates to the IMAX film "Titanica," shown Fridays at 7 and 9 P.M.; Saturdays at 4, 7, and 9; Sundays at 4 and 7.
The film tracks the 1991 expedition to the sunken ship by Russian, Canadian and American scientists, engineers and historians. Admission is $9.75 for adults, $7.75 for children and older adults. Packaged tickets are available at a discount.
The center, south of Exit 14 of I-95, is located at 10 Water Street at the mouth of the Norwalk River. The number for more information is 852-0700, extension 206. ELEANOR CHARLES

SECTION: Section 10; Page 17; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1408 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Midtown South;
Funky Area Lures Not-So-Funky

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
LAST December, when Mark J. Berman moved his six-person marketing communications company, Townsend Consulting Group, down to 5 West 19th Street, he did it for one reason only: Economics.
He was getting twice the space for half the money he was paying at 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street. He figured his clients would turn their noses up at the area, but that was an easy fix: He'd simply go meet them uptown. 
 Now, scarcely six months later, Mr. Berman is sold on his high-ceilinged space, on the eclectic mix of restaurants, on the ease with which he gets cabs, on his whole life style. What's more, his clients are sold, too.
"I keep offering to go visit my clients and they keep opting to come down here," Mr. Berman said. "It's just more casual and more comfortable than midtown."
Is that only a small-company perspective? Hear Ralph Ammerati, partner in the huge advertising firm Ammerati & Puris. In 1981 he moved from Citicorp Center to 36,000 square feet in 100 Fifth Avenue, at 15th Street. He, too, just wanted to save money.
Today, he has more than 100,000 square feet in 100 and its sister building, 104 Fifth Avenue. It's not a perfect situation. The floors are small, so he's spread out over 10 of them. And he's had to put in interior staircases because the elevators are so slow. Still, he wouldn't consider moving back uptown.
"We seldom go uptown for anything anymore," Mr. Ammerati said.
Until recently, midtown south -- the area between 14th and 34th Streets, river to river -- had only one raison d'etre: It was a cheap alternative when rents in midtown got too high. But lately, midtown south has turned into a neighborhood of choice itself.
"In the 80's a great majority of deals were midtown tenants going to midtown south to save $7," said David A. Falk, a senior director at Williams Real Estate. "Now it's people moving within the neighborhood, going to a better building a few blocks away."
Midtown south is by no means a boom town, though. The area has traditionally attracted entrepreneurial companies, many of which went bankrupt in the last recession. And those tenants who still preferred a fancy midtown address to a funky midtown south one suddenly could afford to move uptown.
MarketSearch, a company in Rye, N.Y., that tracks building vacancies, says midtown south's vacancy rate was about 16.6 percent this month; two years ago, it was 11.6.
But now, with midtown rents starting to firm up -- and with large blocks of midtown space growing increasingly scarce -- tenants are starting to look at midtown south again. And brokers report the tenants are doing so with a great deal more enthusiasm.
"There's just less resistance to midtown south now," said Mitchell Konsker, an executive managing director of the real estate firm Galbreath Riverbank and the leasing agent at 345 Park Avenue South, at 25th Street.
Robert A. Silver, a director at Newmark Real Estate who is leasing agent at 111-115 Fifth Avenue, at 18th Street, concurs.
"A lot of midtown people are coming down to take a look," he said. Over the last 15 months, he said, activity has been so brisk that his buildings are nearly 95 percent full.
Leasing is frenzied throughout the area. Edward S. Gordon, the real estate company, says that some 693,000 square feet of midtown south space was leased in the first quarter of 1994, a 219 percent increase over the same quarter of 1993. Moreover, rents topped $17 for the first time in several years.
And it is not only the "artsy" entrepreneurial companies moving in. The fashion industry is embracing the area en masse. Last year Perry Ellis International moved its offices and showrooms to 115 Fifth Avenue, while J. Crew expanded to more than 100,000 feet at 625 Avenue of the Americas, at 18th Street. Nautica Inc. took 22,000 square feet at 11 West 19th Street. And now The Gap is moving its East Coast offices from 3 East 54th Street into 150,000 square feet at 620 Avenue of the Americas, at 18th Street.
"This really legitimizes the area," said Randy Kohana, a managing director at E.S. Gordon who represented the Gap. "Here's a huge corporate tenant moving to midtown south, and that tells other tenants that this is an O.K. area for a prestigious company."
Indeed, several mainline companies are looking at the neighborhood with a fresh eye. First Boston is said to be seriously considering buying 11 Madison Avenue, the old Metropolitan Life building on 24th Street. Prudential Securities has taken 185,000 square feet at 111 Eighth Avenue, at 16th Street; and Beth Israel Hospital bought 300,000 square feet of office space at 10 Union Square East.
"This whole neighborhood has gone through a substantial demographic revolution," said Martin Turchin, a vice chairman at Edward S. Gordon.
Nonetheless, the influx of conservative companies has not substantially changed the neighborhood's laid-back feeling. That's one reason that 20th Century Fox is opening its new FX Cable Network in 70,000 square feet at 212 Fifth Avenue, at 26th Street. The network intends to do man-in-the-street types of interviews at various times of day.
"They don't want just button-down businessmen who disappear at 5 P.M., and they don't want a backdrop of wedding-cake buildings," said David L. Hoffman, a broker with Colliers ABR who represented Fox.
Actually, to think of midtown south as a unified neighborhood is a bit misleading. Until fairly recently, Fifth Avenue and Park Avenue South were considered the area's only "good" streets. Lower Fifth had become a bustling shopping street, and Park Avenue South had enough tall buildings and restaurants to qualify as a poor man's midtown.
But lately, Avenue of the Americas and points west have taken off, too. Ladies' Mile -- 17th Street to 23d Street -- has turned into a discount retail corridor, with Bed Bath & Beyond, Barnes & Noble and numerous other stores opening in the last two years. And office tenants are following down.
IN a sense, the real estate recession immeasurably helped many of the area's buildings. Unlike midtown, where many buildings are owned by rich real estate families or deep-pocketed institutions, midtown south's commercial buildings have traditionally been in the hands of undercapitalized individuals or partnerships. Many of those owners lost their buildings to their mortgagees. Those institutions -- or companies who bought the buildings from them -- have given the properties new life.
Three years ago, 345 Park Avenue South was about 70 percent empty, "a real white elephant," recalled Mr. Konsker. But then Park Avenue South Armory, a Bankers Trust-dominated partnership, foreclosed on the property and spent more than $3 million to put in new windows, elevators, telecommunications wiring and the like. Since then the New York Law Journal, Bill Communications, Kaleidoscope Companies and others have moved in, to the point where the 12-story building has only two empty floors.
Madison Square -- 15 East 26th Street -- is a 345,000-square-foot building that three years ago was in bankrupcty, in disrepair, and only half full. Schroeder Real Estate took it over, refurbished it and started marketing it to giftware companies and nonprofits.
"We have no space left," said Howard Simson, a Cushman & Wakefield director and the building's leasing agent.
S.L. Green Real Estate, a well-heeled landlord that continuously poured renovation money into its six midtown south buildings throughout the recession, has almost no space left in its buildings either. There's been plenty of turnover, but the space has rarely remained vacant for long.
"We don't necessarily command higher rents, but we rent quicker than our competitors," maintained Stephen Green, the company's chairman. "When you consider that carrying vacant space costs as much as 30 cents a foot a month, that's pretty important."
Because the renovated buildings remain in the minority, there has been a lot of intra-neighborhood movement as local tenants try to trade up their space; 345 Park Avenue South grabbed the Law Journal from 111 Eighth Avenue. And many of Madison Square's recent sign-ons, including Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and Covington Fabrics, are moving from just a few blocks away.
"The building is modern enough to accommodate the computer systems that we want to install," said Abby Gilmore, Covington's president. "But it still has a small building feel, in a neighborhood that is our home."

HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Rent Limit For the Elderly
 
Q I have lived for more than 10 years in a rent-stabilized building. I am over 62 years old and retired. My rent at the beginning was $1,200 a month; it is now $1,650 a month. Since I am a senior citizen, is there a limit to how much my rent can be raised when I renew my lease every two years? . . . Frank Catani, Manhattan 

A Your rent may be increased with every renewal unless you are eligible for the Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption Program, said Lou Ganim, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Housing and Community Renewal in Albany, which oversees rent regulation.
Increases on stabilized apartments are set annually by the New York City Rent Guidelines Board. Current guidelines call for increases of 3 percent on one-year leases and 5 percent for two-year leases on renewal leases signed between Oct. 1, 1993, and Sept. 30, 1994.
In New York City, if a tenant or a tenant's spouse is 62 or older and lives in a rent-regulated apartment; if the combined household disposable income is $16,500 a year or less, and if they are paying at least one-third of their disposable income for rent, the person who is 62 or older may apply for the exemption.
If the tenant qualifies, he or she is exempt from future rent-guidelines increases, maximum base rent increases, fuel-cost adjustments and increases based on the owner's economic hardship and major capital improvements.
The program is administered in the city by the Department for the Aging. Applications should be filed with the Department for the Aging, SCRIE Division, 150 William Street, Fourth Floor, New York N.Y. 10038. Telephone: (212) 240-7000.
In counties outside the city covered by the Emergency Tenant Protection Act, the program is administered by the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal. Outside the city, the program is a local option and communities have different income-eligibility limits and regulations.
The Department of Housing and Community Renewal has a Rent Infoline: (718) 739-6400.
 
Designating Proxies At Co-op Elections
 
Q The ballot for my cooperative's annual elections states that any shareholder can choose to have representatives of the board of directors vote his or her shares in any way that the representatives choose. All that needs to be done is for the shareholder to sign the proxy line and not vote for any candidate.
The board's agents in this matter, themselves on and off members of the board, have been the same two people for as far back as anyone can remember. They have never revealed how they voted the proxies. Many shareholders consider this a questionable practice.
Is this the norm for co-op elections? Does it make any sense? What can be done to change the ballot? . . . Jay Maurer, Manhattan
 
A Things can be changed, said Marc Luxemburg, a Manhattan lawyer and president of the Council of New York Cooperatives.
"There are two basic types of proxies," Mr. Luxemburg said. "There's a general instruction proxy, which authorizes proxies to vote for directors using their own discretion. That is probably the most common form, with shareholders typically designating proxies who are board members or people chosen by the board. There is no legal requirement that the proxies reveal how they voted."
But there is also a second common form, he said, not as frequently used as the first. "It is a ballot-type proxy that directs the proxies specifically how to vote," he said. "The discretion of the proxies with respect to that issue is eliminated."
And, Mr. Luxemburg said, there is no mandate that a form of proxy promulgated by the board must be used. "Nothing says people can't use their own form of proxy," he said. "An individual shareholder can make up his or her proxy forms, and the forms can be similar to the second one described."
Also, he said, you may designate almost anyone as a proxy. "You are not obligated to designate the board's choices as proxies," he said. "You can pick anyone you want within the confines of the bylaws. The only legal requirement is that the proxies have to be physically present at the meeting."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Landmark East Side Complex;
Long-Running Fight Comes to an End

 BODY:
Since 1984, the City and Suburban York Avenue Estate, a 14-building complex on the Upper East Side, has been the scene of a bitter dispute over tenant rights, development interests and historic preservation.
The final chapter was played out last month when four buildings were bought by 78/79 York Associates of Mount Vernon, N.Y., a development partnership, in a bankruptcy reorganization; it acquired the others last August at a foreclosure auction. 
 The buildings -- which from 1901 to 1913 made up the world's largest low-income housing project -- had previously been owned by the developer Peter Kalikow, who paid about $43 million for them in 1984.
"We paid $18 million for the first phase and $13 million for the second," said Alan Wasserman, a partner with 78/79 York Associates.
Shortly after Mr. Kalikow bought the complex, between 78th and 79th Streets, he announced plans to raze four buildings and put up four apartment towers. Opposed by the tenants, neighborhood groups and city officials, he postponed demolition.
In 1990, the City Landmarks Preservation Commission further blocked his plans by designating the complex a historic landmark. The city's Board of Estimate, however, voted in 1991 to strip four buildings of landmark status, letting the developer proceed with one new apartment tower. That decision, though, was blocked by a New York State appeals court.
Mr. Wasserman said he bought the units because they would give his partnership, which owns and manages several buildings in the Bronx and upper Manhattan, a stronger foothold in Manhattan. He said the partnership planned to renovate and lease the apartments.
About 100 tenants live in the four buildings bought in April; 1,200 to 1,500 live in the 950 apartments in the 10 buildings bought last summer.
Loretta V. Ponticello, a tenant for 39 years, said the new owner was the first "that has shown an interest in the building as a landmark and is willing to listen, to meet with us and discuss our problems."

LENGTH: 1112 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mustang GT vs. Camaro Z28;
Topless Style With American Muscle

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
LEE A. IACOCCA, who was about to leave the top job at the Chrysler Corporation, was shaking his head. This was a couple of years ago, in his sumptuous office in Chrysler's sumptuous New York headquarters, and he was talking about the electric van I had just driven, which didn't work very well.
The problem, of course, was the battery technology, ancient and not ready for an unpolluted brave new world in which everyone will drink Perrier and will have stubbed out the final cigarette. 
 "Don't you just miss Ford's old flathead V8?" the chairman asked, shaking his head one more time.
Well, yes. A lot of us do miss that simple and wonderfully functional power plant that propelled Fords for more than three decades, until the early 1950's. It was an engine you could actually understand and work on.
It was natural that Mr. Iacocca should feel nostalgic for it, having had a nice career with Ford before he was ousted by Henry Ford 2d. He went on, of course, to create Chrysler's hugely successful mini-van and bring back the American convertible.
Mr. Iacocca knows about V8's, and he stuffed them into another of his better ideas, the original Ford Mustang.
The Mustang's arrival -- amazingly, it was exactly 30 years ago -- stole a march on General Motors, which took two years to respond with a so-called pony car of its own, the Chevrolet Camaro. In the time since, and with a few lapses, the cars have run side by side in the race to put V8 fizz into the blood of sporty-car buyers.
In that time, too, there have been five series of Mustangs and four incarnations of Camaros. They have been coupes and convertibles, hot rods and not-so-hot rods -- which used to be known as "secretary's cars." And now, once again -- for the first time in many years -- both lines are offering all-new convertibles.
The question, of course, is which is better?
For my money, it is the Camaro.
But there is a lot of subjectivity in America's love affair with these cars. As a knowledgeable friend said recently: "Yeah, Camaro beats Mustang in all its specs, but the problem is that it isn't a Mustang."
In terms of those specifications, the Camaro does come out on top. The Z28's V8 engine is a modification of the Corvette's 5.7-liter power plant, and it generates 275 horsepower and 325 foot-pounds of torque. The Mustang GT, with its venerable 4.9-liter V8 (always promoted by the marketing people as 5.0 liters) has considerably less under the hood, producing only 215 horsepower and 285 pounds of torque.
That translates, obviously, into a difference in performance. The Camaro will go from zero to 60 miles an hour in 5.4 seconds, while the Mustang takes 6.7 seconds. The Chevy's top speed is 156 miles an hour, while the Ford can do "only" 141.
Those are hardly serious deficiencies, because none of us are going to be driving at those speeds. So the either-or is subjective in terms of performance as well as image.
Both cars continue with rear-wheel drive, and both engines sound just great, with throbs and burbles to gladden the hearts of cabin-cruiser fans. Both also behave beautifully on twisting back roads, and top-down driving is, well, top-down driving. Which is to say it is wondrous, hair-riffling fun.
The Camaro and Mustang have very different bodies. The Camaro is longer, lower and wider, in the old American tradition. It is sleeker, too, with a sharply raked windshield. The Mustang harks to the past, with styling cues like the chrome horse in the grille, side scoops and triple-tiered taillights.
Both bodies are also stiffer than in the past, and that means less in the way of shake, rattle and roll.
Inside, both are nicely finished and both have equally rotten back seats, the kind you might want to wish on your boss. The carrying capacity of both cars is limited, but you expect that. The Camaro can handle a minuscule 7.6 cubic feet of cargo; the Mustang's capacity is 8.5 cubic feet -- one of the few areas in which its numbers beat the Chevy's.
As noted, the Camaro is considerably bigger than the Mustang, with an overall length of 193.2 inches, compared with the Mustang's 181.5. The Chevy is also a lot wider, at 74.1 inches, compared with the Ford's 71.8. And, as might be expected, the Camaro is heavier, weighing 3,524 pounds, compared with the Mustang's 3,452.
All the same, fuel economy is about even, with a Federal mileage rating of about 17 miles a gallon in the city and 24 to 25 on the highway. But that will probably not matter to most customers; one doesn't buy cars like these to brag about fuel economy over the back fence.
What they are bought for, and what has kept them around and popular through gas shortages, soaring insurance premiums and a general downsizing of delight is that they have been bargains, and they continue to be, considering what you get.
The Mustang GT convertible starts out just a bit less expensive, with a base price of $22,195 and a fully loaded sticker of $27,165, including leather upholstery and an incredible 460-watt stereo system. The Camaro Z28 starts at $22,875, but the price can rise to $25,932 with all the bells and whistles -- but without a leather interior, which won't be available until next year.
For the frugal, both cars can be had with V6 engines, a 160-horse, 3.8-liter in the Mustang and a 145-horse, 3.4-liter in the Camaro. The base Camaro convertible starts at $19,485 and the least expensive soft-top Mustang is $20,635.
The race between the two brands has also led to a competition to see who can most often pace the Indianapolis 500. The new Mustang convertible will lead this year's 33-car field on May 29, as it has twice previously, in 1964 and 1979. Camaro has paced the race four times: in '67, '69, '82 and '93.
The Mustang at this year's race will be a Cobra version, which will have a more potent version of the same engine, producing 240 horsepower. Ford will make 1,000 pace-car replicas and 5,000 Cobras; some have already arrived in showrooms, though they are still scarce.
The company is also considering still more oomph for the Mustang by plugging in a modification of Lincoln's 32-valve V8.
The bottom line on any convertible is its top. Both the Camaro and Mustang have power roofs that are easy to operate and are fully lined, with glass rear windows. The Mustang has a soft cover for its vinyl top, while the Camaro has a three-piece plastic tonneau.
Ford also plans to offer an optional fiberglass hardtop, which will cost about $1,500 when it becomes available on 1995 models.
 
INSIDE TRACK: With pony cars, as with thoroughbreds, a good, big horse will beat a good, small horse every time. Bet on the Camaro.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Lately, There's No Telling Where You'll Find Gold

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
IT'S hard to figure gold these days. While the bond market tanked in early April because of inflationary fears, the price of gold was falling, which seems the reverse of what the precious metal should have done. And now, after the Fed seemed to calm these inflationary fears with four short-term interest-rate hikes capped off with its half-point increase last week, the price of gold is moving higher. As of Friday, the price of gold in New York was at $386.30 an ounce, up $4.50 on the day and $4.80 for the week. 
 As the value of the dollar plunged in April, the price of gold also dropped, falling to $372.10 an ounce. That also seemed backward because traders said the dollar was falling, in part, because of a lack of confidence in the Clinton Administration and its economic policies. The dollar drop was so severe that the United States and 16 of its allies intervened in the currency markets at the end of April and early this month to prop up the beleaguered currency. But now the price of gold is rising as the value of the dollar is falling again.
 JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Turmoil Aside, Mexico Offers Bargains

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
EL ECONOMISTA, the salmon-colored financial newspaper here, has started publishing an unusual notice that says a lot about the shaky state of Mexico's financial markets.
"No More Rumors," reads the newspaper's full-page advertisement. El Economista asks its business-oriented readers to fax in rumors before spreading them. It promises to investigate and then to disregard or to publish what it finds, depending on whether the rumors are unfounded. 
 The concern is understandable. Mexico, and its market, have had their share of panic this year. Kidnappings, the assassination of the leading presidential candidate, extensive political turmoil and fears of a peso devaluation have all taken their toll.
The stock exchange has dropped 19 percent in dollar terms. The peso has slipped 8.4 percent against the dollar. Some $10 billion in foreign capital has left the country. And high interest rates needed to protect the peso have all thrown a blanket over expectations for an economic recovery before Mexico's presidential election takes place on Aug. 21.
All that means many analysts and investors have cooled on Mexico.
"We choose to feel that it's a time to be cautious," said one manager of a New York-based fund who specializes in Latin America and asked not to be identified. "Right now we're just watching it. We'll see what happens after the election."
While other analysts share that caution, they believe the Mexican market is worth entering, though on a selective basis.
"The political uncertainty in Mexico is going to continue, which means that growth may be postponed further than many people are thinking," said Timothy C. Davis, a vice president for emerging markets at Lazard Freres & Company. "That being said, we believe there are some excellent opportunities in Mexico, especially in comparison with other Latin American markets."
Telefonos de Mexico is the formerly state-owned company whose privatization was completed this month when the Government sold its last shares. It is one stock that Mr. Davis and other analysts believe is still comparatively cheap, especially compared with phone company shares in Argentina or Chile.
The Mexico City office of Baring Securities is strongly recommending Telmex and other large companies over smaller ones that might not withstand the vacillations in the market. These large companies include Banacci, a diverse financial institution; Grupo Carso, which operates restaurants and manufactures cigarettes; the construction-engineering company ICA and the Monterrey-based glass manufacturer Vitro.
It remains to be seen if El Economista's anti-rumor crusade amounts to anything. In the meantime, many foreign investors have already decided to sit on the sidelines until after the August election.
Their absence can be seen in the dwindling volumes at the stock exchange, the Bolsa Mexicana de Valores. In January, roughly $500 million a day was traded on the Bolsa. By March that had dropped to $350 million a day. During April, daily volume had declined to $240 million.
So far this year, the Bolsa has zigzagged from an all-time high of 2,881 on Feb. 8 to a low of 1,957 on April 20, the day that the Bank of Mexico demonstrated its commitment to defending the peso by raising the interest rate on 28-day peso-denominated notes, called cetes, to 18 percent.
Interest rates, economic growth and presidential politics have become so intertwined that analysts find themselves hard pressed to come up with clear statements about the market's strength. The bottom line, however, is that it is very difficult for short-term investors to come out ahead because the market is just too volatile.
"With markets like these you have to be willing to be in for more than a year to absorb the volatility," said Richard M. Johnston, director of Latin American investments for Offitbank, a private banking organization in New York.
A look at how Offitbank manages its $6.5 billion portfolio provides an example of how those responsible for spending money in Mexico reacted to events of the last year.
About 10 percent of Offitbank's portfolio is dedicated to emerging markets in Latin America. Last spring, 60 percent of that emerging market share was in Mexican cetes. As the vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement neared, Mr. Johnston said, the percentage dropped to 45 percent.
After angry Maya Indians took up arms in the state of Chiapas in January, he cut his Mexican participation to 20 percent. "Risks changed dramatically," Mr. Johnston said.
The Mexican outlook hit bottom on March 23 when the governing party's presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio, was assassinated. The Bolsa had to close the following day, and United States Treasury officials announced a $6 billion swap arrangement to provide dollars to defend the peso.
Mr. Johnston said he has brought Mexican investments back up to 30 percent, and could go as high as 45 percent by the end of the year. But that would still be 15 percentage points below last year.
The outlook in Mexico for the rest of 1994 is mixed. First-quarter gross national product figures showed a meager rise of five-tenths of a percent while earnings for many companies were disappointing, partly because the 8.4 percent slide of the peso forced many to take foreign exchange losses. Rumors of a formal devaluation are widespread and real growth may not take place until 1995.

LENGTH: 1397 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: May 15-20

BYLINE: By Hurbert B. Herring 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Rates Rise, Stocks Plunge; Rates Rise More, Stocks Soar. Go Figure.
At last we see what the financial markets wanted! It clearly wasn't the water-drip torture of the Federal Reserve raising interest rates a quarter point at a clip, as it did earlier this year, always hinting of more to come. But last week it moved decisively, not only raising the Federal funds rate by half a point, but also lifting the discount rate the same amount after leaving it unchanged for nearly two years, and banks quickly lifted prime rates, too. The markets loved this decisiveness, with the Dow industrials soaring 95 points in four days and long-bond yields falling. Perverse? Not really. If short-term rates reach a level the markets can live with, the thinking goes, then investors won't worry about long-term inflation. "We have gotten the dark cloud of uncertainty from over our heads," said one economist. (If the winds change, of course, economists will be glad to come up with some seemingly opposite rationale.) 

He Who Steals My Trash . . .
Is nothing simple these days? We often hear of towns choking on more garbage than they can handle. But now towns are desperate to keep garbage -- and the courts won't let them. It works like this: a town builds a costly, bond-financed sorting and recycling center, pledging town garbage to keep it humming. But along comes someone who will haul trash away for less, and the equation falls apart. One town went to court to hang onto its old tires, broken toys and junk mail, but last week the Supreme Court turned it down, ruling that towns can't "hoard a local resource." So are fancy trash centers doomed? The Court offered one recourse: subsidize them to keep fees low. What's a civic-minded citizen to do now? Throw out even more stuff?
 
Who Wants to Be No. 2 Anyway?
The winter's incessant ice, apparently, was the last straw: in January, the Census Bureau said last week, Texas edged past New York to become No. 2 in population (California's still safely No. 1; in 1970 it passed New York, which had ranked first since 1810). We knew this was coming, of course, as the nation steadily tilts south and west. But let's put one rumor to rest right now: the Brooklyn Bridge is not being dismantled and shipped to Dallas.
 
Tinkering With Perfection
A good tomato is an elemental joy, a pure and elegant basic of nature. You tinker with it at your peril. But another force is equally basic: the unstoppable march of science. The two collided last week, and science won this round, as the F.D.A. approved the sale of tomatoes genetically altered to keep them firm and fresh. Critics abounded, mainly complaining that no labels are required on these tomatoes. "Consumers have a right to know," one said. But a trade group representative insisted, "It isn't something frightening or mysterious." It is big business: the nation's fresh-tomato market is worth $3 billion or so annually, and Calgene, which developed the altered tomato, stands to get a sizable payoff.
 
Warning Flag on Derivatives
Depending on whom you talk to, financial derivatives are either the greatest thing since take-out coffee or a loaded gun that will end civilization as we know it. For two years the General Accounting Office, which scouts things out for Congress, pondered the matter. And last week it came down squarely on the side of those who see danger, calling for broad new regulation of the companies that create and use these complex financial products. "They identified a regulatory black hole," said Representative Edward Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat, who had asked for the report. But a group of banks and brokerages fired back in a single voice that derivatives are "a critically important risk-management tool."
 
Swindled? Here's the Tax Bill
It's bad enough to lose money in an investment scam, but the final insult would be if, when the smoke cleared, you owed back taxes too. That's what may face investors in something called City-Equity Group. Last week prosecutors charged that Gary Lefkowitz, head of City-Equity, had embezzled up to $130 million that was earmarked for low-income housing projects. Since low-income housing is one of last refuges of those seeking tax shelters, some investors may have claimed tax credits they weren't entitled to. And having just lost your shirt may be no excuse.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Just What Albania Needs?
Albania, where the average monthly wage is less than $30, was in the Stalinist dark ages until recently. By U.N. designation, it is the only "least developed nation" in Europe. So, naturally, what it needs is . . . Coke. And that's what it got last week, as Coca-Cola opened a $10 million bottling plant, adding Albania to the long list of countries where that all-American drink is made. (No, it's not everywhere; a few countries, like Libya, Iraq and Cuba, still ban it.) "It may not be what they need the most," said one observer, but it is still an odd sort of ticket into the family of nations.
 
Trade Gap: It's Mostly Japan
Any talk of this nation's trade deficit quickly zeroes in on Japan, and last week's numbers clearly show why. Yes, the March deficit shrank as exports soared, but of the $7.5 billion deficit that remained, more than three-quarters of it -- $5.8 billion -- was with Japan. That, in fact, is the third-biggest monthly deficit ever with Japan. True, Japan is buying more from the United States, but our economy is so strong that we're buying even more from Japan. So once again America and Japan hit the negotiating table to see if Japan's doors could be pried open a bit wider, and there was talk of "detailed, serious proposals." The tune sounds familiar.
 
COMPANIES
 
The Abortion Pill Is Coming
Given the passions on both sides, no truce is imminent in the abortion war. But at least some battlefields may now change. Last week, under pressure from the Clinton Administration, Roussel Uclaf, the French maker of the abortion pill RU-486, turned over the patent rights and technology to a New York group, the Population Council, which will conduct tests, find a manufacturer and try to get it to American women by 1996. So now abortion clinics, easy protest targets, can be replaced by scattered doctors' offices. The manufacturer will certainly be a small one; no large drug maker would open itself to boycotts. Abortion-rights leaders were elated, seeing an end to the "tyranny of anti-choice extremists," while one abortion foe called the pill a "human pesticide." The war goes on.
 
Is That the TV Ringing?
It's enough to make a technophobe weep. First came the idea of phone companies offering cable programming. Then last week regulators opened the way for a Time Warner cable system to compete for local phone service in Rochester. And don't worry: you can still call all your friends (and telemarketers can still call you). Part of the deal is that rivals can connect to the existing network. What does Rochester Telephone get out of it? More freedom to retain profits earned through efficiency. And the consumer? Lower rates, probably, but perhaps higher confusion.
 
Still Betting on Cable
Bell Atlantic isn't letting the collapse of its linkup with T.C.I. keep it from dreaming of cable television's possibilities. That was clear last week when it chose AT&T and General Instrument to build an advanced video and data network to bring goodies like interactive television and movies on demand to 8.5 million mid-Atlantic homes. So there's old, established AT&T at the center of this high-tech onslaught. It regularly battles local phone companies, but it has made similar deals with such companies to build networks in Connecticut and California. This data highway clearly makes for interesting bedfellows.
 
As the Haft Family Turns
The Haft family has performed a worthy service by bringing a soap-opera tingle to the business pages. Herbert Haft, the patriarch at 73, ousts his son Robert from the Dart Group board and replaces him with his other son, Ronald. Herbert's wife, Gloria, sides with Robert, and she too is history. She seeks a legal separation. The lawsuits fly. But last week the Hafts settled, and while no specifics were disclosed, Mr. Haft and Ronald seem to have bought out Mrs. Haft and Robert. Oh, well, there may be some "Dallas" reruns around.
