HEADLINE: Barry Runs Again to Lead Washington

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Less than four years after a cocaine-possession conviction forced him out of City Hall and into prison, Marion S. Barry Jr. is again running for mayor of Washington.
He finished a six-month sentence in April 1992, but immediately tried to regain the political stage, winning a two-year term on the District Council as representative of the city's poorest ward. Now, he says, pointing to the city's problems of unrelenting violence, poverty and urban flight, Washington needs the kind of strong leadership he provided in his three terms as mayor from 1978 to 1990.
More to the point, he says, the city needs to be rescued from his successor, Sharon Pratt Kelly. 
 "Washington, D.C., needs strong, compassionate and visionary leadership to restore hope, energize its people and guide the city to recovery," Mr. Barry said today as he announced his candidacy in a speech to about 250 supporters at a District of Columbia high school.
Sounding what promises to be his campaign theme, he added: "I am that leader. Our city needs healing. It needs recovery. Who can better help our city recover than someone who has gone through recovery?"
 
Videotape of Drug Use
 In 1990, Mrs. Kelly was elected by more than 80 percent of the vote on a promise to revive the city from the legacy of Mr. Barry, who had been arrested in a downtown hotel. He was caught by Federal agents smoking crack with a woman, and the episode became a national embarrassment for Washington. Videotapes made by the authorities were played repeatedly on network newscasts. After his conviction, Mr. Barry underwent rehabilitation for drugs and alcohol.
Against that background, Mrs. Kelly, a lawyer who emphasized her inexperience with politics, became an easy choice for voters. She set out to trim the bureaucracy that had swelled under Mr. Barry, control the budget, increase revenue, reduce crime, slow the population decline, restore integrity to the Mayor's Office and change the District's onerous relationship with Congress.
As the capital of the United States, Washington operates as no other city, with a quasi-independent status providing Congress the right to approve budgets, set taxes and override any legislative decisions. Only since 1974 have residents elected their mayor; before then the mayor was appointed by the President.
By Mr. Barry's third term, the city was suffering with a budget deficit approaching $300 million and city employment rolls bloated with people who had won jobs through political patronage. Further, in the five years through 1991, the homicide rate increased in six of the city's seven police districts, and crimes against people rose by nearly 47 percent.
 
Return to Early Themes
 But even though Mrs. Kelly eliminated 6,000 jobs, sold bonds to reduce the deficit and persuaded the Federal Government to contribute more to the District budget, she drew increasing criticism for the rising rates of crime, homelessness and unemployment. She also alienated some supporters with her blunt style and with certain expenditures, like $40,000 for a granite fireplace in her office.
At the same time, Mr. Barry's star was rising again. Fueled by feelings among some residents that white Federal authorities had set him up for the cocaine arrest because he was a strong black leader, he returned to the themes of his early days as a civil rights leader, taking up the cause of the poor and unemployed, and crushed a longtime incumbent to win the council seat for Ward 8, which is 90 percent black.
Mr. Barry's message was a far cry from that of the boom times of the 1980's, when he reached out to middle-class blacks, business leaders and other members of the city's Democratic mainstream.
But experts in local politics say that only with that kind of support does Mr. Barry have any chance to unseat Mrs. Kelly. And those groups, the experts say, will be the hardest for Mr. Barry to win over. Councilman John Ray, who announced today he would oppose Mr. Barry and Mrs. Kelly in the Sept. 13 Democratic primary, has characterized Mr. Barry's candidacy as a "hustle on this city."
"He had a terrible record for 12 years," Mr. Ray said of the former mayor. "He left the city bankrupt."
James L. Hudson, a former legal adviser to the city's first elected mayor since 1871, Walter E. Washington, and a former Barry supporter, said Mr. Barry "has to prove himself to voters."
"Even putting aside his drug issue, the city missed some great opportunities," Mr. Hudson added. "By his second and third terms, there was a deterioration of the public infrastructure, and the city became a less inhabitable place to live."
In his 45-minute speech, Mr. Barry stressed two basic themes: that the Kelly administration had betrayed the city by inadequate leadership and that crime and safety would be his top priorities. He proposed that a "gun court" be established for speedy trials in crimes involving guns, that three-year prison sentences be imposed on anyone selling guns illegally, and that schools and churches set up "gun boxes," in which people could leave anonymous information about gun owners.
While he has the certain support of many low-income residents throughout Washington, it remains unclear whether he can convince others that the city would be well served by a man whose social habits once brought it embarrassment.
"There are definitely people who have forgiven him and groups who will never vote for him, black and white, but more white than black," said Mark Plotkin, a political commentator for WAMU, a local public radio station. "Then there are those who want to see how he acts during the campaign, and Barry is savvy enough to know that how he conducts himself may have a bearing. He's now considered a responsible legislator, a low-profile legislator. The city has not really see him since he left. So this is like an audition."

HEADLINE: Move in California to Bar Service to Aliens

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 21

 BODY:
A ballot initiative that would deny public education and non-emergency medical care to illegal aliens in California is the latest and one of the most drastic attempts to curb illegal immigration and its costs.
Backers of the petition drive, "Save Our State," say they have gathered 600,000 signatures, with those of 384,974 registered voters required to place the proposal on the ballot. Voter registrars have until Tuesday to verify signatures, and if the requirement is met, voters will consider the measure in November. 
 In addition to cutting off free social services, the proposal would require teachers, health care workers and the police to report the presence of any "apparent illegal immigrants" they deal with.
Without these services, argued Harold Ezell, one of the initiative's authors and a former Western regional chief of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, illegal aliens would "go back to where they came from."
 
Hurdles Even if Approved
 Opponents of the proposal acknowledge that they will have a difficult time defeating it.
Even if it is adopted, hurdles await. Civil rights groups say the authorities will find it difficult to demand documents of "apparent illegal immigrants" without engaging in racial discrimination.
In addition, the United States Supreme Court has ruled that public schools must educate children regardless of their immigration status. The chairman of the petition drive, Ron Prince, said the proposed measure would offer a promising vehicle for the Court to reverse its position.
Mr. Prince said that the composition of the Court had changed since its ruling on the issue in 1982 and that the ruling had been based on immigration conditions that had changed.
Illegal aliens are already ineligible for welfare and most other public assistance in California. The measure would not deny emergency care, including that for childbirth.
 
Clash of Philosophies
 Already, arguments over the Save Our State initiative have crystallized a clash of philosophies over immigration that has been growing in the nation's border states.
"It's obvious we cannot assimilate all of the illegals in the world," Mr. Ezell said. "How many can we educate, medicate, incarcerate and compensate? Just because they are here illegally doesn't mean they have a right to stay here and a right to our tax dollars."
Mr. Prince placed the proposal in a purely economic context, saying, "The initiative is needed because the state is going bankrupt."
But Arturo Vargas, a lawyer with the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, said the measure would require doctors, teachers and police officers to be "agents of a Big Brother state" by making them verify the immigration status of people they serve.
Despite the backers' assurances that the proposal is racially and ethnically colorblind, Mr. Vargas said it would target Hispanic immigrants, who make up the vast majority of illegal aliens in California.
Mr. Vargas also questioned the assertion that people would stop coming to the United States illegally if the benefits were cut. "That's not why they come," he said. "It would create an underground situation with people living in the shadows of our society."
 
'Too Willing to Pander'
 The political tide seems to be running against opponents of the measure. As the state's economy recovers sluggishly from recession, the state's politicians, Democrats and Republicans alike, remind Californians that the state has already absorbed more than one-third of the country's legal immigrants and more than half its international refugees.
California is also home to a huge proportion of the country's estimated 3.5 million illegal aliens. In San Diego County, which borders Mexico, an estimated 200,000 people, or 9 percent of the population, are in this country illegally.
"I blame the political leadership that has been all too willing to pander on this issue and allow people to believe that if we would just deny education and emergency health care to illegal aliens, all these lost aerospace and manufacturing jobs would return," said Robert Rubin, a spokesman for the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights, based in San Francisco.
Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican who faces a difficult re-election campaign this fall, turned up the heat on this issue last August with a proposal to withhold health care and schooling from illegal aliens and to deny citizenship to any children who might be born to them in the United States. The citizenship proposal would require a constitutional amendment.
A Los Angeles Times poll last September found that 86 percent of Californians considered illegal immigration to be a problem of moderate-to-major proportion. Seventy-six percent said they believed that illegal aliens cost more in social services and health care than they contributed in taxes and productivity. Two months ago, another Los Angeles Times poll found that 62 percent of respondents favored the Save Our State initiative.
The state Republican Party helped to finance the petition drive, but neither it nor Governor Wilson has taken an official position on the measure.
Most Democrats in the latest poll joined most Republicans in supporting the initiative. But the State Democratic Party has not taken a position on it. Opponents of the measure said the party was more likely to emphasize border controls and sanctions on employers who hire undocumented workers.
The state's two United States Senators, both Democrats from the San Francisco Bay area, have contributed strong language on the issue, but more modest proposals. Senator Barbara Boxer urged the use of the National Guard to patrol the border with Mexico, and Senator Dianne Feinstein called for a $1 border-crossing fee to pay for tougher policing of the border.
 
A Crucial Question
 A crucial issue at the heart of the ballot initiative is how educators, health care workers and the police would determine "apparent illegal immigrants" without engaging in racial discrimination.
Mr. Vargas, the defense fund lawyer, said, "I could easily foresee a situation where I myself -- I'm very Mexican-looking, yet I'm a second-generation United States citizen -- where I myself could be subject to demonstrating that I am a citizen of this country merely because I am brown-skinned, black-haired and have a mustache."
But Mr. Ezell brushed aside such concerns. "All we're saying is, 'Ask,' " he said. "It's O.K. to ask. We're not after any color skin. Just ask. It seems like it ought to be O.K. to ask. So what's the big deal?"

HEADLINE: Pooling Risks and Sharing Costs in Effort to Gain Stable Insurance Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Few parts of President Clinton's health plan sound so simple as the idea of charging the same insurance premiums to all people in a geographic area, whether they are young or old, sick or healthy.
The goal is to return health insurance to "what it was meant to be: a fair deal at a fair price," Mr. Clinton said last week. 
 But in health insurance, nothing is simple. While many Republicans agree that the Government should limit the variation in premiums, the idea of such "community rating" raises a host of political, philosophical and technical questions, like these:
*How much will rates go up for young, healthy people, whose premiums are now below the average? Are these people prepared to pay higher premiums in return for greater security?
*Is it fair to raise premiums for young people while lowering premiums for their parents, who often have higher incomes and greater assets?
*Is it right to charge the same premiums to smokers and nonsmokers? Should insurers be allowed to give a discount to people who take responsibility for their health, watch their diet and exercise regularly?
*How should the Federal Government and the states divide responsibility for regulating the price of health insurance, a field long dominated by state officials?
 
Spreading the Risk
 The move toward community rating is a reaction to the experience of the last decade, in which health insurance became prohibitively expensive for many people. Some of these people had a history of illness. Some were healthy, but were considered likely to incur high medical costs. Some were healthy, but obtained their insurance through small groups in which other people ran up high medical bills.
Insurers today charge much higher premiums to people who are old or sick. A 64-year-old may pay four to six times as much as a 20-year-old.
Community rating is an attempt to stabilize health insurance premiums by pooling risks and sharing costs. "The principle of risk spreading is essential to equitable insurance," said Salvatore R. Curiale, the Superintendent of Insurance for New York State, which has gone further toward community rating than most states.
In July 1992, Governor Cuomo signed a bill to establish community rating of health insurance policies for individuals and small businesses in New York. Mr. Curiale said that the law, which took effect in April 1993, had been successful.
"The community-rating mandate did cause premiums to increase for younger people," he said. "But about 60 percent of the people affected by the change received rate decreases or increases no greater than 20 percent. Individual and small-group health insurance is more available, and it appears that premium rates are more stable."
Marilyn W. Ogden, an owner of Fritz Helmbold Inc., a meat-processing company in Troy, N.Y., said the change probably helped level off her company's rates. "For a small business like us, community rating is very helpful," she said. Eight of the 18 employees are over 55, and the company would have to pay higher premiums without community rating.
Gail E. Shearer, manager of policy analysis at Consumers Union, described community rating as "the fairest way to share health care costs" short of a single-payer program financed by the Government with broad-based taxes.
Arthur V. Ferrara, chairman of the Life Insurance Council of New York, a trade association for insurers, gave the experiment a mixed review. "I have to agree with the superintendent to a certain degree," he said. "Thus far, community rating appears to have worked reasonably well in the Insurance Department's view.
"But from the public's point of view, this law has caused tremendous strain on the younger insurance-buying population," said Mr. Ferrara, who is also chairman of the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America. "If senior members of our society pay less, someone else has to pay more. That's the younger members. Many young people have opted to drop their coverage rather than pay the high costs associated with health insurance."
Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, all people would be required to carry health insurance, including the unemployed. Insurers could not reject people because of their medical problems. Employers would pay most of the cost for their workers. The Government would help buy insurance for low-income people, including many of the unemployed.
In a recent monograph, the American Academy of Actuaries, a professional organization of insurance experts, assessed the likely effects of community rating. The academy takes no position for or against community rating, but says policy makers and the public should understand the consequences.
In general, it said, "the young would subsidize the old, males would subsidize females at most ages, the healthy would subsidize the sick and the poor may subsidize the wealthy, since younger people generally earn less income than older people."
President Clinton would not allow variation in premiums because of age. But many members of Congress have concluded that some adjustment for age is needed. Many insurers say they can accept a modified form of community rating and see it as inevitable.
 
On Fairness
Incentives Needed To Insure the Ill

Simplifying one part of the premium formula immediately creates complexity in other areas.
The idea of pure community rating is that all people with the same coverage should pay the same premiums, regardless of age, sex, medical history or occupation. But obviously it costs more to care for sick people. So most proponents of community rating, including Mr. Clinton, acknowledge that health plans enrolling sicker people should receive more money.
Thus, many experts say that if the Government requires community rating of premiums, it must also have some way of redistributing money from plans with healthy customers to plans with a less healthy clientele.
"Otherwise," said Alice F. Rosenblatt, an actuary at Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, "there would be a strong financial incentive for health plans to avoid costly high-risk individuals. In general, 4 percent of claimants generate 50 percent of claim costs."
Or, as Mr. Curiale said: "We don't want to penalize a company because it takes older, sicker patients. It's inappropriate to have some companies benefit because they have younger, healthier people as customers."
 
Taking a Regional Average
 The device for redistributing money among insurance companies is called a "risk adjustment mechanism." Payments to insurers and health plans are adjusted to reflect the relative risk of their customers, the likelihood that they will incur medical costs in the future.
Under the pooling arrangement in New York, the demographic characteristics of each insurer's customers are compared with a regional average. An insurer receives money from the pool if, for example, it has a disproportionately large number of people who are old or have AIDS. An insurer must contribute to the pool if its customers are younger and healthier than the average.
Ms. Rosenblatt, the actuary, said, "If you require community rating, you must have a risk adjustment mechanism at the same time." In theory, if there were a perfect method of risk adjustment, insurers would have no incentive to seek out low-cost patients. But there is currently no such perfect method.
Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, a new Federal agency, the National Health Board, would have to develop a risk adjustment method by April 1995. The bill does not say how this should be done.
 
About Age
Should the Young Subsidize the Old?
 Older people generally use more health care than young people, but whether they should pay higher premiums is an explosive question.
Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, said insurers must be allowed to consider age as a factor in setting premiums. "Young working people already support the retirement benefits of people over 65," she said. "It would be most unfortunate if those people were also asked to subsidize health insurance premiums of their parents, who have better-paying jobs."
Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, said pure community rating could provoke "a generational war." Another Republican, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, said, "A 27-year-old with three kids shouldn't subsidize a 57-year-old in his peak earning years."
But John C. Rother, chief lobbyist for the American Association of Retired Persons, strongly defended Mr. Clinton's proposal to ban the use of age as a factor in setting premiums.
"The notion that older people are better off doesn't hold when you look at individual cases," he said. "Given the layoffs of the last few years, many people in their late 50's and early 60's make less than earlier in their careers."
Moreover, Mr. Rother said: "There is pervasive age discrimination in the workplace. Many employers try to avoid hiring older workers because of the higher health costs. Community rating should encourage employers to hire older people."
While insisting that age must be a factor, many insurers are willing to limit the variation in premiums. Mary Nell Lehnhard, senior vice president of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, said the Government might stipulate that the maximum premium for older people would be two or three times the premium for young people. Older people now pay as much as five or six times as much as young people.
Community rating redistributes money in other ways, too. For example, it evens out the costs of health insurance for workers and nonworkers. Nonworkers are believed to have higher medical costs; some are out of work because of health problems.
One result of community rating is that employers would pay higher premiums to subsidize health insurance for nonworkers, said John F. Sheils, a vice president of Lewin-VHI, a consulting concern that specializes in medical economics.
Mr. Sheils said that employers, taken together, would pay $44 billion a year in subsidies for nonworkers. Federal aid for small low-wage businesses would offset $11 billion of this cost under Mr. Clinton's proposal. "The net result is that employers would provide $33 billion a year in subsidies for nonworkers," said Mr. Sheils.
 
In New York
Confident Of Coverage
 New York provides the largest demonstration of how a community rating system might work, though its law is less sweeping than what Mr. Clinton proposed. States do not regulate large companies that serve as their own insurers; the New York law applies only to small groups with 3 to 50 workers. If a company sells insurance to such groups, it must take all applicants and set premiums through community rating.
Data compiled by Mr. Curiale's office show that, after the law took effect, premiums increased for nearly two-thirds of all people with individual or small-group coverage from commercial insurers. Premiums doubled for 5 percent of them.
Despite the increases, Mr. Curiale said that coverage was now more secure. "What you had before was an illusion," he said. "If you were young and healthy, the insurance company would accept you. As soon as something went wrong, the rate for you or your group would go sky high. With open enrollment and community rating, you may pay more, but you have stability. You have coverage that can't be taken away."
 
Company Perspective
 But Cecil D. Bykerk, chief actuary for the Mutual of Omaha Companies, said: "The first year is not working very well. Since the imposition of pure community rating in New York, the average age of our policyholders has gone up 3.5 years, from 41.5 to 45. That's a very significant rise. Younger people are bailing out. If you're going to have universal access to insurance, which we support, then you need some kind of mandate for people to buy."
One lesson from New York is that the shift to community rating probably ought to be gradual.
In New York, the community rating requirement was applied to all small-group contracts on April 1, 1993. "There was some panic and a lot of uncertainty as April 1 approached," Mr. Curiale said. "Insurers sent out letters telling people, 'Your contract is terminated April 1, and we can't tell you what the cost of new coverage will be.'
"If we did it over again," he said, "we'd make it effective as the old contracts expired."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "FOR AND AGAINST: Community Rating of Health Insurance"
 
WHAT IT IS -- The concept requires insurers to charge the same premiums to all people in a geographic area, regardless of factors like age, sex, medical history or occupation.
 
HOW IT WOULD WORK -- Premiums would be set by averaging the expected cost of insuring everyone in the area. Money would be redistributed among insurance companies to reflect the relative risk of their customers, the likelihood that they will incur medical costs in the future. A health plan with a large share of elderly or sick patients would receive extra money from other companies through a pooling arrangement, not by charging higher premiums.
 
ARGUMENTS FOR -- Community rating restores insurance to its original purpose, spreading risks among diverse groups of people. In recent years, insurers have tried to insure only the healthiest people while shunning high-risk customers who most need protection. Insurers should not be allowed to charge higher rates to sick people and older people.
 
ARGUMENTS AGAINST -- Pure community rating is unworkable and inequitable. It will raise premiums for young people while lowering premiums for older people, who often have higher incomes. Insurers also ought to be free to offer discounts to nonsmokers and others with healthy habits.
 
WHO SUPPORTS IT -- Labor unions, consumer advocates and lobbyists for the elderly favor community rating. They say the market should not be sliced up into different demographic groups.
 
WHO OPPOSES IT -- Big businesses, which generally run their own health plans, do not want to be included in the community-rated pool. If their health insurance is community rated, businesses say, they will not get the benefit of savings they achieve through efficient management of their health plans and through programs promoting healthy behavior by employees.
 
LEGISLATIVE OUTLOOK -- Congress appears likely to limit the variation in premiums as part of any comprehensive legislation. There is wide support for a modified form of community rating, with some modest variation in premiums on account of age.
 
Graph: "CASEBOOK: How Policyholders Fared"
 As part of a 1992 law regulating health insurance, New York requires community rating of premiums, so that people with the same coverage pay the same amounts without regard to age, sex, health status or occupation. Graph shows the percentage of small group and individual insurance policyholders in New York State whose rates decreased and increased according to certain percentages. (Source: New York State Insurance Department)

HEADLINE: Proposal for Welfare Cutoff Is Dividing Clinton Officials

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
As he completes his welfare plan, President Clinton must resolve a fight that has divided aides for months and has led one faction to accuse another of trying to rip holes in the social safety net.
The fight is over whether families who follow all the rules can eventually be dropped from both welfare and a work program that Mr. Clinton is proposing. While the Administration wants to enroll recipients in the work program after they have received aid for two years, the question is what happens to those who spend several years in it and still do not find jobs on their own. 
 Can they re-enroll indefinitely, as long as they are willing to work? Or can states cut off some families, leaving them with neither welfare nor their subsidized minimum-wage jobs?
The issue is being contested with unusual fervor because it cuts to the program's philosophical core. While states already reduce payments to women who flout certain rules, this may be the first Federal law that cuts off entire families whether they follow the rules or not.
There are no reliable estimates of how many of the 15 million indigent women and children who rely on Federal assistance may be left without jobs or aid. While Mr. Clinton's welfare advisers sent him a confidential memorandum in March referring to "what we hope will be a small number," outside economists have said hundreds of thousands of families may eventually be affected.
 
Weighing Good Intensions
 The possible move is strenuously opposed by advocates for the poor, who say it may punish well-intentioned families and start the nation down the slippery slope of abolishing welfare. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, has also told the Administration he considers the move unacceptable.
But at the same time, it is being advocated in Congress not only by Republicans but also by some moderate and conservative House Democrats. They argue that the nation cannot afford an unlimited jobs program and that without the threat of being cut off, some participants will never find jobs on their own.
"This is like crossing the Rubicon," said Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research and advocacy group that opposes cutting off families. "There's no more fundamental issue."
Administration officials were sufficiently sensitive about the debate that none would publicly comment. The Department of Health and Human Services has drafted a memorandum this week asking Mr. Clinton him to resolve the issue. Officials are also asking him to decide another issue: whether states should be allowed to deny additional payments to mothers who had additional children while on welfare.
Mr. Clinton plans to send Congress a bill next month to expand training available to welfare mothers during the first two years they receive aid. But Mr. Clinton plans to require those who are still unemployed at that point to join his proposed work program, which will subsidize their wages in public or private jobs.
 
Clinton Silent So Far
 But he has said nothing about whether the work program itself should be limited, and the internal debate shows the difficulty of translating work slogans into work programs.
The faction that wants to limit the program is being led by Bruce Reed, a White House aide. This group argues that Government aid was never meant to be inexhaustible and that a cutoff is needed to change a system universally regarded as a failure.
Unless there is the prospect that all aid will truly end, they say, recipients will lack incentives to find jobs on their own. Without limits, they fear the jobs program may even entice people to leave unattractive jobs and go on welfare.
In closed meetings, Mr. Reed, a former campaign aide, has also raised political concerns. He has said that Mr. Clinton's opponents will accuse him of failing to keep his pledge to "end welfare as we know it" unless the work program, too, has an end.
The faction that objects to cutting off families from the work program is led by David T. Ellwood and Mary Jo Bane, both assistant secretaries of Health and Human Services. They have argued that there are plenty of incentives for people to find jobs.
Families that find private jobs, they note, will be eligible for tax credits that can raise their incomes by as much as $3,400 a year. People in the work program will be barred from receiving the credits.
In addition to that economic incentive, recipients will also be forced to search for work on their own at least once a year. And they can be dropped from the work program if they receive an offer but fail to accept it.
Allowing states to drop people from both work and welfare, even if they received no job offers, Mr. Ellwood has said, would throw people deeper into poverty and would violate the idea that people who played by the rules should not be cut adrift.
Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, said the majority of the nation's five million welfare families could find some sort of job.
 
A Big Minority
 "But there's a sizable minority whose problems are so severe and whose lives are in such disorder," he said. "I'm very skeptical they could hold jobs outside a sheltered workshop."
Resorting to ball park estimates, Mr. Burtless said the number of such cases could eventually range anywhere from 300,000 to 800,000.
A House Republican bill with 163 co-sponsors would give states the option of dropping families from the work program and welfare after three years in the work program. A bill by Representative Dave McCurdy, Democrat of Oklahoma, would go even further, requiring states to do so. The bill, which has 29 Democratic co-sponsors, would allow states to exempt 10 percent of the participants from the limit.
"There has to be some end to this," Mr. McCurdy said in an interview last week. "If there's not a deadline out there, there's a tendency to procrastinate."
The Administration seems committed to giving recipients at least two years in a work program.
The question is whether states will then be allowed to drop families who are still willing to work. The decision has already been made about families who are unwilling to work: if they do not show up, they do not get paid.
Among those predicting this week that the Administration would not cut off willing workers was Governor Cuomo.
Saying it could only happen in "a moment of madness," Mr. Cuomo said it would dump a new poverty problem on state governments. And he added: "It would be bad for our soul as a people."

HEADLINE: Children in Rural South Are Least Likely to Be Left Home Alone

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The children most likely to spend time without adult supervision live in Midwestern suburbs, while rural Southerners are the least likely to leave their children at home alone, the Census Bureau has found.
In a report on the child-care arrangements of working mothers, the bureau found that 1.6 million youngsters spent time unsupervised after school. That finding accounts for about 7.6 percent of children of grade school age whose mothers work. 
 The report, "Who's Minding the Kids," said Midwestern children were the most likely to be left without adult supervision, with 12.1 percent falling in that category. In the West, 7.5 percent were left unsupervised, while the figures were 5.7 percent in the Northeast and 4.8 percent in the South.
The children most likely to be left unsupervised lived in suburbs, where the rate was 9.3 percent, as opposed to 6.8 percent in cities and 5.3 percent in rural areas.
Martin O'Connell, a population expert at the bureau, said suburban parents might be more comfortable leaving their children alone because they felt able to rely on nearby neighbors to provide help in emergencies.
The percentage of children left alone increased with age. Aside from the age of the child, the working time of the mother was the prime factor in determining whether a youngster spent time alone.
The work schedule is usually set by the employer and the school schedule by the school board, Mr. O'Connell said, adding that "often the twain do not meet."
The Census Bureau also found these other characteristics of child care:
*Of the 21.1 million children from the ages of 5 to 14 whose mothers work, about 76 percent spent most of their time in school when their mothers were working.
*Fathers cared for the children of 8.4 percent of married working mothers and less than 1 percent of working mothers who were not married.
*Grandparents and other relatives cared for 10.2 percent of the children of single mothers, while the rate was 3.8 percent for married working mothers.
*Among children too young for school, 23 percent were in organized child-care centers when the mother worked, 20 percent were cared for by the father, and 18 percent were with other family members. Others were cared for by nonrelatives or taken to work with their mothers.
*Paid child-care cost an average of $2.15 an hour in organized centers, $1.93 an hour for care in the homes of nonrelatives and $2.73 an hour for a nonrelative to come to the child's home.
Mr. O'Connell said he did not know whether a recent increase in the number of fathers caring for children represented a real trend, because the study was conducted in late 1991, when the economy was slow and many fathers may have been home because they were out of work. He said he wanted to reserve a conclusion until new studies could look at what would occur when more fathers were working again.
Whites were the most likely to leave children unattended, with 8.3 percent doing so, while 3.6 percent of blacks and 4.8 percent of Hispanics left children alone.
High-income individuals and those with some college education were more likely than others to leave children unattended.
Some 8.8 percent of the children of parents with one to three years of college were left at home alone, while the rates were 8.1 percent for children whose parents had finished college, 6.8 percent for children whose parents had finished high school and 6.6 percent for children whose parents had less than a high school education.
Nine percent of children in families with incomes of $4,500 a month or more were left unattended. The figures were 7.4 percent at incomes of $3,000 to $4,499, 7.2 percent at incomes under $1,500 a month and 6.6 percent for incomes of $1,500 to $2,999 a month.

HEADLINE: Coliseum: Its Worth Depends on Whom You Ask

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
One hundred million dollars is what the Metropolitan Transportation Authority says it must have for a portion of the New York Coliseum site it is negotiating to sell to developer Mortimer B. Zuckerman. For his part, Mr. Zuckerman says he will not budge from his $80 million offer. And an appraiser hired by the city put a preliminary price of $57.5 million on the property.
What gives? 
 The huge disparity in values underscores the subjective nature of appraising real estate, a process appraisers themselves acknowledge is an inexact science at best.
"There is a saying in real estate," said Paul N. Fox, director of valuation services for Jones Lang Wootton, an international real estate brokerage and consulting company. "Your property is worth what someone will pay for it."
 
Continuing Tug-of-War
 The disagreement over the value of the transaction is just one of the complications that has thrown the developer, the M.T.A. and the Giuliani administration into a three-way tug of war over the fate of the Coliseum.
On Friday John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, told a City Council subcommittee that an appraiser hired by the city put a tentative price of $57.5 million on the Coliseum site, 40 percent less than the $80 million Mr. Zuckerman has agreed to pay.
But later in the hearings, Susan Fine, director of real estate for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the property, testified that the real-estate professionals the M.T.A. had consulted said the $100 million the agency was asking for the site was a reasonable price.
Appraisers take certain steps in determining a property's value, Mr. Fox said, including uses for a property, size and cost of potential development and the projected return on the investment from rents or resale.
Appraisers also look to the sale prices of recent transactions of the same kind. But the dearth of commercial development projects in Manhattan in recent years has given professionals very few comparisons. The uncertainty of the city's real-estate market, which has shown encouraging signs of recovery recently, also has made appraisals in New York City less dependable than usual, experts say.
Moreover, any attempt to put a value on the current development potential of the Coliseum site is muddied by the complex nine-year history of the transaction, the political overtones of the recent effort by Mr. Zuckerman to renegotiate his deal and the looming court battle over the existing contract. Mr. Zuckerman has filed a suit against the city and the M.T.A. asserting that certain terms of the contract are not enforceable. The trial is to start June 1 in State Supreme Court.
The site in question, 3.4 acres at 59th Street and Columbus Circle on the southwest corner of Central Park, holds an exhibition hall and an office building. In 1985 the M.T.A., in partnership with the city, put property up for sale so the office building and hall would be replaced with a large mixed-use development. Mr. Zuckerman, in partnership with others, won the right to redevelop the complete Coliseum for $455 million. He planned to build 2.7 million square feet.
But court challenges against the city and the M.T.A. kept the project in limbo. During that time, commercial property values fell. Because the court suits did not involve Mr. Zuckerman, the city and the M.T.A. were willing to renegotiate the transaction.
In 1989 Mr. Zuckerman signed a contract to build a 2.1 million square-foot complex on the entire site. It calls for Mr. Zuckerman to pay $338 million for the property. Mr. Zuckerman could lose a $33.8 million down payment if he does not close.
Citing the real estate market's decline, Mr. Zuckerman has been negotiating a reduced price. A tentative deal calls for the M.T.A. to get $100 million for about half the site. That transaction would include about $20 million in city subsidies.
Under this plan, the M.T.A. would keep the office building and perhaps find an interim tenant.
Some public officials, including Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, a Manhattan Democrat whose district includes the Coliseum area, are calling for a settlement of the existing contract that would clear the way for an interim use of the site, and a fresh start on development in the future.
The Giuliani administration has pressed for some sort of new project in the short term, saying the city needs the construction jobs and the taxes a Coliseum project would generate. It would also be a sign, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has said, that the city's economy is rebounding.
Some critics, including Ms. Eldridge, have suggested that the Giuliani administration's support of Mr. Zuckerman is influenced by the fact that Mr. Zuckerman owns The Daily News, which endorsed Mr. Giuliani's mayoral campaign.
To justify its position on the matter, the city earlier this month hired James Felt Appraisal and Consulting Service to appraise the parcel now being negotiated. Starting at a base value of $100 million for a vacant, unencumbered parcel, the appraiser deducted from that value $20 million for the cost of demolishing the Coliseum and for asbestos abatement, $6 million for garage repairs, $2.5 million for subway improvements, $2.5 million for the cost of separating the office building from the exhibition hall, $11.4 million for the M.T.A.'s potential share of cash flow and $100,000 for legal fees.
 
Another 60 Days?
 Mr. Dyson is pressing for a second step in the valuation process. If a deal is struck, he has said, the city will give any other potential developer 60 days to top Mr. Zuckerman's offer.
The M.T.A. declined to join the city in having an appraisal made, saying that the process was counterproductive because a tentative price has been established and because the real estate market is in a state of flux.
But Mr. Dyson told the Economic Development Subcommittee of the City Council that the appraisal assured the public that Mr. Zuckerman was not paying a low price.
The appraisal company is to make its final report before the end of May. Its preliminary report puts fair market value of $57.50 per square foot for approximately 1 million square feet of development and 850 parking spaces in an underground lot.
Mr. Zuckerman has said his goal is to build an office building of about 900,000 square feet with a small retail component.
In the opinion of some real estate professionals the Columbus Circle location would not necessarily be a plus for potential office tenants.
"In judging the value of Columbus Circle for office use, I might take off points for that location," said Stephen B. Siegel, president of Edward S. Gordon, a brokerage company. "It is not in an area that caught on as an office district. No matter what the views are from top floors, some office tenants might not want to be there."
Yet Donald Trump, in partnership with General Electric Pension Trust, has plans to turn the office building across the street -- formerly occupied by Gulf & Western and now by Paramount Communications -- into an apartment building. Mr. Trump has said he expects to get $1,000 a square foot for apartments there.

HEADLINE: A Big Drop in Flower Sales May Prompt an Industry Recount

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 21

 BODY:
At a time when homeowners everywhere are planting flowers, a statistical mystery about a phantom $106 million loss in sales is growing in the field of floriculture, a thriving industry in New York that produces flowering plants in greenhouses.
If Federal statistics are correct, the wholesale value of floriculture crops in the state dropped from $250 million in 1992 to $144 million in 1993. Agricultural economists said the figures were obviously wrong. 
 "It makes no sense," said Marvin Miller, an economist for the George W. Ball Company in Chicago, a major supplier of seeds for greenhouse operations around the country. "The figures do not fit with anything we are seeing in the field, and our competitors are saying the same thing."
In Suffolk County, which accounts for more than half of all the plant production in the state, Ralph Freeman, the floriculture expert of Cornell University's Cooperative Extension Service, said, "It's impossible."
"It's the only phase of agriculture in New York that is expanding and growing," Mr. Freeman said. "It can't drop $100 million. There has been a significant expansion that takes place every year."
The mystery arose early this month when the National Agricultural Statistics Service in Washington issued its 88-page "Floriculture Crops 1993 Summary."
California was the leading state, with $658 million in sales, Florida second with $543 million, Texas third with $181 million, Ohio fourth with $149 million and Michigan fifth with $146 million. Some of these states were up slightly and some down slightly from the year before.
But the New York figures showed a substantial decrease that dropped the state from third place in 1992 to sixth in 1993. The drop, reflecting the loss of $106 million in sales, came as everybody in the field was convinced floriculture was expanding.
New York's fall in the rankings has no effect other than on pride. The figures have no economic impact, nor are they used to allocate money.
The disputed figures for New York were supplied by the Agricultural Statistics Service in Albany, based on a census of growers. Robert Schooley, the chief statistician in Albany, said he raised questions about the apparent discrepancy as soon as reports came in from enumerators.
Jim Brewster of the Agriculture Statistics Service in Washington compiled the national report. He said that the missing $106 million posed a problem but no formal investigation was under way, although it was being "gently looked into."
Mr. Brewster and the economists agreed that the roots of the apparent discrepancy date to 1990, when floriculture sales figures for the state jumped to $208 million from $125 million the year before. The figure rose to $230 million in 1991 and then to $250 million in 1992.
"The numbers have been heavily inflated in recent years," said Thomas C. Weiler, a professor of floriculture at Cornell University in Ithaca.
Mr. Miller said, "Nobody in the industry has believed those figures for the last three years." He offered a possible explanation for the phantom $106 million: it never existed. "We think a statistical aberration has now been corrected," he said. "We feel that there has been a correction, but we can't get anybody to admit it."

HEADLINE: Political Notes;
An Interested Guardian Of Utility-Tax Revenue

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

 BODY:
To many New Jersey mayors, one of the best political equivalents of the fox guarding the henhouse is the way Trenton watches over tax revenue meant for the cities.
Public utility companies pay the state millions of dollars each year in lieu of local taxes on certain properties. The state forecasts the revenue, collects the tax and then distributes the nest egg to the municipalities to help them balance their budgets and relieve property taxes. 
 But in recent years, a succession of governors have used the surplus from the utility tax to feather their own budgets.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman had expected to raid the same henhouse to help balance her proposed $15.4 billion budget. But last week she found an unlikely watchdog guarding the door: her fellow Republican and chief booster, Assembly Speaker Chuck Haytaian.
Adopting a stance that puts him at odds with Mrs. Whitman but perhaps in good favor with voters as he seeks a United States Senate seat, Mr. Haytaian said he would support legislation to return any surplus utility-tax revenue to local governments.
"This money belongs to the municipalities, and that's where it should go," Mr. Haytaian said. "The state has no legitimate claim to it, and its loss will not doom this budget. We can deal with it."
And how much money might that be? Mr. Haytaian took another swipe at the Whitman administration by writing to the nonpartisan Office of Legislative Services, asking for "advice on the proper amount" of excess revenue.
"Estimates given by State Treasurer Brian Clymer range from zero dollars to $63 million," Mr. Haytaian said in his letter.
 
Promoting the Truth, To a Certain Extent
 The New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission has suggested that the Legislature enact a truth-in-political-advertising law. The real task may be where to draw the factual line.
Frederick M. Herrmann, the executive director of the commission, said candidates had sometimes gone overboard in describing the extent of their education, their work history and their literary accomplishments.
The commission has proposed simply that the Legislature come up with a law that would prohibit false political advertising. Mr. Herrmann said few states had such legislation, but the commission patterned its proposal after a law in Washington State.
"It's not unheard of from time to time for candidates to falsify their records or their opponents'," Mr. Herrmann said. "The recommendation is really to get at outright falsifications. One of the real problems is with resume inflation."
 
More Like a Prison, Less Like a Home
 John Rowland, a Republican candidate for Governor in Connecticut, wants to send more criminals to prison, and he wants to do so more quicker and less comfortably than he thinks is now the case.
For example, Mr. Rowland's law-and-order platform calls for two-strikes-and-you're-out sentencing, one fewer chance for the repeat felon than most politicians are advocating.
To drive home another of his views on how criminals are handled, Mr. Rowland paid an unannounced visit last week to the state's newest prison, the $72 million York Correctional Institution under construction in Niantic. He liked little of what he saw, including an electronic scoreboard in the gymnasium marked Home and Visitors.
Mr. Rowland said that in the last 10 years the state could have doubled the number of prison beds to 18,000 if officials had been less intent on "coddling" criminals by building "palaces" like York where "extremely expensive" architectural features and "lavish" details put any high school or senior center in the state to shame.
The Correction Commissioner, Larry R. Meachum, said later that Mr. Rowland had selected a women's prison designed for rehabilitating its inmates. For women from poor, abusive backgrounds, he said, York might indeed be the nicest place they have spent time. But that also makes it a place where they might be able to change their behavior, he said.
Mr. Rowland was unappeased. "I do not believe criminals should be coddled and pampered," he said. "A prison should not be a place people enjoy going to. It should be a place they want to avoid."
 
Another Generation With Those Cuomo Genes
 Andrew Cuomo demonstrated some of his father's political reflexes the other day when he was asked about New York City Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to deny shelter to homeless families who refuse to join treatment or training programs.
The younger Mr. Cuomo, now an Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, was in New York on Friday, barnstorming for the Clinton Administration's own plan to combat homelessness.
With Mr. Cuomo by his side and advocates for the homeless eager for Federal money, Mr. Giuliani extolled the virtues of the Federal plan, saying it "reflects the philosophy and many of the same principles found in the city's new plan." Both plans stress reliance on nonprofit groups to provide shelter and on an array of social programs to help the homeless eventually find permanent housing.
But Mr. Cuomo's father, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, refused to endorse Mr. Giuliani's city plan because of its tough medicine for uncooperative homeless families. The lack of support from the Governor was surprising, since in many respects the Mayor's plan reflected the major recommendations the younger Mr. Cuomo had made last year when he headed a commission on homelessness convened by Mayor David N. Dinkins.
When Andrew Cuomo was asked if he supported Mr. Giuliani's tough-love policies, he demonstrated his father's gift for sidestepping an uncomfortable question.
"I haven't had a chance to review in detail the Mayor's plan, but what I would say is, on the Federal Government's side, we are not in the business of doing the job of local government for local government," Mr. Cuomo said. "So if the local government has an intelligent reasoned approach, this Federal government will not be second-guessing a local government."

HEADLINE: Meyer Parodneck, 89, Advocate For the Poor of New York, Dies

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS 

 BODY:
Meyer Parodneck, who promoted self-help programs for New York's poor ranging from a milk cooperative to community housing, died on Friday at his winter home in West Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Parodneck, who lived in Brooklyn, was 89.
The cause was cancer, his family said. 
 Mr. Parodneck was the founder and president of the Parodneck Foundation for Self-Help Housing and Community Development, and president of the board of the Urban Homesteading Assistance Board.
Born in Poland, Mr. Parodneck came to Manhattan at the age of 10 and grew up in poverty on the Lower East Side. He graduated from New York Law School in 1924 and practiced as a trial lawyer and corporate counsel.
During the Depression he was drawn to social issues. Appalled by the eviction of homeowners unable to meet their mortgage payments, Mr. Parodneck held rallies at courthouses to prevent evictions, and lobbied Congress for mortgage payment relief legislation.
 
Helped Form Cooperative
 Heeding warnings from social workers and consumer groups that milk was not getting to poor children in New York City and hearing pleas from upstate farmers that they were not earning enough to survive, he helped form the Consumer-Farmer Milk Cooperative in 1938.
It was the first consumer-farmer cooperative of its kind in the nation. In the beginning, the cooperative sold 10,000 quarts of milk a day at prices as low as 7 cents a bottle, slightly below the going price. It eventually grew into a $6 million-a-year operation with milk processing plants in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
Over the years the cooperative and Mr. Parodneck waged a series of battles with commercial dairies, trucking groups and labor unions to hold down the price of milk.
 
Housing Projects
 By the 1970's, however, the leaders of the cooperative found that while their organization was financially successful, it had departed from its original purpose, since milk was easily available. To that end, with the guidance of Mr. Parodneck the cooperative sold its milk business and put the proceeds into housing projects of the new Consumer-Farmer Foundation.
Using a network of settlement houses and community groups, which included its former milk customers, the foundation offered low-interest and no-interest loans to tenants on the Lower East Side and Clinton in Manhattan, and the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.
The loans helped tenants rehabilitate their own buildings and abandoned structures, in what came to be known as urban homesteading.
Last year the Consumer-Farmer Foundation changed its name to the Parodneck Foundation for Self-Help Housing and Community Development.
Mr. Parodneck is survived by his wife, Pauline, of Brooklyn, and a daughter, Carol Stern of Gaithersburg, Md.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Meyer Parodneck. (Susan Greenwood for The New York Times, 1988)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
For Yanks, Everyone's Getting In the Act

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN 

 BODY:
Be ready. The message extends to the farthest end of the Yankee dugout and the most distant seat in the bullpen. The execution of the message from Manager Buck Showalter throughout his clubhouse can separate good teams from better and better from best.
The length of the Yankee bench produced a 5-4 victory over Baltimore yesterday, the 28th in 40 games, the most successful start to a Yankee season since Casey Stengel was pushing buttons 36 springs ago. 
 Modern-day button pushing is made more complex by an era of diluted talent and incentive clauses. Yesterday, as Paul O'Neill's major league-leading .465 average stayed on the bench for a day, as Wade Boggs was held out again because of a rib problem and the nagging injuries of starting pitcher Melido Perez created complications, depth became a decisive factor.
Scott Kamieniecki, for now a part-time starting pitcher, held the Orioles to one run in three and one-third innings of relief after Perez was limited to five innings by a strained lower back and painful big toe on his right foot.
"The good thing is Buck's using everyone," Kamieniecki said, "and when you use everyone you stay strong."
Gerald Williams, a backup outfielder in his seventh start of the season, produced a two-run, game-tying single in the first inning. "I can't dwell on wanting to be an everyday player," Williams said. "And I'm not."
 
Melvin Homer Keys 5-Run First
 And Bob Melvin, who at this time last month was an unemployed catcher, hit the three-run homer that completed a five-run first inning that wound up being enough to win. Melvin became the fifth designated hitter Showalter has used this season. He understood the value of a seat on the Yankee bench before he was signed to a minor-league contract April 26 and promoted May 14.
"I follow box scores," Melvin said. "I like to watch managers and see how they manage games. Buck keeps everybody involved. He's pretty flexible with his lineup. He gives everybody a chance."
Kamieniecki's chance, so far, has consisted of six relief appearances in his nine outings. He did not improve upon his 3-0 record yesterday, and he did not earn his first save. Kamieniecki just rescued the Yankees on a bright afternoon after Perez (3-2) struggled just long enough to earn a victory.
The Yankees won for the ninth consecutive time at home, their longest winning streak at Yankee Stadium since 1987, because Kamieniecki and Steve Howe, in his first appearance since returning from the disabled list Friday, combined to hold the Orioles to one run and two hits in the last four innings.
 
Injured Perez Needs Relief
 Showalter tried to discourage Perez from starting because of the injuries, and Kamieniecki was sent to the bullpen before the game in case of a sudden problem. Perez will not start again until next Saturday at Kansas City.
"The team is playing so well," Perez said. "I'm excited to play right now. I said, 'I don't want to wait so long to play.' "
In the first of Perez's five innings, his shortest outing of the season, he allowed a run-scoring single by Rafael Palmeiro, who extended his hitting streak to a club-record 23 games, the longest in the major leagues this season. Cal Ripken's double, inside third base and down the left-field line, scored a second run.
The lead did not last long because of the Baltimore starter Arthur Rhodes's problems. Making his first start since he was on the disabled list with tendinitis in his left knee, Rhodes (1-5) did not retire a hitter in the second inning. After the game, he was sent to the Rochester farm club.
"He didn't miss any bats when he was in the strike zone," said Oriole Manager Johnny Oates.
Rhodes allowed five earned runs in the first on Gerald Williams's two-run single to the left of third baseman Leo Gomez, and Melvin's three-run homer over the left-center field fence.
Perez allowed a fifth-inning double by Palmeiro that scored Mark McLemore, who had tripled. Kamieniecki gave up a run-scoring double to Harold Baines in the seventh. In the ninth, pinch-hitter Chris Hoiles sent a fly ball to the right-center warning track.
That was as close as the Yankees came to a scare, before Howe produced two groundouts to earn his third save. Another button pushed. Another Yankee victory. Another day in first place.

HEADLINE: Defending Federal Aid for Small Companies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Washington Growing as a Financial Angel to Industry" (May 1) expresses concern about possible pork barrel projects and says that accusations of special-interest awards have already surfaced in the case of a $50 million award by the Advanced Research Projects Agency to OIS Optical Imaging Systems Inc., makers of active-matrix flat panel displays. 
 As the inventor and pioneer of this technology -- the focus of the new $1 billion initiative and one in which Japan Inc. has so far invested at least $4 billion -- let me say emphatically that these accusations have no basis and are simply expressions of sour grapes by large companies like I.B.M. and AT&T. Such giants have so far refused to make any investment themselves beyond some R & D work but were holding out their hands for the $50 million.
The language written into the Federal appropriations bill, reportedly to suit OIS, involved an obvious requirement for qualification for the award -- namely that the company should already be in the business of making active-matrix displays and should have made substantial investments of its own before the award. Neither I.B.M. nor AT&T (nor any of the other complainers ) has so far made such a commitment in the United States (I.B.M. has a joint venture with Toshiba in Japan; AT&T is still sitting on the fence). OIS is the only American company presently manufacturing, albeit in small quantities, these key components. It seems eminently fair that OIS should receive this comparatively small award, which is significant to it but would make little difference to a company like I.B.M.T.
 
PETER BRODY
Pittsburgh, May 2
 
The writer, president of Active Matrix Associates, is not associated with OIS Optical Imaging Systems Inc.

HEADLINE: Time to Widen the Tony's Scope

 BODY:
Broadway theater is about to honor itself with Tony awards for this year's "best." Millions watching on television three weeks from tonight, or reading the winners' publicity blurbs thereafter, will be given the impression that these are the best there are. That may be -- or may not.
Tony awards go only to shows in 35 big houses in or near the midtown theater district of New York City. That is a mistake. The Tony was established almost 50 years ago, when "Broadway" meant American theater. Times have changed. It is time the Tony changed, too -- to include Off Broadway stages which, along with regional theater, have become consistently lively and creative. 
 Indeed, this year's Pulitzer Prize for drama went to Off Broadway's "Three Tall Women." So did the New York Drama Critics Circle Award. But it will not get a Tony. "Driving Miss Daisy" and "Oleanna" were not eligible either.
This year's Tony nominations for musicals expose another flaw. The rules say four shows will be put to the 700 eligible voters. The nominating committee felt only two had Tony quality, but the committee that sponsors and administers the awards insisted on four. So there are four now, including two previously rejected.
The case for confining Tony awards to 35 designated theaters is basically economic. Broadway shows cost more to produce; their Tony ballyhoo yields higher profits. Off Broadway operates in smaller theaters, at lower ticket prices, with wage concessions from the theatrical unions and actors.
The economic discrepancy is obvious, but not insurmountable. The loser, meanwhile, is the credibility of the awards. While there are usually excellent productions on Broadway, that is not always the case, and there are often better productions that get less acclaim and television exposure off Broadway.
New York City thrives on its magnetism as America's theatrical center, on Broadway and off. The Tony's focus is too narrow.

HEADLINE: Don't Fudge on China

 BODY:
By the end of next week, President Clinton must decide whether China has met the modest human rights conditions he set last year for renewal of its favorable access to American markets. He should face up to the reality that these conditions have not been met and propose targeted economic sanctions to Congress. These should be designed to send a strong political message while limiting the economic damage to both sides. Some damage is inevitable, but it is a cost worth paying for principle and consistency.
Chinese leaders plead that this has been a difficult year -- uncertainty over who will succeed Deng Xiaoping, problems with economic reform, inflation, new pressures for democracy, peasant and labor unrest. They ask the U.S. to suspend its human rights concerns and accept repression for the sake of stability and growth. 
 To indulge this request would betray American principles and credibility and encourage Chinese leaders to ignore the political and social problems that now threaten economic reform.
China's future course will be determined in Beijing, not Washington. But as China's top trading partner and most important diplomatic interlocutor, the U.S. has unmatched potential to influence Chinese decisions. Annual fights over trade privileges are a messy way to exercise this influence. But they were the only levers available to Congress when the Bush Administration responded inadequately to the Tiananmen Massacre of 1989.
The Clinton Administration tried to offer China a reasonable way out in a May 1993 executive order. But China, lulled perhaps by past American toothlessness and publicly aired divisions between U.S. economic and diplomatic officials, chose confrontation instead.
The executive order set seven conditions China had to fulfill to have its trade privileges renewed this summer. Two were absolute: stop exporting goods made by prison labor and allow free emigration for otherwise eligible dissidents. It also needed to show progress in five other areas: accounting for political prisoners, allowing Red Cross visits to prisons, easing repression in Tibet, adhering to the International Declaration of Human Rights and ending jamming of the Voice of America.
China has released prominent dissidents, allowed others to emigrate and accepted the principle of Red Cross visits. But it has only made promises concerning prison labor and the Voice of America. And it has intensified repression in Beijing, Shanghai and Tibet and failed to demonstrate significant progress in several of the specified areas. That mixed record might have narrowly justified renewal had China not gone out of its way to show contempt for American human rights concerns. Beijing has, in effect, called the President's bluff.
Mr. Clinton now needs to retaliate by proposing selective sanctions that send the strongest political message at the lowest economic cost. Rather than revoking trade privileges across the board, he should propose higher duties on specific categories of goods -- for example, those produced by companies run by China's army. Sorting out the origin of Chinese imports presents technical problems. But U.S. trade negotiators have managed to come up with selective lists before.
Whatever Mr. Clinton decides to do on China, the consequences will be huge. If he backs off in the face of Beijing's bullying, China's democrats, intellectuals and minorities will pay a high price and American credibility on issues from human rights to nuclear proliferation will be nil. If his choice of sanctions touches off a trade war, China will be unable to sustain its present rapid growth rate, while profits and jobs in a number of American export industries, notably aerospace, will be lost.
But the real significance of Mr. Clinton's choice transcends even these weighty specifics. Balanced and respectful relations between the U.S. and China are the key to future peace, prosperity and democracy throughout the dynamic East Asia region. For the last five years, at least, those relations have been anything but balanced and respectful.
The way to repair the relationship is not by fudging real differences over basic issues like prison labor, torture and religious persecution. It is by consistently following through on the reasonable policies Mr. Clinton announced a year ago.

HEADLINE: Journal;
Disney's Bull Run

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
Mickey Mouse didn't make his fame and fortune by mocking all that Americans hold dear. But his adoptive parent, the Walt Disney Company, is increasingly finding itself cast as the bad guy as it tries to build a historical theme park, Disney's America, near hallowed Civil War ground in Virginia.
A controversy that began last fall as a standard debate about the perils of development -- Disney's America would radically transform a pastoral county 35 miles west of Washington -- is now escalating into a cultural civil war. It's getting bloody, and far more than a single business enterprise is at stake. The battle over Disney's America is part of a much larger struggle between theme-park America and authentic America: Will this country preserve its real history, which requires education and reflection to be understood, or simply turn it over to the Imagineers of Disney, to be repackaged as socko virtual reality? 
 Last week more than 30 intellectual big guns calling themselves Project Historic America attacked Disney's America. Noting that the park was adjacent to 13 historic towns, 16 Civil War battle sites and 17 historic districts, David McCullough, author of "Truman," accused Disney of creating "synthetic history by destroying real history." His fellow critics include Arthur Schlesinger Jr., William Styron and, fittingly, Shelby Foote, the historian who became a star on the PBS documentary "The Civil War." They were belatedly joined by Ken Burns, the producer of "The Civil War," who lent qualified support to the protest even though he is developing a movie with the Disney studio.
The unbuilt Disney's America has outstripped even Euro Disney as a public-relations headache. Last fall Michael Eisner, Disney's chairman, had to disavow an executive's announcement that a park attraction would "make you feel what it was like to be a slave." Since then, Disney's America has been challenged by the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the Sierra Club, the National Audubon Society and the Wilderness Society. Once Disney revealed that Mr. Eisner's compensation for 1993 was $203 million, Virginia taxpayers took a harsher look at why their Governor, George Allen, pushed them so hard to subsidize $163 million in road construction on Disney's behalf.
Still, the issues of money, urban sprawl and environmental disruption that attend the park are between the Virginia voters and their consciences. The esthetic issues dramatized by Disney's America concern everyone. As The Economist recently reported, theme parks are growing so rapidly that their revenues have passed those of movie box offices in the United States. New virtual-reality technology -- as championed by Iwerks, a company formed by Disney alumni -- will spread "downsized" theme parks in suburban malls. At what point do these simulations of experience cease being mere escapist fun, like old-fashioned amusement parks, and replace authentic experience of our own environment and heritage?
This question has always been inherent in the Disney parks. Frontierland and Main Street in Disneyland, or "France" and "Italy" in Epcot Center, are ideologically loaded fantasies of the real things. But Disney's America raises the ante, not only by simulating history on a larger scale but by doing so in such close proximity to our bona fide historic trusts.
Disney's America will not merely affect its neighboring battlefields but the nation's capital and beyond. Will the Smithsonian, or the Lincoln Memorial, or Mount Vernon soon have to add new electronic gimmickry to compete for kids' attention with Disney's oxymoronic promise of "an authentic re-enactment" of a Civil War battle? Will Colonial Williamsburg, itself a doctored imitation of history and a precursor of Disneyland, add Audio-Animatronic colonials to its cast of actors?
When Ada Louise Huxtable, the architecture critic, sounded the alarm about the new "unreal America" in a remarkably prescient 1992 essay in The New York Review of Books, Disney's plan for a historical theme park had yet to be revealed. But even then Mrs. Huxtable saw an America in which "themed entertainment" was driving out not just "the actual deposits of history and humanity" but "our sense of reality or interest in it." With the advent of Disney's America, the big bad wolf is standing right outside the door, poised to devour our past.

HEADLINE: Shouldn't the Fed Act in the Public Interest?;
Inflation Signs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Lester Thurow's "Fed Goes Ghostbusting" (Op-Ed, May 6) states that "Sophisticated investors including George Soros, Citicorp and Bankers Trust took huge losses because of the Fed's action" to support his criticism of Fed tightening. 
 Our well-publicized losses this year have nothing to do with the Fed's action. If anything, our investment strategy was geared toward the Fed's acting earlier and more dramatically. Mr. Thurow cites one lagging indicator after another to support his case that there is no inflation. Unfortunately, the majority of the leading indicators of inflation turned up many months ago. Since the effects of monetary policy have a long lead time, those are more relevant.
Moreover, Mr. Thurow ignores the fact that a 3 percent funds rate was an accommodative measure put in place to fight the "50-mile-an-hour headwinds" that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has cited.
With the banking system's balance sheet vastly improved and the economy expanding well above its long-run potential, the notion that monetary policy should be accommodative is absurd. The real question is whether it should be neutral or restrictive.
 
STANLEY F. DRUCKENMILLER
Managing Director
Soros Fund Management
New York, May 9, 1994

HEADLINE: Shouldn't the Fed Act in the Public Interest?;
No Time for Stalling

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a mutual fund investor, I was pleased with "The Fed Goes Ghostbusting" by Lester Thurow (Op-Ed, May 6). He points out the lack of any inflation signs and recommends that the Federal Reserve Board should stop raising interest rates. But his arguments seem to have little effect. 
 A May 10 Business Day headline reads "Stocks Fall Over Fears of Inflation." The Dow Jones did indeed fall 40.46 points, but "Stocks Fall Over Fear of Another Fed Rate Hike" would be more accurate.
The main reason I closed a number of 2.38 percent money market accounts and certificates of deposit last summer and went into a mutual fund was my feeling that the new Administration's policies, like reducing the national debt and working for better and less costly health care, should insure a sounder national economy. It looked as if this was indeed happening, and by early February I was running ahead by 7 percent, not bad for seven months.
At this point the Fed leaked a rumor that it was thinking of jacking up the interest rate. This started a slide in the Dow Jones and soon afterward the Fed did raise the rate, which further depressed the market. This was followed by two more leaks and raises until my account is now so low that I am 1 1/2 percent below my original investment.
As for looming inflation, I'm buying gasoline for 99.8 cents, the lowest in years. If I need a new second car I have a choice of several under 10K with major technical and esthetic improvements over past models. Medicare insurance checks, which used to take months to process, are coming back almost by return mail, and my American Association of Retired Persons supplemental insurance carrier is passing a small dividend.
Supermarkets are competing with one another to offer bargain food specials. Several new ethnic restaurants have opened in our vicinity, with excellent dishes at affordable prices.
Future foreign competition alone should stifle any tendency to inflation. Aside from making some Republicans happy, deliberate stalling of the economy doesn't make sense at this time. Thank you, Professor Thurow.
 
WALTER DORWIN TEAGUE JR.
Nyack, N.Y., May 10, 1994
