HEADLINE: Shouldn't the Fed Act in the Public Interest?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Fed Goes Ghostbusting" (Op-Ed, May 6), Lester Thurow makes a formidable critique of the Federal Reserve and the premature fear of inflation that led it to a threefold raise of interest rates. Real wages have declined, productivity has risen, prices are competitively geared against an inflation spiral, United States companies are running nowhere close to their production limits, the economy is not overheating. 
 Yet, he notes, "the Fed is intent on killing a very weak recovery that has yet to include most Americans" by hiking credit costs. Bond traders and investors sold off in haste, seeking protection against a Fed policy that aims for zero inflation, when there is no sign of price escalation in sight.
On the day of the market selloff, unemployment in New York mounted to 8.2 percent for March, oil prices fell to a healthy low, and purchasing power (in real terms) continued its historic downward trend. The immediate cause of the flight of the traders was the new unemployment figures: the rate went from 6.5 to 6.4 percent, largely because low rates of hiring in a long, hard winter were at last corrected. In short, there were 100,000 jobs more than expected. But this was in a labor force of 120 million, which excluded nearly 12 percent of black and Hispanic job seekers.
Is it not a function of government, even in a business-minded society, to protect underprivileged citizens against market excesses? We look to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the Food and Drug Administration to protect us, to the Securities and Exchange Commission and the courts to curb abuses of market power.
Should the Federal Reserve not put the defense of national interests ahead of its concerns for the speculative anxieties of bank funds and bond traders?
 
WALTER GOLDSTEIN
Professor of Public Policy
Rockefeller College, SUNY
Albany, May 9, 1994

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;
Trying to Keep the U.N. United, Within City Borders

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Although the United Nations has been wedded to New York for nearly 50 years, intense competition erupted in the 1990's to lure prized agencies like Unicef and the United Nations Development Program to the suburbs and even overseas. City officials, fearing the diplomatic equivalent of losing the Brooklyn Dodgers, redoubled efforts to keep the agencies firmly rooted on the banks of the East River.
Now those efforts are starting to pay off, local officials say. The city has found a new home for Unicef, which wanted to relocate, and is pursuing other footloose agencies. City officials are also encouraged by renewed real estate activity around the United Nations complex. 
 And as the world body redefines its role in the post-cold-war era, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali is seeking more unified agency operations, which bodes well for New York.
"The U.N. is a franchise industry for New York, and it enhances our reputation as an international city," said Lance Ruiz Carlile, vice president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
The exploration of new sites originated because of space needs as well as cost pressures in the early 1990's, when the United Nations was strained by delays in aid from the United States and the collapsing Soviet Union.
Unicef, which decided to stay in Manhattan last fall after reviewing 75 proposals for other locations, has recently chosen 633 Third Avenue for its expansion site. The United Nations Development Corporation, a city and state agency, is buying the building from the Travelers Companies for Unicef for an undisclosed price. The children's aid agency will occupy 18 of the 41 floors as a condominium.
Unicef will continue in its main building, the nearby 3 United Nations Plaza, also owned by the U.N. Development Corporation. As an additional incentive to stay, Unicef will get the deed when the bonds are paid off in the year 2026. Community Board 6 approved the plans last week. Unicef has 900 jobs in its headquarters; that is expected to grow to 1,500 in coming years.
Several other agencies hunting for sites may follow to 633 Third Avenue. "Unicef's decision gives us a much better chance to keep the others," Mr. Carlile said. "Its lead makes the case for efficiency and consolidation."
New plans for a 23-floor diplomatic office building at 871 First Avenue, opposite the United Nations, signal private confidence in U.N. growth, despite the slumping real estate and construction market. Albanese Development Corporation, a private company, plans to start the project this fall and says it is negotiating with several countries about occupying the building.
In addition, Mayor Giuliani announced this month plans to sell the 427-room, government-owned U.N. Plaza-Park Hyatt Hotel. "We've already gotten lots of calls," Mr. Carlile said.
But the rivalry for agencies is not over. Germany made a lucrative offer, including free rent and $184 million for relocation, to entice several agencies to Bonn. A plum is the United Nations Development Program, which aids overseas development. "It's not a household name like Unicef, but it has even more jobs, about 1,200," said Mr. Carlile. No action has been taken, and officials say that the longer the offer lingers, the more likely the agency will stay put.
"We have a very good relationship with the city of New York," said Juan Carlos Brandt, a spokesman for the Secretary General. "The Mayor's office is dedicated to easing our problems, and we're very happy to be here." BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
Board Defies Mayor Over Fulton Fish Market

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE 

 BODY:
No one was surprised last week when Community Board 1 endorsed plans for a new business improvement district for lower Manhattan. But the board also defied the Giuliani administration by recommending that the B.I.D.'s boundaries include the Fulton Fish Market.
Tom Cusick, the project manager for the proposed district and president of the Fifth Avenue Business Improvement District, told the board that the Mayor's office had requested the market be left out of the B.I.D. discussions because of what he called "investigations." 
 In March, Randy M. Mastro, the Mayor's chief of staff, said that "new procedures and initiatives" were being planned for oversight issues at the market, which for decades has been considered a haven for organized crime.
"Ever since I was a kid," said Anne Compoccia, the chairwoman of the community board, "some agency has been periodically investigating the market. They can't defame hundreds of working men and women."
But Jill Minelli, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Business Services, said that because the market was city owned, it would not contribute financially to the B.I.D. "Since the city is already handling services there," she said, "we recommend that the fish market not be included in the B.I.D."
The B.I.D. proposal now goes to the City Planning Commission. If approved, it moves on to the City Council. M.H.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;
Caldor's Success May Lure More Big Stores to Downtown

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
When the Caldor Corporation opened a branch in the old Alexander's department store on Roosevelt Avenue eight months ago, its executives were uncertain. "We weren't 100 percent sure this was the right market for us," said Marc Balmuth, Caldor's president. He's no longer uncertain.
"It's one of our highest-volume stores," Mr. Balmuth said. "We believe it's successful because the area is densely populated and it's continuing to grow." Caldor, a discount chain based in Norwalk, Conn., acquired a long-term lease on the site in Federal Bankruptcy Court in 1992. 
 Caldor's arrival is just one sign of change in an area that has recently grown in population, investment and economic activity. Since 1986, the number of retailers in downtown Flushing has increased 7.6 percent to 874, and it is now one of the city's largest retail districts. City planners have proposed a huge expansion of the retail area, and a major street improvement project is under way.
Business and community leaders say that the presence of Caldor's could attract other chains like Mandee, Strawberry's and Benetton. And City Councilwoman Julia Harrison and some business leaders are seeking to create a business improvement district to help market the area.
"It's nice to have a store of that magnitude come in because then we can go out and get things we lack, like women's department stores," said John Watts, chief of staff for Councilwoman Harrison. Additional businesses would complement Caldor as well as Stern's department store, a Roosevelt Avenue mainstay, and other big newcomers like E. Land Shop, which opened in December.
But some business leaders are concerned that large retailers could hurt the mom-and-pop establishments that account for most of Flushing's stores. "We need to make sure our present businesses are protected," said Jeff Chen, head of the Flushing Chinese Business Association, which has about 300 members.
But Mr. Watts says that given the proposals for expanding the downtown area, there will be more than enough business to go around without damaging the smaller stores. Last October, city planners called for rezoning a manufacturing district on either side of Prince Street, which would more than triple the allowable commercial density and also permit residential development.
Thousands of immigrants, mostly Chinese and Koreans, have settled in downtown Flushing in the last decade, and many banks came on their heels, competing for the Asians' savings. The banks were also attracted by the influx of hundreds of restaurants, Asian grocery stores and fashionable boutiques. Some 50,000 people pass through downtown Flushing daily. Shoppers can ride 19 bus lines and one subway line to get there.
The City Economic Development Corporation is completing a $10.5 million street improvement project. Its first phase, rebuilding Prince Street, was completed about five years ago.
The second phase, along Main Street, is scheduled to be finished in August. Roadways have been repaired, traffic lights and lighting fixtures installed and trees planted. Catie Marshall, a spokeswoman for the development agency, said that a third phase, along Union Street, was still being planned.
The street improvements have created traffic jams for months. But Joe Chen, who owns Tsui Garden, a Chinese restaurant at 136-11 38th Avenue, praises the project. "The street repairs needed to be done," he said. "Without them, I don't think so many people would be moving in."
Asked about the effort to bring in large retailers, Mr. Chen said: "I'm in the restaurant business and I worry whenever I see a new restaurant opening up. This is a very competitive area and if I were in the retail business, I wouldn't look on it favorably." LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:
New York Jewelers Unite To Be More Competitive
 The streets of New York may not be paved with gold, but 47th Street and the surrounding jewelry district come close -- and, in the face of growing domestic and global competition, the jewelers want to keep it that way. Last week, merchants joined forces with Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, the Fashion Institute of Technology and the Gemological Institute of America to form the Diamond and Jewelry Industries Development Corporation. 
 "If the city is to remain a significant force in the industry," said Ralph Destino, chairman of Cartier Inc. and a member of the corporation's board, "it's going to have to battle for it."
The development corporation will provide technical assistance to manufacturers and sponsor forums on the export trade as well as worker training programs. The Borough President's office has pledged $780,000 for capital improvements to 47th Street and the surrounding area, which will include outdoor video cameras to improve security for merchants carrying precious cargo. The jewelry industry employs 26,000 people.
 
Nordictrack Is Opening Two Stores in Manhattan
 Nordictrack, the company that brought cross-country skiing into the American home, is starting up two stores in Manhattan.
The first site opened last week in Union Square, which is also home to Paragon and Herman's. "It's turning into a sporting goods mecca," said Tom Knierim, associate director of the 14th Street/Union Square Local Development Corporation. The second Nordictrack shop, at 650 Madison Avenue at 60th Street, is scheduled to open in late June.
The store in Union Square, at 202 Park Avenue South at 17th Street, will carry the company's full line of products, including apparel and sports books as well as aerobic and strength-training equipment. Chris Werle, a spokesman for Nordictrack, which is based in Chaska, Minn., said the 4,000-square-foot store would offer discounted and close-out goods. The Madison Avenue store, he said, will be smaller and "more upscale and trendy."
 
Red Hook Group Helps Merchants Deal With City
Four years after it was founded, the South Brooklyn Local Development Corporation in Red Hook now finds itself with a membership of more than 200 businesses, an annual budget of $400,000 and plans to make the area cleaner, safer and more convenient for businesses and residents.
"Basically we're trying to set up a business improvement district," said Michael Butler, who was named economic development director of the group last month. "We help local businesses deal with city services -- like the Sanitation Department -- or help them utilize existing programs for tax credits and lower energy costs."
With financing from the state and city, the nonprofit group is planning security patrols, clean-up crews and a free shuttle bus to the subway so residents can avoid paying two fares. This month the group began running a Saturday bus tour of Red Hook for residents and visitors in Manhattan and Brooklyn Heights.

HEADLINE: The Kids Managing America's Money

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
THE stock market's skidding, the bond market's bombing and if you had to invest all by yourself, you might be in a panic. But fortunately, like millions of Americans, you've hired a pro to take care of all that: a mutual fund manager, or two or three. Wise old hands, these silver-haired money managers have seen it all before and know what to do when times get tough. Right?
Guess again. These days, more than a third of all mutual funds, including some of the biggest, are run by people in their 20's and 30's, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund-tracking service. Many of these managers were born in the 1960's and were in grade school during the last terrible bear market, which began in 1973. Some had not even started managing other people's money in 1987, when the markets collapsed. 
 While hard numbers are difficult to come by, everyone agrees that there are more youngsters running funds now than 5 or 10 years ago.
Why? For one thing, the number of mutual funds has boomed, to 3,800 (excluding money-market funds), from 1,800 in 1987, as Americans dismayed by falling returns on other investments have rushed into this kind. That's a lot of new funds in need of managers.
So much money has come the funds' way -- assets are now $1.5 trillion, up from $114 billion a decade ago -- that some of the most experienced managers have stopped accepting new money. As a result, "More and more, we're being forced to look at funds and managers that haven't been around as long as we'd like," said Ken Gregory, a principal in Litman/Gregory & Company, a financial advisory firm in Orinda, Calif.
The young'uns can be found in all parts of the business, from plain vanilla American stocks to obscure bonds from exotic countries, at conservative insurance companies and aggressive hot-growth "boutiques," managing funds sold by brokers and funds you can buy directly.
Some, like Robert K. Citrone, 29, of Fidelity Investments, specialize in investments new to mutual funds, including emerging-markets debt. Others, like a group of Texans led by 32-year-old Jonathan C. Schoolar, are traditionalists, following a stock-picking system laid down by their forebears.
Some, like James P. Goff, 30, and Warren B. Lammert, 32, of Janus Capital, started buying stocks when they were sprouts and read The Wall Street Journal when other college kids read Rolling Stone. Others, like Patricia Bannan, 32, and Catherine Dudley, 34, of the Phoenix Funds, got into the business more serendipitously.
Some, like Jennifer L. E. Leichter, 33, of Putnam Management, work in close-knit teams under an experienced supervisor at firms in the business a long time. Others, like David Herro, 33, are building businesses almost from scratch; they are the supervisors. And others, like Michael Gordon, 29, of Fidelity, work for long-established firms that treat managers as autonomous entrepreneurs.
For all the agreement that younger people are managing bigger amounts, there is no consensus on whether this matters.
Peter Lynch, the 50-year-old who propelled Fidelity's Magellan Fund to tremendous returns in the 1980's, scoffs at "the age issue." Fidelity is famous for allowing young people to invest customers' money early in their careers, and Mr. Lynch, who started running Magellan when he was 33, thinks that's as it should be. Noting that Newton and Einstein made their most significant discoveries in their 20's, he said of managing money, "You can be good at this business in three years."
Other astute money managers disagree, and vehemently. One is William H. Gross, 50, managing director of the Pacific Investment Management Company and sometimes called the Peter Lynch of the bond business. "It takes years of seasoning, developing not only your instincts but also a knowledge of yourself and other people," Mr. Gross said. "You can't become a good money manager in three years. You haven't proven yourself in bull and bear markets, you haven't experienced all the emotion of the market over time."
Some of the young fund managers have done better than average, some worse. But so far, no young manager has driven a fund off a cliff. Of course, most haven't had driver's licenses very long. And with the bull market in recent years, it has been hard to lose money. Now, with the markets slowing, the road may be rougher.
There have always been young money managers; hot-shots like Mario Gabelli had to start somewhere. But it was usually not by managing billions of other people's dollars. "When I was 28, I thought I was pretty good, and I was," said Mr. Gabelli, now 52. "I did very well then, but it was with family assets, which was not a lot of money."
In fact, until recently, nobody in the fund business was managing a lot of money. Ten years ago, only 20 funds had assets of $1 billion or more; today, almost 300 do, and Fidelity Magellan alone has $33 billion (and is run by a 35-year-old, Jeff Vinik). Mr. Gabelli said he will entrust neophytes with small sums, but he prefers fund managers who've been clawed by the bear. "We have a saying that we don't want to age our clients' greenbacks with our green staff," he said.
But experienced managers are increasingly hard to come by, fund companies complain, particularly in hot areas like international investing.
Because money managers tend to stick with what they know, new kinds of investing tend to attract new -- almost always young -- managers. Lately, lots of new investment techniques have sprung up, including some that use complex computer models to pick stocks or bonds.
MEANWHILE, some managers have left their funds to join private investment partnerships, where they can make a lot more money. (Virtually all fund managers have total compensation in six figures, with those running the largest and most successful funds making more than a million.) And many old hands have retired, sometimes selling their firms for big bucks.
But for every veteran who leaves, there are many rookies clamoring to get in. Next month, more than 22,000 people will take an exam to receive the degree of chartered financial analyst, a step toward becoming a money manager. That's more people, by several thousand, than have received C.F.A. degrees in 30 years.
And many funds are happy to see the fresh faces. Elizabeth Katsivelos, director of career services at Columbia Business School, said more funds are hiring M.B.A.'s right out of school.
How can you tell whether a newcomer is managing your money? It isn't easy. Legally, funds don't have to disclose managers' ages; until last year, they didn't even have to give out the managers' names. Now that funds must identify the people running them, they try to fudge by claiming they are run by a team, or by listing a senior executive along with the whippersnapper who's really in charge, complained John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds.
The following look at a dozen managers who were all born in the 1960's and manage more than a billion dollars for six very different kinds of mutual-fund companies shows a bright and energetic group whose self-confidence can strike one as either heartening or terrifying.
 
 
 
THEIR ELDER STATESMAN IS 32
 YOUTH does not always mean innovation. Some of the youngest fund managers are, rather, disciples, dedicated to carrying on the work of their founding fathers.
Take the young Texans who manage about $10 billion in stock funds for AIM Capital in Houston. When AIM got into this business in 1986, it hired two of the oldest managers around, Harry Hutzler and Julian Lerner. Both men, devotees of the stocks of fast-growing companies, known as growth stocks, began working with the bright youngsters who came off AIM's trading desk.
Mr. Hutzler retired last year, leaving Jonathan C. Schoolar, 32, in charge of continuing "the discipline," as they call their stock-picking system, which focuses on companies' earnings growth.
Though the largest fund, AIM Weingarten, had bad years in 1992 and 1993, the boys have faith in Mr. Hutzler's method. "The discipline has worked fantastically," said Robert M. Kippes, 28. "All we have to do is be willing to work hard, follow the discipline, and the rest is history."
Mr. Lerner, now 69, still manages one of the funds with Lanny H. Sachnowitz, 29. He said he admires the young men, who are full of energy and computer know-how but not full of themselves.
"It's pretty heady stuff, when you're a young person and they're throwing millions of dollars at you," he said. "You've kind of got to keep your feet on the ground."
All four are competitive and passionate sports fans. Three of the four are Texans born and bred. The fourth, Joel E. Dobberpuhl, 27, is a Minnesotan with no desire to go back North. They display a bit of impatience with people who ask how such young guys can manage money. "A lot of it just gets back to common sense and stupidity," Mr. Dobberpuhl said. "You can be stupid when you're 60, too."
 
 
 
YOUNG AND FREE AT FIDELITY
 NO fund company has more young managers, with more responsibility, than Fidelity Investments.
As the country's largest mutual-fund company, Fidelity often comes across as the Boston Behemoth, a monolithic investment machine. But in truth, "our equity fund managers are essentially autonomous," said William Hayes, who heads the stock-fund group.
Which gives a lot of freedom to managers like Michael Gordon, 29, who joined Fidelity in 1987, right out of Harvard. He was interested in stocks, he said, "but it wasn't like I was reading The Wall Street Journal daily from the time I was 11." He became an analyst, ultimately specializing in biotechnology stocks.
In 1990 he became manager of the Fidelity fund that focuses on biotech issues. That year and the next, such stocks soared, and the fund boomed, growing from $70 million at the end of 1989 to more than $1 billion by the end of 1991. But in 1992 the rocket burned out; the fund suffered double-digit losses and investors fled. Mr. Gordon was not blamed for the losses, which hit the entire biotech market, and he moved on, serving as an assistant on Magellan and then last year taking over the $1.5 billion Blue Chip Growth Fund, which unlike most of its competitors is in the black this year. But the scars remain. "I do have a healthy respect for the market," he said, "a good amount of fear."
Robert Citrone, 29, doesn't seem to have that fear -- at least not yet. He joined Fidelity in 1990 with an M.B.A. from the University of Virginia, and started as an analyst of corporate bonds. But a stint in research on foreign-government bonds had given him an interest in emerging-markets debt, and Fidelity encouraged him to pursue it.
Three and a half years ago, Fidelity's funds had no investments in emerging-market debt; now Mr. Citrone manages $7 billion, spread across many kinds of funds.
But after some superb performances, these bonds have plunged this year; the New Markets Income Fund he runs has dropped more than 20 percent. Undaunted, Mr. Citrone thinks these markets still offer "huge upside potential."
 
 
 
DIFFERENT PATHS TO THE TOP
 LOTS of young fund managers are freshly minted M.B.A.'s who probably carried their sandwiches to school in briefcases and traded bonds instead of baseball cards. But there are exceptions.
Neither Catherine Dudley, 34, nor Patricia Bannan, 32, intended to be a money manager. A year after graduating from the University of Connecticut, Ms. Dudley tired of running a restaurant. As for Ms. Bannan, fresh out of the University of New Hampshire, "I didn't know what I wanted to do, but I knew I wanted to eat."
Both ended up at Phoenix Life Insurance in administrative jobs; both jumped at the chance to work as junior analysts for Robert Chesek, the firm's growth-stock manager, who retired last year. Within three years both were managing portfolios.
Today, Ms. Dudley manages, among other things, the $2.2 billion Phoenix Growth Fund, which hasn't been a barn-burner (it has averaged a 6 percent annual gain over the last three years, while the S.& P. 500 has made 9 percent a year). This year, however, Ms. Dudley's strategy looks better; the fund's losses are more modest than those of the index or the average growth fund.
Ms. Bannan serves as president of Phoenix Investment Counsel and runs the $2.8 billion Phoenix Balanced Fund, which like the growth fund has tended to lag its peers in good years but beat them in bad ones.
Experience is more important than age, Ms. Bannan said, "but there are benefits to being younger. You have a more open mind, fewer biases, and a fresher outlook."
 
 
 
BORN TO BE FUND MANAGERS
IN earlier decades, they would have had to spend more time as analysts before running other people's money. Nevertheless, some of today's young guns seem to have been born to be fund managers.
That seems the case for James Goff, 30, and Warren Lammert, 32, comanagers of the $1.5 billion Janus Venture Fund. The two have a lot in common. Both bought stocks as kids, both went to Yale, and both went to interviews with Fred Alger Management without being sure just what it was the firm managed. The answer was growth stocks; both joined the firm as analysts. And both moved to Janus Capital in Denver, following Thomas Marsico, who at 38 runs the big Janus 20 Fund.
Mr. Lammert did once make a break for it, deciding to get degrees from the London School of Economics and Harvard so he could go into teaching. But he changed his mind and was soon back in Denver, skiing, playing hockey -- and investing.
Both started managing private accounts for Janus in 1991, and soon started separate mutual funds. But they didn't take over the enormous Venture fund until the end of last year, when James Craig decided he needed to devote his full attention to the firm's flagship Janus Fund, which had soared to $9.1 billion in assets. Their first few months haven't been easy; the fund is down almost 5 percent this year. But that's no worse than the average fund investing in small companies.
The young managers get a lot of feedback from above. For example, Mr. Lammert said, Thomas Bailey, the founder, "will remind you how many of his friends became ski instructors in the 70's -- of how things can get worse."
 
 
 
A 'GRAND OLD MAN' AT 33
 SELF-CONFIDENCE is a hallmark of young mutual-fund managers, but some stand out for it -- and for other people's willingness to take a risk with them.
When David G. Herro, 33, who manages the $1.4 billion Oakmark International Fund, started managing overseas investments, he was 26, and the sum of his international travel was a fishing trip to Canada. He also had a master's degree in economics from the University of Wisconsin, a year's work experience selling meat for Hormel, and a longtime love of stocks, which he picked up working as a golf caddy for stockbrokers in his hometown, Fond du Lac, Wis.
So he confidently accepted an invitation to start an international fund for Principal Mutual Life, and three years later to move to the State of Wisconsin Investment Board, where he ended up managing $800 million in pension funds. In 1992 he moved to Harris Associates in Chicago to start the Oakmark fund. Last year the fund gained 54 percent; this year it's about even, as are most international funds.
Since January Mr. Herro has traveled to China, Hong Kong, Japan, Australia and twice to Europe and is going back to Asia next month. He would like to marry and have a family, he said; for now he shares an apartment with his brother.
As the fund has grown, Mr. Herro has hired two younger assistants, and two more researchers are on the way. "I'm the grand old man at 33," he joked. He added: "What I may lack in experience, I have in discipline and the ability to be a good learner."
 
 
 
THRIVING IN JUNK BONDS
 IN some areas of investing, young people predominate because there simply aren't many old hands around. That's particularly true in the booming bond business, which in recent years has seen many new kinds of investments that might not attract older managers.
"It's an old-dog, new-tricks kind of thing," said Jennifer L. E. Leichter, 33, who runs more than $2 billion in junk-bond portfolios for Putnam Investments in Boston. Some of the people on her investing team are in their 20's, she said; her boss is 40.
After graduating from Swarthmore in 1983, Ms. Leichter (pronounced LIKE-ter) became a research assistant at Kidder, Peabody; in 1987, she and her husband, Fred, moved to Boston and she joined Putnam, which has been running funds since 1937 and uses tightly knit teams headed by senior people.
She started managing money in late 1988, and soon became responsible for Putnam Diversified Income.
The fund has soared an average of 12.4 percent a year in each of the last three years, outpacing rivals; this year, it has fallen about 4 percent, average for such funds.
Ms. Leichter has two young children and hobbies that include gardening and curling -- akin to shuffleboard on ice. She expects to continue managing funds "unless I make some killing or inherit a tremendous amount of money. It's a tremendously enjoyable way to make a living."

HEADLINE: Can They Deliver?

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Maybe it's the sugared walnuts, chocolate syrup and ice cream. Perhaps it's pride of place, or plain old enlightened self-interest. But on the last Thursday of each month, in Room EF-100 of the Capitol, a ground-floor hideaway a few steps from the gift shop, a group of instinctively fractious politicians comes together for lunch and a make-your-own-sundae sit-down.
They represent constituencies almost as diverse as America, yet 14 of them are crammed together in just over 300 square miles, a land mass one twenty-fourth the average size of a single Congressional district. Most of them toil in comparative anonymity, 200 miles from home, where City Council members are just as likely to get local ink or air time. 
 "They might as well be on Mars as far as the public is concerned," said Gene Russianoff, a senior attorney with the New York Public Interest Research Group.
They are New York City's Congressional delegation, and after years of famous feuds, retirements, redistricting and rebirth, they stand at a crossroads: facing a chance, and a challenge. They have a Democratic White House for the first time in more than a decade and clout on important committees, and are part of the second-biggest state contingent, with 31 members to California's 52. But they have to stick together.
What they do will make a difference in everything from how the city gets the Federal aid that amounts to 10 percent of its budget, to whether subways are rebuilt to how the poor and homeless -- and the world's premier private hospitals -- are treated in the brave new health care world.
Led by the unlikely duo of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, the fourth-ranking member of the House Ways and Means Committee, and sped by the overdrive energy of Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, New Yorkers again hold pivotal posts in the Capitol Hill baronage from which they largely fell in the era of 70's reform.
What is more, they are trying to develop a unity that has eluded New York Democrats since the days of the machines, and that was less an issue when the Republican 1980's relegated them to the status of loyal opposition. It has long been tricky to get this choir to sing from the same page.
"It was very difficult," said former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who as a Congressman from Greenwich Village two decades ago instituted the bipartisan sundae lunches. "I used to con them into coming by providing ice cream. I think we got a lot done within this limitation, which was: 'Don't push me around.' "
In fact, members and their staffs say, much has changed since Mr. Koch's days, when strong egos like his and Bella Abzug's and Elizabeth Holtzman's tugged and tussled. Now, a more collegial spirit rules. Even Mr. Rangel and Mr. Moynihan have set aside mutual differences to lead the delegation into refusing to support President Clinton's health care package unless it makes the Medicaid reimbursement formula more favorable to New York.
"The problem is that states and localities have had 12 years of deprivation across the country and it's 435 tiny bird beaks opening and saying, 'Give us food,' " said Sandra Cuneo, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Washington counsel. "And the Federal Government doesn't have a lot of money, and it's a very difficult time."
But with President Clinton in the White House, Mr. Schumer said, blaming Washington won't wash. "Now we've got to produce, we've got to deliver," he said.
 
KINGS OF THE HILL
 
Daniel Patrick Moynihan
Democrat, elected 1976
Alfonse M. D'Amato
Republican, elected 1980
No New Yorker stands taller in Washington than Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the philosopher king of the Finance Committee, whose merest word can now move the White House to action on issues from a Whitewater special prosecutor to human rights violations in Tibet. He says and does pretty much what he
wants, and this year, that is to take his time on a health care bill in the Finance Committee, and press the Administration to reform welfare.
Student of history, lover of architecture, master of demography, Mr. Moynihan extends his energies from reorganizing the Social Security Administration to rebuilding the General Post Office adjoining Penn Station as a new Amtrak terminal. The jury is still out on his biggest task, health care, but he faces only a pesky Democratic primary challenge from the Rev. Al Sharpton.
There could be no starker Frick to Mr. Moynihan's Frack than Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Long Island Republican who barely won a third term in 1992 after repeated inquiries into his ethical conduct in office.
In fact, the two have often worked cooperatively, offsetting each other's strengths and weaknesses, and Mr. D'Amato does a friendly but devastating impression of Mr. Moynihan's distinctive, spluttering speech.
He has raised constituent service and attention to parochial concerns to a high art, but his pull has diminished under a Democratic White House. As the ranking Republican on the Banking Committee, Mr. D'Amato did not let his own past ethical problems dull his ardor for criticizing President Clinton over Whitewater. His colleagues in the Republican leadership seem to have reined him in a bit lately. But he has announced his intention to seek the chairmanship of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, the clearinghouse that raises money for Republican campaigns around the country.
 
A LEAGUE OF THEIR OWN
 
Charles B. Rangel
Democrat, 15th District, Harlem, elected 1970
Charles E. Schumer
Democrat, 9th District, Brooklyn and Queens (Park Slope, Sheepshead Bay, Forest Hills, Far Rockaway), elected 1980
The undisputed leaders of the city's House delegation are Mr. Rangel, the wily 12-term veteran and expert on drugs, poverty and urban affairs, and Mr. Schumer, the hotshot Harvard lawyer who has made himself a major force on crime and gun control, most recently with his upset victory on the Federal assault weapons ban. Both are voluble, inveterate schmoozers, capable of working a crowd or navigating a back room, but Mr. Rangel's rambling style hides an iron fist and Mr. Schumer's smile can't mask a steel-trap mind.
Just two senior colleagues and an indictment stand between Mr. Rangel and the chairmanship of the Ways and Means Committee, the gate of all taxing power. But even if Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois is forced to resign due to the investigation into his dealings with the House Post Office, Mr. Rangel's friends say he would not challenge the ranking Democrat on the committee, Representative Sam M. Gibbons of Florida, because Mr. Rangel and other veteran black members are finally coming to the point where the seniority system works in their favor and would not want to upset it.
"He will one day be the most powerful black man America has ever known," Mr. Schumer says.
Still, Mr. Rangel's seniority has not brought him all the rewards he might have hoped. Last year, in a cost-saving move, House Democrats abolished four nonlegislative committees, including Mr. Rangel's panel on narcotics, and he took it hard. He has sometimes been persona not so grata at the White House for his stiff criticism of Mr. Clinton during the 1992 campaign.
The criticism of Mr. Range: He is sometimes disorganized. But he gets high marks for collegiality and acuity.
"If it gets any better, I'd be afraid," Mr. Rangel said of cooperation among the state delegation. "I don't ever want to see the line between Democrats and Republicans wiped out, but we are so hellbent on bringing money back to the city and state that I've yet to remember a controversy that caused us to go into a Democratic caucus."
The fault found with Mr. Schumer: He is too ambitious, and just too ubiquitous for his own good. But while his colleagues may envy him, most admire him even more. Mr. Schumer can segue from being the President's point man on the omnibus crime bill in the House to attacking plans of other states to gain a share of unclaimed stock dividends from New York. He is a prodigious fund raiser, with a war chest of more than $2 million.
For the moment, Mr. Schumer's ambitions for higher office are stymied. Mr. Moynihan's ascension to chairmanship of the Finance Committee impelled him to run again this year instead of retiring, and Mr. Cuomo's decision to seek a fourth term blocks a shot at the governorship.
 
WHEELERS AND DEALERS
 
Thomas J. Manton
Democrat, 7th District, Queens and Bronx (Long Island City, Astoria, Whitestone), elected 1984
Edolphus Towns
Democrat, 10th District, Brooklyn (Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill), elected 1982
No vote is easier for most members of Congress than one that bashes New York, so city officials prefer to have provisions benefiting the Big Apple embedded in legislation before it ever comes out of committee.
"The worst of all possible worlds is to have a floor vote on an issue that affects New York, because if you're standing there all by yourself, chances are, you'll lose," said Judy Chesser, who was the city's chief lobbyist in the Koch and Dinkins administrations.
For tasks like this, New York sometimes relies on vote-traders like Mr. Manton and Mr. Towns.
Mr. Manton, the Queens County Democratic leader, is an old-fashioned Irish pol who sits on the House Democratic Steering and Policy Committee, which makes committee assignments. A former police officer, he is an unabashed believer in patronage, and has been critical of the Clinton White House -- which he supported early and often -- over the lack of same. He is a friend of Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, the chairman of the powerful Energy and Commerce Committee. City officials give him credit for helping a few years ago to slow down the Federal requirement that the city end sludge-dumping at sea.
Mr. Towns, who grew up in North Carolina, where black sharecroppers depended on tobacco for a living, is one of the cigarette industry's most reliable supporters in the House. A one-time social worker and former chairman of the Congressional black caucus, he is generally liberal, but his votes lack a consistent ideological pattern. (He has opposed stricter auto emissions standards, for example, earning the enmity of New York environmentalists but earning points with Chairman Dingell.)
 
GETTERS AND SPENDERS
 
Jose E. Serrano
Democrat, 16th District, South Bronx, elected 1990
Nita M. Lowey
Democrat, 18th District, Bronx, Queens and Westchester, elected 1988
Floyd H. Flake
Democrat, 6th District, Jamaica, St. Albans, Queens, elected 1986
Mr. Serrano and Ms. Lowey represent the city on the Appropriations Committee, the panel that determines spending for a panoply of Federal programs. Mr. Flake is a demon advocate for Federal housing and community projects for his eastern Queens district.
Mr. Serrano, chairman of the Congressional Hispanic caucus, is likely to take a prominent role in coming debates over whether spending on immigrants should be cut to help finance other programs. In local politics, he often strikes an independent course, remaining conspicuously loyal to Mayor Dinkins when other Hispanic politicians are critical, and has established a good working relationship with Mayor Giuliani, in contrast to the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer.
Ms. Lowey, a one-time neighbor and former aide to Mario M. Cuomo, represents parts of the city as a result of 1992 redistricting. She is an outspoken advocate of abortion rights, but procedural ignorance left her outmaneuvered last year on a vote to retain curbs on Federal funds for abortion for poor women. An ebullient sort, she takes scrupulous credit for programs for her district.
Mr. Flake, a prominent African Methodist Episcopal minister, travels the country on church business and has built a housing and social services empire for his Queens congregation. In 1991, he survived charges of evading taxes and diverting Federal funds from his church when the case was dismissed.
 
THE HEIRESS
 
Susan Molinari
Republican, 13th District, Staten Island and Brooklyn, elected 1990
The lone Republican in the city delegation and heiress to a Staten Island political dynasty, succeeding her father, Guy. As a young woman and supporter of abortion rights, she is a darling of the media and national Republicans, and she flirted briefly with the idea of running for Governor this year. But she is reflexively conservative on most other issues, consistently winning awards from national conservative groups for her pro-business, anti-tax stands.
 
COLORFUL CHARACTERS
 
Gary L. Ackerman
Democrat, 5th District, Queens and Long Island, elected 1983
Major R. Owens
Democrat, 11th District, central Brooklyn, elected 1982
Former Representative James H. Scheuer once lamented that the only way to get noticed as a member of Congress from New York was to stand naked in a Macy's window.
Two members of the current delegation stand out in different ways.
Mr. Ackerman, a genial glad-hander, famous for his white carnation boutonnieres and annual importation of an entire New York deli groaning board to Washington for a fund raiser, chooses the food for the monthly delegation meetings. As a member of the Post Office and Civil Service Committee, he has sometimes blocked removal of Federal offices from New York, and on the Foreign Affairs committee has picked up the interest of his old friend, former Representative Stephen J. Solarz, in Asian issues.
Mr. Owens, a former librarian and a community development chief in the Lindsay administration, is an old-fashioned bedrock liberal. Shy and not a press-seeker, he has taken in recent years to performing rap speeches on the House floor, including this mordant commentary on the 1990 Congressional budget accord with the Bush Administration:
At the big white D.C. mansion
There's a meeting of the mob
And the question on the table
Is which beggars they will rob.
 
THE FRESHMEN
 
Jerrold Nadler
Democrat, 8th District, Upper West Side to Coney Island, elected 1992
Nydia M. Velazquez
Democrat, 12th District in Brooklyn, Queens, Manhattan, elected 1992
Carolyn B. Maloney
Democrat, 14th District, Upper East Side and Queens, elected 1992
The newest kids on the block, these members owe their election to the 1992 redistricting and various flukes.
Mr. Nadler was chosen by party officials as the Democratic nominee after the longtime incumbent, Ted Weiss, died on the eve of the primary; Ms. Velazquez won in a crowded field in a newly drawn district intended to favor a Hispanic candidate, and Ms. Maloney, pulled along on President Clinton's 69 percent margin in her district, squeaked to a sliver victory over the veteran Republican, Bill Green.
Of the three, Ms. Velazquez has emerged in the eyes of her colleagues as a comer. A former liaison for the Puerto Rican Government on the mainland, she is a member of the Banking and Urban Affairs Committees, and a fierce fighter for her poor constituents on the Lower East Side and Williamsburg.
Mr. Nadler, a brainy former yeshiva boy, has put off some of his new colleagues with his untiring loquacity, but most expect him to rise to influence with seniority, just as he did in the State Assembly. Ms. Maloney, who drew the wrath of fellow Democrats by voting against Mr. Clinton's economic stimulus package last year, is generally a liberal stalwart. But she battles a reputation as a lightweight, as she did in the City Council, and in a recent hearing of a banking subcommittee, repeatedly had to be fed questions by an aide.
In a sign of their efforts to become known back home, Ms. Maloney and Mr. Nadler were the third- and fourth-biggest frankers in the House last year, spending $212,000 and $190,000 on taxpayer financed mailings.
 
THE EARLY BIRD
 
Eliot L. Engel
Democrat, 17th District, the Bronx and Westchester, elected 1988
As a member of the Education and Labor Committee, Mr. Engel last year helped win a waiver from Federal insurance law that saved the city's public hospitals $500 million. But he may be best known for his annual arrival on the aisle of the House in time to be first in line to shake the President's hand at the State of the Union Message. He learned the tactic as a freshman from the Mississippi veteran, Representative Sonny Montgomery, who advised him it was a good way to get noticed.
"You have to get there a couple of hours early," Mr. Engel said. "Sonny brings cookies. Some of the elitists don't like it, and people poke fun at it, but my constituents love it, and every year we get a flood of calls afterward."

HEADLINE: Canada Acts To Cut Fishing By Foreigners

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, May 21

 BODY:
Canada has given itself the legal authority to seize foreign fishing boats outside its 200-mile limit in the North Atlantic in an attempt to stem the depletion of cod, flounder and redfish.
The law, enacted by both houses of Parliament this month, focuses on an area about half the size of New York State, known as the Nose and the Tail of the Grand Banks, fish-breeding grounds on Canada's continental shelf, southeast of Newfoundland. 
 "We're going to very clearly tell the vessels that we sight or target that they either move or be moved," Fisheries Minister Brian Tobin said at a news conference in St. John's, Newfoundland on Tuesday. He said he expected Canada to start enforcing the law within 30 days, the time it takes to get the final regulations written and approved.
While the law is politically popular here, it has drawn fire from domestic critics and foreign governments. Some say that if Canada is able to extend its maritime jurisdiction to international waters, other nations might do the same and unravel years of negotiations on the Law of the Sea.
"This is knee-jerk nationalism," said Armand de Mestral, professor of international law at McGill University in Montreal. "It's unfortunate that a country like Canada that needs international law and has a reputation for respecting international law takes matters in its own hands like this."
 
U.S. Envoy Objects
 The United States Ambassador, James J. Blanchard, said that while Washington "shares Canada's concerns" about the depletion of the fish stocks, "we think they should have worked within multilateral institutions to deal with this problem."
Roy Christensen, spokesman for the European Union in Ottawa, said, "there is the principle involved. We would have liked Canada to act multilaterally."
Canadian officials, however, said both the new law and the Government's stated rejection of international challenges to it were temporary measures in response to an emergency situation.
"Canada is acting purely because it is driven to act," said Mr. Tobin, chief architect of the law. "We have conducted diplomacy down to the last few pounds of fish. We either continue to talk about it, or we try to save those last few pounds and use them as a basis for restoring the stock."
In trying to rebuild the stocks, Canada has also imposed stringent measures on its own fishermen. A two-year-old ban has left 33,000 fishermen and fish plant workers unemployed, three-quarters of them in Newfoundland.
Under the new law, any ship found taking endangered species will be towed into port, and its captain will be arrested and put on trial. If convicted, he could be fined as much as $360,000 and lose his catch.
 
'Pirate' Vessels the Targets
 Bonnie Mewdell, press secretary in Mr. Tobin's office, said the crackdown was aimed at neither the United States nor Europe. The targets, she said, are "pirate" vessels, which she defined as those either without international registry or flying "flags of convenience" and fishing just beyond Canada's 200-mile limit.
To avoid international conservation agreements, some foreign fishermen flag their vessels in countries like Panama, Honduras and Belize. These flags of convenience require little or no compliance with international rules.
About a dozen of the so-called pirate vessels were sighted last week just beyond the 200-mile limit early last week in the Grand Banks, a relatively shallow area east of Newfoundland that is the spawning ground of cod and other threatened species.

HEADLINE: New Haven Prepares for 6,500 Athletes and 500,000 Spectators

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THE 1995 Special Olympics World Games are more than a year away, but at the games headquarters in New Haven activity is already heating up.
Every night several committees meet at the headquarters on the 17th floor of the New Haven Savings Bank building off Chapel Street. One might be working out transportation between the different game locations, another developing a marketing campaign and still another coordinating with town governments planning receptions for foreign athletes. With 6,500 athletes from 120 countries, 2,500 coaches, 45,000 volunteers and as many as 500,000 spectators, there is a lot of planning to do. 
 Consider the problems facing the kitchen committees, said Arthur R. Henick, a spokesman for the games. Not only do the cooks have to worry about varying ethnic tastes among the thousands of athletes, but many of the participants have dietary restrictions because of some physical condition.
"You walk in through one door and there's three more doors facing you, and then nine when you get those doors open, and so on and on," Mr. Henick said.
Timothy P. Shriver, the chairman of the Games Organizing Committee and son of Eunice Kennedy Shriver, who organized the first Special Olympics games in 1968, said he was encouraged that more than 12,000 volunteers and $16 million in cash, goods and services had already been pledged.
"On the one hand, things are going unbelievably well," Mr. Shriver said. "So many people have responded to the challenge, and are working so hard. On the other hand, even when you have that much excitement and energy there's always a feeling that you're behind. One minute I'm euphoric and the next I have to sit down and quell the panic."
"An event of this magnitude, you can't sit down three months beforehand and say, 'What do we need to do to make this great?' " Mr. Shriver said. "A lot of what we're trying to do, we've got to get in the pipeline quickly. If it's going to happen it's got to happen now."
John F. Gontero, chairman of the New Haven Chamber of Commerce, said local businesses were being urged to offer discounts for meals, lodging and anything else people will need when they come to New Haven for the games. The city was chosen to be host for the games last year because it has sports centers, access to the water for sailing, and because the state was strongly committed to bringing the games to Connecticut. (Strong contenders were Boston and Miami.)
"We really want to let these people know that we care about them, and we want to make them comfortable while they're here," Mr. Gontero said. "These athletes are very special people, and the people who volunteer with them are special people. This is more than a chance to make money. We're looking for a chance to show everyone the best side of New Haven."
Edward J. Kavanagh, dean of graduate and continuing education at Quinnipiac College, said: "This is one of the rare times when the entire New Haven area community, the schools and businesses and the governments in New Haven and the suburbs, everybody has gotten together and sat down at the table to accomplish something. I can't think of anything else that would have triggered this kind of cooperation."
 
250 Events, 19 Sports
 The games are scheduled for July 1 to 9 next year. In all, there will be 250 events in 19 sports at more than a dozen venues.
Though all the athletes are mentally retarded, the competitions impress everyone who comes to watch, Mr. Henick said. One weight lifter who is expected to compete, for instance, routinely lifts three to four times his own body weight.
Loretta L. Claiborne from York, Pa., epitomizes the Special Olympian. Ms. Claiborne, who is 40 years old, recalls that when she was a young girl her teachers wanted to send her to an institution; her mother fought to keep her in school, and prevailed. Today, she has run in 256 marathons (her best time in Boston was three hours, three minutes) and expects to run in 1995, in the first full Special Olympics marathon.
Ms. Claiborne recently spoke to two civic groups in New Haven, attracting more than 250 people, to ask for their help with the games. "Now I can only hope we get two volunteers for every person who heard me," she said with a laugh.
The Connecticut games already have their own mascot, Spencer the whale, who wears sunglasses and a Special Olympics medal. They also have their own license plate, which says "Connecticut" above the registration number and "Sport Spirit Splendor" below it, and carries the Special Olympics symbol on the right-hand side. (For each plate, $35 goes to the games.)
Models have been built showing what the games committee hopes to do with the New Haven waterfront, erecting tents that will cover 9.1 acres off Frontage Road for a strip of booths offering art, food, information and theater and recreation areas.
Each of the state's 169 towns is planning some type of ceremony to recognize Special Olympians from around the world.
"The town can decide whether it's a picnic on the green or a potluck supper at the town hall or a reception at the local public library," Mr. Henick said. "The point, to make the athletes feel welcome."
The games committee will also be producing local and regional games for the Connecticut Special Olympics through November as a trial run of the sites and the organization.
Several major donors have already stepped forward. The Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, which operates the Foxwoods Resort and Casino in Ledyard, will donate $2 million, the largest contribution in the history of the games. Southern New England Telephone Company, U.S. Healthcare, United Technologies Corporation and I.G.A. Food Stores will each donate $1 million.
The Knights of Columbus, which has its world headquarters in Connecticut, will donate $1 million and provide 6,000 volunteers. "We have 30,000 Knights in Connecticut, plus their wives and children, so we have a huge pool to draw from," said Harvey G. Bacque, assistant to the Supreme Knight.
 
A Cause to Rally Around
 Last year $15 million of the $93 million the organization gave to charity went to benefit people with mental retardation, as did a significant part of the 43 million hours of volunteer time its 1.5 million members logged worldwide, Mr. Bacque said. Recruiting volunteers for the Special Olympics, he said, is generally fairly easy.
"It's one of those causes that people easily rally around," he said. "And it's not difficult getting people for the Connecticut games because it's probably not going to happen in Connecticut again in our lifetime. Everybody wants to be a part of it."
For the first time the games are being held in a waterfront community and for the first time they will include sailing. But its proximity to the sea was not the only factor in the choice of New Haven as host for the games.
Mr. Henick said the concentration of colleges and universities in New Haven put about 90 percent of the sports installations needed within a three-mile radius. Also, Connecticut has the third largest state Special Olympics competition in the country, demonstrating a strong commitment to the program.
There was also evidence that the state was backing the games, Mr. Henick said. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. was the first Governor ever to appear before the site selection committee, and the state offered a $20 million loan guarantee toward the games' $28 million budget.
Mr. Henick said the games should do much more for Connecticut, pumping $50 million to $100 million into the local economy. The Special Olympics games will be the largest sporting event in the world in 1995, and will make Connecticut the center of widespread attention. For the first time, the opening ceremonies are expected to be broadcast live on prime-time television.
"It could have an enormous effect on a number of factors," Mr. Henick said. "Connecticut, and New Haven specifically, could get a boost as a destination for tourism, for instance. Or it could show that Connecticut and New Haven can put on a world-class sporting event, which could attract more events of this sort."
 
Federal Aid Sought
 Robert N. Laemel, director of games operations for the city of New Haven, said he was coordinating with the United States Commerce Department to get financial aid to make the city look its best by the time of the games.
"We want the city to sparkle and shine, not just in the world games but into the future," Mr. Laemel said. "We don't want everything to drop and go back to normal when the games are done."
For instance, he said, suggestions have been made that New Haven could develop a world-class softball complex or a museum of the world Special Olympics. Also, he said, there are the 45,000 volunteers being recruited for the games.
"We want that system to remain in place so this kind of people power can be put to work for New Haven as we move forward after the games," Mr. Laemel said. "As a committee, we want to keep the street festival going, we want to keep the harbor celebration as a permanent event."
Mr. Gontero said businesses, too, hoped to build pride in New Haven that could be sustained long after the games. A recent round table organized by the chamber attracted more than 100 people who wanted to help organize the games.
"There's no arm twisting," Mr. Gontero said. "People are just coming out to do the work because they believe in what's happening, and that's really good to see."
 
Still a Long Way to Climb
 Five local schools -- Yale University, Southern Connecticut State University, Quinnipiac College, the University of New Haven and Albertus Magnus College -- will offer dormitories and dining halls for the athletes.
Mr. Kavanagh said he estimated the staff at Quinnipiac would put in a total of 18,000 hours preparing the school between now and the lighting of the torch.
Summer school classes will halt for a few weeks in 1995. A football clinic and wrestling camp that has been held at Quinnipiac every summer for years will also have to be relocated.
"We're going to turn over the gym and the infirmary, the student union and computer center and the theater, even the alumni hall meeting room," Mr. Kavanagh said. "About the only thing they won't be using will be our classrooms. They're using about all of our ancillary and support services."
Mr. Shriver said it was heartwarming to see so many people offer so much to the Special Olympics. But, he said, the games committee must still find thousands of other volunteers and raise millions more in cash and services.
"We're still looking at the mountain, with a long ways to climb," Mr. Shriver said. "We'll get there, though. Somehow we will. It's a big challenge, but we have to remember that that's the nature of the games, and follow the example of the athletes."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: The Birds, the Bees and the Coolidges

BYLINE: By Derek Bickerton; Derek Bickerton's most recent books are "Language and Species" and the forthcoming "Language and Human Behavior."

 BODY:

THE RED QUEEN
Sex and the Evolution of Human Nature.
By Matt Ridley.
405 pp. New York:
Macmillan Publishing Company. $25.
 
THE SEX IMPERATIVE
An Evolutionary Tale of Sexual Survival.
By Kenneth Maxwell.
Illustrated. 324 pp. New York:
Plenum Press. $24.95.
 
THE EVOLUTION OF DESIRE
Strategies of Human Mating.
By David M. Buss.
262 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $22. 
SEX! Without it, we wouldn't exist; there would be nothing more complex than blue-green algae in some scummy pond. Love makes the world go round? No, sex does, providing the endless variety of types from which evolution selects and making the choosing of breeding partners the main event in the evolutionary drama.
At least, this is the latest version of Darwinism shared by three new books -- "The Red Queen: Sex and the Evolution of Human Nature," "The Sex Imperative: An Evolutionary Tale of Sexual Survival" and "The Evolution of Desire: Strategies of Human Mating." All of them proclaim that sex -- not the survival of the fittest -- is the force behind everything from the evolution of peacocks' tails to the ballooning of human brains. And all three reflect more than a revision of evolutionary theory, for they concern the shaping of human nature itself. Two decades ago Edward O. Wilson, in his monumental book "Sociobiology," prophesied (or, some would say, threatened) that "having cannibalized psychology, the new neurobiology will yield an enduring set of first principles for sociology." These books try to fulfill that prophecy by showing that biology can provide deeper and more far-reaching explanations of human nature than studies of culture can.
The authors bring a diverse set of qualifications to this task. David M. Buss, the author of "The Evolution of Desire" and a psychology professor at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, seems to be a trifle edgy about how his colleagues will take his allegiance to sociobiology. The other two seem more at ease. Kenneth Maxwell, the author of "The Sex Imperative," is an emeritus professor of biology at California State University in Long Beach, and Matt Ridley, the author of "The Red Queen," though he has been primarily a science editor at The Economist, has also published ethological papers on the mating habits of birds.
Although the books differ in focus, they inevitably overlap in content: Mr. Ridley and Mr. Maxwell both discuss the enormous size of whales' testicles (100 pounds for the blue whale, according to Mr. Maxwell; up to a ton for the right whale, claims Mr. Ridley). And all three authors tell the same story about President Coolidge, his wife and the rooster. (In Mr. Maxwell's telling, when the Coolidges "were touring a poultry farm accompanied by separate guides, Mrs. Coolidge asked how often the rooster performed his duty and was told, 'Several times a day.' She said, 'Tell that to Mr. Coolidge.' When the message was relayed to the President, he asked whether the rooster did it all with the same hen, and was told, 'No, each time with a different hen.' The President replied, 'Tell that to Mrs. Coolidge.' ")
Mr. Maxwell's book is the least polemical of the three. Where Mr. Buss and Mr. Ridley are interested in making a case against the prevailing view of humans as primarily cultural animals, Mr. Maxwell simply presents life's stunning array of sexual tools and tactics in order to illustrate the adaptability of life forms to their environments. Between Mr. Maxwell's first two chapters, on life's origins and evolutionary theory, and his last three, on the heady future of sperm banks, in vitro fertilization and genetic engineering, he sandwiches 14 detailed chapters about the nuts-and-bolts aspects of sex in our own and other species. Did you know that some lizards have two penises, and that most birds don't have any and must resort to what the author coyly calls "cloacal kissing"? Did you know that when a dog and a bitch get stuck, it's no accident, just the male dog's way of making sure no other dog inseminates "his" female? Have you heard of the Kansas con man "Dr." John R. Brinkley, who became a millionaire in the 1920's and early 30's by transplanting goats' testicles into aging roues? (The men got to pick their own goats.) If you find such things fascinating, this is your book.
For "The Evolution of Desire," Mr. Buss and his colleagues interviewed 10,000 people from 37 different cultures about their courtship and sexual practices; oddly enough, though, the full results of this survey are never presented, even in summary form. Drawing impressionistically on this survey, Mr. Buss marches, sometimes ploddingly, through the human mating cycle, providing animal analogies along the way, to show that every quirk of the mating game in every culture can be attributed to the gene's single-minded agenda: reproduce yourself and zap your competitors whenever possible. Thus, Mr. Buss analyzes how we select partners for long-term and short-term relationships (for long-term relationships, we tend to go for secure mates who will be good parents; for short-term relationships, we choose mates who will be vigorous and energetic), and he describes how men and women differ in their strategies for choosing mates (women choose more stable relationships because they must carry their young for nine months and then nurture them for years; men tend to be more promiscuous because they can scatter their seed with impunity).
Mr. Ridley's book, "The Red Queen," is the most thoughtful (and he's by far the best writer). The "Red Queen" in his book is the "Alice in Wonderland" character who had to run as fast as she could just to stay in the same place. The term was first used, as Mr. Ridley mentions in passing and belatedly, by Leigh Van Valen, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Chicago, to describe "arms races" between prey and predator species in which each side improves its equipment but neither gains an advantage. In other words, each runs in place not to win the struggle for survival, but merely to avoid losing it.
Mr. Ridley tailors the Red Queen analogy -- not without occasionally stretching and tearing it -- to fit competition between the sexes. He makes a convincing case that sex itself originated in an arms race between parasites and their hosts. Asexual organisms, whose DNA never changes, make sitting ducks for parasites, who quickly learn their hosts' weaknesses. But sexual species, whose DNA varies with each generation, can always keep one jump ahead of the parasites.
Mr. Ridley argues that once sex was established, it began to drive evolution. In choosing their mates, organisms -- usually the females of the species -- determine to some extent what the next generation will be like. Although females try to make good reproductive choices by picking out males whose outward appearance indicates health and vigor, whatever attributes they do choose spread through entire species, even when those choices seem quirky. For instance, female birds may choose mates with gaudy plumage and long tails, even though these attributes attract predators and make flight difficult; maybe, if they could explain their choice, they would say that male birds who have survived with such handicaps must be extra tough and smart!
Perhaps Mr. Ridley's most daring claim involves the explosive growth of hominid brains, and hence the vastly enhanced intelligence of human beings. According to him, intelligence could have evolved only if humans had persistently selected smarter and smarter mates. Although he neatly demolishes some alternative theories of brain growth, he fails to explain why only hominids found intelligence sexy, or why, in Mr. Buss's cross-cultural survey, women ranked intelligence only fifth out of 18 desirable attributes. (The first four seem to be love, dependability, emotional stability and ambition.)
The arguments advanced by Mr. Buss and Mr. Ridley may arouse hostility in two types of readers: those who believe that culture has a bigger hand than biology in ruling human behavior, and those who deny fundamental differences between the mentalities of the two sexes. Mr. Buss partly defends himself against the first group by showing that the results of his survey of mating habits were surprisingly uniform. And Mr. Ridley defends himself against the second group by insisting that sexual equality doesn't depend on sexual sameness (although his choice of Camille Paglia as his authority on feminism won't help him here).
For the most part, though, the authors are antipathetic to those who oppose sociobiology. They observe, correctly I think, that the social sciences have spent too much effort cataloguing relatively superficial differences between humans and too little effort studying the deeper bonds that unite humans with one another and with other species. Yet doubts remain about the authors' sociobiological leanings: are we really getting to the truth of human nature, or are we simply replacing one bias with another?
One's suspicion is especially aroused by remarks like this by Mr. Buss: "Fast food chains are popular precisely because they serve [fat, sugar, protein and salt]. . . . They reveal the food preferences that evolved in a past environment of scarcity." Really? The desire for cheapness and quickness in our ever-faster and more regimented societies couldn't have anything to do with it? Mr. Buss sounds this kind of deterministic note more often than Mr. Ridley.
WHEN Mr. Buss makes analogies between humans and other creatures, he picks any species he pleases, from shrike to sunfish, provided that one feature of its behavior seems to match one in the human repertory. Mr. Ridley is more careful. He draws his analogies either from species that are closely related to humans or from those that seem to share behavior similar to ours -- for example, from ibises and swallows, which, like us, form monogamous unions but live in large groups.
Still, no matter how careful one is, it is unclear just how helpful interspecies analogies are, anyway. When a bird practices what zoologists call "extra-pair copulation," can we really call this adultery? "That is what it is," Mr. Ridley declares flatly. While "adultery" sounds sexier than "extra-pair copulation," confusing the two terms amounts to ignoring the vast body of law, custom and religious doctrine (wholly unknown to swallows) that defines adultery among humans. Moreover, the intent of the two activities is completely different. Those who engage in extra-pair copulation usually aim to make babies; adulterers usually try to avoid making them.
Mr. Ridley is a also shaky in handling the subject of homosexuality. On the one hand, he sees the promiscuity of male homosexuals as typically masculine behavior; on the other hand, he attributes homosexuality to a lack of testosterone at a crucial prenatal stage, which, he says, causes male homosexuals to act more like women than like men. Maybe there's an answer to this apparent contradiction, but Mr. Ridley doesn't supply it.
Behind these particular concerns with Mr. Ridley's and Mr. Buss's books lies a more general one: Isn't it a bit odd that the latest pronouncements of science should so often echo the cynical, age-old "wisdom" of locker rooms and bars? If this criticism seems harsh, consider Mr. Ridley's contention that "the best [that men] can hope for" in a civilized society "is a good-looking younger mistress and a devoted wife who is traded in every decade or so." If sex is war, can we learn the whole truth about it when all three reports come from the same trench, from a man's point of view? Mightn't a woman give a different perspective, especially since her view, according to sociobiology, is genetically bound to be completely different?
And there is a final paradoxical question that needs to be raised: Isn't it possible that the belief that biology plays a bigger role than culture in shaping human nature is itself determined by culture, by the shift from the Great Society to the post-Reagan ethos of everyone for himself?
Both Mr. Ridley and Mr. Buss insist that they are describing not what humans should be like, but what they are like. Fair enough -- but is it all that they're like? Sociobiology explains things we share with other species, not those that make us different. I'm not saying we should defend the blinkered, culture-is-all orthodoxy. Yet a biology-is-all orthodoxy is equally blinkered and confining. Maybe the swinging of the intellectual pendulum makes as good an object lesson as any about the ever-elusive mystery of human nature.
 
 
 
THE CHARMS OF A GAUDY MALE
 The question Darwin failed to answer was why. Why on earth should females prefer gaudiness in males? Even if the "preference" was entirely unconscious and was merely an instinctive response to the superior seduction technique of gaudy males, it was the evolution of the female preference, not the male trait, that was hard to explain.
Sometime during the 1970's it began to dawn on people that a perfectly good answer to the question had been available since 1930. Sir Ronald Fisher had suggested then that females need no better reason for preferring long tails than that other females also prefer long tails. At first such logic sounds suspiciously circular, but that is its beauty. Once most females are choosing to mate with some males rather than others and are using tail length as the criterion -- a big once, granted . . . -- then any female who bucks the trend and chooses a short-tailed male will have short-tailed sons. . . . All the other females are looking for long-tailed males, so those short-tailed sons will not have much success. At this point, choosing long-tailed males need be no more than an arbitrary fashion; it is still despotic. Each peahen is on a treadmill and dare not jump off lest she condemn her sons to celibacy. The result is that the females' arbitrary preferences have saddled the males of their species with ever more grotesque encumbrances. Even when those encumbrances themselves threaten the life of the male, the process can continue -- as long as the threat to his life is smaller than the enhancement of his breeding success. From "The Red Queen."

The New York Times
