SECTION: Section 7; Page 44; Column 3; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1001 words

HEADLINE: Why Less Is Not More

BYLINE: By James K. Galbraith; James K. Galbraith is the author of "Balancing Acts: Technology, Finance and the American Future" and, with William Darity Jr., "Macroeconomics," a textbook.

 BODY:

LEAN AND MEAN
The Changing Landscape of Corporate Power
in the Age of Flexibility.
By Bennett Harrison.
324 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $25. 
 IN "Microcosm," George Gilder evoked a vision of entrepreneurial triumph and emergent smallness in the American 80's: "Small business starts nearly tripled, from 270,000 in 1978 to some 750,000 in 1988. The result, contrary to predictions of rising unemployment, was a total of some 15 million new jobs."
Those seeking perspective on this vision should turn to Bennett Harrison's "Lean and Mean." There you will find that "among the 245,000 new companies that were started up in the United States in 1985 . . . 75 percent of the employment gains by 1988 occurred in those firms that, at birth, had already employed more than 100 workers when they were first launched. Moreover, this group of businesses constituted only three-tenths of one percent of the 1985 cohort."
"Lean and Mean" gives us the new world economy as it really is -- an economy that is still dominated by big business, in which the life of the small remains nasty, brutish and short. Compared with the big companies, Mr. Harrison tells us, small businesses pay lower wages and fewer benefits, lag in technology and are far, far more likely to fail. Oh, and one other thing: they are often not really independent. Rather, they exist in their millions only as the vulnerable dependencies of the large corporations, which they serve as contractors or suppliers.
This is a serious book. Mr. Harrison, a professor of political economy at the H. J. Heinz 3d School of Public Policy and Management at Carnegie-Mellon University, and the author, with Barry Bluestone, of "The Deindustrialization of America," gives due space to debunking Mr. Gilder and also David Birch, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology researcher whose career rests on the small-business job-creation myth. But he has harder targets than conservative popularizers. In particular, he takes aim at a large body of recent socioeconomics, which has offered the phenomenon of "industrial districts," based on small and midsized businesses, as a model for social organization in an age of rapid technological change.
The two central exhibits in the literature on industrial districts are the manufacturing centers of northern Italy and, of course, Silicon Valley. In "The Second Industrial Divide" (1984), Michael J. Piore and Charles F. Sabel of M.I.T. argued that small enterprises in Emilia-Romagna, Prato and elsewhere had developed, more or less by historical accident, into independent networks of manufacturers, using numerical control and other flexible technologies to adapt to changing markets, free of domination by large multinational corporations. Mr. Harrison, himself a recent emigrant from M.I.T., takes a second look at these "success" stories and finds that they have not withstood the test of a decade's time.
In Emilia-Romagna (Bologna and environs) the metalworking districts have fallen to the takeover prowess of the big-business Sasib group, itself an outpost of Carlo De Benedetti, the rescuer of Olivetti. In Veneto, near Venice, independent garment shops have fallen under the corporate sway of Benetton. And in Prato, Italy's most famous independent woolen-textile district has, according to Mr. Harrison, "fallen prey to the unequal power of the middlemen," even as the local infrastructure has proved unable to cope with the demands on it from the previous patterns of decentralized growth.
As for Silicon Valley, Mr. Harrison maintains that there is another reality behind the popular perceptions. In his view, the California valley is no melting pot of laissez-faire turned small-firm mecca, but the progeny of the Defense Department and Stanford University, fueled by military and aerospace demand, "a construct of a small number of powerful institutions."
Small businesses there are, he says, but often not for the reasons we imagine: "In what Business Week . . . first named the 'casino society,' small firm start-ups themselves became commodities, to be bought and sold in order to generate capital gains."
Moreover, while boosters paint a picture of painless production and good jobs at high wages for all, Mr. Harrison believes the reality is dual: high wages, golf courses and tennis courts for some; low wages and poor conditions for many others, especially migrants, notably in the southern part of the valley around San Jose.
The future that Mr. Harrison offers us resembles Japan. But in Japan he sees what is there: linked networks of large multinational corporations, conquering world markets on the backs of their dependent suppliers and pliant unions even as they scour the poor countries for reservoirs of cheap labor to which the least complex of their operations can be farmed out. American workers lose twice as our companies join this game: low-wage import competition depresses manufacturing wages, and the increasingly powerless position of service providers depresses wages even in jobs not directly subject to competition from trade.
IT is an unpleasant picture, and one made more so by the principal weakness of this book, namely its inchoate policy prescriptions. At times Mr. Harrison seems to be cheering on the American companies (like General Motors, in its joint venture with Toyota, Nummi Motors, and in the innovative assembly lines of its Saturn subsidiary) that are evolving from traditional mass production to global linked networks. At times he reiterates a more conventional critique of American corporate culture -- "short-termism" linked to quarterly performance statistics, for example -- but it is not clear how this fits into his central thesis. And at the end he embraces the fashionable but vacuous idea that "technology, training and technical assistance" can put us on a "high road" toward higher wages and a more decent society.
Sadly, nothing in this bleak portrait of our new world suggests it will be nearly so easy.

TYPE: Review

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 22, 1994,

SECTION: Section 6; Page 26; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3080 words

HEADLINE: MAYOR ON A ROLL;
Ed Rendell

BYLINE: By Ben Yagoda; Ben Yagoda is the author of "Will Rogers: A Biography." He teaches journalism at the University of Delaware.

 BODY:
A HUSKY MAN IN A DARK BLUE suit steps up to the podium, fixes his audience with a purposeful stare and says, "My name is Edward G. Rendell, and I am the Mayor of Philadelphia."
Ed Rendell proceeds to deliver a short version of the speech he has given to mayors' conferences and neighborhood groups and at black-tie dinners around the country, the speech that, no less than his accomplishments, has made his reputation as (in Al Gore's words) "America's mayor." He talks about how, in January 1992, he took the reins of a city with a $250 million deficit, whose bonds were rated below junk, that was ranked by Financial World magazine as the worst-managed of America's 30 largest cities and that was on the verge of bankruptcy. He talks about how he succeeded in balancing the city's budget in 18 months -- without raising taxes, without begging for handouts from Harrisburg, Pa., or Washington and (Rendell maintains) without lowering the quality of city services, but rather by instituting cost-cutting and efficiency procedures, privatizing many city functions and taking a hard line with municipal unions. 
 By this point in The Speech, the crowd is usually ready to follow Rendell wherever he wants to go. A former Philadelphia District Attorney, he is a natural, even a brilliant, extemporaneous speaker, able to communicate conviction and energy and a sense of mission, all with a common touch. But on this April day in Washington, The Speech is not going over too well.
In a Capraesque move, Rendell has hired a room at the National Press Club, invited the news media at large and journeyed from Philadelphia to present some ideas he thinks are worthwhile. The trouble is, the dozen or so reporters present already know Rendell's Philadelphia story; some of them have probably already written it. They need something new.
The second half of The Speech is Rendell's attempt to give it to them. After listing his administration's accomplishments, he pauses and says: "But it's not enough. The best management in the world isn't going to save Philadelphia." In the last 25 years, he says, the city has lost 263,000 jobs, 30 percent of its tax base and more than 20 percent of its population. Its poverty rate is 20 percent. It is plagued by violence, drugs, AIDS and unemployment. And a balanced budget isn't going to do anything to halt these trends.
But all is not lost, Rendell says. He has a plan: "If we got every single thing in this plan, there's no guarantee that cities will succeed. But if we do nothing -- if the United States of America sits by and does nothing -- there is a guarantee that cities will fail."
At least he's gotten them to start taking notes.
"A LITTLE GIRL ONCE ASKED JOHN KENNEDY, 'HOW did you become a war hero?' He said, 'Simple -- they sank my boat.' "
It's a few weeks before the Washington address, and the 50-year-old Rendell (the accent is on the second syllable) is sitting in his office in Philadelphia's Second Empire City Hall, sipping one of 10 Diet Cokes he will consume in the course of the day and talking about his reputation as Philadelphia's savior. "I became captain of a boat that was three-fifths underwater and listing," he says. "I had no choice. I had to right the ship."
The analogy is true as far as it goes, but doesn't seem quite a sufficient explanation for the acclaim Rendell has received. As far as the national press is concerned, he's like the goody-goody of the neighborhood: the mayor with whom every city's newspaper unfavorably compares its own chief executive. Mayor Richard Riordan of Los Angeles flew to Philadelphia last year for an audience with Rendell. Rudolph Giuliani, also an admirer, had Rendell address top New York City officials at a daylong Gracie Mansion meeting in March.
The outgoing Rendell clearly relishes the national attention, but he's sincere when he says that it wasn't solicited. "Frankly, it makes me a little sheepish," he says. "We're not doing anything that, say, Rich Daley hasn't done in Chicago, but he's just a self-effacing guy, and we did it all at once."
Rendell's near apotheosis is all the more striking in view of the depths to which he had fallen a few short years ago. In 1986, after completing two terms as District Attorney, he was defeated in the Democratic primary for Governor of Pennsylvania. The next year, he challenged Mayor W. Wilson Goode in the primary and lost again. "I wasn't sure whether or not I was done," he says of his political career.
But he couldn't let go of the idea of making one more run. Something of a policy wonk before the term was coined, and convinced that many of Philadelphia's problems stemmed from gross mismanagement, he spent three years studying the solutions of other mayors and governors, many of them from the nonideological "Reinventing Government" school of cost-cutting and efficiency. (A copy of David Osborne and Ted Gaebler's opus "Reinventing Government" is one of three books in Rendell's office, but he says he hasn't read it.)
As the 1991 mayoral election neared, it became apparent that there would be more than one black candidate running for the Democratic nomination -- extremely significant in a city where the race card is always on the table. "I'd never rest if I didn't try it one more time," Rendell says.
As it turned out, there were three black candidates (as well as one other white), and Rendell was 15 points ahead in the polls. He used the breathing room, which continued through the general election, to conduct what amounted to a yearlong civics-seminar-cum-reality-check for Philadelphia's citizens, preparing them for the bitter medicine he had in mind.
"I was determined to tell people what I planned to do," he says. "If they didn't want it, I was reconciled to not winning. But we did some focus groups, and people felt things were so bad that they were ready to accept almost anything that sounded rational."
Rendell got 68 percent of the vote. He hit the ground sprinting, concentrating all his formidable energy, inventiveness and persuasiveness on ways to get the city back on its fiscal feet. He instituted "competitive contracting," in which private contractors bid against city agencies, for many city services. So far, 19 services have been privatized, including custodial services at City Hall, food service in Philadelphia jails and horseshoeing for police horses; 26 more are on the drawing board.
Most dramatically, some nine months into office, Rendell offered unionized city workers a contract that froze wages for 33 months, cut paid holidays and sick days and shifted control of health plans from the unions to the city. The unions struck, hoping for public support. They did not get it. Sixteen hours later, they accepted the city's offer.
Savings would total an estimated $374 million over four years. And Rendell had the perfect sound bite, should he need one, for his 1995 campaign: "I stared down the unions."
AT LEAST AS IMPORTANT AS WHAT he did for the city's balance sheet is what he did for its mood. When Rendell was inaugurated, Philadelphia had not yet healed the psychic wounds suffered on a May day in 1985 when, with the consent of the Police Commissioner, the Fire Commissioner and Mayor Goode, a police helicopter dropped a bomb on a West Philadelphia row house occupied by the radical group Move and set in motion a chain of events that ended in the deaths of six adults and five children.
"People forget that in Wilson's first year and a half he did some great things," Rendell says. "But after Move, he was never the same." The city's first black mayor, Goode always had the guardedness of many pioneers. But the Move tragedy turned him into, in the words of a political associate, "the man who couldn't laugh."
By contrast, Rendell has a high-energy, kibitzing, informal but sometimes inspirational style. And he seems to be constantly in motion, barreling into a room like a runaway bowling ball or tooling through the city in his Ford Crown Victoria. His first year in office, he was everywhere -- doing cannonball dives into city swimming pools, stopping in at three, four or five events during a single lunch hour (Rendell will appear before virtually any group that asks him, with the stipulation that he never stays for lunch), even being (famously) photographed scrubbing a City Hall toilet. The director Jonathan Demme was so impressed that, while filming "Philadelphia," he turned the camera on Rendell, explained the situation of the scene and told him to be mayoral. Rendell's first-take improvisation is in the finished film.
He's like Frank Rizzo (but without the bluster) or Ed Koch (without the sneer) -- a Mayor who in some ineffable way defines a city at a certain point in its history. In Rendell's case, a significant component is his Upper West Side directness and verve, exotically appealing traits to the notoriously insular Philadelphians. (His father, who died when Rendell was 14, was a middleman in the garment trade; his mother, still a Manhattanite, was born a Sloat, a family famous for its line of women's skirts.)
Rendell is almost as popular in Philadelphia as he is in the nation's newsrooms, but, after a two-year honeymoon, he has taken some political hits in the city lately. A Federal judge recently ruled that a Democratic candidate for State Senator won an election last year because of fraudulent absentee ballots; Rendell, who had repeatedly dismissed the allegations as no big deal, came out tarnished. Early this month, a ballot proposition to significantly alter the city's charter -- strongly supported by the Mayor -- was defeated 6 to 1. The roster of constituencies that are upset with him has grown to include many residents of the city's outlying neighborhoods (who tend to feel that he's more concerned with Center City) and preservationists, who have criticized his commitment to protecting historic buildings.
"Nothing gets me madder than preservationists," Rendell says. "Arts groups are almost as bad, but at least they produce some income. Preservationists don't produce anything."
Rendell has described himself as "the ultimate fraternity guy," and it was his sense of the world as a keg party that led to the closest thing to a scandal his administration has known: an article in the April issue of Philadelphia magazine describing the (married) Mayor's "humorous" propositioning of the writer, a 33-year-old woman. The local press had a good time with it all, the Philadelphia Daily News headlining one of its many reports "Fresh Prince of the City."
By being rather eloquently apologetic at a news conference the day after the story broke, the Mayor managed to minimize (for the time being) the fallout from the incident. "I'm not perfect," he said. "I'm not a saint. I have foibles and failings like everyone else. People who expect their elected officials or their business leaders or their sports figures to be perfect human beings, they're in for a rude surprise."
Rendell has been mentioned as a possible candidate for national office. Even if he's re-elected, his term as Mayor will be up just in time for the New Hampshire primary in 2000. He himself downplays the possibility: "My guess is Jews may be the last substantial minority represented on a national ticket. And when was the last time there was a mayor who was a viable candidate?" But if he ever does run, he doesn't think the Philadelphia magazine flap will be a problem: "Bill Clinton got elected with stuff that was 20 times worse."
ED RENDELL'S FATHER'S IDEA OF a great politician was Adlai Stevenson, which helps explain why Rendell says he takes no satisfaction from being known as the Mayor Who Balanced the Budget and Broke the Unions, why the analogy to Republicans like Giuliani and Riordan goes only so far. When he's not using the sinking ship metaphor, he likes this one: He took office as the doctor of a patient with cancer and a bullet wound to the chest. He took care of the bullet wound. Now comes the hard part.
And so, with the city's fiscal house in order, Rendell has turned his attention to trying to cure the malignant trends, or at least arrest their advance. One facet of his treatment is economic development: convincing existing businesses not to leave the city and prospective ones to set up shop there. Rendell estimates that he spends 75 percent of his time on this effort, a figure borne out by a day spent in the Mayor's company.
One of a half-dozen development meetings starts late in the morning, when Bill Batoff, longtime Democratic fund-raiser and power broker, ushers into the Mayor's office the youthful owner of a 65-employee photo-processing and computer-imaging plant and introduces him to the Mayor. After everyone is seated, the owner, who has a deep tan, starts his pitch: "We've outgrown our present location, but there are certain inherent problems with the city. We've got operations in Miami, and we have to ask ourselves, 'Do we move south to Miami?' Miami's a stepping stone for us."
Meanwhile, Rendell is holding his tongue -- no mean feat for someone as turbocharged as he is. But his fingers are drumming furiously on the round conference table, and his leg is pumping up and down so hard that the table appears to be in jeopardy of tumbling over.
"I grew up in Philadelphia," the fellow goes on. "I want to stay here. But I'm a businessman. I want to do what's responsible for the company. Ed, I'll be blunt. The thought of moving to another location in the city scares me."
When he's done, Rendell gives his pitch. It turns out that the plant is in an area close to one the city hopes will become a Federal empowerment zone, a designation that, among other things, will allow a business to get a $3 million loan at 2 percent interest. Close, but just outside its borders.
Rendell punches up some buttons on his phone. "Can somebody redraw a map maybe?" he asks the staffer at the other end of the line. "See if you can get his block in."
When he hangs up, Rendell tells the guy he should put together a wish list of tax and regulatory breaks, and go through a copy of the empowerment zone legislation. "If there's anything you like, give me a call."
BUT A FEW JOBS HERE AND THERE can get you only so far. Rendell is adamant about not going to Washington or Harrisburg for "handouts" (he almost spits out the word), but he also knows that without outside help, cities like Philadelphia are doomed. He says that when President Clinton's economic stimulus plan was voted down last year, he knew with crushing finality that Philadelphia and other cities could not expect much help from the Federal Government. "There's no money for revenue sharing," he says. "There's no $40 billion available. We might as well ask for $400 billion as 40."
And so he started thinking up ways to "level the playing field, maybe tilt it slightly in our direction, but without a negative budgetary impact on the Federal Government."
"Here's an example: The Defense Department currently has something called the D.F.A.S. -- the Defense Finance and Accounting Service. It's in locations scattered around the country, and the Defense Department has wisely decided to consolidate. I would have the President say that in these types of relocation decisions, the preference should always go to available sites in distressed urban areas."
Rendell also wants Washington to institute "urban impact statements," modeled after environmental impact statements, which would scrutinize Federal moves for possibly harmful effects on cities. And, convinced that regionalization -- that is, fiscal cooperation between a city and its suburbs -- in some form is the only hope for cities in the 21st century, he wants the Government to offer incentives to areas that get with the program.
"That kind of favoritism is a dangerous path," cautions David Osborne. "Soon there'll be rural impact statements and suburban impact statements and minority impact statements, and another kind of minority impact statement."
In March, Rendell packaged his ideas into a 13-point plan he calls the New Urban Agenda and presented it during a private meeting at the White House with the President and the Vice President. After 40 minutes of vintage Rendell salesmanship, the two leaders offered no commitments, but their general seal of approval. In parting, Gore cracked, "Too bad you didn't have any ideas today, Ed."
At the National Press Club, Rendell isn't getting the response he wants. The capital is a place where things are done in traditional ways, and the New Urban Agenda is too different -- it's not about a candidate, or pending legislation, or (obvious) political advancement. It's just ideas.
Rendell himself seems a little subdued, as if cowed by the singularity of the forum. Fortunately, he knows that his vision won't live or die with the coverage of today's speech. This morning he met with H.U.D. Secretary Henry Cisneros, a longtime ally, and with Robert Rubin, a top White House economic policy adviser, who told him, Rendell reported afterward, that he liked a lot of his ideas and wanted to help get them through.
After the news conference breaks up, Rendell latches on to one reporter, a bespectacled fellow in a tan suit who's asked what happens to be the $64,000 question: in essence, Why does Rendell think Congress and the Administration will commit to showing this kind of favoritism toward the cities?
"I can show you study after study that if cities slide down the tubes, suburban areas go right down with them," Rendell says. "So it does make a difference."
He is gesticulating strenuously, jabbing his finger at the reporter, who looks as if he just wants to go back to his cubicle. But Rendell is finally on a roll, and he doesn't want to stop.
"See, what you just said is the problem in this country today. I mean, isn't it a little embarrassing when a foreign correspondent comes to America and you have to take them to maybe a few designated areas and try to keep them away from the rest of the city? You can walk 10 minutes from the Capitol and see disgraces. And see disgraces. So it is a matter of national policy, and -- I'm not blaming you -- what you've expressed is one of the reasons we're here, because people don't understand."
At this point the reporter manages to say thanks and sidle away. Rendell looks around, searching for someone else to convince. But the room is empty. There's nowhere else to go but home.

LENGTH: 406 words

HEADLINE: Slashing Youth Programs Will Only Feed the Crime Problem

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In a crime-preoccupied city, which has not made a dent in violent crime by juveniles (up 80 percent since 1988), where a 1992 New York City-Federal survey found 20 percent of high school students admitting they carried a weapon, and where homicide is the leading cause of death for those younger than 25, any proposal to eliminate youth recreational, job training and summer employment programs is irresponsible. The Giuliani administration's plans to slash Safe Streets, Safe City youth programs would be a costly mistake socially, politically and economically. 
 When doors to adaptive pathways are shut in the faces of kids while allocations for police and prisons swell unimpeded, conditions are created for more minority youth to join the nearly 25 percent of young African-American men whose lives are entwined with the criminal justice system. Most commonly, they have participated as consumers or peddlers in epidemic self-mismedication with misery-numbing psychoactive substances. Just as large pharmaceutical companies profit handsomely from the 9 million Americans who use such a middle-class euphoriant as Prozac, so too do impoverished, undereducated, and undersupervised young inner-city entrepreneurs enjoy big, easy sales in anti-despondents.
Tragically, inner-city drugs contribute directly and indirectly to the approximately 8,000 murders of African-Americans annually in the United States, fully 90 percent committed by African-Americans. For impoverished communities, the drug-war-created black market is far more lethal than drugs themselves.
Beyond restoring to the budget the money designated for elimination, we need more investment in counseling, recreational, educational and vocational training services for our most vulnerable of children and teen-agers
Open public school facilities during the evenings and summers, build more extensive links with the private sector for internship and mentoring programs, and make certain every at-risk adolescent is known to, and seen at least weekly by, a school guidance counselor. Without such steps, New York is perilously close to becoming a city that, as Richard Murphy, former Youth Services commissioner, put it, "can guarantee a child a jail cell, but not an after-school program."
 
JAN I. HARMAN
New York, May 14, 1994
 
The writer is a psychologist and adjunct faculty member in secondary education, City College-CUNY.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1724 words

HEADLINE: Vietnam Revisited: A periodic report.;
Security Tactics in Vietnam Still Inspire Widespread Fear

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam

 BODY:
The terror of arbitrary arrests, secret trials and penal servitude that gripped Vietnam in the decade after "liberation" has begun to fade against the glare of the nation's economic dawn. But fear still casts a subtle shadow over this long-suffering country.
By 1988 Vietnam's Communist leaders began a struggle to improve their nation's image and attract desperately needed foreign investment. It is believed that by then, all but a few hundred of the tens of thousands of political prisoners held in the country's network of prison camps had been freed. 
 But although overt opposition to the Government is quiescent, the police still make midnight calls on sleeping families, and an unlucky suspect can expect to spend up to a year in jail before being tried. Political trials, which are closed to foreign observers, still result in long prison sentences for such vaguely defined crimes as "counterrevolutionary propaganda." Prudent citizens choose their words carefully, even in casual conversation.
For some, the stress of uncertainty has proved insuperable.
The proprietor of a leather-goods store in this city, which many people still refer to as Saigon, told a visitor that two of his brothers had recently committed suicide, fearing that they were about to be re-arrested and sent for another term in a "re-education camp" or one of the "new economic zones" set up immediately after the war -- Vietnam's equivalent of Siberian gulags. The family was friendly with many American customers before the fall of Saigon in 1975, and like many Vietnamese with American contacts, they were subjected by the Communists to severe hardships.
Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch, PEN American Center, the Catholic and Buddhist churches and the State Department, among other organizations, are sharply critical of Vietnam's disregard of Western perspectives on human rights. But criticism makes Hanoi bristle.
Le Mai, Deputy Foreign Minister for American affairs, said in an interview that "foreigners who come here to press their ideas about human rights on Vietnam are not welcome." Another Government representative was asked for an interview with Doan Thanh Liem, a lawyer serving a 12-year sentence for associating with a privately sponsored American relief project known as the Shoeshine Boys that helped street urchins. He replied, "Human rights questions are very delicate, and your request is unwelcome."
The Communists overturned society in South Vietnam when they conquered the country in 1975, and deep scars remain.
Most of the hundreds of thousands who had served in South Vietnam's armed forces were sentenced to terms of up to 13 years in the re-education camps, where duties included breaking rocks and clearing mine fields.
Owners of shops or land were thrown into the streets, and their belongings were confiscated. In some cases they were shipped to the "new economic zones" -- drought-stricken wilderness in the scrub jungles of Song Be Province and similar regions -- where they were expected to farm and to feed themselves.
Foreign critics of the Government acknowledge that some of those arrested have been terrorists, who are not considered "prisoners of conscience."
Early last year the police arrested 18 overseas Vietnamese who returned to Vietnam and were accused of plotting to set off bombs in the country. The defendants, who included several United States citizens, were sentenced to terms ranging from 15 to 20 years. The State Department, hoping to protect the prisoners' legal rights, has asked for access to all United States citizens arrested in Vietnam.
 
Buddhist Monks Seen as Challenge
 Vietnam's Communist Party sees a much greater potential challenge to its authority from some of the nation's Buddhist monks, and the Government has responded vigorously. Hanoi is aware that most Vietnamese are at least nominal Buddhists, and even under Communism, Buddhist monks have immense influence.
One year ago, exactly 30 years after Buddhist monks began a campaign that ended in the overthrow and death of President Ngo Dinh Diem in South Vietnam, a new generation of monks threw a scare into the Hanoi Government. The episode began in May 1993, when a man entered the Linh Mu pagoda in Hue, set himself on fire and burned to death.
The incident recalled the fiery 1963 protest suicide of the monk Thich Quang Duc in Saigon, an incident that ignited a nationwide wave of unrest.
After last year's immolation, the Hue police tried to arrest the pagoda's chief monk, Thich Tri Tuu, but the arrival of the police at the pagoda prompted a large anti-Government demonstration.
Thich Tri Tuu and three other monks were charged with inciting the demonstration, and all were convicted. Thich Tri Tuu and Thich Hai Tang received four-year sentences, and Thich Hai Chanh and Thich Hai Thinh were each sentenced to three years.
[A chain of informants that reaches into the prison camps has kept track of the imprisoned monks, and on May 14, the International Buddhist Information Bureau in Gennevilliers, France, reported that all four were "dangerously ill" as a result of a hunger strike, and were being fed intravenously. The Government said that the monks were not being mistreated and that their hunger strike was unjustified.]
 
Many Monks Feel Intimidated
 A visit to several Buddhist monks who were active in the 1963 insurrection against the Saigon Government found them intimidated and fearful of arrest.
"Because I have known you for three decades," one of them said, "I couldn't turn you away, but please don't mention that you have seen me. The police watch this pagoda all the time. Monks from Hue and Vung Tau are in prison now, and many others could be arrested tomorrow, even though we have done nothing. You can't help any of us, except by remaining silent."
Rolando Medina, the Vietnam specialist on the staff of the London-based human rights organization Amnesty International, said Vietnam's monks have little freedom of action.
"The leader of the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam, Thich Huyen Quang, has been under house arrest since 1982, and we regard him as a prisoner of conscience, even though he is not formally imprisoned," Mr. Medina said. The Government banned the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam in 1981, and has tried to replace it with a Government creation, the Vietnam Buddhist Church.
Last December, despite his house arrest, Thich Huyen Quang issued a statement in which he asked the Government to abandon the one-party system and hold elections. But the national leader of Vietnam's Buddhists remains confined and isolated in his pagoda.
The Government also exercises control over the Catholic priesthood here, and has asserted a right to veto Vatican appointments of archbishops in Vietnam.
 
Attention Demanded By Rights Group
 Some of the human rights cases taken up by Human Rights Watch/ Asia, an organization based in Washington, demand urgent attention, officials of the group say.
On March 7, Nguyen Van Ho, a former Communist Party cadre and founder of a Vietcong veterans' group, was arrested at his home here. According to Dinah PoKempner, a spokeswoman for Human Rights Watch, Mr. Ho is believed to have been arrested for writing and distributing an article urging party leaders to permit greater freedom of expression and to restore human rights in Vietnam. Family members have not heard from him since his arrest, she said.
Two other political prisoners championed by international human rights organizations are Dr. Nguyen Dan Que, an endocrinologist sentenced to 20 years for calling publicly for democratic reforms, and Doan Viet Hoat, an English professor who published an underground newsletter, who drew a 15-year sentence. According to his wife, Mr. Hoat began a hunger strike in early April, and although he is in poor health, he is compelled to work on a punitive hard-labor gang.
During a visit to Vietnam in August, Senator Charles S. Robb of Virginia tried to bring medicine needed by Dr. Que to the prison camp where he was held, but he was rebuffed by Vietnamese officials.
Human rights groups also fear that the forcible repatriation of some 60,000 Vietnamese emigres now in prison camps in Hong Kong, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and Japan will bring further misery to many thousands.
 
Pervasive Control Not Always Harsh
 Although the hand of Hanoi's Communist authority presses heavily on some Vietnamese, many others find Government influence ubiquitous but not necessarily harsh.
"We haven't had any real trouble with the police or the District People's Committee," said a shopkeeper in a Mekong River delta town, "but sometimes we get called in by the police, which is always frightening. Lately the police have been encouraging some of us to write to relatives who are living abroad, to invite them to visit Vietnam. Naturally, the police know very well which of us have Viet Kieu relatives."
Viet Kieu, or overseas Vietnamese, of whom there are about one million, are regarded by Hanoi as Vietnamese citizens, regardless of what other citizenship they hold.
Many Vietnamese say that the 19 years that have elapsed since the end of the Vietnam war have softened the harsh Marxist-Leninist cast of government, and that even a certain degree of criticism is tolerated. One public figure who is permitted some freedom of expression is Nguyen Xuan Oanh, a Harvard-educated economist and one-time Deputy Prime Minister of the South Vietnamese Government, who remained in Vietnam when Saigon fell in 1975.
Dr. Oanh, now an adviser to the Hanoi Government on economics and trade, is no respecter of ideology, and he believes that Communism for many party leaders is a doctrine of faith rather than a political system.
"When any religious group challenges the Government, the Government naturally reacts," he said. "What would you expect? For some party members, Communism is a kind of religion. When they are challenged by leaders of another religion, they feel threatened on their own terms."
Another southern Vietnamese believes that time will heal Vietnam's wounds. "The old guard, both persecutors and their victims, are dying off or growing senile," he said. "Little by little, Vietnam is rejoining the world, and our children or grandchildren will know better times."

HEADLINE: Haiti's Generals Remain Defiant As a Strict Embargo Takes Effect

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 22

 BODY:
As a sweeping international embargo took effect here today, Haiti's military leaders appeared to be resolved to ride out the sanctions, convinced that the United States would not mount an armed intervention to unseat them.
The broadened embargo, pushed by a Clinton Administration that has been increasingly exasperated by the Haitian military, covers all trade with the country except for medicines and certain foods. A United Nations ban on shipments of fuel and arms has been in place since October. 
 The action is aimed at forcing the military to surrender power and make way for the return of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Five American naval vessels and a number of Coast Guard cutters are patrolling the waters around Haiti to enforce the embargo, but the smuggling of fuel from the Dominican Republic, which shares the Caribbean island of Hispaniola with Haiti, has remained active.
Even in backing the wider embargo, which was enacted by the Security Council to go into effect at midnight Saturday, the Administration acknowledged that the measure might not be enough to bring about Father Aristide's return. In recent weeks, Administration officials, including Mr. Clinton, have said the use of force in Haiti should not be ruled out.
Haiti's military leaders have defiantly used the two-week grace period between the Security Council's unanimous vote on May 6 and the application of the sanctions to put together a new civilian government, naming an 81-year-old Supreme Court Justice, Emil Jonassaint, as provisional president.
People close to the military junta say that Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the army commander who presided over the coup that ousted Father Aristide in September 1991, has been busy working on plans for new elections to be held in the fall.
The new sanctions took effect when a midnight deadline passed and the military leaders did not step down. Rather than resign to defuse the crisis, associates of General Cedras say, he is contemplating a run for the presidency himself, and would be replaced in the army command by his closest aide, Gen. Philippe Biamby.
The United States and the United Nations have insisted that both men, along with the Port-au-Prince police chief, Col. Joseph Michel Francois, relinquish their commands.
"The military leadership has been meeting quite a bit, and they have decided that all of this noise out of Washington is just bull," said one Haitian businessman with extensive army contacts. "If Cedras decides to resign, it won't be because he is bowing in the face of all of the heat, but because he wants to become president."
In the last days before the deadline, workers at the army-controlled port here labored furiously to unload cargo ships carrying essential goods aimed at enabling the country's leadership to hang on to power .
At the same time, the army took the precaution of stockpiling large amounts of gasoline and diesel fuel smuggled in from the Dominican Republic.
 
Help From Next Door
 Haitian political analysts say that a potentially explosive dispute in the Dominican Republic over the results of the presidential election held there last week has further strengthened the Haitian Army in its resolve not to surrender power.
These analysts believe that the United States would be reluctant to have both countries on this island plunged into crisis, and therefore would soft-pedal demands that the Dominican Republic enforce the embargo against Haiti, at least until a controversy over who won the Dominican election blows over.
It took nearly two months to end a similar election controversy in the Dominican Republic in 1990. Haitian political analysts said a delay like that in settling the current dispute would be of vital help to the army, because few believe that the international community can allow total economic sanctions on Haiti, already the poorest country in the hemisphere, to remain in place for long.
 
The Hard Line
 Asked if the military would consider any negotiated return of Father Aristide to power, bringing an end to the sanctions, Bernard Sansaricq, a conservative politician who is closely allied to the Haitian Army, said:
"This is something in your mind, not in ours. We don't discuss how to lift the embargo, we discuss how to manage it.
"Do whatever you want, and we will do whatever we have to to survive. Eventually we will win."
For some here, convinced that the army leadership is eager to find a face-saving way out, talk like this is reminiscent of the bluster of the former dictator, Jean-Claude Duvalier. Just days before he fled into exile on a special American plane, Mr. Duvalier scoffed at reports that he would surrender power, boasting that he was "strong as a monkey's tail."
A former Haitian official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said of the top army leaders, "There is a lot of tough talk, but I wouldn't be surprised to see these guys leaving just like Jean-Claude."
But others say another historical parallel, this one involving the originator of the 29-year Duvalier family dictatorship, is more apt. "In 1963 we were confronted with a very similar situation," said Kern Delince, an exiled former Haitian colonel who has written extensively on the country's army. "All of the diplomacy in the world failed to impress Francois Duvalier, and the United States decided to intervene. The island was surrounded with ships and the plans were all drawn up, but at the last minute the decision was canceled."
After 32 months of success in measuring Washington's resolve, Mr. Delince said, Haiti's army leadership is convinced that no intervention will take place, and nothing short of military action will change their minds. "They feel that the United States is still ambivalent toward Aristide, and as long as that is the case, no embargo is going to get them to leave," he said.

SMUGGLERS ENJOY BRISK TRADE
 MALPASSE, Haiti, May 22 (AP) -- Smugglers made a mockery of a toughened embargo on Haiti today, shipping in hundreds of gallons of gasoline and diesel oil from the Dominican Republic. Armed Haitian soldiers stood by and watched.
Eight hours after new United Nations sanctions took effect, boats loaded down with fuel crossed Saumatre Lake from the Dominican Republic to Haiti. Boats docked every five minutes, with the four or five people aboard unloading the fuel in 5- and 10-gallon jugs to black marketeers on the Haitian side.
Haitian border guards and armed civilian auxiliaries allowed the fuel to be loaded onto vehicles headed to the capital, Port-au-Prince.
Gasoline that sells for $1.60 a gallon in the Dominican Republic goes for $8 a gallon in Port-au-Prince, with the Dominican and Haitian militaries pocketing much of the difference.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New Flavors for Readers of Food Magazines

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
Saveur, a lush new magazine for people with sophisticated tastes in food, enters the burgeoning field of epicurean food magazines this week. A creme de la creme publication in every sense, it not only aims at the top end of the market but also tosses away concerns about calories and fat.
"Enjoy food. Stop worrying about it. Trust your palate and your heart," writes Dorothy Kalins in the editor in chief's letter in the first issue. 
 Saveur, which loosely translates from French as "savor" and is pronounced sah-VERR, is published by Meigher Communications under a licensing agreement with Bonnier, the Swedish media conglomerate that publishes Saveurs in France. Virtually all the editorial content in the American edition (which drops the final "s" because the name was thought to be confusing enough without it) will be original.
 
New Territory
 Saveur and Fine Cooking, a magazine introduced by the Taunton Press earlier this year and aimed at a similar audience, are staking out new ground. The two are deliberately taking the opposite circulation strategy from the hugely successful seven-year-old Cooking Light, a Time Inc. magazine that is aimed at a more general readership.
Cooking Light, with its healthy approach to food, broke through the one million mark in circulation two years ago and is rising to the top of the category. Bon Appetit is still the official leader, according to the latest figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations, but probably not for long. Cooking Light has said it will raise the circulation it guarantees to advertisers to 1.2 million in September from the current one million, while Bon Appetit has cut back its guarantee to one million from 1.2 million.
While the category leaders, which also include Gourmet and Food & Wine, go for big numbers, Saveur and Fine Cooking have decided that less is more -- in circulation if not in calories. They are going after affluent baby boomers who have a real interest in food and are ready to devote time and energy to its preparation. Both magazines have starting circulations of 100,000.
"If people who make specialty food products are looking for upscale customers, there is a growing interest in baby boomers as they grow up," said Martin Landey, chairman of Cox-Landey & Partners, an advertising agency. "Saveur is beautifully done."
Saveur has been able to attract nonfood advertisers including Mercedes-Benz and Sotheby's.
 
Food Advertising Only
 Fine Cooking, however, accepts only advertising related to cooking.
"We feel that we have a specialty audience and that they are buying us for cooking and food," Jan Wahlin, its publisher and editor, said.
Fine Cooking is very much in the spirit of other Taunton Press publications, which include specialty magazines for woodworkers, home builders and people who enjoy sewing and gardening. The new magazine, Mr. Wahlin said, is about the how and the why of cooking. While Saveur has features on the regional cooking of Oaxaca and Provence, Fine Cooking is more likely to examine how a master chef prepares a certain dish.
Both magazines are relatively expensive: Saveur has a cover price of $5 and Fine Cooking is $4.95. Bon Appetit, Food & Wine, Gourmet and Cooking Light are all priced at $2.95.
After its first issue, Saveur will be published every two months beginning in September. Fine Cooking is also published six times a year.
 
 
Kitchens and Flower Gardens
 The traditional Big Three of the field -- Bon Appetit, Food & Wine and Gourmet -- are monthlies that have tried to be more than food magazines. All three offer handsome photographs of beautifully prepared food and gleaming kitchens, but their pages may also include scenes of sunlit fields, church spires and brilliant flower gardens in faraway lands. Travel is an important topic for each magazine.
Indeed, Food & Wine's cover article for May is "The Best of Paris," while Bon Appetit features "The French Countryside."
 These three magazines, along with Cooking Light and Eating Well, are all down in advertising so far this year, an indication that despite the hopeful talk from publishers, the industry has not quite recovered from its recession.
 
Bon Appetit's Ad Woes
 The advertising drop is most noticeable at Bon Appetit, where ad pages are off 51.7 percent for the year through April. Much of the decline, however, can be attributed to its new rate policies. When Conde Nast acquired the magazine from Knapp Communications last year, it revised the ad rules to conform with its corporate policy of only selling ad pages at stated rates and not making special deals off the rate card. Some mass-market food advertisers defected.
Food & Wine, published by a partnership of American Express and Time Inc., was down 2.5 percent in ad pages through April, while Gourmet, also published by Conde Nast, was down 11.1 percent.
While the Big Three include some mentions of healthy cooking, they are more likely to feature praline pecan tarts and apricot jalousie with amaretto cream. But low-fat approaches to cooking are found throughout the pages of two other magazines -- Cooking Light and Eating Well.
 
Accent on Health
 Eating Well, published six times a year by Telemedia Communications Inc., offers healthy recipes for chocolate chip cookies and low-calorie but creamy cheesecakes.
"We're targeting the baby-boom generation and a lot of our readers are moving into prime heart-attack time," Deborah DuCharme, the associate publisher, said.
Cooking Light, in the words of its publisher, Jeffrey C. Ward, is "more mainstream, more middle America -- that's where we want to be." It publishes eight issues a year.
Another relative newcomer to the field is Cook's Illustrated, which differs from the others in that it does not carry advertising. It is like a Consumer Reports for cooks in that it tests cookware, kitchen equipment and -- most of all -- recipes.
"Instead of hiring food experts to do their versions of recipes, we will take a category and go into the kitchen for two to five days and cook as many versions as we can," said Christopher Kimball, the magazine's editor and publisher and one of its four owners.
For a recent article, Cook's Illustrated roasted 32 turkeys, then described what techniques worked best. In a coming issue, it will report on test results of 44 pie pastry recipes. It will also discuss how to boil an egg.
"We are a magazine about the process of cooking," Mr. Kimball said. "We are about American home cooking and how people cook at home."
The four partners began the magazine in mid-1993 with an investment of $500,000, which Mr. Kimball said was returned by the end of the year. The magazine, which carries mostly black-and-white photography and many diagrams, gets its revenue from circulation. Its cover price is $4.95 and a one-year subscription, for six issues, costs $24.95.
Asked if there was a downside to not carrying advertising, Mr. Kimball replied, "There may be, but I haven't found it."

HEADLINE: Alec Nove,78, Dies; British Economist and Critic of Soviets

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Alec Nove, a Russian-born British economist and longtime critic of the Soviet system, died on May 15 in a hospital in Voss, Norway. He was 78 and lived in Glasgow.
The cause was a heart attack he suffered while vacationing in Norway, his son David said. 
 Professor Nove taught at the University of Glasgow from 1963 until he retired in 1982, and also headed its Institute for Soviet and East European Studies. He taught at the London School of Economics from 1958 to 1963.
Summing up his career on Friday in the British newspaper The Independent, Tam Dalyell, a British author and Labor Party figure, wrote, "Nove tutored informed opinion about the Soviet Union for 30 years."
Professor Nove's books included "An Economic History of the U.S.S.R." (Viking Penguin, 1969) and "The Soviet Economic System" (Unwin Hyman, 1977).
His 1989 book, "Glasnost in Action: Cultural Renaissance in Russia" (Unwin Hyman), was praised in the United States as a helpful and compassionate Baedeker for the bumpy road of glasnost and perestroika, no matter what unpredictable turn they might take.
In a 1976 article, Professor Nove wrote that the prospects for Soviet agriculture were bleak unless the peasants were "again made to feel a direct interest in the result of their work." He added, "In five years' time there will still be shortages, and Soviet leaders will still be worrying about how to improve the performance of this, the weakest sector of the Soviet economy."
He was a fellow of the British Academy and the Royal Society of Edinburgh.
Professor Nove was born Aleksandr Novakovsky in Petrograd, Russia, now St. Petersburg. He was the son of Jacob Novakovsky, a social democratic Menshevik who moved to London with his family in 1924.
He is survived by his wife and three sons.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Garbage haulers are attracting new followers on Wall Street.

BYLINE: By John Holusha 

 BODY:
TRASH is making a comeback, and that is good news for companies like WMX Technologies Inc., the nation's biggest collector, hauler and disposer of refuse, with revenues of $9.1 billion last year.
Trash, after all, is cyclical. During a recession, households and business buy less and throw out less. That was bad news until recently for WMX, formerly known as Waste Management Inc., because there was less material to be handled and because it was forced to trim prices to keep business from being diverted to competitors. 
 As a result, income per share fell to 93 cents in 1993 from $1.72 the previous year and the stock price slid from a high of $36.375 last June to around $23 in April. It has recovered a bit since, closing at $25.875 on Friday, but there has been little to inspire investors, particularly when first-quarter earnings came in at 34 cents a share, down 17 percent from 41 cents a share in the corresponding period a year ago.
But trash, it seems, is something of a lagging indicator, with volume starting to increase six to nine months after the economy begins to expand.
As a result, some analysts see a turnaround for the company because, while it has diversified internationally and into other technologies, it still derives the bulk of its revenues and earnings from the trash business in the United States.
Some analysts, including Andrew M. Barish of Robertson, Stephens & Company in San Francisco, have issued buy recommendations on WMX. Mr. Barish said his recommendation was based on a turn in the fundamental business and some internal changes. He said the stock had the potential to trade at $35 a share in the next 12 to 18 months.
 "The business is the best that it has been in three years," he said. The volume of trash handled by the company increased 6 percent in the first quarter, and WMX was able to hold the line on pricing or increase it slightly. That compares with a price decline of 1 percent toward the end of last year.
"They also did some internal things, dealing with some underperforming divisions and closing some recycling facilities," Mr. Barish said. As a result of the changes and the likelihood of improving earnings, he said the market's expectations for WMX might be too low.
Selling or closing operations is new for WMX, which grew by acquiring small trash-hauling operations and using them as feeders for its large, regional landfills. These big, lined landfills are rapidly replacing town dumps, which are being closed because of environmental regulations.
Browning-Ferris Industries, a company usually mentioned in the same breath as WMX, will also benefit from larger volumes of trash. But at a price of $28.125 a share, its stock is near the 52-week high of $30.25 set in February, so it does not appear to have as much potential to appreciate.
A less-known company, Sanifill Inc., a Houston-based operator of landfills that has recently moved into collection as well, may prove more interesting to investors.
In a recent report, Alex. Brown & Sons noted that the company had been following a strategy of building and acquiring landfills to accept municipal solid waste, construction and demolition debris and nonhazardous oilfield waste. Growth has been rapid, with revenues increasing to $121 million last year from $39 million in 1990. Earnings increased to $13 million from $7.7 million.
The analysts at Alex. Brown say Sanifill can probably increase earnings 20 percent a year for two years, reaching $1.35 a share from 87 cents in 1993. At that level, the analysts said, the stock should trade in a range of $24 to $27 a share. Sanifill shares closed Friday at $22.75 each, down 75 cents.

HEADLINE: Republicans Open Convention Today

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
New York's Republican State Committee gathers at a Manhattan hotel today for an old-fashioned convention where back-room deals and last-minute lobbying may have much to do with the party's chances of defeating Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in November.
It is widely assumed that the 394-member committee will give State Senator George E. Pataki a majority of its votes, making him the designated gubernatorial candidate of the party apparatus. But the size of Mr. Pataki's victory may determine whether he must survive a tough primary before turning his attention to Mr. Cuomo and whether he will be the consensus choice of both the Republican and Conservative Parties. 
 The convention will also sort out the rest of the Republican ticket. Bernadette Castro, a political novice who appeared in advertisements for her father's convertible sofa-beds as a child, is the leading candidate to challenge Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. But decisions on lieutenant governor, attorney general and comptroller all remain open, and are likely to depend on the outcome of today's gubernatorial balloting.
Aides to Mr. Pataki said yesterday that he would prefer to balance his ticket with a woman as lieutenant governor, and top campaign officials were said to be considering a list of three or four potential candidates, some of them women. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Mr. Pataki's leading supporter, said he thought the Assembly minority leader, Clarence D. Rappleyea of Chenango County, would be "the kind of person we should be considering."
But the aides said Mr. Pataki was unlikely to make a choice until after today's vote, when he could judge whether he needs support in a particular region or an appeal to Conservative Party leaders.
Two candidates, Joseph Holland, a Harlem lawyer and businessman, and Dennis C. Vacco, a former United States Attorney from Buffalo, are running for attorney general. Assemblyman John J. Faso of Columbia County, who has campaigned diligently for close to a year, is favored to win the Republican Party's endorsement for state comptroller.
But party leaders could quickly change the structure of any of those races if they feel it is important to help balance Mr. Pataki's ticket.
It is uncommon in the television age for such decisions to actually be made at political conventions, which usually showcase previously anointed candidates. The uncertainty reflects both the divisiveness within the State Republican Party and its 20-year exile from the governor's office. But party officials believe the unscripted quality of the convention will generate badly needed exposure for a field of little-known candidates.
"I think it's unusual, but I also think it's healthy and good that there will be attention focused on this process," said John Sweeney, the executive director of the Republican State Committee.
The convention's critical moment is scheduled for this afternoon, when delegates meet in a ballroom at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers to vote for governor.
After Mr. Pataki, 48, won endorsements last week from the Suffolk and Nassau Republican leaders, who control the two largest delegations to the convention, all sides agreed that the Senator, a 10-year veteran of the Legislature and former Mayor of Peekskill, would take at least 51 percent of the vote. That would make him the party's designee, giving him an automatic spot on the Sept. 13 primary ballot.
But there is great suspense about whether Mr. Pataki is strong enough to keep his main rival, Herbert London, a New York University professor, from receiving 25 percent of the vote. Any candidate that gains that much support will also be placed on the ballot, insuring a primary.
"We're going to get over 50 percent," Mr. Pataki said. "It's just a question of how much we get over 50 percent."
Those who do not reach the ballot at the convention can still join a primary if they collect 15,000 valid signatures on nominating petitions in a five-week period this summer. That can be expensive and complicated, and New York has a cottage industry of election lawyers trained to challenge the validity of petitions by opposing campaigns.
Shutting out Mr. London at the convention is critical for Mr. Pataki for several less obvious reasons.
After running competing gubernatorial candidates and splitting the anti-Cuomo vote in the 1990 general election, the Republican and Conservative parties badly want to unite around a single candidate this year. Although the recession was already taking a toll on Mr. Cuomo's popularity in 1990, he won with 53 percent of the vote, while the Republican candidate, Pierre A. Rinfret, won 21 percent, edging out the Conservative nominee, Mr. London, by a single percentage point.
Mr. London has broad grass-roots support within the Conservative Party this year. Although the Conservative chairman, Michael Long, said Mr. Pataki was acceptable to the party, he predicted that the Conservatives would endorse Mr. London at its convention on June 4 if he gets 25 percent of the Republican vote.
"There's no ifs, ands or buts that he's the favorite for the Conservative endorsement," Mr. Long said of Mr. London. "If he breaks 25 percent he'll probably get that endorsement. If he doesn't get the 25, I'll sit down and talk to him and see where he's at."
An overwhelming majority vote would also help Mr. Pataki to create an impression of party unity after months of infighting. A battle between the state's two most influential Republicans -- Senator D'Amato, who supports Mr. Pataki, and the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, who backs Mr. London, has left the party deeply divided.
Both men have pressed their allies to support their candidates. The Bronx Republican leader, Senator Guy J. Velella, who owes his position as chairman of the Insurance Committee to Mr. Marino, announced yesterday that his county would support Mr. London.
Two other Republicans -- Bill Green, a former Congressman from the Upper East Side, and Evan G. Galbraith, a former Ambassador to France -- plan to compete for the gubernatorial endorsement at the convention. Neither is given much chance of breaking the 25 percent threshold, but both say they will try to get on the ballot by petitioning.
A fifth candidate, Richard M. Rosenbaum, a former state party chairman from Rochester, is bypassing the convention to run an outsider campaign aimed at depicting the selection process as corrupt.
During the convention, Mr. Rosenbaum will broadcast advertisements that ridicule the party. "The bosses pick their man; the convention falls in line," intones a narrator as black-and-white film clips show soldiers marching in lock step. To drive home the point, the Rosenbaum campaign has scheduled a conference today that will feature a puppet show.

HEADLINE: A Wrinkle in the Jet Age: Propeller Planes

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
More than 35 years after jet aircraft first carried passengers and 25 years after the test of the first supersonic Concorde, propeller planes are making a comeback, flying more and more passengers on routes long served by jets.
While the smaller airplanes are considerably less expensive for airlines to operate, many communities fret over the sound of whirring propellers on their runways. Many passengers board propeller planes reluctantly or refuse to fly them at all, unhappy about the relative safety, greater turbulence or lack of amenities. 
 Some cities that have recently lost all their jet service say they have become less attractive to outside businesses.
"It is hard to present ourselves as a state-of-the-art, high-tech company when you have to get on a 19-seat turboprop to get here," said Harry Keairns, vice president of planning and finance for Computer Support of Sioux City, a company in Sioux City, Iowa.
City officials say contracts for conventions planned in the city were canceled or put on hold after United Airlines ended jet service last year. And Mr. Keairns said his company occasionally sent drivers to Omaha, 90 miles away, which has jet service, to pick up clients who did not want to take a propeller flight to Sioux City.
Last year, more than 50 million passengers in the United States flew on propeller aircraft, mostly on regional airlines, on flights of less than 500 miles or two hours. Propeller planes are now widely used in virtually every area of the country, and are common at every major airport from which such short routes are flown.
In the last five years, airlines have replaced jets with propeller planes on at least 375 routes, according to research by Kidder, Peabody & Company. Another 202 routes gained jet service, for a net loss of jet service on 173 routes.
"It's a simple matter of economics," said David A. Swierenga, chief economist for the Air Transport Association, a trade group in Washington. "Carriers are matching the size of the plane to the number of passengers in a particular market."
 
 
Driving to Other Airports
 Airport officials and travel agents in cities that have recently lost jet service, like Sioux City; Springfield, Ill., and Worcester, Mass., say many residents drive to neighboring cities to board jetliners.
"A lot of people don't like the smaller planes because they are slightly less safe," said Michael Berger, an owner of Premier Travel, a travel agency in Sioux City.
Direct comparisons of the safety records of jet aircraft and propeller planes are not compiled by any agency or group, but industry executives generally agree that the rate of accidents resulting in deaths on propeller planes has been two to three times that of jets. Generally, smaller propeller planes have a higher accident rate than the larger ones.
The International Airline Passengers Association, a group in Washington that monitors air safety in foreign countries and provides travel-related services, advises its members to fly on propeller planes only in good weather and daylight hours to minimize the chance of accidents.
Yet Walter S. Coleman, president of the Regional Airline Association in Washington, said the accident rate for propeller aircraft had dropped by two-thirds in the last decade from the previous 10-year period.
The shift toward propeller planes is a result of the airline industry's continuing effort to turn a consistent profit since the industry was deregulated in 1978. In the mid-1980's, airlines started building big hub airports to which they funneled passengers from nearby cities. The airlines assigned jet aircraft to serve many of these feeder routes, thinking they would be needed as demand grew.
 
 
Savings of 20% to 40%
 But after long and steady growth in passenger traffic, demand leveled off, leaving the airlines with too much capacity and years of billion-dollar losses. Over the last four years, the world's major airlines have lost $15.6 billion.
Because jet aircraft are more expensive to operate on shorter flights than propeller planes, airlines in the United States and in countries throughout the world are switching to propeller-driven planes, finding they can reduce operating costs by 20 to 40 percent on a typical route.
How big a difference does a propeller aircraft mean to passengers? Fares generally do not change with a switch to propeller planes, and the travel time is not enormously different. On a flight from LaCrosse, Wis., to Minneapolis, for example, a deHavilland Dash 8 propeller aircraft operated by Mesaba Airlines makes the 120-mile trip in 50 minutes; a DC-9 jet operated by Northwest Airlines takes 42 minutes. Even though jet aircraft have far higher top speeds, short routes often consist of a long takeoff and long landing with just a modest sprint in between.
In some ways, the smaller turboprop planes provide better service, because an airline usually replaces a single jet flight with more frequent service on turboprops, saving passengers considerable waiting time.
The nation's fleet of passenger-carrying turboprops is also somewhat younger than the airlines' jet fleet, with an average age of 9.4 years in 1993, compared with 10.8 years for jetliners.
Manufacturers of propeller planes are trying to narrow the gap between the experience of flying on a jet and traveling on one of their planes. While many commuter planes have 19 seats or fewer, no cabin service and no bathroom, some propeller planes have up to 65 seats or so, and flight attendants who serve food.
To reduce noise -- which is generally greater on turboprops because the planes have less sound-deadening insulation than jets -- manufacturers have added more blades to the propellers or changed their design so that they turn more slowly and are quieter. Most manufacturers of propeller aircraft are based outside the United States, but 40 to 70 percent of the parts for the planes, including the engines and cockpits, are made by American companies like General Electric and Honeywell.
And the differences among pilots are minimal, industry executives say, with comparable experience among jet and propeller pilots, especially those who were recently hired. Minor differences in training requirements for the different planes are expected to be eliminated soon by the Federal Aviation Administration.
But behind the passenger discontent are differences that cannot be erased. Propeller aircraft generally fly at lower altitudes, where turbulence is greater, and passengers feel it more because of the planes' smaller size, much as a speedboat's ride is affected more by waves than a yacht's.
 
As Time, and Rain, Goes By
 And boarding a propeller craft is usually a vivid reminder of what is ahead. Rather than walking down a covered ramp, impervious to wind or precipitation, passengers on a propeller plane may walk outside, past spinning propellers, buffeted by noise and sometimes by inclement weather. Remember Ingrid Bergman and Paul Henreid walking out to board the Lockheed Electra in "Casablanca"?
The issue of small-aircraft safety was raised anew in December when a plane operated by Northwest Airlink, an affiliate of Northwest Airlines, crashed in icy weather in Hibbing, Minn., killing all 18 passengers. The final results of the investigation into that crash are expected shortly.
Some communities are so fearful that the loss of jet service will curtail economic development that they have guaranteed profits to airlines that continue to provide jets. Amarillo, Tex., for example, decided in March to insure a profit for American Airlines if the airline continued to provide jet service to Dallas, 356 miles away. American had announced that it would switch to propeller planes on that route.
Trans World Airlines and the Lehigh-Northampton Airport Authority in Allentown, Pa., forged a similar agreement last year. To stem the loss of passengers to airports in Newark and Philadelphia, Allentown's airport had been searching for ways to add to the roughly 25 daily jet departures it offered last year. So, it promised T.W.A. minimum revenues of $5,000 for each round trip between Allentown and Baltimore.
More hope for the fans of jet services comes from aircraft manufacturers like Canadair, based in Montreal, which have started building jet aircraft with as few as 50 seats, enabling airlines to operate jet service at a lower cost.
 
 
Trend Likely to Continue
 Despite the various efforts to retain or restore jet service, the shift to propeller planes is likely to continue, industry analysts say.
"Economics demand that airlines bring their costs down," said Michael J. Boyd, president of the Aviation Systems Research Corporation, a consulting firm in Golden, Colo. "The wave of the future in many markets is going to be turboprops."
That prospect is unsettling to Dennis Gann, executive director of the Sioux City Convention Center and Tourism Bureau. He is in charge of the $16.5 million center built five years ago, which he said had already lost one convention, and might lose others, because his city no longer had jet service. Mr. Gann added that some convention planners said his city would be attractive only if jet service was restored.
"I don't like bouncing around like a cork," said Don Pevsner, a lawyer in Miami who flies more than 100,000 miles annually. He said he avoided flying on propeller-driven planes at all cost and would drive hundreds of miles out of his way to board a jetliner instead.
"Everybody has a certain amount of fear of flying," he said. "Why exacerbate it?"

HEADLINE: Commencements;
Hofstra Graduates Hear an Appeal for Love

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 22

 BODY:
Before 650 graduates of Hofstra University's College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, and alumni from the Class of 1944, the newspaper columnist Murray Kempton received an honorary doctorate today for his achievements in a 50-year career in journalism.
Under a cloudless sky, Mr. Kempton, 76, called upon the graduates, who sat in rows of chairs on the college's well-manicured football field, to "love one another or wither." He repeatedly spoke of "family values," which by his definition meant protecting society's weakest members, particularly the elderly and women and children on welfare. 
 Mr. Kempton, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1985 for his commentary in Newsday, has also been editor of The New Republic, a commentator for CBS-TV and a columnist for The New York Post.
The afternoon commencement was the largest of seven to be held today and Monday for the university's 1,800 graduates, said James M. Shuart, Hofstra's president. The Class of 1994 is one of the largest in the university's history, he said.
Earlier today, at the commencement for the undergraduate School of Business, the university presented Presidential Medals to Paul B. Townsend, editor and publisher of Long Island Business News, and Frank G. Zarb, a former Hofstra board chairman and vice chairman and group chief executive of Travelers, the insurance company.
The United States Attorney for the Eastern District, Zachary W. Carter, a graduate of Cornell University and the New York University School of Law, is to receive the Presidential Medal, which honors career achievements and leadership, at the evening commencement for the Hofstra Law School on Monday.
At the evening commencement of graduate students of the School of Liberal Arts and Sciences and the School of Business, the United States Ambassador to Haiti, William L. Swing, received an honorary doctorate of humane letters. Mr. Swing's 30 years of diplomatic service has covered the terms of eight presidents.
Last year's New York State Teacher of the Year, Patricia James-Jordan, is to receive an honorary doctorate on Monday from the Hofstra School of Education.
Dr. Herbert Stein, the economist and former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Richard M. Nixon, is to receive an honorary degree from Hofstra's New College.
