HEADLINE: The Puzzle of New Jobs: How Many, How Fast?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Faced with nervousness in the credit markets, the Clinton Administration is growing concerned that the robust job growth in recent months might become a victim of further interest rate increases. But there seems to be little the Administration can do about it.
So far, job growth has continued despite rising interest rates, and is running well above the rate needed for the President to deliver on his campaign pledge of eight million new jobs during his four-year term. The economy has added an average 245,000 net new jobs a month this year to the national employment rolls. 
 It is that healthy pace that has the credit markets worried, and, if it continues, could cause them to seek higher interest rates to slow the economy.
 
The Market Mind-Set
 "The market is going to do whatever it thinks it should do, regardless of what the Administration says," said Robert Giordano, director of research at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Administration officials do not dispute that statement. But as job growth accelerates, they are trying to calm the markets, and about the only tool they have is jawboning. The Administration's top economic officials believe they have a strong case to make that the current job growth will not result in inflationary labor shortages. In the past, such shortages have prompted employers to push up wages to hire or keep qualified workers. Price increases have followed to pay for the higher wage costs.
"Of course, you should always be watchful with respect to inflation, but you should think about it in the circumstances of the present economy," said Robert E. Rubin, the President's chief economic adviser, who left as co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs to join the Administration.
Mr. Rubin ticks off several reasons why the relationship between employment and inflation is not the same today as in the past. When labor at home seems in short supply, he says, American businesses can fall back, more than in the past, on foreign production capacity and foreign workers to supply their domestic customers with goods that are in short supply at American factories.
"You have an international supply rather than a national supply, so that when the economy hits bottlenecks, there is then access to international supply to relieve those bottlenecks, rather than simply having to increase prices dramatically," he said. "And even when you are at full capacity in an industry, there is now a constraint that did not used to exist with respect to raising prices, and that restraint is international competition."
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich also argues that the current levels of economic growth and job creation are not inflationary. "It is very difficult for the Administration to say to Wall Street that we will do everything we can not to push growth beyond the current pace," Mr. Reich said, "and then turn around to Main Street and say we will do everything we can to bring about more jobs. But as long as we stay on the present path, we don't have to engage in the debate."
Mr. Rubin, Mr. Reich and other Administration officials also argue that the Administration's labor program will help to hold down inflation by making the labor force more flexible. They point specifically to programs like subsidized worker retraining, subsidies to help unemployed workers become self-employed and Government help in finding new jobs for the unemployed. The Administration's Re-Employment Act, introduced in March, embodies some of these goals. The jawboning of the credit markets seems to include an appeal to Congress to pass the bill.
"I don't think that anybody can say with scientific precision what is the exact rate of unemployment that starts to lead to an acceleration in inflation," said Gene Sperling, deputy assistant to the President for economic policy. "But I think our view is that whatever that rate is, our goal should be to lower it, through increasing the productivity of workers and the efficiency with which they move from job to job. I believe that over the long run, financial markets will come to recognize this."
Maybe. But right now there appears to be a gap. While many Administration officials say the unemployment rate -- now at 6.4 percent -- can fall below 6 percent without becoming inflationary, the credit markets say the danger point is above that level.
"Let's say that in August, the unemployment rate dropped to 6.1 percent; would we get another rate hike?" asked Mr. Giordano of Goldman, Sachs. "Probably. The inflation watch would begin. If the Federal Reserve did not raise rates, then the credit market would come under pressure to push up rates on its own."
Similarly, the credit markets seem to accept as noninflationary President Clinton's original goal of creating eight million new jobs in four years, or nearly 170,000 a month. But it is not so sanguine about the present, much higher level of job creation.
"Job growth beyond 200,000 a month is a trajectory that will blow us through full employment," said Robert DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers. "Bondholders ask, 'What is your job growth forecast; how do you see it for the next few months?' If you tell them 250,000 a month, they walk away saying there is going to be trouble with inflation. They are not thinking of it as jobs, but as more income, more spending, more demand for scarce resources, more overheating."
The credit markets represent the nation's most important lenders, the people and institutions who have lent trillions of dollars through the purchase of bonds. They view inflation as dangerous because it can erode the purchasing power of their money while it is still out on loan. So they demand higher rates to offset this loss.
 
The Rise in Rates
 That began to happen last fall, as the national economy, and job growth, entered a period of greater strength than at any time since 1989. Although interest rates on loans of two years or more were creeping up, the Federal Reserve delayed action until early February. But the Fed's quarter-point increases in short-term interest rates in February, March and April were rejected as too small by bondholders. They pushed up long-term interest rates, until the Fed last week put through a half-point rate increase that seemed at least temporarily to calm the markets.
Now, there is concern that long-term rates could rise further, if job growth and the economy strike the credit markets as too strong, and the unemployment rate continues to fall.
"We can't control the short-term fluctuations in the credit market," Mr. Sperling said. "What we can do is focus on the long-term steps that pave the way for an economy that can handle increased job growth, while still keeping inflation low."

HEADLINE: Business Objects to a Code in China

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration approaches a June 3 deadline for renewing China's favored trade status, American companies with operations in China are being asked by human rights campaigners to embrace a code of conduct that many of them do not like.
A prominent rights group, Human Rights Watch, is urging such companies to adopt a voluntary code that includes proposals that American companies not use products made by prison labor, discourage political indoctrination in the workplace, and encourage their senior executives to discuss rights abuses with Chinese officials. 
 The proposal, a form of which has also circulated as proposed legislation in Congress for several years, has drawn a swift and negative reaction from big American companies.
Many of these companies -- which include Motorola, General Electric, International Business Machines and Xerox -- have significant investments in China, or they regard China as a major market. They have lobbied strenuously in Congress and at the White House to preserve China's trade benefits as a way of retaining and expanding American companies' share of expanding Chinese markets.
 
No Moral Responsibility
 They say that embracing such codes of behavior would undermine their competitiveness and raise suspicions in the Chinese Government.
"The impetus of laying on the American business community a corporate code of conduct simply gives credence to the idea that business is morally responsible for the human rights situation in China," said Robert A. Kapp, president of the United States-China Business Council, a group that promotes commercial links between the two countries. "We don't accept that."
While there is some sentiment in Congress for a voluntary code, China's stiffest critics, like Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, think that Congressional efforts should now focus on whether to revoke China's most-favored-nation trading status, and on other potential sanctions.
Ms. Pelosi said she supported a voluntary code of conduct, but did not see that as a substitute for canceling Chinese trade privileges. She said she found corporate opposition to voluntary standards of conduct difficult to understand.
"The business community resisted this in the past, as now," Ms. Pelosi said. "I think it's ironic that the business community opposes a voluntary code of conduct. How do you oppose something that's voluntary."
Richard Dicker, an associate counsel for Human Rights Watch in New York, said American companies would signal their support for American policies in support of human rights by adopting a code of minimum conduct.
"The objective here on our part is to insure that U.S. business operations in China do not encourage or contribute to oppressive practices, and in a positive way contribute to the human rights climate by taking a positive approach," he said.
The question of voluntary codes for American business abroad was first raised in 1977 by the Rev. Leon H. Sullivan of Philadelphia. who outlined principles for how companies should operate under apartheid in South Africa, in ways that were sensitive to black aspirations.
 
Inapt Comparison Seen
 Human Rights Watch tries to draw parallels between the Sullivan Principles for South Africa and its proposed code of conduct in China. But American companies reject both the analogy and the proposal.
"In China, it would be particularly inappropriate because of the nature of the Chinese economy -- the economy being state-directed while moving toward some market freedom," said Robert McNeill, executive vice chairman of the Emergency Committee for American Trade, which represents leading American businesses. "In China, companies would be seen as agents of the U.S. Government," Mr. McNeill said. "And the danger with codes of conduct that are initially voluntary is that they can become statutory."
Mr. Kapp said American companies would not accept efforts to impose rules of conduct on their China operations.
"There is a great uneasiness about notions of codes of conduct," he said. "First, it becomes a process of public shaming. It is very easy to say things that sound good. No. 2, the advocates of heavy economic pressure against China, to compel China to change its domestic political behavior, believe they are dealing with universal values. That is one of the explanations for what I believe is a cavalier approach to national sovereignty."
The five voluntary measures proposed by Human Rights Watch would prohibit the use of prison products by American companies, discourage compulsory political indoctrination in the workplace, embrace nondiscriminatory employment practices -- which means not discharging people for their political beliefs, allow workers to discuss work-related issues freely, and have American executives discuss human rights issues in their localities with Chinese officials.
Timothy Kellogg, director of corporate communications for Motorola, said the company felt comfortable with its rules.
"We have a very strict internal code of conduct that has been translated into Chinese," Mr. Kellogg said of the code used in Motorola's $120 million semiconductor and pager manufacturing plant in Tianjin. "What we have in place is more than adequate. Any effort that goes beyond that appears to make us a Government agent."
George Jamison, a spokesman for the General Electric Company, said G.E. had not made any public statement on corporate guidelines.
Mr. Jamison said China was an important market for the company, adding, "Over the next decade we have $13.5 billion in potential export opportunities."
 
Pride in Chinese Employees
 Several business groups, including the Emergency Committee for American Trade, have been distributing details of American business activity in China to legislators and Administration officials. In one such packet, I.B.M. called China its fastest-growing market, and said that its 385 Chinese employees "leave the security of the socialist system that provides subsidized housing, education, and medical care to experience risk and reward in the Chinese marketplace." I.B.M. said it contributed more than $1 million last year to a hospital, a model-classrooms project and the state-run Beijing Film Academy.
Similarly, Xerox said it backed "human resource development" through financial support of a management institute in Dalian and a training center in Shenzhen. The company said it "supported cultural activities primarily in Shanghai and contributed to the overall well-being of its Chinese employees by offering thoroughly modern working conditions and facilities in China."
But Representative Pelosi, who has led Congressional efforts to revoke China's preferred trade status because of its rights abuses, described such corporate drum-beating as off the mark. "We're talking about fundamental rights," she said. "They support cultural activities. Isn't that nice. I find it disingenuous."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Human Right Guidelines"
 
Human Rights Watch wants American companies doing business in China voluntarily abide by these five principles:
 
Companies will try not to use prison labor or purchase products made by prisoners, because conditions in Chinese forced-labor plants violate international human rights standards.
 
Companies will not permit compulsory political indoctrination in the workplace, a practice common in state-owned enterprises.
 
Companies will embrace non-discriminatory employment practices, which in this context primarily means keeping workers' political beliefs out of hiring and firing decisions.
 
Companies will encourage freedom of association and expression concerning work-related issues in their plants.
 
Compaies will have senior American executives discuss human rights issues with Chinese officials in their localities and reinforce the idea that human rights abuses cause problems with business relationships.

HEADLINE: Villalba Journal;
How Don Calo (and Patton) Won the War in Sicily

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: VILLALBA, Sicily

 BODY:
Biagio Plumeri sits at the desk of the man a lot of people around here regard as a key to the Allies' speedy occupation of Sicily in World War II.
Mr. Plumeri, a 55-year-old tomato farmer who has been part-time mayor on and off since 1967, is not much troubled that President Clinton will not stop at Villalba in June when he visits Italy to help celebrate the 50th anniversary of the liberation of Rome by Allied forces. 
 Mr. Clinton, who will attend the D-Day commemorations in France, plans to visit Anzio and Nettuno, the beaches between Rome and Naples where Allied forces went ashore on the Italian mainland in January 1944. But the Allies actually stepped into Europe six months earlier, on July 9-10, 1943, when American soldiers of Gen. George Patton's Seventh Army and British troops of Gen. Sir Bernard Montgomery's Eighth Army made amphibious landings at Licata and Gela and along the beaches of Sicily's southern coast. A month later, the island was in Allied control.
"We don't really mark the day," Mayor Plumeri admitted.
Villalba's moment of glory came in 1943 because of one of Mr. Plumeri's predecessors, a prosperous local farmer named Calogero Vizzini, known locally as Don Calo. Mussolini's Fascists hated him; the American invaders named him Mayor, and most people around here say he was considerably more than just a footnote in the history of the invasion.
"They came up Route 121 from Caltanissetta, armored vehicles, jeeps," Mr. Plumeri recounted, mixing childhood memories with what older folks had told him about that sunny day. "One tank was hit near the turnoff when the Germans took them under fire, and a soldier died.
"One guy took a white sheet and fixed it to a pole, and we all walked out, even us little kids, like a parade. They only stayed 24 hours, and then pushed on to Palermo. But they named Don Calo mayor."
Don Calo, he said, had established his fortune in the town in 1922, before the Fascists came to power, when he led disgruntled peasants who grabbed land from the aristocratic absentee landlords. Every peasant got a plot, he said, but Don Calo, with characteristic forethought, kept more than 12,000 acres, for himself.
Among those who remember, sitting like lizards in the sun on benches around the town's main piazza, dressed in the customary black cardigans and soft peaked caps, oral history is at best an inexact science. But Don Calo is recalled as a kind of St. Francis in baggy high-rise trousers and suspenders.
"Don Calo was a magnanimous person, a good man, not vindictive, despite the many outrages committed," said Giuseppe Selvaggio, 72, who deserted his Italian Army unit in Rome at the twilight of the war and walked 40 days home to Sicily.
Sitting in the Catholic Men's Social Club, he described Don Calo as an indulgent man. "When the Fascist mayor and political secretary were supposed to be arrested," Mr. Selvaggio said, "Don Calo told the Americans: 'Let them go. They're good people. They aren't molesting anyone.' "
"The Vizzini family was anti-Fascist," he recalled. "They struggled against Mussolini, especially Calo Vizzini. He was under house arrest on his own property."
For decades after the war Vill alba's politics were rock-solid Christian Democratic, though in the last elections the majority voted for Silvio Berlusconi, the tycoon-turned-politician who is Prime Minister of a right-wing coalition. But no one ever much liked the Fascists around Villalba.
When Don Calo died in 1947, a death notice read: "He received from friends and foes alike, that most beautiful of all tributes: He was a gentleman."
Indeed, dozens of anti-Fascists like Don Calo were named mayors when the Americans arrived in Sicily, including Don Calo's friend Giuseppe Genco Russo, who was appointed mayor over in Mussomeli, a nearby farming village.
But in 1974, an Italian parliamentary commission investigating the resurgence of organized crime concluded that at the time of his appointment during the American Seventh Army's one-day visit to Villalba, Don Calo had probably been the boss of all bosses of the Mafia. Mr. Genco Russo, who later succeeded him, was at the time his No. 2.
When the black market sprouted in postwar economic confusion, the commission said, Don Calo's men ran it. When the Communists held a rally in Villalba in September 1944 that ended in a shootout, it said Don Calo probably sent in the gunmen.
In his book, "Crime in America," Senator Estes Kefauver wrote how in the course of investigating organized crime in the United States, he found indications that American intelligence agencies used Mafiosi to contact anti-Fascist figures in Sicily before the invasion. That could explain why Sicily fell rather quickly.
Senator Kefauver said that Moses Polakoff, the lawyer for Meyer Lansky, had told him about being a go-between for Naval Intelligence with Lucky Luciano, who was born the next big town up from Villalba.
After the war, stories sprouted and became legend. One had it that when the American tanks arrived in Villalba, Luciano himself jumped from one of them to embrace Don Calo.
Most historians caution against such reports. But Nicola Cattedra, a former editor of l'Ora, a Palermo paper, and author of the book "The Black Line," has revived the debate.
"I don't want to criminalize the United States," Mr. Cattedra said. "But they met formidable resistance, and then after only a very few days, they arrived in Palermo. The Americans wanted to win the war, and they found a group within the country that counted."

George S. Patton drove on to Palermo. (Nicola Scafidi); Don Calo, as he was known, was believed to be the boss of bosses of the Mafia. (Paolo Titolo/Contrasto for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Index Reaches 3 1/2-Year High In Broad Commodities Rally

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Led by gains in cocoa, coffee and soybeans, commodity prices rallied broadly yesterday, pushing up an important market index.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities, a widely watched gauge of inflation, climbed to a three-and-a-half year high. The index rose as high as 238.54, its highest since October 1990, before receding to 238.36, up 4.67, its fourth consecutive gain. Of its 21 components, all but petroleum and orange juice were higher.
 
Cocoa at 4-Year High
 Cocoa prices surged to a four-year high, with July cocoa rising $130 to $1,397 a ton on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, helped by the recent rise in coffee prices. Almost one-third of the world's cocoa is produced in the Ivory Coast, where reduced shipments of coffee contributed to a 56 percent rise in coffee prices this month. Coffee for July delivery gained 8.15 cents, to $1.3905 a pound, its highest price in five years. 
 Dry weather drove soybeans to their highest prices in 10 months on concerns that dry weather in the Midwest could damage the 1994-95 crop. A mass of high pressure could move over the Midwest next week, Mike Palmerino, a senior agricultural meteorologist with the Weather Services Corporation, said.
The soybean contract for delivery in July rose as high as $7.3250 a bushel, its daily limit, before retreating to settle 29.75 cents higher at $7.3225 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade. The July wheat contract gained 10 cents, to $3.3675 a bushel, while July corn gained 6.5 cents to $2.7525 a bushel.
"The idea of no rain over the Memorial Day weekend has the market nervous," Doug Jackson, an analyst with the Farmers Commodities Corporation in Des Moines, said. "Everyone's worried about a longer-term dry weather pattern."
 
Demand Rising for Copper
 Copper prices rose to 16-month highs yesterday. Traders said that European copper use could rise by 4 percent this year and that consumption by Korea, Taiwan and China would offset the decline from Japan, where recession has cooled demand.
Copper for July delivery rose 3.90 cent, to $1.0635 a pound, its highest since January 1993, on the Commodity Exchange of New York.
Gold prices also rose. Gold for delivery in June, the most active contract, rose $3.60, to $389.90 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange.
Crude oil, meanwhile, fell on the perception that a seasonal surge in demand for gasoline had not yet materialized. Crude for July delivery settled down 15 cents at $18.06 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Unleaded gasoline fell 0.39 cent, to 52.21 cents a gallon, and heating oil ended 0.41 cent lower, at 47.91 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Zaire Drifting Into Anarchy As Authority Disintegrates

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire

 BODY:
After four years of political turmoil, Government authority here is simply dissolving away, leaving the cities and the countryside to pillaging soldiers and roaming gangs of thugs and bandits.
Zaire is coming to represent a new specter in Africa -- the stateless country. 
 Where once there was the "big-man rule" of President Mobutu Sese Seko, there is now what some Zairians are calling "no-man rule."
The President is still nominally in charge, but he is rarely seen or felt. The rapacious central authority that he personified for nearly three decades has so disintegrated that vast stretches of the interior are without any government and the congested capital is largely lawless.
The same phenomenon has been seen in Somalia, where the "technicals" -- carloads of gun-toting youths -- are now back in the streets of Mogadishu. It can also be seen in parts of West Africa, where fighting in Liberia and Sierra Leone has given way in places to more or less permanent anarchy. And Rwanda, one of Zaire's eastern neighbors, is slipping deeper into a chaotic civil war.
But Zaire, the size of the United States east of the Mississippi, could turn into "Somalia and Liberia rolled into one," a State Department memorandum warned last year.
Zaire's 40 million people have seen their living standards drop every year for more than a decade. The economy is in a shambles, with external debt at over $10 billion. Prices rise a hundredfold a year. There is virtually no investment.
The infrastructure is crumbling. About 85 percent of the 85,000 miles of roads that existed at independence in 1960 have reverted to bush. A satellite earth station has broken down, so national radio and television now has trouble reaching Kisangani, Lubumbashi and other cities.
Shaba Province, the mineral-rich area to the south that was the scene of turmoil in the 1960's and of invasions by Katangan rebels in 1977 and 1978, has declared autonomy. Many regard that as the first step toward secession.
AIDS is rife. A prevention program has been largely abandoned, so by all accounts the epidemic is soaring.
In March the international relief organization Doctors Without Borders undertook a survey of children up to 5 years of age in Kinshasa. It found that 1 out of every 10 was malnourished and 1 out of 40 was starving.
The Cite, Kinshasa's sprawling slum, which houses more than a million people, is so depressed that even the nightclubs are quiet. Most people there eat one meal a day.
 
Government Services Are Breaking Down
 It is difficult to find any services that the Government provides. Schools and health clinics are closing. The sweltering streets of Kinshasa, with potholes the size of bomb craters, are crammed with pedestrians. There are no buses or other organized transportation except private open-air trucks.
Recently, the bridge to the port at Matadi needed $250,000 worth of repairs. The sum exceeded what was in the Government's coffers, and so it was raised by private companies.
Presiding over Zaire's descent into chaos is President Mobutu. Now 63, he took office in a coup in 1965 with the backing of the Central Intelligence Agency, which feared that instability could lead to Communism in the old Belgian Congo, and he has been Washington's point man in Central Africa more or less ever since.
Washington has made it clear that Mr. Mobutu is currently in disfavor because he is blocking democratic development. And he is something of an international pariah because he has looted Zaire, accumulating, one former minister testified, about $5 billion. The United States and Western European nations have refused him visas. Still, he survives.
And as conditions go from bad to worse, that old refrain that helped to preserve Western backing for him throughout the 1970's and 1980's -- when all is said and done, who else can hold the country together? -- is becoming fashionable again in some Western capitals.
 
Opposition Duels With Dictator
 Now Mr. Mobutu has embarked on a long and complicated political game with the opposition. In response to the growing discontent, he convened a National Conference four years ago to chart the country's future. It soon turned against him and came out with a new Constitution and even a new Prime Minister, Etienne Tshisekedi, an implacable opponent of Mr. Mobutu.
Eventually, Mr. Mobutu dismissed Mr. Tshisekedi and appointed a Prime Minister of his own, Faustin Birindwa. In March 1993, Mr. Tshisekedi was ejected from his office by soldiers, and the country ended up with two prime ministers, two Cabinets, even two Constitutions.
Now, there is an agreement on a new, single constitution, but the opposition is divided between hard-liners, who want nothing to do with Mr. Mobutu, and moderates, who believe they can work with him. And there is a suspicion that the President is back in effective control.
There is a sense of stalemate to it all. Frederic Kibassa Maliba, head of the overall opposition coalition called the Sacred Union, sat in the shade of a tree in his backyard and put it this way: "On the one side, there's Mobutu. He has no popularity, only his army and his printing press to make money. On the other is the people. We have no army, we have no money. We can't overthrow him and he can't overcome us."
Mr. Tshisekedi, a husky man of 61 with gold-framed glasses and a round face, will not relinquish his claim to the premiership or agree to work with his archenemy. "I'm not a rebel," he insisted, ensconced in an office behind his well-guarded yellow house on the outskirts of town. "It's Mobutu who is the rebel."
In the middle of all this, Mr. Mobutu has withdrawn into a peculiar semiretirement. He rarely ventures out of his pink-marble palace in Equator Province, 700 miles to the north. His grip, exerted through half a dozen intelligence and police agencies, is perhaps less suffocating than it was.
The last time the President came to the capital, he spent the night not at one of his luxurious mansions but at the headquarters of the Special Presidential Police, apparently out of concern for his safety.
 
Mobutu's Image Now More Muted
 A decade or two ago, the President, sometimes called "The Guide" or even "The Messiah," seemed omnipresent. His image and his totems of office -- a leopard-skin cap and an elaborate hand-carved ebony cane -- were everywhere: on the currency, in the newspaper, framed over the desk of every major bureaucrat.
Now his image is fading somewhat. The evening television no longer begins with a montage that depicts him floating down from the clouds. "Mobutuism," a hodgepodge of aphorisms and Chinese Communist-style exhortations that once was official doctrine, is no longer taught in the schools.
Perhaps more surprising are the number of opposition newspapers, dozens of them, with names like Storm of the Tropics and The Beacon. They appear irregularly and, since few can buy them, they are draped over lengths of string on the roadsides, where they attract crowds.
One such paper, Umoja, recently printed a cartoon depicting the President strangling a poor Zairian. That would have been cause enough for execution some years back.
There are also half a dozen human rights organizations. "We are not accepted by the regime, we are tolerated," said Bruno Lokuta Lyengo, vice president of one group, Voice of the Voiceless.
He said vast rights violations continued, with people kidnapped from their homes or stopped at gunpoint and taken to secret detention centers. "In a way it's gone from bad to worse," he said. "What's unsettling is that the state is only in quasi-existence. If the state ceases to exist, it's the law of the jungle out there and only the strong will survive. The strong are the ones with the guns."
 
Security Forces Remain Menacing
 The army, with 40,000 troops, and the police, with 30,000 officers, are perennial sources of danger, underpaid and continuously on the prowl. They station themselves on the roads to levy fines for imaginary traffic offenses, and rent themselves out to provide security for hotels and businesses and even visitors. They have even taken to begging for soap.
Twice in recent years they went on rampages, pillaging homes and shops and killing scores of people: in September 1991, when they were owed back pay, and in February 1993, when they found that the newly minted currency they were being paid in was not accepted by shopkeepers.
To try to head off further unrest, in April the military raised the soldiers' salaries to 2,000 New Zaires a month, or the equivalent of about $4. But a recent study found that a family of six needs $80 a month to get by.
The staggering inflation comes largely because the Central Bank simply prints money whenever more is needed. Huge stacks of currency are sometimes required to buy a round of beer. To make larger purchases, visitors took to carrying backpacks. At one point, $1 fetched 4.5 million Zaires, then 7.2 million, then 9 million.
Three times in recent years the bank has issued totally new currency to try to solve the liquidity problem. During a much ballyhooed monetary reform in October, the New Zaire was set at 3 to the dollar. By February it had fallen to 115. Now it is at 460 and sliding rapidly.
In stores the goods are coded by numbers, and customers have to check a giant blackboard up front to find out the prices. The true rate of exchange is set many times a day by illegal money traders who congregate in a park nicknamed Wall Street, close to the United States Embassy.
 
Economic Outlook Is Still Gloomy
 There is little prospect that Zaire will solve its economic troubles any time soon. The main exports, cobalt and copper from Shaba, have effectively halted. The machinery has broken down, the foreign workers fled and many mines were destroyed and flooded during fighting. Last year the main company, Gecamines, produced only 10 percent of what it did in 1990.
Western aid donors have turned away. The United States Agency for International Development, which pumped some $900 million into Zaire beginning in 1965, has closed down its operations. The World Bank, citing the country's arrears, also pulled up stakes. Last year Zaire paid just $5 million to all debtors, out of roughly $500 million due in interest alone.
Almost without being noticed, the country is breaking apart. The most remote province, Kivu, a prime food-growing area, cannot move its goods westward. So it trades almost exclusively with Tanzania and Kenya. Kasai refuses to recognize the new currency and so still uses the old one. Shaba, in addition to declaring autonomy, has been the scene of ethnic violence as Katangans turned against Kasais and expelled them, displacing about 400,000 people.
Throughout much of the country, travel is hazardous. The only artery connecting the capital with the vast interior is the churning Congo River, choked with waterlilies, much as it was the only artery in 1877 when Henry Morton Stanley stood on its banks and described it for readers of The New York Herald.

HEADLINE: U.S., Japan Back Talks On Trade

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
After four days of talks, American and Japanese trade experts reached broad agreement today on a new format to revive their stalled negotiations intended to open Japan's closed markets to more imports from abroad, American officials said.
Barring any last-minute hitches, the two sides will announce the new negotiating format Tuesday. 
 [Early on Tuesday, Reuters reported that the talks had ended, with both sides saying an announcement would be made later in the day.]
The framework is meant to rescue the trade negotiations the United States and Japan established last July, but which collapsed in acrimony in February when the White House accused the Japanese of resisting any serious measures to open their markets. The Japanese, in turn, accused Washington of trying to set quotas for American exports to Japan.
The tentative deal clearly involves concessions by both sides. Essentially, the Japanese agreed to drop their opposition to quantitative and qualitative indicators that would measure if they are indeed opening their closed markets, the officials said.
 
Specific Targets Dropped
 The United States agreed to forgo demanding that Japan meet any specific numerical targets for imports -- from either the United States or the world at large -- in any of the five areas covered by the accord. Those are Japanese automobiles, auto parts, insurance, medical equipment and telecommunications equipment.
The United States also agreed that it would not deem Japan in noncompliance with any future accord if Tokyo did not show progress on every numerical indicator. For example, the two sides agreed that one way to measure if Japan's auto market was opening was by counting the number of Japanese car dealers displaying American cars in their showrooms.
Another indicator would be to measure not only the number of showrooms with American cars, but also their geographic spread around Japan, and whether they are just in Tokyo, or in other cities as well.
Each sector has seven or eight such indicators to measure progress, and as long as Japan shows progress on some indicators in any given sector -- even if it is not necessarily showing progress in all of them -- the United States will not threaten trade sanctions, officials said.
"What we wanted is a framework that gives us the ability to measure results," said the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, who along with two trade experts, W. Bowman Cutter and Charlene Barshevsky, worked out the new arrange ment. "What the Japanese side wanted was assurance that they would not be held to numerical quotas for imports in any one sector. Both sides are moving toward accommodation of their respective concerns."
The United States also agreed to qualitative indicators on its part to show whether it was making an earnest effort to enter the Japanese markets. For instance, the Japanese said they would want to measure the number of American companies teaching Japanese to sales personnel working the Japanese market, and also the number of American companies conducting seminars and other educational programs on how to do business in Japan.
American officials said what was striking about the negotiations was that the Japanese originally came to Washington saying that they were here only for "exploratory talks" and could not make any agreements.
 
Desires of Japanese
 Twice when the Japanese bureaucrats who were involved in the negotiations appeared to be dragging their heels or stonewalling the American side, Mr. Kantor telephoned Japan's Foreign Minister, Koji Kakazawa, and a few hours later the Japanese negotiators adopted a more flexible approach.
American officials said this underscored to them the degree to which the new Japanese Government wanted a breakthrough with the Americans on the trade dispute, possibly to demonstrate to the Japanese public that the new Cabinet of Prime Minister Tutsomo Hata can manage that country's most important bilateral relationship.
But some American trade analysts wondered aloud if the American side, also eager to get these talks back on track, might have given away too much.
"We still don't know the details, but what bothers me is the idea that if the Japanese don't meet all their goals, we will not do too much about it," said Lawrence Chimerine, economist at the Economic Strategy Institute, which tends to take a hard line on Japan-American trade issues. "To make this work, there has to be some kind of penalty or sanction for non-compliance, otherwise what is the purpose."
 
A Deal Before July
 All that was agreed to at this stage is a framework for the negotiations. Now the hard bargaining on the details begins. The two countries are aiming to make a deal final before the annual summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial democracies scheduled for July 8-10 in Naples.
The mere resumption of the United States-Japan trade talks, though, has both economic and political ramifications for both Governments. In economic terms, it help strengthen the dollar in world currency markets, which will also take some of the pressure off the Federal Reserve to continue raising interest rates.
Ever since Japan and the United States broke off the trade talks with Tokyo last Feb. 11, currency traders have driven up the value of the yen and driven down the value of the dollar on the assumption that the United States wanted a weaker dollar in order to squeeze Japan into making trade concessions. When the yen rises in value it makes all of Japan's exports more expensive and harder to sell abroad.
Politically speaking, the resumption of trade talks removes an important thorn in ties between Washington and Tokyo in advance of the visit to the United States next month of the Emperor of Japan and in advance of the Group of Seven summit meeting. Neither the American nor Japanese side wanted to go into the Group of Seven meeting with a simmering trade war between them.
 
A Surplus for Japan
 The lastest trade figures out of Tokyo underscore the fact that Japan continues to export a lot more than it imports. Japan's worldwide trade surplus in April rose 8.1 percent, to $11.12 billion, from $10.29 billion a year earlier. Tokyo's surplus with the United States jumped 8.9 percent in April, to $4.38 billion, from $4.02 billion a year earlier.
But just as the Clinton Administration appeared to be putting one major trade headache behind it, another new one emerged. Last Friday in Geneva a panel of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade ruled illegal an American boycott against tuna that is caught in huge nets that also kill dolphins.
The GATT tribunal ruled that a longstanding American law intended to protect dolphins, who often swim with tuna, is an illegal trade barrier. The complaint was brought against the United States by European Union on behalf of some European tuna processors who buy tuna from Mexico and other countries that use the purse seine nets that trap tuna and dolphins together.
The GATT ruling is politically very sensitive because it goes to the heart of a major complaint in Congress about the GATT agreement: that it allows international bureaucrats in Geneva to override American laws and values. This debate is known in the trade world as "GATTzilla versus Flipper," and it has strong resonance on Capitol Hill -- not only among environmentalists opposed to the new world trade agreement, but others who worry that it will limit American sovereignty generally.
"This decision is proof positive that environmental laws are undermined by GATT," said Lori Wallach, director of Public Citzen's Trade Program. "Many laws will be found illegal by GATT and then Congress must eliminate the laws or face perpetual tuna sanctions."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rising Commodity Prices Cause a Sharp Bond Selloff

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
For the second consecutive trading day rising commodity prices were behind the sharp selloff in bonds, as investors focused on inflation and its potential to erode the value of their investments in the future.
Also contributing to yesterday's tumbling bond prices was the selling that often precedes a Treasury auction as dealers get rid of old bond notes to make room for the new ones and, possibly, bring down the price they have to pay for them. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 112/32 , to 8531/32 , as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 7.43 percent, from 7.30 percent on Friday and the highest since May 16. The bond price dropped Friday as the yield rose to 7.30 percent, from 7.23 percent Thursday.
Despite the surge in the yield, however, it is still comfortably within the the trading range of the last two months, with a low of 7.10 percent and a high of 7.63 percent.
David Jones, chief economist for Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, said that with the Federal Reserve unlikely to move interest rates higher again soon, the market's focus shifted to commodity prices, this week's Treasury auctions and the dollar.
The Commodity Research Bureau Index, a basket of commodities considered by many as a gauge of future inflation, rose 4.67, to 238.36, its highest daily close since October 1990, when it reached 242.81. It still has a long way to go to get back to its level of 272 in 1988.
While a lot of the surge in the index is due to weather, Mr. Jones said there were signals that were worrying investors.
"While there has been a sharp increase in the C.R.B. index, the strength has mostly been in grains, which are more sensitive to the bad weather," Mr. Jones said. "But investors are beginning to see early indications of price pressures in the industrial commodities area of the index, like oil, lumber, and copper."
These components he noted, surged to push the index higher earlier in the day. "And while grains are volitile , the underlying pressures in the industrial commodities point to an expanding economy and that is the attention getter," he said.
"Oil, for instance, which has shown a significant increase this month, will be seen in the May Consumer Price Index next month. "
Mr. Jones said at the Treasury auctions this week, the five-year note auction tomorrow is that one that seems to be worrying traders and dealers.
"In general, short-maturity auctions have gone well, and the two-year note auction is not expected to do poorly," he said. "But there is some concern about the five-year issue and that is why you saw some positioning in the street for the auctions."
And finally there is the question of the dollar, which was not expected to weaken with the economy growing fast enough to draw five Fed increases in short-term rates since February. "A weaker dollar is a reinforcing element in inflation," Mr. Jones said, noting that a falling dollar makes imports more expensive. "Some wonder if this weakness in fact is a vote against the Clinton foreign policy, or its domestic effectiveness. I sense an element of uneasiness on foreign policy, but you can't prove that." He said that a recent hint of economic recovery in Germany had helped the German mark and pushed the dollar lower.
With no economic news yesterday and the first report of the week, April durable goods orders, not scheduled until tomorrow, investors were easily distracted.
Trading in two and five-year note issues saw yields rise ahead of the auctions, as prices dropped in order to clear dealer inventories faster. In when-issued trading the yield on a two-year note, to be auctioned today, rose 15 basis points, to 5.96 percent, while the five-year note, to be auctioned tomorrow, rose 17 basis points, to 6.76 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
Traders said the higher yields also meant that it will be easier for the dealers to move the paper coming to market this week.
Some analysts believe the market may also be looking ahead to this week's real gross domestic product data for the first quarter. In the first revision of the first quarter's growth rate, the Commerce Department is expected to report a growth rate of 2.3 percentm on Friday, according to a survey by the Reuters news service. The original growth estimate released last month put the growth at 2.6 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
After the fall of his airline magazines, an executive aims for a smoother ride with sports yearbooks.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A MEDIA advertising executive whose network of in-flight magazines prospered mightily, only to collapse when the airline industry retrenched, is seeking to replicate his earlier success in a more earthbound arena.
Jeffrey S. Butler founded the East/ West Network in 1968 and built it into a company that at its peak published and sold the advertisements in 19 magazines available to passengers of airlines like Continental, Eastern, Pan Am, Trans World and United. By offering marketers one-stop access to affluent fliers through a network of regional and national publications with controlled circulations, East/ West's advertising revenues reached $50 million to $60 million a year in the 1980's. 
 But by 1992, as many airlines combined, filed for bankruptcy or stopped flying, Mr. Butler's empire had shrunk to three titles -- then, one by one, to none. East/West closed, making it one of the largest, and most notable, media company casualties of the recent industry recession.
"I spent 23 years of my life on that," Mr. Butler recalled ruefully in a telephone interview.
"The first 20 years were fantastic," he added. "The last three, it was like watching the world go away. Every day when I picked up the paper, there was more bad news."
Looking to start over, Mr. Butler explored fields that he said "would offer big growth potential." Sports came to mind, because, as he put it, "I don't think the Knicks and the Bulls are going to merge."
Through a serendipitous encounter with a next-door neighbor, Mr. Butler said, he learned that the Loeb Partners Corporation had invested in a small, money-losing company called Sports Media Inc., which published the yearbooks that eight sports teams distributed to season ticket holders and sold in arena and stadium souvenir shops.
"The idea was that if a national sports network could be created, " he said, "it would open up an advertising opportunity."
Sports Media, which is based in New York, hired Mr. Butler as chairman and chief executive in July 1992. Since then, he has been assiduously seeking to make lightning strike twice, albeit at a lower elevation the second time.
Sports Media now has licensing agreements with 47 professional teams to publish their yearbooks, with a goal of 60 by the summer. It also distributes yearbooks that seven baseball teams publish on their own.
The company is also expanding the sales territories of the yearbooks to tap into the growing interest in teams outside their local markets. For instance, coverage of the games of the Atlanta Braves, Chicago Cubs and New York Mets by so-called cable television superstations has gained those teams fans across the country. So the yearbooks, which usually cost $6.95 a copy, are being sold through sporting goods chains like Herman's and Oshman's, bookstores like Barnes & Noble and B. Dalton, and newsstands, as well as at traditional venues like game sites.
And Sports Media has established an advertising sales network that enables marketers like American Express, Pepsi-Cola and Sony to buy, if they choose, an ad in every yearbook at an average cost estimated at $180,000 a year. Mr. Butler said ad pages had averaged around eight per yearbook, adding that Sports Media would break even at 15 pages per yearbook.
Yearbook advertising sales revenues for Sports Media, in the fiscal years ending July 31, were $176,589 in 1992; $359,694 in 1993, and a projected $943,000 in 1994. In the 1995 fiscal year, revenues from football advertising are estimated by John Peasley, vice president for advertising, at $1 million to $1.5 million, with revenues from basketball advertising at similar or higher levels.
Yearbooks are clearly "a niche business," said Alan Friedman, editor of Team Marketing Report, a newsletter in Chicago that covers the sports marketing industry.
"They're probably bought more by the hard-core fans with intense interests," he added, partly because their partisan editorial content made them "more like fan magazines."
And while yearbooks are "a marketing tool for a team," Mr. Friedman said, they face competition from many sources, including newspapers and newsletters, both authorized and unauthorized, aimed at a team's fans; game programs, and publications like Sports Illustrated and USA Today Baseball Weekly.
Still, Mr. Butler is sanguine about the prospects for Sports Media.
"There's a passion for sports," he said, adding that in his East/West days, he attracted potential advertisers to luncheons by presenting colorful airline industry executives like Herbert D. Kelleher, the chairman, president and chief executive of Southwest Airlines.
"But it's not the same thing as meeting a team," Mr. Butler said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Signs of a Rise in Inflation Send Dollar Falling Again

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday as signs of surging inflation in the United States prompted traders to dump American assets.
But the dollar eked out a gain against the yen amid optimism that the United States and Japan would break an impasse in trade relations during talks in Washington. 
 "People are still very bearish about the dollar," said Tom Hoge, vice president of corporate currency trading at the Bank of New York. "Nobody is comfortable holding American assets."
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 futures contracts, a closely watched gauge of inflation, rose as high as 238.54 yesterday, its highest level in three and a half years, driven by gains in cocoa, coffee, soybeans and copper.
"Higher commodities prices are scaring away dollar buyers," said David Durst, a trader at Bear, Stearns & Company. "Inflation is the worst thing for a currency."
Currency trading was less active than usual yesterday because many European markets were closed for the Whitsun holiday. London, the world's largest foreign exchange center, was open.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6433 marks, down from 1.6470 marks yesterday.
Optimism about trade talks between the United States and Japan kept the dollar from falling against the yen yesterday, traders said. The dollar rose to 104.40 yen in New York, from 104.25 yen on Friday.
American and Japanese negotiators met for a fourth day today to try to restart formal negotiations, which broke down in February. Progress in trade talks would help the dollar because the Clinton Administration is considered less likely to call for a strong yen if the Japanese make concessions aimed at curbing their trade surplus with the United States. The dollar fell against the yen last year after President Clinton and his aides said a strong yen would trim the surplus by making Japan's exports more costly.
In other trading, the British pound was quoted at $1.5075, down from $1.5065 in New York late Friday. The dollar fell to 5.6255 French francs from 5.6315 francs and to 1.4045 Swiss francs from 1.4060 francs. The Canadian dollar rose to 72.64 United States cents, from 72.48 United States cents on Friday.

HEADLINE: Greek Telecom Offering Set

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: ATHENS, May 23

 BODY:
Greece announced today that it would sell up to 25 percent of the state telecommunications company on the stock market this year, in a move intended to energize the Athens stock exchange, which has been reeling from a currency crisis.
The profitable Greek Telecommunications Organization, scheduled for sale since 1990, will be offered on the stock market, and an unspecifed stake will be for sale in the United States and Japan, the National Economy Minister, Yannos Papandoniou, said. 
 The move to sell shares in the company, which shows annual operating profits of more than $600 million, was eagerly awaited as a way of injecting life into the Athens stock exchange and attracting fresh capital, analysts said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Growth Seen at 3.6%

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
The United States economy is set to grow at a 3.6 percent pace this year despite aggressive moves by the Federal Reserve to restrain the pace of business activity, a leading group of economists said today.
In an annual survey, the National Association of Business Economists forecast that growth would not ease until 1995, when it will still rise 2.8 percent. 
 The economy grew 3 percent last year. In the first quarter of 1994, the growth rate slipped to 2.6 percent, but the association expects it to rebound to 3.4 percent before the middle of the year.
Last week, the Fed raised short-term interest rates by half a percentage point. It was the fourth time the Fed has tightened credit this year.
The survey found that so far this year inflation is scarcely a problem. It predicted that the Consumer Price Index would rise 2.8 percent for the year, up slightly from the 2.7 percent of last year.

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;
Owners Propose Givebacks by Players

 BODY:
Major league owners proposed a series of givebacks on non-economic issues yesterday, prompting DONALD FEHR, the head of the players' union, to say management doesn't want an agreement.
"There are a whole series of player benefits that have been negotiated over the last 20 years that they want to restrict or eliminate," Fehr said after a 3 1/2-hour session at an airport hotel in Los Angeles, the second meeting between the sides in five days. 
 Fehr said management presented proposals dealing with schedules, termination of pay for released players and trade demands. He said the owners want to eliminate service time for players called up in September, which would delay players from becoming eligible for arbitration and free agency.
"That's an extraordinary proposal," Fehr said. "You would get a player up for a contending team to help them get into the playoffs, but he wouldn't get any major league credit for it. Those are not the kinds of proposals -- that have been in place for years and years -- that are likely to create the impression that clubs are desirous of reaching an agreement."
These were the first management proposals since owners reopened the collective bargaining agreement on Dec. 7, 1992. Management's negotiator, RICHARD RAVITCH, has said he intends to propose a salary cap. He said of yesterday's meeting:
"There was a long list of noneconomic items in the contract that the owners would like to see change. They listened. There was discussion about the historical genesis of why they were in the agreement the way they were. Nothing was agreed upon; it wasn't expected it would be." (AP)

HEADLINE: So Inviting, So . . . Sony;
Can a Public Plaza Be Too Corporate?

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
When the public spaces on the ground floor of 550 Madison Avenue were run by AT&T, they were spare, monumentally scaled and usually empty. Today, as Sony Plaza, they are colorful, more intimately scaled and often crowded. They are also -- unmistakably -- Sony's.
In an annex at one side of the atrium, midblock between 55th and 56th Streets, hang six blue banners, all but one bearing the Sony name. The banner for City Bakery proclaims "Sony Commissary"; for Gottfried's Newsstand, "Sony Plaza Newsstand." Banners mark the Sony Signatures store and the Sony Wonder Technology Lab, a new attraction opening tomorrow in the annex. Opposite are the Sony Style showrooms, with more Sony banners in what was an open-air arcade when the building served as AT&T headquarters. 
 As the finishing touches are put on Sony Plaza, the reworking has set off a debate over whether this accretion of corporate identity has created the impression that the atrium is more a private preserve than a public domain, as it was meant to be.
Many agree that Sony's redesign has made the space more attractive, and drawn more people. But Sony also made its own name a little too visible, some officials and urban planners say.
"It feels a lot like a Sony lobby," said Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission. "And that's not something that I'd like to see replicated around the city in other spaces."
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan has endorsed most of the changes made by the Sony Corporation of America as a "considerable improvement," but added that she is "nonetheless concerned that the overall effect of the plaza is overly commercial."
Community Board 5 in midtown Manhattan has opposed Sony's plan to install an 11-by-20-foot high-definition television screen on the ground floor of the annex to silently promote the Sony Wonder exhibition.
 
Renovation Meets Intense Scrutiny
 Sony's renovation, designed by Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, has become the subject of intense scrutiny because the spaces were provided as public amenities by AT&T under a 1978 agreement with New York City. In return for the public space, AT&T was granted a development bonus equal to nearly six floors of the 36-story tower, which it still owns.
Also as part of the deal, AT&T agreed to build a science museum, which became the Infoquest Center exhibition. In the four-story annex where Infoquest was housed, Sony has built its Wonder Technology Lab, designed by Edwin Schlossberg, which is to be free to the public.
Planners, architects and neighborhood leaders have wrestled for years with the question of what do when public amenities built by private developers fail to live up to expectations. Some have been completely changed, like the arcade at 2 Lincoln Square on the Upper West Side, which was turned into a branch of the Museum of American Folk Art. Others have simply languished.
What makes the Sony case of such interest is that it involves a high-profile tower (topped by its renowned Chippendale-style pediment) in one of the densest quarters of Manhattan, where office workers, shoppers, out-of-towners and street dwellers can make good use of benches, chairs and tables under large trees, in a controlled climate.
"There isn't a seat in the house at lunchtime," said H. Guy Leibler, the president and general manager of Sony Plaza Inc., which operates the atrium, stores and exhibition. "People are talking, eating, walking through. There are new people who are here every day. People from the neighborhood are starting to use this as a meeting place."
Sony has argued that the way to bring the public into the space is to enliven and make it more comfortable. One of the architects, Charles Gwathmey, said the idea behind the renovation was "to engage the public in a landscaped greenhouse space."
 "The misconception -- and there is one -- is that all of this is now private," Mr. Gwathmey told the architects' panel. "The only thing that's private are the retail stores. The amount of space that was taken in comparison to the bonus was, I think, minor. And the judgment always has to be the quality of the new space and the offerings of the new space."
Russell Sanders, an account representative from Avon Products, was visiting Sony Plaza the other day to check out its progress. He works nearby and recalled the atrium as a barren space through which a lot of litter blew.
He has noticed the growing use of the plaza and the growing Sony presence, too. "I think it's more commercial," Mr. Sanders said, "but my impression is that it's like commercials on television. If Sony wants to maintain the space, they're using the commercials to pay for it. That's the price to be paid for having the plaza."
Community Board 5, however, believes an important threshold will be crossed with the installation of the giant television in the atrium. By a vote of 23 to 14, it recommended rejection of the proposal, but the Planning Commission later approved it and Sony plans to install it.
"Inevitably, people will congregate before the video screen," said Nicholas Fish, the community board chairman. "That will certainly take away from the ability of other people to simply come and read a book or daydream without being assaulted visually.
"Public spaces should be as neutral and inviting as possible and really ought to be a refuge for people who want to escape from the hustle and bustle of midtown, rather than being another corporate theme space."
In the eyes of Amanda M. Burden, a member of the Planning Commission, the AT&T space was, if anything, too serene. "It wasn't usable," she said at a meeting of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects. "It worked for the eye. It was beautiful to walk through -- wonderful shadows and light, wonderful monumentality. But it was really cold, physically cold, physically uncomfortable."
 
A Convert to Sony's Side
 Although Ms. Burden originally opposed Sony's plans, she became a convert. And on April 20, she was one of seven commission members to vote in favor of the latest modifications proposed by Sony, including installation of the large television screen. Three members were opposed. Mr. Rose abstained.
Ms. Messinger also supported the changes. She said in her report to the planning commission that the suitability of the television screen depended on its programming.
Mr. Leibler, the Sony executive, said that two-thirds of those seated in the atrium would be able to ignore the screen if they chose. Those who cared to watch, he said, "will find the programming interesting, cultural and very reflective of what's happening in Sony Wonder" -- not at all commercial, and unconnected with any Sony product.
 
 
 
TECHNOLOGY, SONY STYLE
 The Sony Wonder Technology Lab, which opens tomorrow, is a hands-on showcase of technological innovation, geared mainly to children. The exhibition is reached by an elevator at the north end of the Sony Plaza atrium, on 56th Street, off Madison Avenue.
The displays include dozens of screens and speakers that present the history of modern communication; a small theater with a large-screen high-definition television, and studios that simulate television and music production, environmental research and planetary exploration.
 Admission is free. Sony Wonder is open Tuesdays and Fridays, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Wednesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., and Sundays, 12 P.M. to 6 P.M. It is closed Mondays.

HEADLINE: Commencements;
2,801 Degrees Conferred On New Yale Graduates

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, May 23

 BODY:
Yale University held its 293d commencement today under sunny skies, conferring 2,801 degrees and provisionally awarding 218 law degrees. The law school's spring term ends after the university's commencement, and the law faculty votes on the degrees on June 1.
The Yale Concert Band performed as graduates filed into the university's historic Old Campus to be seated in front of a blue-and-white-striped canopy, under which school officials and others were seated. 
 Some graduates added personal touches to their attire. Graduates of the university's Divinity School attached halos made from pipe cleaners to their caps. Several rows back sat graduates of the School of Forestry and Environmental Studies who had attached plastic branches, pine cones and grass to their caps.
The university chaplain, Federick Jerome Streets, began the ceremonies by joking about the summerlike weather, with temperatures in the 80's. "Please note, requests for clouds cannot be accommodated," he said.
 
Eight Honorary Degrees
 During the ceremony, Yale also awarded eight honorary degrees. Among those receiving degrees were Mario Vargas Llosa, the author; Jack B. Weinstein, senior Federal District Court judge, and Robert E. Cooke, professor emeritus, State University of New York at Buffalo.
Also receiving honorary degrees were Gladys Iola Tantaquidgeon, Mohegan medicine woman and founder and curator of the Tantaquidgeon Indian Museum; Amos Tversky, Davis-Brack Professor of Behavioral Science, Stanford University; Martin Puryear, artist; Kurt Masur, music director, New York Philharmonic, and Maxine Singer, president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.
The graduates gave a standing ovation to Ms. Tantaquidgeon, who celebrates her 95th birthday on Tuesday.
There was no commencement speaker today. Sargent Shriver, the first director of the Peace Corps, spoke at the Class Day ceremony on Sunday.
After today's commencement, graduates attended ceremonies and received degrees at the Yale school or college they had attended.
 
Drew University
 MADISON, N.J., May 23 (AP) -- Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York told Drew University graduates today that drugs have weakened the nation and that they need to strive to make America great again.
Mr. Cuomo said he hoped that the graduates would look beyond the material luxuries their education would provide and would strive to restore those qualities "that made us great, that won the Second World War, that made us dominant in the world."
He said the nation now suffers from economic and educational inferiority, homelessness and drug addiction. "We lost it in the 1960's when we turned to things like heroin, cocaine and later crack because we became a little arrogant and self-satisfied," he said.
Mr. Cuomo was invited to give the commencement address to 413 graduates by Thomas H. Kean, Drew's president and former governor of New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Westchester Loses Bid to Force Cutting of Trees Near Airport

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, May 23

 BODY:
Westchester County today lost yet another bid to force four Connecticut landowners and the Town of Greenwich to cut down trees that the county says interfere with landings at the Westchester County Airport. But county officials said they would fight on.
In a decision announced today, the United States Supreme Court, without comment, let stand a Connecticut State Supreme Court ruling that blocked Westchester County's attempt to obtain an easement to trim or remove the trees. 
 But Marilyn Slaatten, the Westchester County Attorney, said that the easement was a small point and that she planned to go back to the Federal District Court to argue that the trees are a public nuisance and a safety hazard.
"The Supreme Court's decision was on just one question," Ms. Slaatten said. "We will probably be fighting this for another few years."
 
Number of Flights Drop
 Airplanes have been passing safely over the trees from the time the airport was built in the 1940's. But by 1988, the trees had grown so tall and the landings so steep that the airport was forced to shorten one of its two runways by 1,300 feet. Small private planes can still land on the runway but bigger commuter planes and corporate jets cannot. Takeoffs are not affected.
While the number of annual flights in and out of the airport has dropped to 180,000 from 200,000 in the last 10 years, the drop may have as much to do with the economy as the shortened runway, said Joseph J. Petrocelli, Westchester's acting commissioner of transportation.
Most of the trees are on the grounds of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, a girls' school in Greenwich that is less than a mile from the airport in Harrison. Some are 75 feet high.
Cutting the trees and allowing planes to come in lower over the school's fields would pose a safety threat to the students, said Patrick Gaffney, a Manhattan lawyer whose firm represents the school without charge.
"Way before the airport was built and even before airplanes existed, these trees were growing," Mr. Gaffney said. "Many of the trees that the County of Westchester sought to have removed were over 100 years old."
 
Modernizing Airport
 The airport is undergoing a modernization that is expected to be completed next year. A parking garage and a new terminal will replace the World War II Quonset hut that has welcomed passengers since the 1940's.
If the trees had been in Westchester, the county could have claimed eminent domain. But because the trees were in Connecticut, though less than a mile away, the legal battle has lasted four years.
After two years of trying to negotiate a deal with the landowners to allow Westchester to trim some trees and cut and replace others, the county filed suit in 1990. The county won, with a Federal judge ruling that it was entitled to an easement because planes had flown over the property for so long without challenge.
But the landowners appealed and the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit sent the case to Connecticut's highest state court for review. The landowners won that battle when the State Supreme Court ruled that Westchester could not tell Connecticut landowners what to do.

HEADLINE: Clinton Plan Imperils City Hospitals

 BODY:
President Clinton's health-care plan, in the main a valuable reform effort, would inadvertently brutalize New York City hospitals. That is the opinion not only of local hospitals, but also of independent analysts. The problem for New York is that the President's plan -- and Congressional knock-offs like the recent proposal by Senator Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts -- would pay for universal coverage primarily by imposing gargantuan Medicare cuts that are unevenly distributed.
About half of Mr. Clinton's in-patient Medicare cuts would come from hospitals that train doctors and hospitals that serve indigent communities. New York hospitals do a lot of both: they account for 5 percent of national in-patient Medicare expenditures, and about 15 percent of Medicare's contributions toward medical training and indigent care. And though universal coverage would provide inner-city hospitals with a new revenue stream, the extra fees would not come close to making up for the lost Medicare and other reimbursements. 
 The Administration contends that hospitals can absorb Medicare cuts without cutting services. That might be true of hospitals in general. But it is not true of hospitals in New York City. They would be caught in a vise; Washington would squeeze revenues by cutting Medicare while Albany -- because it controls in-patient fees -- would prevent city hospitals from offsetting Medicare cuts by jacking up prices to non-Medicare patients.
Congress could take some of the bite out of Medicare cuts by applying those cuts across the board. For example, it could cut payments that now compensate hospitals for inflationary increases in medical prices -- a cut that would affect hospitals evenly. Instead, the President has proposed a small across-the-board cut and a huge 60 percent cut of money for medical training.
Some staff members of the Administration and of key Congressional committees admit that proposed Medicare cuts hit New York City unfairly. But they have been powerless to solve the problem because Congress is not ready to focus on details, and even if it were, it would be in no mood to figure out how to replace the lost Medicare savings. The danger is that Congress will succumb to temptation and pass reform that looks good on paper but pays for itself by ravaging inner-city hospitals.

HEADLINE: Lean on the Dominican Republic

 BODY:
Sanctions can work to restore democracy in Haiti -- if they are strong and if they are enforced. New, stiffer sanctions went into effect at midnight on Saturday. But as long as contraband gasoline flows freely across the border with the Dominican Republic, the U.N. embargo against Haiti exists in name only.
The immediate need is to get tough with the Dominican Republic, reminding its Government that these sanctions, approved by the United Nations, are mandatory and that those who ignore them will pay dearly for defying the international community. 
 U.N. investigators are now looking at violations of the embargo on the border; Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali will decide what action to take after reading their confidential report.
Unfortunately, the Clinton Administration is already signaling that it is not prepared to comply with the spirit of the embargo. In addition to its mandatory sanctions, the U.N. has called upon member states to freeze assets and revoke visas for supporters of Haiti's illegitimate military rulers. But the U.S. is only doing this selectively, exempting key supporters of the junta: the Mev, Brandt, Acra and Madsen families. Also, three Haitian senators who played important roles in the coup against President Jean-Bertrand Aristide reportedly will be allowed to keep their U.S. visas. These are precisely the people who need to be made most uncomfortable. Their privileges should be revoked.
Undermining the sanctions even as they go into effect is a dangerous policy. It increases the clamor for military intervention, and the likelihood that President Clinton, under pressure to achieve a foreign policy success, will conclude that an invasion of Haiti is not just an option but a necessity.
Pressure must be applied to the Dominican Republic, even though the results of recent presidential elections are unclear. Joaquin Balaguer, the incumbent President, claims victory but his opponent, Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, says many of his followers were defrauded of their votes, and independent observers have backed up these claims.
Mr. Balaguer seems set to hunker down, as he did after the last questionable election, in 1990, and wait for the controversy to die down. No doubt he is hoping the United States, in its desire to preserve some semblance of stability on the island, will not make too much noise over election fraud.
That would be a mistake. While pushing the Dominican Government -- no matter who is in power -- to police its border, the U.S. also needs to support those who are trying to insure the fairness of the vote. In the Dominican Republic as in Haiti, long-term stability will come only one way: through democracy. This is not the time for mixed messages, on either side of the island.
